With “Dancing With the Stars” retired from ABC’s schedule for the year and CBS’s lineup in repeats, television ratings were down considerably on Monday night, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Nonetheless, CBS still led over all, garnering the night’s most viewers at 9 p.m. with a rerun of “Two and a Half Men” (13.7 million). ABC led the 8 p.m. hour with the holiday special “Shrek the Halls” (11.2 million) followed by “Dr. Seuss’ How the Grinch Stole Christmas” (11.7 million). Back-to-back episodes of ABC’s “Samantha Who?” averaged a much smaller 6.8 million viewers each at 9 p.m. NBC earned its best ratings of the night in that time slot with “Heroes” (8 million), but the network finished no better than third place over all, drawing 7.2 million for “Chuck” and just 4 million for “My Own Worst Enemy.”.

William Petersen, above left, the star of the CBS series “C.S.I.: Crime Scene Investigation,” has solved the mystery of his next job: he has joined the ensemble of the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago, the company announced. Mr. Petersen, who currently appears in Steppenwolf’s production of “Dublin Carol,” will become the 42nd member of the group. He previously announced that he would step away from a full-time role on “C.S.I.” after this season but would continue to appear as a guest star and serve as an executive producer. ... Britney Spears, above right, has announced her first concerts in five years, The Associated Press reported. Her tour, to promote her new album, “Circus,” is to begin on March 3 in New Orleans and visit 27 cities en route to its final show on April 28 in Chicago. ... The Soho Rep Theater has announced its next production, following its extended run of Sarah Kane’s graphically violent (though popular) play “Blasted.” On Jan. 15, the theater will begin previews of “Sixty Miles to Silver Lake,” a new play written by Dan LeFranc and directed by Anne Kauffman. Co-produced by Page 73, the play stars Joseph Adams and Dane DeHaan as a father and son on a memorable drive. It is scheduled to open on Jan. 22 and to end a limited run on Feb. 8.

Blockbuster has announced a three-year deal with the concert production company Live Nation to sell tickets and merchandise for Live Nation events in 500 of its retail stores, Reuters reported. The announcement comes as Ticketmaster’s contract to sell tickets for Live Nation concerts is set to expire at the end of the year and Live Nation prepares to start its own ticketing operation in 2009. Blockbuster has faced increasing challenges as it battles with other video rental services and as DVD sales decline, but Nathan Hubbard, the chief executive of Live Nation Ticketing, told Reuters that the two businesses were compatible. “The fan who buys his ticket offline has a lot of demographic overlap with the consumer who rents his DVD offline,” he said.
On a cold, foggy morning in Los Angeles, Sandra Oh and Jason Bateman announced the nominees for Film Independent’s Spirit Awards.

After a trip that included talks in the Middle East on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and a farewell speech to NATO foreign ministers in Brussels, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice stopped at Buckingham Palace for a classical musical recital with Queen Elizabeth II, above right, at which Dr. Rice herself, above left, was the main attraction, The Associated Press reported. Accompanied by Louise Miliband, the wife of the British foreign secretary, on violin and three members of the London Symphony Orchestra, she performed Brahms’s piano quintet, Op. 34, and received a recording of the performance as a gift from the queen. A classically trained pianist, Dr. Rice performed with the Denver Symphony Orchestra at the age of 15 and accompanied the cellist Yo-Yo Ma in 2002 when Mr. Ma was awarded the National Medal of the Arts.

It’s back: the dreaded curse of “Tristan.” At the Metropolitan Opera, Gary Lehman, above left, sang in place of an ill Peter Seiffert, above right, in Tuesday night’s performance of “Tristan und Isolde.” Last season, Mr. Lehman was one of four tenors to sing Tristan in a six-performance run because of various illnesses and mishaps. Mr. Seiffert drew attention during the current run for wearing an earpiece to receive electronic cues instead of relying on the usual stage prompter. “Tristan und Isolde” continues at the Metropolitan through Dec. 20.

It’s the rare opera finale that doesn’t include bloodshed: A new deal between La Scala opera house in Milan, Italy, and an Italian performers union will ensure that La Scala’s gala opening night will take place Sunday as scheduled, The Associated Press reported. The Fials union, which represents about half of the orchestra musicians and chorus singers at La Scala, had been on strike since July and rejected new contracts in October, forcing the cancellation of productions of “La Dame aux Camélias” and “The Merry Widow.” La Scala’s new season will begin with a production of Verdi’s “Don Carlo” directed by Daniele Gatti. The opera will be broadcast live in high definition in movie theaters, including the Miller Theater at Columbia University; a full list of participating theaters can be found at www.emergingpictures.com.

SWEENEY--Mary Elizabeth, RSCJ, former Provincial Superior of the Society of the Sacred Heart, died November 26, 2008 at Teresian House, Albany, NY. She was a member of the Society of the Sacred Heart for 72 years. Born in Rochester, NY, Sister Sweeney was a graduate of Newton College of the Sacred Heart. Sister Sweeney was noted for her financial acumen. She served the Society in financial management and investment throughout her life. She was Treasurer of Newton College of the Sacred Heart and of the United States Province of the Society of the Sacred Heart. She served on the investment committee of the New England Jesuits. She was President of the Newton Country Day School Corporation and a Trustee of Stuart Country Day School in Princeton, NJ and Newton Country Day School of the Sacred Heart. Sister Sweeney lived in retirement at Kenwood Convent of the Sacred Heart, Albany, NY. Sister Sweeney is survived by her sisters Mrs. Anne Sweeney Johantgen of Brockport, NY and Miss Jean B. Sweeney of Rochester, NY. She was the daughter of Michael Edward Sweeney and Helen Hammond Sweeney and sister of the late Sr. Helen Sweeney, RSCJ. The funeral Mass was celebrated in Albany. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated Thursday, December 11, 6pm at Newton Country Day School of the Sacred Heart, 785 Centre St.

9 P.M. (CBS) THE GRAMMY NOMINATIONS CONCERT LIVE! COUNTDOWN TO MUSIC'S BIGGEST NIGHT For the first time, nominations for the Grammy Awards in at least six categories will be announced live in prime time, backed by performances from past winners. Celine Dion, Foo Fighters, B. B. King (above), John Mayer, Christina Aguilera, Mariah Carey and Taylor Swift are scheduled to perform at the Nokia Theater in Los Angeles. L L Cool J and Ms. Swift are the hosts. The show also celebrates the opening of the Grammy Museum. The Grammy Awards will be shown on CBS on Feb. 8. 6:30 P.M. (HBO) JACQUES D'AMBOISE IN CHINA: THE OTHER SIDE OF THE WORLD As a principal dancer with New York City Ballet and then as founder of the National Dance Institute, Mr. D'Amboise has inspired countless young people, quite simply, to move. This documentary follows Mr. D'Amboise, children from New York and alumni of the institute as they travel to Shanghai, where they collaborated with the dancer Dou Dou Huang and more than 100 Chinese youngsters in a performance that merges hip-hop, freestyle jazz and traditional Chinese folk dance in honor of the 2007 Shanghai Special Olympics.

SHIELDS--Dennis, Ph.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is profoundly saddened by the sudden passing of our esteemed Professor of the Departments of Developmental and Molecular Biology and of Anatomy and Structural Biology. Dennis was a member of the Einstein faculty for 30 years, where he served in numerous roles, including first Director of our Belfer Institute for Advanced Biomedical Sciences and Acting Chair of Developmental and Molecular Biology. Dennis was known to his students and colleagues as a wonderful mentor, teacher, thinker and friend, as well as a brilliant scientist. His unexpected death is a tremendous loss to Einstein. His warmth, intelligence and humor will truly be missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Toni; their children, Rebecca (a 2nd-year medical student at Einstein), Matthew, and Jacqueline; and son-in-law David. Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

Total spending on political advertising this year by candidates and interest groups reached at least $2.6 billion, the highest ever in a presidential election year, according to an organization that tracks such expenditures. Most of it -- $2 billion -- was spent on local broadcast television, which should surprise no one living in a battleground state.

RACKMAN--Rabbi Emanuel. The Partners, Associates and Staff of Gottlieb, Rackman & Reisman, P.C. mourn the passing of Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, esteemed father of our founding partner, Michael I. Rackman. Our condolences go out to him and other members of the Rackman family.

The Best, for a Quarter In a discussion of the best quarterbacks in the N.F.L., you would not expect to hear the names Shaun Hill and Matt Schaub. But when breaking down the game by quarters, they are the most efficient passers in the game in the second (Hill) and third (Schaub) quarters.

GLASS--Jack ''Yankel'', of Brooklyn, NY passed away November 30, 2008 at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn after a prolonged illness with his family at his side. He was born in Brooklyn on August 1, 1924, son of Sophie and William Glass. He was a lifelong resident of Brooklyn with the exception of the years spent in the US Navy during WWII. A dedicated social activist during his entire life. He was involved in a number of humanitarian causes including the trade union movement (A member of the Hat Workers of America), civil rights movement, and the various anti-war movements of the past 40 years. A beloved family man, he is survived by his ever loving wife of 60 years, Gloria (Kopelman) Glass of Brooklyn, NY; a sister Florence Baroff of Boca Raton, FL; two devoted sons, Howard and Karen Glass of Keene Valley, NY, Norman Glass of Brooklyn, NY; three beloved grandsons, William and Rahat Glass-Hussain of Burlingame, CA, Daniel and Jennifer Glass of Sag Harbor, NY, Charles and Sarah Glass of Sag Harbor, NY; as well as three great - grandchildren, Emily Glass, Jonah and Sophie Glass-Hussain. He was a loyal friend to many, kind and compassionate, with an infectious sense of humor. He was memorable to all those he came in contact with. There will be no calling hours, private services for the family will be held at the grave site. In celebration of his life, the family has requested that donations in his memory be made to the Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Ave., Montgomery, AL 36104. (http://www.splc.org)

SPERRY--Ann. Sculpture Center's Board of Trustees and staff are deeply saddened by the passing of Ann Sperry. Ann exhibited at SculptureCenter in 1987 and then served on the Board from 1997-2005 and continued as a valued advisor to the organization. In addition to her many accomplishments as a sculptor, Ann was a passionate advocate for artists and was deeply committed to the field. She will be greatly missed.

CASLOW--Charlotte. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Charlotte Caslow, beloved mother of Robert and Miriam and Eric and Madeline. The Caslow family has long expressed their love of the Jewish community and devotion to social and humanitarian causes through their exceptional philanthropy and compassion to serve those in need. Through Robert and Miriam's participation on our Board of Directors and the families' unwavering support of numerous agencies within our human-service network, we are enabled to strengthen the Jewish community in New York and around the world. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Charlotte's children, Eric and Madeline and Robert and Miriam; to her grandchildren, Emily and Nathan Gindi, Heather and Jeff Pavell, David and Lisa Caslow, and Adam Caslow; to her greatgrandchildren; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

SCHOENFELD--Gerald. We join our colleagues in sending our deepest condolences to Pat Schoenfeld, the Schoenfeld family and our dear friends at the Shubert Organization. We will deeply miss Jerry, our industry's esteemed leader and our great friend and neighbor. Regardless of the crowded streets and walkways, 44th St. feels empty without Jerry. But Jerry's spirit glows on every marquee and lights our way to keep up the work of our beloved Mr. Schoenfeld. Helen Hayes Theatre Martin Markinson The Tick Family Susan Myerberg Alan Markinson Hector Angulo, and all of us

Partner of Abrams, Gorelick, Friedman & Jacobson. Service on Thursday, December 4th at 11:30am at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck.

CASLOW--Charlotte, December 1, 2008, age 89. Survived by loving and caring children, Robert and Miriam and Eric and Mady. Adored by her grandchildren, Adam Caslow, Emily and Nathan Gindi, David and Lisa Caslow, Heather and Jeff Pavell. Blessed with eight wonderful great-grandchildren. Also survived by devoted brother, Joseph Brownstein. She and her husband, Rubin, shared 65 years of marriage until his death. Charlotte was central to our family and our model for living a full and meaningful life. She will be greatly missed.

RACKMAN--Emanuel Rabbi. Bar-Ilan University (BIU) and the American Friends of BarIlan University (AFBIU) note with profound sadness the passing of the deeply beloved Chancellor Emeritus of BIU, Rabbi Emanuel Rackman one of the most prominent and courageous religious leaders of his generation. Rabbi Rackman devoted over 30 years to BIU, first as President and later as Chancellor. His tireless devotion to social justice stemmed from a conviction that Halacha is a central moral force to address injustice. In his honor, BIU's Law Center and the Center for the Advancement of the Status of Women proudly bear his name and that of his beloved wife, Ruth Z''L. We extend our sincerest condolences to his sons and their wives, Michael and Judy, Bennett and Ruth, and Joseph and Eliane, his eight grandchildren and 14 greatgrandchildren. Prof. Moshe Kaveh, President, BIU Dr. Mordecai D. Katz, Chairman, Global Board of Trustees, BIU Michael Jesselson, Chairman, AFBIU Moshael J. Straus, President, AFBIU Mark D. Medin, EVP & CEO, AFBIU

BERRY--Eliot Ward, died of heart failure on November 29, 2008, age 59. Beloved father of Christopher, son of Nancy and Rynn Berry, and brother of Charles, Peter and Rynn, Jr. Eliot graduated from Buckley, Choate, the University of Pennsylvania (BA '71) and King's College, London University (Ph.D.) and received a Fulbright at Kassel University in Germany. He was a superb natural athlete and insightful and elegant writer. Author of Tough Draw, regarded by Arthur Ashe and Herbert Warren Wind as one of the best books ever on the game of tennis and the psychology of competition, Eliot brought to his craft a novelist's eye and ear, a scholar's encyclopedic knowledge and joy of literature, and an accomplished competitive athlete's awareness of the exhilaration and lonely struggles of athletic competition at the highest levels. He was inducted into the University of Pennsylvania Athletic Hall of Fame in 2000 in recognition of his achievements in football, squash and tennis. He was All-Ivy in all three sports. As a place kicker, he was signed to both the Pittsburgh Steelers and Atlanta Falcons; a gifted tennis player from a young age, he won the New York State 16s, was third-ranked in the East and played on the 1970 ECAC Championship Team; and in squash he played on the international tour, was number one for the U.S. Team at the World Championships in 1977 and won the Metropolitan Squash Singles Championship in 198082. Eliot's other published works included a novel, literary criticism and Topspin, another acclaimed book on the professional tennis tour. At the time of his death Eliot had recently completed an authorized screenplay of Albert Camus's iconic The Stranger. He was founder and principal of Eliot W. Berry & Co., real estate appraisers. A memorial service will be held at St. James' Church, Madison Avenue and 71st Street, Friday, December 5, at 12 noon. Contributions may be made to the Al Molloy Squash Fund at the University of Pennsylvania's Weightman Fund.

LONDON -- A panel of immigration judges ordered the immediate return to prison on Tuesday of a radical Islamic preacher known as Abu Qatada, dubbed by Britain's tabloid newspapers as ''Osama bin Laden's right-hand man in Europe.'' The judges accepted warnings from the Home Office, Britain's interior ministry, that the cleric, a 47-year-old Jordanian of Palestinian origin, might try to flee if he were allowed to remain free on the bail granted to him five months ago.

RACKMAN--Rabbi Dr. Emanuel. The entire Yeshiva University family is bereaved by the passing of one of the most distinguished rabbinic alumni of its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. Rabbi Rackman served as a chaplain in World War II, and in the Air Force Reserves thereafter, and was the revered rabbi of Shaaray Tefila Congregation in Far Rockaway and later was spiritual leader of the Fifth Avenue Synagogue in Manhattan. He served as a vice president and later as Provost of Yeshiva University, and was the recipient of an honorary Doctorate of Divinity in 1961. Most recently, he was Chancellor Emeritus of Bar Ilan University in Israel, after serving for several years as its President, then as Chancellor. He served as President of the New York Board of Rabbis, President of the Rabbinical Council of America and as Chairman of the Commission on Jewish Chaplaincy in the US Armed Forces. He will be long remembered for his outstanding achievements throughout his distinguished career. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his sons: Michael Rackman, Rabbi Bennett Rackman and Joseph Rackman, their spouses, grandchildren and great-grandchildren and to the entire Rackman Family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman, YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman, RIETS Board of Trustees

YEE--Marya Lenn, 1954 to 2008. The partners and staff of Donovan & Yee, LLP greatly mourn the sudden passing of Marya Lenn Yee. Over the years, Marya touched many friends, colleagues, and clients with her intelligence, warmth and generosity of spirit. Marya was at the pinnacle of her professional career and one of the most respected litigators in the copyright, trademark and unfair competition area. She was an active member of the Copyright Society of the U.S.A. and past New York Chapter President. In addition to her brilliant legal work, Marya lectured and taught extensively, always willing to share her knowledge and experience to help younger attorneys starting out in practice. She will be sorely missed by her firm, friends and colleagues. Mary Donovan and the Staff of Donovan & Yee, LLP

SPERRY--Ann. The Board of Directors and Staff of Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts mourn the untimely passing of esteemed Board Member Ann Sperry. Lawyers for the film director Roman Polanski, who fled the United States before his sentencing for statutory rape 30 years ago, asked a judge here to dismiss the case against him based on claims of judicial and prosecutorial wrongdoing revealed in a documentary film. The request was filed with Judge David S. Wesley in the Los Angeles Superior Court on Tuesday afternoon. It cited the film ''Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired,'' in which a former deputy district attorney described having coached the judge in the case, though he was not directly involved in the prosecution.

GARFIELD--George H.,age 80, died of Alzheimer's Disease in Houston, Texas on November 28, 2008. He was born in Boston; his early years were in Concord, MA. After receiving his MBA from Stanford University, he pursed a successful investment management career in New York City. George was co-founder of the firm of Inverness Counsel; he will be remembered warmly by his many friends and associates in New York City. George was a member and vestryman at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan. George has been a resident of Houston, Texas since 2004. George was a greatgrandson of President James A. Garfield. He is survived by his wife of 21 years, Nancy Elizabeth Wright Garfield, a brother John Garfield, four children, four step-grandchildren, eleven great-grandchildren. Services will be conducted at St. Martin's Episcopal Church, Houston, Texas at 10:00am on Friday, December 5, 2008. Donations to honor George may be directed to Disabled American Veterans. To share a memory or place a tribute visit www.mem.com

POLLAK--Kate Lasky, died Saturday after a brief illness. She was 100. Kate had been a social activist, holder of a masters degree in English, a reading specialist in the NYC public schools, an adoring and adored wife and mother, and a wonderful friend and confident to her entire family. She is survived by her children, Helen and Richard, her nephews/nieces Sharon, Rona, Ilene, Lauren, Phillip, and Lenore, and myriad other beloved friends and family.

Bad Call From the Start The Raiders' decision to attempt a fake field goal Sunday was flawed on so many levels it was hard to determine which part of the blunder was the most egregious. There was the immediate result of the decision, a 67-yard fumble return for a touchdown by Chiefs cornerback Maurice Leggett. There was the resulting swing in momentum, which meant that instead of taking a 6-3 lead, the Raiders trailed, 10-3. And there was the postgame admission by Coach Tom Cable that the botched play was more than a year in the planning.

DALY--Mary C. The alumni of St. John's University School of Law are deeply saddened by the death of our beloved Dean, Mary C. Daly. She was a caring and gentle woman, a scholar, and a person of extraordinary integrity. Her effective leadership of the Law School, her dedication to excellence, and her warm outreach to us--the alumni, have enriched each of us, the Law School and the legal community. As we celebrate Dean Daly's life at a funeral Mass tomorrow (10:30am, St. Thomas More Church, St. John's University, Queens campus), we, the alumni, pray that she is at peace in her eternal reward and extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. NOVAK--Judith Atran. The Atran Foundation sadly announces the passing of Judith Atran Novak on November 18, 2008. She leaves behind her loving husband, Dr. Michael P. Novak, daughter Jennifer Jolie, and Atran Foundation family members: mother Ruth Atran, sister Diane Fischer, President of the Atran Foundation, and sons Drs. Kenneth and Jeffrey Novak. Judith served as a member of the Foundation for 26 years and as a Director for the past 21 years. She was an integral part of the operation and philanthropy of the Foundation. Her legacy continues through the membership of her two sons Ken and Jeff, and her niece Alison Fischer. Although her passing came too soon, she lives on through the smiles and memories of her six grandchildren, Emma and Sylvie, Marc and Lauren, and Erika and Danielle, and through the lives of extended family and friends touched by her brave and triumphant spirit. She will be missed by all who passed through her life.

Fourth-Quarter Fade Drew Brees is regularly among the league's passing leaders, and he is on pace to surpass 4,000 passing yards for the third year in a row. But in his two-plus seasons with the Saints, he has never engineered a fourth-quarter comeback. In that time, including the playoffs, New Orleans has won only once in 19 games when it was not leading after three quarters. (The Saints beat the Eagles, 27-24, on Oct. 15, 2006, after entering the fourth quarter tied, 17-17.)

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- The University of Vermont last played a varsity football game in 1974. The century-old football stadium is now used only for soccer. And the football conference Vermont belonged to has disbanded. Doug DeLuca knew all of this when he enrolled as a freshman in the fall of 2006. A high school wide receiver who did not want to give up the game, DeLuca figured he would just start a club football team at Vermont.

YEE--Marya Lenn, 53, died December 1, 2008 of injuries sustained in a plane crash in California. A founding partner of the intellectual property law firm Donovan & Yee, she was a longtime trustee and member of The Copyright Society of the USA and served on its Executive and Young Lawyers Committees. She was a mentor to many young lawyers and a friend and advisor to artists, designers and fledgling entrepreneurs. A graduate of Brooklyn Law School, she was Topics Editor of the Law Review. Political activist, contributor to liberal causes and devotee of theatre and music, she was especially proud of her son Benjamin's service to the Barack Obama campaign and her son Max Michael's gifts as a jazz musician and interest in science. She is survived by her sons Benjamin, 24 and Max Michael, 20, and their father, Chester; her sister Helena, brother-in-law Richard, niece Rebecca, nephew Jeremy and her cousins Lilly, Felicia, Ilana, Myra, Herschel and their children. Funeral services at 12:30pm Friday, December 5 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. Donations can be made to SHARE (212937-5570) in Marya's memory.

Home Games Needed After 12 games, it appears that home-field advantage will be critical in the National Football Conference. The top eight teams in the American Football Conference all have winning records on the road, but only the first-place Giants and the eighth-place Redskins have winning road records among the top eight N.F.C. teams.

If you are in Washington for the inauguration, you may be able to party in a bar or restaurant longer than you might have expected. There is a movement afoot in the District of Columbia to extend the hours in which alcohol can be served to 5 a.m., from Jan. 17 to Jan. 21. Currently, bars must close by 2 a.m. on weekdays and 3 a.m. on weekends.

RANNEY--Mary, RSCJ. Tyler Perry, the actor, filmmaker and producer of “Madea’s Family Reunion” and “Why Did I Get Married?”, testified on Wednesday in a copyright infringement lawsuit in Marshall, Tex., The Associated Press reported. Mr. Perry is being sued by Donna West, a playwright who says that he took material from a script she wrote, called “Fantasy of a Black Woman,” for his 2005 movie “Diary of a Mad Black Woman.” That film went on to earn about $50 million, and Ms. West is asking a jury to award her all of its profits. On the stand, Mr. Perry said that his script was an original work, but said during cross-examination that he was not sure if anyone saw him write it. “I never stole anything from anybody — never,” Mr. Perry said, according to The A.P.

The surprise run of NBC’s resurrected “Knight Rider” will come to an abrupt halt in the network’s midseason schedule, The Hollywood Reporter said. The show, which was one of the first to receive a full-season order, will have its finale on Feb. 25 and be retooled for next season. NBC also announced that it would air a special one-hour episode of “The Office” after the Super Bowl on Feb. 1, and that the final episode of “E.R.” would air on March 12. The reality series “Celebrity Apprentice,” in which famous people try not to be fired by Donald Trump, will return on March 1, and a new drama, “Kings,” starring Ian McShane of “Deadwood,” will have its debut on March 19. The struggling shows “Heroes” and “Chuck,” both absent from NBC’s January schedule, will return on Feb. 2.

In just one day of online existence, the Funny Or Die video “Prop 8­ — The Musical” has received more than 1.2 million hits. The comedic song-and-dance diatribe about the California ballot initiative to define marriage as existing only between a man and a woman stars a cast of dozens, including John C. Reilly, Neil Patrick Harris, Maya Rudolph, and Jack Black as Jesus Christ.

The coming production of “The Nutcracker” by Ballet BC in Vancouver has been rescued by an anonymous benefactor who purchased 1,000 tickets to the show, the CBC reported. Ballet BC had already committed to the production, which will feature the Moscow Classical Ballet, when it laid off 38 staff members, including its dancers and artistic director. The Vancouver City Council voted to give a one-time grant of $85,000 to the company, and the sale of 1,000 tickets, to be donated to a foundation for poor children, will ensure that “The Nutcracker” will take place as scheduled. Elsewhere, the Charleston Symphony Orchestra has received anonymous pledges of up to $75,000, The Post and Courier reported. In November, the orchestra’s president announced during a concert intermission that the symphony was facing a $250,000 shortfall.

After a process filled with more back-and-forths than a performance of “Do-Re-Mi,” the owners of the Trapp family home in Austria said the house would not be reopened as a hotel, Agence France-Presse reported. From 1923 to 1938, the villa in Aigen, near Salzburg, was the home of Capt. Georg von Trapp, his children and their governess, Maria, later immortalized in the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical “The Sound of Music.” In July, the house was officially inaugurated as the Villa Trapp, and local officials were expected to approve the owners’ plans to turn it into a hotel. But on Wednesday, these plans were rejected by the city, whose residents feared the house would be overrun with tourists. In a statement quoted by Agence France-Presse, the owners said: “There is no objective or legal reason to block a 14-room hotel in Aigen.”

The nation’s employers shed 533,000 jobs in November, the 11th consecutive monthly decline, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported Friday. Not since December 1974, toward the end of a severe recession, have so many jobs disappeared in a single month. The unemployment rate rose to 6.7 percent, up just two-tenths of a percentage point from October in part because it does not include all those too discouraged to look for work any longer or those working fewer hours than they would like. The number of part-time workers who want full-time work rose sharply, to 7.3 million, up 62.2 percent from November of last year.

Jets defensive end Shaun Ellis has been charged with possession of marijuana, driving without insurance and speeding. The Jets allowed Ellis, a team captain, to play against the Broncos, and he will play against the 49ers on Sunday. The police said Ellis was uncooperative.

A few weeks ago, I was in San Francisco, having dinner at a restaurant called Café Gratitude, which serves food that is vegan, gluten-free and raw. Each dish is named with an affirmation ("I Am Sensational" is the pesto pizza, made with buckwheat sunflower seed flatbread crust; "I Am Thankful," coconut-curry soup), and you must say them aloud when you order. When I asked for an "I Am Sassy" -- sort of like a lemonade -- my sweet-eyed waiter responded "You are sassy!" as a way of both acknowledging my order and confirming my essential sassiness.

That was KalPa's Mika Järvinen on Thursday, becoming the first netminder to score in an SM-liiga game. The goal came in the last minute of a 4-2 KalPa victory over Lukko at Lukko's Äijänsuo Arena in Rauma.

Representatives for Texas Tech Coach Mike Leach have contacted the search firm that Washington is using to hire a coach and informed them that he was no longer interested in the Huskies' head coaching job, according to a person with direct knowledge of the search who spoke on condition of anonymity because no hire has been made.
Nestled in the mountains of south-central Colorado, the town offers four seasons of outdoor sports without the trappings of popular resort towns like Telluride or Aspen.
The chiefs of the Big Three automakers and the United Auto Workers were back on Capitol Hill to plead for federal cash.
Mr. Becerra, who is being considered for the position of United States trade representative, would bring a grasp of trade issues and would add a second Hispanic to the Cabinet.

A towel designed by the artist Ed Ruscha.If buying a piece of art is out of your budget these days, you'll be glad to hear that the Art Production Fund's popular charity beach towels are back. Now that the weather is heating up in Miami - sorry, New Yorkers, it's scoring above 70° over here - it's it's time to score some blankets fashioned by Raymond Pettibon, Ed Ruscha, Karen Kilimnik, Alex Katz and Julian Schnabel, among others. They're available for $50 at the Standard and Raleigh hotels in Miami, but for those just dreaming of the sun, go to target.com or worksonwhatever.com.

Over at the Sundance clubhouse here, folks seemed upbeat this week - or at least as upbeat as people who spend their days in dark rooms watching independent flicks by the hundred can be. Ticket packages for January's festival are sold out. Some 50,000 movie-goers and hangers-on are once again pointed toward Park City, Utah.

Video | Can you tell the Christmas story for radio or video in under 30 seconds? That was the challenge from the Churches Advertising Network in Britain, issued to churches, youth groups and individuals. Here's the winning entry, from Frankie Hipwell-Larkin of Portsmouth:

Nearly 90 notable figures in the world of sustainable agriculture and food sent a letter to the Obama transition team earlier this week offering their six top picks for what they called "the sustainable choice for the next U.S. Secretary of Agriculture."
Yesterday we covered when and under what circumstances it was or was not O.K. for a child to lie to a parent.

An article in the January issue of Consumer Reports , "Best & Worst Cell Phone Deals," has designated the Samsung Blackjack II the best smartphone made, ahead of the most popular phone on the market, the iPhone (ranked No. 10), and the new T-Mobile G1 Google Phone (No. 11). The highest-rated BlackBerry was the Pearl (No. 13).
Updated, 5:13 p.m. | ALBANY -- The long battle over which party will control the State Senate appears to be coming to a close.
The new service pack - or software upgrade - for Microsoft's Vista operating system will soon be available for download.
The tranquil atmosphere has lured many new residents to St. Albans, Queens.

DealBook's latest column on the thorny question of executive compensation generated plenty of discussion on our site. It also drew a thoughtful response from Roland A. Paul of the law firm Ivey, Barnum & O'Mara in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Paul, whose practice focuses on corporate, commercial and securities matters, has practiced law at Cravath Swaine & Moore and Simpson Thacher & Bartlett and was general counsel of Howmet Corporation in Greenwich.

Updated, 5:41 p.m. | Even before Richard Ravitch presented his rescue plan on Thursday for saving the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the responses -- first, from environmental, transportation and labor advocates, and then from elected officials -- began to pour in. Most expressed support for, or at least urged careful consideration of, the Ravitch plan, but some politicians raised concerns about the report's call for tolls on the city-owned East River and Harlem River bridges. Selections from their statements in response follow.

Two national feminist groups have endorsed Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Democrat representing parts of Manhattan and Queens, to succeed Hillary Rodham Clinton as the next United States senator from New York should Mrs. Clinton be confirmed as secretary of state.

Lately, the pomegranate has been touted as something of a wonderfruit. This reddish-pink fruit holds hundreds of juicy, red seeds and has been credited with lowering cholesterol and reducing risk for prostate cancer.
The use of drugs ("truth serums") in interrogations.
The results of a new study may call into question current national treatment guidelines.
The Rutgers football team can close the regular season Thursday night by beating Louisville at home in a nationally televised game for its sixth consecutive victory.

Culture | You know about the dumbing down of culture, but did you know this is also an "age of mass intelligence"? A writer for The Economist sees culture as not a road to hell but a two-way street, with heavy traffic in both directions. He cites the growing appeal of museums, literary festivals, operas, and so forth. Why? "More people have been trained at universities to want, or expect, more intellectual stimulation." [More Intelligent Life]

How much longer can "Slumdog Millionaire" be classified as an Oscar longshot? The Cinderella of this year's Oscar race, "Slumdog," about a young Indian man vying for a life-changing prize on a television game show (and filled with singing, dancing and lots of Hindi), was chosen by the National Board of Review on Thursday.
From left: "Mark," 2007 (Jacob Dyrenforth); "Storage Headboard (after John G. Shea)," (2005), (Simparch)

The stupendous photos of Life magazine need no longer merely yellow and crumble in your grandpa's cardboard boxes. The vast archive is now available, digitized and lovely, on Google, which is increasingly assuming the role of public trust. It's all searchable, and any good citizen should set aside an hour to tour around.

Film | The Oscar-touted film "The Dark Knight" is "a surprisingly explicit allegory to our current age of terrorism," an essay says. The Joker's terrorism "has no rational, comprehensible motivation," presenting Batman and his allies with "a menace they can neither understand nor control." At its core the movie asks, "At what point do the exceptional methods required to fight terrorism become a threat to the society which employs them?" [Azure]

The cost of a college education is soaring to another layer of the stratosphere, on its way to being unreachable for most students. Not exactly shocking news, which came out of this week's report "Measuring Up 2008," issued by the National Center for Public Policy and Higher Education.
David Pogue reviews the new  Motorola/Kodak Motozine ZN5, a phone camera.
Banks continue to consolidate at a furious pace, even as bills aimed at closing a tax loophole for bank mergers gather support in Washington.

Here's something to add to the today's list of holiday sales: Housing Works will have a sale of 500 vintage Yves Saint Laurent pieces on Dec. 11, from 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. The location is 157 E. 23rd, between Lexington and Third (212-529-5955), and prices will range from $45 to $250. According to Housing Works, the clothes-evening dresses, pinstriped suits, frilly blouses and more-are from one New York donor. (The period seems to be 70s-80s; sizes run from 32 to 44.) The sale, with refreshments, is free and open to the public.

Kim White, a designer based in Los Angeles, makes women's handbags from vintage automotive fabrics. She loves the bold patterns of the '60s through '80s, she says, and the upholstery material is rugged enough to resist wear and stains.
"Homeland Security USA," a reality show produced with the full cooperation of several agencies of the Department of Homeland Security, will have its premiere on Jan. 6 on ABC.

Health | Lately medicine has been showing us that we're biochemically separate and unequal. So how can a health care system that favors same and equal, with drugs that help the most people, possibly keep up with all this diversity of disease and specialized cures? Meet "pharmacogenomics": eugenics for drugs. [City Journal]

Dave Itzkoff reports: "The surprise run of NBC's resurrected 'Knight Rider' will come to an abrupt halt in the network's midseason schedule, The Hollywood Reporter said. The show, which was one of the first to receive a full-season order, will have its finale on Feb. 25 and be retooled for next season. NBC also announced that it would air a special one-hour episode of 'The Office' after the Super Bowl on Feb. 1, and that the final episode of 'E.R.' would air on March 12."

In case it wasn't already clear that Barack Obama is going to have a lot to deal with when he takes office, the Government Accountability Office, Congress's investigative agency, has released a list of 13 urgent issues for him and the next Congress.
I'm looking out there for the one person who apparently was not offended by the spelling of "whiskey'' in my column on Speyside single malts. If you are that person, allow me to explain.

Dave Itzkoff also reports on two tweaks to the CW's midseason schedule: "A new horror-themed reality series called '13 - Fear is Real' will have its debut on Jan. 7, and the comedy series 'Reaper,' about a young man who learns his parents have sold his soul to the devil, will return to the network's lineup on March 17."
As hard as it may be to leave 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, President George W. Bush and First Lady Laura Bush have settled on a new home.
Forget books, MP3 players or vacuums. Amazon.com wants to offer you a copy of the human genome this holiday season.

I know, 'cause I made it. I thought it might be fun to take guesses, since it's not something I make too often. When we're done with that, then I hope that some of you can help me figure out how to make it better.

Texas leads the nation in wind energy, but it is also is the largest producer and consumer of energy -- the latter largely due both to its size and to the presence of big industries like oil, gas and chemicals.

You don't need one of those gold tickets anymore to have a straight view of the Capitol during President-elect Obama's swearing-in. With at least 1.5 million people expected to crowd Washington for the event, his inaugural committee announced that it would open the entire National Mall to spectators.

The Fire Department will close a firehouse on Governors Island and eliminate night tours at four other firefighting units starting Jan. 17 to achieve an $8.9 million agency budget cut necessitated by New York City's financial crisis, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta announced Wednesday.
When a company had trouble selling houses in its Lough Fern Heights development in Milford, Ireland, it decided to offer a throw in: a new apartment in its Privacy Beach Resort in Bulgaria.

Fulvio Di Rosa’s latest venture, Borgo di Vagli, has emerged from the ruins of a medieval hamlet near Cortona, Italy.
About 100 readers wrote to say that they had bought the Storm and now regretted it. Some samples:

Prudential Financial plans to sell its minority stake in Wachovia's brokerage unit to Wells Fargo in a deal that could yield the nation's second-largest life insurance company a $1.7 billion after-tax gain.
"Hysterical Paradise," 2008 (Jennifer Vanderpool)

Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on NBC: The Labor Department announced that over 1,100 lawyers lost their jobs last month. So lawyers are losing their jobs, C.E.O.'s are being forced to work for a dollar a year, and Ann Coulter's jaw has been wired shut. In many ways, this could be the greatest Christmas ever when you think about it.
The fact that a Secretary of Agriculture has yet to be named has some chefs, farmers and animal welfare advocates wondering whether food and farming have been shoved to the Obama D team.

Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: This morning, President-elect Barack Obama nominated New Mexico Gov. Bill Richardson to be Secretary of Commerce. Given the state of our economy, that might be the toughest cabinet job of all of them, which means, once again, the Mexican guy gets stuck with the job nobody wants to do.

Sean Avery, accompanied by the man who charged forward and signed him in Dallas, Stars co-G.M. Brett Hull, will meet with N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman Thursday in the league's New York office. Whatever the ruling is on Avery's comments, it's fairly certain that he's out of the picture in Dallas and that the team must find a way to dispose of his four-year, $15.5 million contract.

Politics | To understand Obama, look back to the oratory of ancient Greece and Rome, a columnist says. "Oratory was the supreme political skill, on whose mastery power depended ... The Greeks and Romans, in short, knew all the rhetorical tricks, and they put a name to most of them. It turns out that Obama knows them, too." Let's count the ways. [Guardian]

A militia group in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The name Mai Mai derives from the Kiswahili for water (maji), and refers to the militiamen's custom of daubing themselves before battle with a mixture of palm oil and water.
The Jacob Burns Film Center is set to unveil its latest addition in Westchester.

It's comforting to know the Mets will not be deterred from taking taxpayer money funneled through Citigroup to keep the name of that failing institution on the team's new ballpark (itself somewhat subsidized by public largesse.)

When I set out to find guest bloggers, my goal was to find parents whose life equations were made of different variables than mine, to reflect the range of ways to be a parent. Enter Allison Tate, who, lives in a house full of boys, and sometimes feels lost amid the testosterone.

Art | Inside the world of models who pose nude for artists: They're typically students, or in art or theater, and they needn't have great bodies. And sometimes they encounter the "eew" factor: "I'd hate it when they'd say, 'Keep your robe on. Just drape it, just show one breast.' I'd go, 'Oh, I'd rather be naked.' I mean, seductive, erotic. ... In a group setting?" [Chicago Tribune]

More than 100 people who are down on their luck, including wounded veterans, battered women and terminally ill patients, are about to be offered something they may never have imagined -- three days at Barack Obama's inauguration in Washington, all expenses paid.
Unshakable and indomitable - from the Kenyan term bwogo, meaning shake or scare.

Nadim Audi of the New York Times bureau in Cairo flagged these items:
The cultural equivalent of comfort eating - i.e., consumption for pleasure, reassurance, and security.

Junk bond peddlers should have taken a vacation in November. That's because there were no -- count 'em, zero -- high-yield corporate bond deals done last month on the entire planet, according to data from Thomson Reuters. That is the worst showing since March 1991, when the market for junk debt, more politely known as high yield, was in ashes.

Updated, 7:20 p.m. | A state commission led by Richard Ravitch, a former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, presented a wide-ranging rescue plan on Thursday for the region's subways, buses and commuter railroads that includes a new "mobility tax" on payrolls in the region; tolls on the free East River and Harlem River bridges; a much smaller fare and toll increase than the cash-strapped authority has threatened; few service reductions; and improvements in bus service.
The slogan of YouTube is "Broadcast Yourself." I've got to wonder if many YouTube users are broadcasting information about their tastes in video far more widely than they understand.

A 14-year-old girl walking to school in Queens on Thursday morning was struck by a yellow school bus and later died at a hospital, city officials said. The girl, who was not immediately identified by name, was struck at 8:10 a.m. as she crossed the street near 57th Avenue and 90th Street in Elmhurst, the police said. She suffered injuries to her head and was transported to Elmhurst Hospital Center, where she was declared dead at 8:54 a.m., the authorities said.
Venture capitalists were decidedly somber about the prospects of start-up companies in the tough economic climate, as they spoke on a panel at a clean-energy conference in Austin.

The red carpet is hardly the place for meaningful discussions - questions are more along the lines of, "Who are you wearing?" - but the Baguette tried to get in at least one serious question at Wednesday's night premiere of "The Reader." As the Bagger reported yesterday, Thelma Adams, from the Huffington Post, asked some pointed questions in a column about the movie's portrayal of the sexual relationship between a 15-year-old boy (David Kross) and a woman more than twice his age, who turns out to be a former guard in a Nazi concentration camp (Kate Winslet)?

Most people have heard of multiple sclerosis but have little sense of what the disease really is or how it affects the lives of those who have it. The latest Patient Voices from my colleague Karen Barrow sheds needed light on those living every day with the disease.

In politics, it is apparently never too early to start raising money. And that is the underlying message of a fund-raising dinner Gov. David A. Paterson is hosting Thursday night in Manhattan for State Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli's campaign in 2010.

We will get right to the action from Wednesday night with a look at the Western Hockey League. But first, if you want to know more about the team the United States will send to the world junior championship tournament later this month, take a look at the bottom of Wednesday evening's More Morning Skate post by Stu Hackel, who had the first words here on the subject. In other news, the Windsor Spitfires remain atop the rankings of the Canadian Hockey League. The full report on the rankings is here.
[UPDATE 10/19: Columbia University's environmental journalism program is suspended and The New York Times announces a fast round of 100 new newsroom job cuts.]
David Carr, The Carpetbagger, gives his own daily take on awards season news.
President-elect Barack Obama’s aides say he is considering making a major foreign policy speech from an Islamic capital during his first 100 days in office. But where should he do it?

The Bagger did not go to Wednesday's press conference for "Revolutionary Road," but Karina Longworth made it and brings back a very tangy dispatch from the frontier of Kate vs. Kate. Ms. Winslet, so far, has accomplished the delicate and perilous job of promoting both "The Reader" and "Revolutionary Road" and says how they end up in the Oscar race is really not her affair.

Many soups have simple origins, none more so than an ancient peasant dish of southern France called, simply, boiled water: garlic simmered in water to give it flavor, with a few crusts of bread added for bulk. This dish is a great example of how an almost absurdly simple preparation can be quickly and easily converted into one that is nearly grand.

Earlier this week, when Women's Wear Daily posted an entire set of designers' suggestions for what the incoming First Lady Michelle Obama might wear for the inauguration, we were a bit preoccupied with her spouse's announcements about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, other national security team appointments and well, how the new administration was taking shape.
"We're No. 3!" "We're No. 3!"
As part of its pitch for billions of dollars in federal aid, General Motors has agreed to a flurry of austerity measures, including the sale of its much-discussed corporate jets.

The chiefs of the Big Three automakers and the United Auto Workers were back on Capitol Hill today for a Senate Banking Committee hearing in which the companies pleaded for federal cash. Floyd Norris, the chief financial correspondent for The Times and author of the High & Low Finance column and blog, was live-blogging the proceedings here, with the most recent posts at the top.
There's a hot new strategy sweeping the hedge fund industry -- it's called pulling up the gates.

Not everyone one is minding their manners. Writing in Awards Daily, Sasha Stone says that if it's Oscar season, then the outlook for flying mud is high. But she thinks that "Slumdog" will be wearing some fairly effective Teflon for the coming season:
Who's next, Plaxico Burress?

Back in 2001, who would have guessed that Henry Blodget, the high-profile Internet stock analyst, and Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general who banished him from Wall Street, would end up under the same journalistic umbrella?
I will be live blogging the Senate hearing today on the automakers, in which the companies will plead for cash. The rest of the posts will be on the Lede blog, which you can switch to here.

Executives of the country's largest car companies have returned to Washington today to once again press Congress for tens of billions of dollars in federal help. But as The Times's Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley report, "the political climate on Capitol Hill is still doubtful for the automakers," and they write that presidents, current and future, may have to get involved before lawmakers and auto executives can reach an agreement:

On the Op-Ed page today, Charles Seife says that there are enough missing ballots and other problems in Minnesota that we will never be sure who got the most votes. He calls for invoking a Minnesota law that allows for the flipping of a coin to decide a tied election.
I've been ruminating over economic prospects for next year, and I'm getting scared.

One of the things that the Bagger always forgets while covering the awards silly season is that you have to see the movies first. And so he has been criss-crossing Manhattan for weeks in search of any celluloid that has a whiff of potential laurels. And Wednesday night's outing, likely the last of the season, took him to "The Reader."

I'm continuing to indulge myself over Depression economics. So here's a reply to people wondering why I dismissed the real balance effect -- the fact that a fall in the price level raises the real value of the money supply (or more strictly the monetary base) and hence makes people wealthier, possibly raising aggregate demand even if interest rates are stuck at zero.

Starting on Jan. 1, New York City ambulances will take many cardiac arrest patients only to hospitals that use a delicate cooling therapy believed to reduce the chances of brain damage and increase the chances of survival, even if it means bypassing closer emergency rooms.

World | A piracy expert goes back to the 16th century to identify five factors common to successful pirates, including Somalia's: "an available population of potential recruits, a secure base of operations, a sophisticated organization, some degree of outside support, and cultural bonds that engender vibrant group solidarity." But a retired admiral doubts the "alleged nexus" between piracy and terrorism. (See also this global, Google-enabled "Live Piracy Map 2008") [Proceedings, U.S. Naval Institute]
The editors of T Magazine present What Gives, a guide to holiday gifting.
The idea seems simple enough. The rich world would pay the poor world to save a type of natural commodity from which we all benefit - trees.

Thanks to many readers who responded to the popcorn experiment, we've got plenty of data and should have results for you soon. While the researchers, Pierre Chandon and Nailya Ordabayeva. are crunching the numbers, let me address some questions raised about the "health halo" I described in my Findings column and Lab post about Dr. Chandon's research.

Anthropology | For years, scientists studying the "biology of beauty" have held that men prefer women with an hourglass figure because it's a sign of fertility. But now an anthropologist concludes that nature favors women with less slim waists, and that includes men. "Only in countries where women are economically dependent on men (such as Japan, Greece and Portugal) do men prefer the thin-waist ideal of female beauty." [Newsweek]
Eliot Spitzer, who aggressively pursued Wall Street as New York's attorney general and was later forced to resign as the state's governor, has a new calling as a financial commentator for Slate.

THE NEW YORK TIMESFrench Seek to Trump Buffett's Bid for Constellation EnergySeeking a strong foothold in the United States, Electricité de France, the giant French utility, offered on Wednesday to pay $4.5 billion for half of Constellation Energy's nuclear power unit, a deal that could scuttle a proposed takeover by the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett.

Few self-help books for family members of those with Alzheimer's disease are as universally praised as "Learning to Speak Alzheimer's,'' by Joanne Koenig Coste. The book preaches a counterintuitive approach she calls "habilitation,'' which is a fancy word for entering the topsy-turvy reality of the cognitively impaired person rather than trying to force them into a world they no longer understand.

In the latest sign of consolidation among midsize American banks, Capital One Financial plans to buy Chevy Chase Bank for about $520 million, The New York Times's Eric Dash reported. The deal will allow it to rely more on customer deposits for financing.

Relations between Carl C. Icahn and Leon D. Black, the founder of the Apollo Management, may not be at their warmest right now, after Mr. Icahn filed suit against his close friend and fellow billionaire, but The Deal has dug up a video on YouTube that shows how chummy the two deal-makers have been in the past.
iPerceptions, a Web site analytics start-up, has landed $3.65 million in a round of new financing. The funding was led by Telesystem and Skuli Mogensen, a private investor.

Economy | A case study in tilting against the oppressive weight of conventional wisdom: a nine-minute video compilation called "Peter Schiff Was Right, 2006-2007" (noted on Joe Nocera's Executive Suite blog on Wednesday). It shows Schiff, head of a brokerage firm, enduring ridicule and scorn on cable TV business shows as he accurately predicts the housing meltdown and current crisis. [YouTube, Executive Suite]
No one wants to be WaMu-ed.

In late 1998, while Washington was in the throes of the Monica Lewinsky scandal, Rahm Emanuel, a departing senior political aide to President Bill Clinton, ventured out to an elegant restaurant in Dupont Circle for something of a job interview, The New York Times's Michael Luo writes.
When Wesley R. Edens and his partners founded their investment firm a decade ago, they chose a name that evoked unshakeable bastions: Fortress.

The Wikimedia Foundation, the nonprofit entity behind the immensely popular Wikipedia, just announced a new project that is meant to make it a lot easier for inexperienced authors to contribute articles and edits to the project.
General Motors wants some forgiveness - $32 billion of it.
Danish domestic airline Cimber Air said Thursday it has taken over key parts of bankrupt budget airline Sterling Airways for an undisclosed amount.
It was the letter J that opened the door for Helvetica into the subways.

Citigroup's top executives and Robert E. Rubin, a director and senior counselor at the firm, are ready to forgo their bonuses this year as the bank reels from the effects of the financial crisis, The Financial Times reported.

The United Automobile Workers union said Wednesday that it would make major concessions in its contracts with the three Detroit auto companies to help them lobby Congress for $34 billion in federal aid, The New York Times's Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley write.

General Motors and Chrysler are considering accepting a pre-arranged bankruptcy as the last-resort price of getting a multi-billion dollar government bailout, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person familiar with internal discussions.

Asian companies have been snapping up choice overseas assets, mainly in Europe, with mergers and acquisitions hitting a record $58 billion so far this year despite the financial crisis, The Associated Press reported.

General Motors has promised Congress that it can recreate itself as a different kind of car company - smaller, with a more cooperative relationship with its union, and a lineup of fuel-efficient cars to compete with the best of the foreign brands.

Credit Suisse announced Thursday it would cut 5,300 jobs - 11 percent of its global workforce -- and Nomura of Japan said that it planned 1,000 job cuts at its London office as the financial crisis and economic downturn intensifies.
Financial institutions from Morgan Stanley to GE Capital are trying to beef up their deposit gathering. Goldman Sachs is reportedly even considering starting an online bank.

New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg said he had advised President-elect Barack Obama's transition team to boost U.S. economic growth by fixing the credit markets so that cities and states can resume borrowing to build infrastructure projects.
Goldman Sachs said on Thursday it has rejected an offer from Panasonic to buy its shares in Sanyo Electric because it believes the offer price is too low.

Investors in the Reserve Primary Fund, the giant money market fund that has been frozen for more than two months, are finally getting some details about how the beleaguered fund plans to handle its continuing liquidation, The New York Times's Diana B. Henriques reported.

Legg Mason's Bill Miller, a celebrated value investor but whose stock picking is far off the mark this year, said on Wednesday the "bottom has been made" in U.S. equities, and forecast opportunities for strong gains once markets rally.

Constellation Energy, it seems, isn't inclined to rush into the arms of Electricité de France, the giant French utility that on Wednesday offered to pay $4.5 billion for half of Constellation's nuclear power unit, a deal that could scuttle a proposed takeover by the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett.
The economic decline took a turn for the worse after the market shocks of October. In November, the problems only deepened, The New York Times's Michael M. Grynbaum writes.

Federal regulators on Wednesday adopted new rules designed to stem conflicts of interest and provide more transparency for Wall Street's credit-rating industry, widely faulted for its role in the subprime mortgage debacle and ensuing credit crisis.

Politics | "Was Larry Summers right about women and science, after all?" Ruth Marcus asks. Research, echoing work noted on this blog in May, suggests the ex-Harvard president "may have been on to something" when he linked innate aptitude to the dearth of tenured women on elite science faculties. Yet those impolitic words may help explain his getting an Obama post that doesn't require confirmation hearings. [Washington Post, Ideas]

Fluctuations in currency exchange rates are wreaking havoc in some second-home markets, particularly in countries like Spain and Bulgaria that rely on British buyers. A year ago a pound fetched €1.40; today it is worth only €1.16, making overseas property far less attractive to the typical "A Place in the Sun" fanatic.

One of the most simple and effective ways to improve the physical and mental health of impoverished people is to add iodine to the salt supply.
A judge in Milan on Wednesday suspended the trial of 26 Americans, most of them believed to work for the C.I.A., and several Italian intelligence agents accused of kidnapping a terrorism suspect.

A stadium vendor has settled a lawsuit by the family of a girl paralyzed in a car accident in 1999 caused by a drunken Giants fan for $26 million. The amount of the settlement had been sealed until Wednesday, when a state appellate court in Newark overturned a lower court’s decision to keep the settlement private. Antonia Verni, 11, and her mother, Fazila, sought to keep the settlement private because of concerns over how the girl’s estranged father handled funds from earlier settlements with other defendants.
BAGHDAD -- Mustard-colored and twice the size of an iPod it is the most interesting and depressing of reads for anyone working in Iraq.
A prominent prosecutor who resigned after the mistaken release of racist, political and pornographic e-mail messages found on his office computer will not face charges stemming from the case.

The aunt and onetime guardian of an emaciated and shackled 17-year-old boy has been arrested, as the police tried to determine how she knew the couple accused of holding the teenager against his will for nearly a year.
A man has received 45 years in prison in a plot that left a pizza delivery man-turned-robber dead from a bomb locked to his neck.
Sixteen Indiana National Guard soldiers sued the military contractor KBR, saying its employees knowingly allowed them to be exposed to a toxic chemical in Iraq five years ago.
Former Gov. Jeb Bush said he was interested in the seat Senator Mel Martinez is giving up, and the field of possible candidates could quickly narrow to make way for him.

Rejecting prosecutors’ calls for a life term, a federal judge in Seattle reimposed a 22-year prison sentence for a terrorist trained by Al Qaeda who was convicted of plotting to bomb Los Angeles International Airport at the turn of the millennium.

A preview of the holiday decorations, the tree and the red, white and blue theme chosen to celebrate this year’s Christmas at the White House.
Hong Kong food safety authorities said late Tuesday that for the fourth time in less than two months they had found a batch of Chinese eggs contaminated with illegal levels of melamine.
A French aid worker kidnapped at gunpoint in Kabul, the Afghan capital, on Nov. 3 and later seen in a hostage video was released by his captors Wednesday, French officials said.
A series of strong earthquakes off the coast of the Indonesian island of Sumatra has not reduced chances of another devastating jolt in the region, according to a new study.
Bangkok’s international airport creaked back to life on Wednesday after the end of a weeklong siege, above, by antigovernment protesters.

Robert Bardin and Robert Palomo, event planners, have opened a Chelsea showroom where they are selling their collection of French and American furniture, lighting and sculpture, most of it dating from the 1920s through the 1960s and amassed over the last 15 years. They have 60 pieces on display in vignettes in the showroom and 150 stashed in a warehouse in New Jersey. Midcentury Italian chairs in their original orange wool upholstery ($4,800 for the pair), near right, face a midcentury American sofa, restored and reupholstered in a gray-green fake suede ($6,500), next to a new Chinese document chest ($8,500) and a midcentury Arteluce Triennale lamp ($9,500). The Bardin Palomo Collection is open Monday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., or by appointment, at 432 West 19th Street (Ninth Avenue), (212) 989-6113.

Federal immigration officials returned more than 80 ancient artifacts to the Egyptian government on Wednesday, pieces that had been stolen from a museum near Cairo in 2002 by a United States Army helicopter pilot and later sold to an antiquities dealer. The antiquities, right, seized by Immigration and Customs Enforcement after an investigation in 2006, were among 370, dating to 3000 B.C. or earlier, that were discovered missing from a museum in Maadi, a suburb of Cairo. At a ceremony in Manhattan, Peter J. Smith, special agent in charge of the immigration department’s Office of Investigations, returned the artifacts to Egypt’s consul general in New York, Hussein Mubarak, and Attiya Radwan, who oversees the Central Department for Upper Egypt Monuments.

The week of Thanksgiving is usually one of the music industry’s biggest and most important, but sales were low this year despite several high-profile new releases. Guns N’ Roses’ “Chinese Democracy” (Geffen), an album 14 years in the making that was sold through an exclusive deal with Best Buy, sold 260,000 copies; some early estimates for it were nearly triple that amount. “Chinese Democracy” opens at No. 3 on the Billboard album chart, behind Kanye West’s new “808s & Heartbreak” (Def Jam), which sold 450,000, and Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine), which moved 267,000 in its third week. Last week’s No. 1, Beyoncé’s “I Am ... Sasha Fierce” (Columbia), dropped to No. 4 with 257,000; Ludacris’s “Theater of the Mind” (Def Jam) opens at No. 5 with 213,000; and the Killers’ new “Day & Age” (Island) opened at No. 6 with 193,000. Over all sales were down 13 percent from the week of Thanksgiving last year.

A five-day auction of Asian artwork at Christie’s in Hong Kong sold 35 percent less than its presale estimates in another sign of the declining global economy’s impact on the art market, Reuters reported. The auction had been expected to take in more than $225 million, but it ended Wednesday with total sales of $146 million, and more than 30 percent of its 2,400 lots went unsold. A Christie’s Hong Kong auction in May ended with total sales of $310 million, an all-time high for its Asian offerings. “Like all markets we are affected by confidence, and we’ve definitely seen less confidence in our world in the last two or three months,” Edward Dolman, the chief executive of Christie’s International, told Reuters.

The Marvel comics mini-series “Secret Invasion” concludes Thursday with a twist ending: The world has lost faith in Iron Man, who was unable to prevent an infiltration by shape-changing aliens, and turns to Norman Osborn, the Spider-Man villain known as the Green Goblin, who delivers the final blow to the extraterrestrial threat. The events put Osborn and a cabal of nefarious allies in charge of the Marvel universe. The “Secret Invasion” series has been a best-seller for Marvel; its first issue sold more than 270,000 copies. So what will its author, Brian Michael Bendis, do for a follow-up? “What we really need to do is spend some time with the characters and deal with the aftermath of all that’s happened,” he said in an interview. “We need to dig deep down and see what they’re made of.”.

THE holiday shopping season is upon us, and if Hollywood really understood what the public needs at this time of year, they'd do a modern-day remake of ''It's a Wonderful Life,'' with George Bailey threatening to jump off the bridge because of all the impossible people for whom he needs to shop. Consider, for example, the latter-day George Bailey's earnest and environmentally evolved sister-in-law, who these days wraps her gifts in fabric that she demands be returned to her so she can recycle it. What could he possibly get for that selfless woman that won't make her think he's a wastrel jerk?

TAMARIN--Steven B.,M.D. The entire Continuum Health Partners family acknowledges with sadness the untimely passing of our dear friend and colleague, Steven B. Tamarin, M.D., a devoted member of the medical staff at St. Luke's and Roosevelt Hospitals and a former member of the medical staff at Beth Israel Medical Center. Steve was one of the true pioneers in the field of Family Medicine and contributed significantly to its growth as a recognized medical discipline. He was beloved by his patients, and will forever be remembered by all who knew him and worked with him. To his family, friends and loved ones, we extend our most heartfelt condolences. Stanley Brezenoff, President and CEO, Continuum Frank J. Cracolici, President, St. Lukes and Roosevelt David J. Shulkin, M.D., President, Beth Israel Ruth Levin, Sr. VP, Managed Care, Continuum

Ramon S. Velez, who was the son of a poor Puerto Rican farmer and became the baron of a sweeping array of poverty programs in the South Bronx, receiving high praise for registering hundreds of thousands of Hispanic voters and stinging criticism for profiting from his humanitarian initiatives, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 75. The cause was complications of Alzheimer's disease, his wife, Caroline, said.

STEINBERG--Meyer (Mike). ''Death leaves a heartache no one can heal, love leaves a memory no one can steal. But I have to move on but I know you are still with me. In my heart and my soul, you're like my guardian angel. You were my best friend before you left and you still are to this day. And I know that one day I will see your smile again, hear your laugh and touch your face, but til that day all I can do is wait.'' I miss you so much dad, you are with me always. Susan

WAS a holiday season ever so economically and environmentally fraught? The ethics of financial responsibility and conservation suggest that one recycle and regift, while the national economy requires a huge infusion of cash. A freshly cut tree is essential for many people's Christmases, but the globe is heading toward meltdown. Even the act of wrapping a present has become a politically charged act. The only thing that could make this year's shopping more perplexing is the high-minded do-gooder on your list. The last thing you want is to appear frivolous, ungreen or materialistic in your choice of gift for this righteous citizen.

Lazio tied the score with a penalty kick and went on to a 2-1 victory in extra time over A.C. Milan in the quarterfinals of the Italian Cup in Rome. Milan played with 10 men after the Brazilian star Emerson was sent off in the 69th minute, but it took the lead on a goal by Andriy Shevchenko in the 77th minute. Lazio drew even in the closing moments when Giuseppe Favalli brought down Goran Pandev and Mauro Zandev scored from the penalty spot for his first goal since Nov. 9. Pandev scored the winner in the second minute of extra time. It was visiting Lazio's first win over Milan at the San Siro in five years and it will face either Fiorentina or Torino for a place in the semifinals.

FRIEDMAN--Daniel J. The Abrams, Gorelick, Friedman & Jacobson, P.C. family sadly notes the untimely passing of our founding partner, Daniel J. Friedman. Dan was an extraordinary insurance attorney who began his law career at the Kings County District Attorney's office, where he excelled at prosecuting arson and other financial crimes. He joined Abrams & Martin, P.C., our predecessor firm, and immediately excelled in defending Lloyd's Underwriters and domestic insurance companies in Federal and State Court litigations. Over the course of his 32 year legal career, Dan's skill and professionalism earned him the respect of his clients and adversaries, one of whom wrote ''A Hole in the Wall'', a novel that detailed a litigation involving a fraudulent insurance claim. The insurer's attorney was fashioned after Dan. Dan exemplified what a ''partner'' in law firm should be -he was a wise counselor, mentor and teacher. His work ethic and dedication to our firm, the law and his clients is revealed in the exhausting schedule he maintained despite his illness, culminating a few weeks ago in an oral argument before the New York Court of Appeals. We extend our love and prayers to Dan's loving wife, Lenni; his children, Holly, Michelle and Robert; sonin-law Danny; grandchildren Ryan and Chelsea who gave him unbounded joy; and brother Richard. Michael E. Gorelick, Glenn A. Jacobson and the Abrams, Gorelick, Friedman & Jacobson, P.C. family.

BEEKMAN--Augustus A. The Board of Directors and staff of Little Flower Children and Family Services of NY express our deep sorrow on the loss of Augustus Beekman, our past Board President (1983-1987) and loyal friend. Gus Beekman, once a child at Little Flower, became the second African American Fire Commissioner in NYC. He lead the agency with grace and strength, and his example will continue to inspire and lead us. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Gus Beekman's family and friends.

Look for more ''campaign accessories'' bought for Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska in the end-of-cycle financial report to be filed Thursday by the Republican National Committee. Revelations that the committee had bought about $150,000 in clothing and other items, labeled as ''campaign accessories,'' from stores like Saks Fifth Avenue and Neiman Marcus in September for Ms. Palin and her family caused a stir before the election.

COLE--Lewis. Columbia University School of the Arts Film Program mourns its former Program Chair and Professor, Lewis Cole, who died on October 10, 2008 from complications due to ALS. Donations in Lewis' memory can be made to Project ALS.

WALSH--Donald Emmett, died at the age of 63, retired in 2005 as a senior partner after a 38 year career with KPMG, LLP. Graduate, benefactor and trustee of Iona College in New Rochelle, NY. Beloved father of John Robert and his wife Jennifer, Robert George and the late Laurie Ann. Dear brother of Thomas and Maureen Rice. Dear grandfather of Kristen, Sarah and Amy. Visitation at the Castle Hill Funeral Directors, 1528 Castle Hill Ave., Bronx, NY Thursday 7-9pm, Friday 3-5 and 79pm. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:30am, St. Helena's Church. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to St. Helena's School, Bronx, NY.

RACKMAN--Emanuel. With the kindest of hearts, a deeply compassionate soul and a profound commitment to justice, Rabbi Rackman embodied the principle of Tikun Olam. We were fortunate, for nearly 50 years, to call him teacher and friend. May his guidance, decency and vision continue to inspire us all. The Sage Family

SPAIN: ETA SUSPECTED IN MAN'S DEATH Two gunmen suspected of belonging to the Basque terrorist group ETA shot and killed a businessman on Wednesday, two weeks after the arrest of the group's military leader, Spanish officials said. The victim, Ignacio Uría Mendizabal, 71, was shot at close range as he got out of his car in Azpeitia, near San Sebastián. Mr. Uría was an official with a construction company involved in building a high-speed rail network that would link the Basque region to the rest of Spain. VICTORIA BURNETT
RACKMAN--Emanuel, Rabbi. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Rackman family. Our dear friend and inspirational leader will be deeply missed. The Siegel & Gelbart Family
