Her vitality, warmth and generosity will be greatly missed. The family will receive visitors 3-7pm on December 5 at the NY Society for Ethical Culture.

Typically, presidents have to wait until long after they have left office for holidays to be declared in their honor. But officials in one Alabama county have speeded that process for President-elect Barack Obama. In Perry County, where residents voted overwhelmingly for Mr. Obama on Election Day, members of the county commission voted to set aside the second Monday in November as ''Barack Obama Day.''

WEINRIB--Ernest, died peacefully on December 3, 2008. Loving and devoted husband of Florence; father of Richard, Neil and Lisa; grandfather of Oren, Laura, Carly and Jamie; greatgrandfather of Simon; brother of Helen and Seymour. Ernie will be remembered for his wit, wisdom and passion for golf. Born in Brooklyn, he fought in Europe during WWII, married his Penn State sweetheart, Florie, and earned a law degree from St. John's. A civic leader and real estate pioneer in the Five Towns for over 50 years, he will be deeply missed by family and friends. Funeral service on December 4 at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, 12pm.

Auburn fired Coach Tommy Tuberville on Wednesday, ending a successful tenure that included an 85-40 record and six consecutive victories over archrival Alabama. No. 1 Alabama is undefeated, while Auburn is 5-7. Tuberville's tenure ended after three days of meetings with Athletic Director Jay Jacobs.

The Chargers are not yet mathematically eliminated, but the final blow to their disappointing season seems just around the corner. San Diego is three games behind first-place Denver, with four games to play, including the season finale against the Broncos. But there is always motivation to beat Oakland, one of San Diego's fiercest rivals. Not only would a win help stave off the Chargers' seemingly inevitable elimination from contention, but a victory would also postpone two other ignoble feats. The Chargers have not had a losing season since 2003 and have not lost to the Raiders in 10 games since then, either. One of LaDainian Tomlinson's two 100-yard games this season was in a Week 4 victory over Oakland, a team he has torched throughout his career. Oakland, meanwhile, is on the verge of its sixth straight 10-loss season. NAILA-JEAN MEYERS

9 P.M. (CNN) CNN PRESENTS: SCREAM BLOODY MURDER Christiane Amanpour, above, reports on the failure of world governments to stop genocide -- from the Holocaust and ethnic massacres of Armenians to systematic terrorism and violence in Cambodia, Rwanda, Iraq and Darfur -- and those unsung heroes who raised their voices to urge the world to help end the atrocities. The program commemorates the approaching 60th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Tips on having a low-budget wedding, dangerous holiday decorations, and ways to celebrate a holiday -- frugally -- during a recession.

YEE--Marya Lenn. The Copyright Society of the USA mourns the passing of Marya Lenn Yee, an outstanding attorney, and a wonderful friend and colleague. Marya was a beloved member and former Trustee, and a former Chair of the New York Chapter, of the Copyright Society of the USA. She will be sorely missed. Our thoughts and prayers are with her family and associates. The Copyright Society of the USA
STEINBERG--Meyer (Mike), 6/19/19 to 12/4/03. You are forever in our hearts. We love you, Jean, Bonnie, Carol and Lois
WEINRIB--Ernest. Temple Israel of Lawrence mourns the loss of our esteemed member. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. Jay H. Rosenbaum, Rabbi Garrett L. Gray, President

RACKMAN--Rabbi Emanuel. On behalf of Touro College and Touro University, I express my deep personal sorrow at the passing of Rabbi Rackman, a beloved and wonderful friend of many years who encouraged me to fashion and build a new school of higher learning based on Torah and Parnassah. May his memory be a blessing. Dr. Bernard Lander, President and Founder

CONNELL--Stephanie (Shep), on December 2, 2008. Teacher, commercial artist, artist. In the 1970s, she was identified as one of the top 200 American Women artists. Survived by her two sons, Eric and Joseph, granddaughter Elizabeth, daughter-in-law Susan and close personal friend Ron. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in her name be made to the Art Students League or the Jane Goodall Institute. Service Monday 11:30am at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
RAHTZ--Henrietta, December 2, 2008, age 91. Widow of Robert; sister of the late Lloyd Barenblatt. Survived by son Roger, daughter-inlaw Laura, grandsons Joshua and David.

WEINRIB--Ernest. The Board of Governors and the members of The Seawane Club record with sorrow the loss of our beloved member, Ernest Weinrib. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Florence and family. Geoffrey D. Lurie, President

YOU, of course, are not a design snob. Some people are aesthetically aware. Some, like your younger sister, are oblivious, particularly to the pain it causes you to walk into the mismatched chaos they call home. That Miró poster on the wall that she's had since college. The squat, naked-people coffee cups. The Mamie Eisenhower plate, which once belonged to your grandmother, displayed without a shred of irony. You want -- indeed it is your obligation -- to find a gift that will not merely improve the homes of your design-challenged loved one, but influence and inspire him or her. You want to suggest that there is another way.

LONDON -- The annual ceremony at which Queen Elizabeth II formally opens Parliament was overshadowed on Wednesday by an uproar in the House of Commons over a police raid last week in which Scotland Yard's elite counterterrorism squad searched an opposition member's parliamentary office for evidence for a possible criminal case against the member of Parliament and a civil service whistleblower. The queen's journey in an ermine-trimmed gown and gilded carriage to the Palace of Westminster became almost a sideshow as a packed Commons chamber, meeting after the ceremony, erupted into angry dispute over the raid last Thursday. It was the Commons' first opportunity to respond, in formal session, to what many members have described as the most threatening assault on Britain's parliamentary sovereignty in memory.

We're going through Reformation times, and in Reformation times things aren't neat and clean. BISHOP ROBERT DUNCAN, of Pittsburgh, a conservative who led his diocese out of the Episcopal Church in October. [A1]
ROSENTHAL--Hal, Dearest Mucka, A day doesn't end without you in my heart. Love, your Hon Joy

KANN--Walter, 85, of New Canaan, CT, and Palm Beach Gardens, FL, on December 1st, 2008. Loving husband of Maryann, devoted father of Michael and Jacqueline, and grandchildren, Sebastian, Claudia, Samantha and Benjamin. He is also survived by his sister Ruth Arieli, and cousins here and in Israel. Emigrating from Germany in June of 1938, he served in the U.S. Army during WWII. After completing courses at Camp Ritchie he served as an MI interrogator in Germany and was honorably discharged as a Tech Sgt. 316th, HQ Intelligence Army Detachment in 1946. Walter graduated Phi Beta Kappa from CCNY in 1948. He thereafter began a dynamic 60-year career in commodity trading, longserving as a high level executive and board member at Philipp Brothers, NY, and its successor companies for 38 years, living in Tokyo heading up Phibro's Japanese operations from 1953 through 1956. In 1985 he helped found Newco AG, Switzerland, serving as chairman through 1999. He remained active in business until his death. He was known and respected worldwide, but particularly in Asia and South Africa. Avid collector of model trains, and lover of classical music, he will be most remembered for his quick wit, integrity, strong determination and generosity to those in need. He is sorely missed by all. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Walter & Maryann Kann Scholarship Fund/Kingsborough Community College Foundation, 2001 Oriental Blvd., Brooklyn, NY 11235 would be most appreciated. The family will be sitting shivah at home through Sunday evening. Funeral services will be held on Friday, December 5th, at 11:00am, at the Riverside Chapel 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue in NYC.

Odetta, the singer whose resonant voice wove together the strongest songs of American folk music and the civil rights movement, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 77. The cause was heart disease, her manager, Doug Yeager, said.

Edward S. Rogers Jr., who transformed Canada's first FM radio station into one of North America's most diverse communications and media companies, died on Tuesday at his home in Toronto. He was 75. The death was announced by Rogers Communications, the company he founded and of which he remained chief executive. The announcement said that the death of Mr. Rogers, who was known as Ted, was related to congestive heart failure.

YOU know who they are and you fear them. Their taste is cutting edge, their judgment lacerating. They can shatter your self-esteem with a look. And you find yourself in the position of having to buy a present for them.

CONCESSIONS The United Automobile Workers union said it was willing to change its contracts with struggling automakers to help them secure $34 billion in government loans. With sales of Saturn vehicles falling, General Motors said it was ''exploring alternatives'' for the brand that once was considered a symbol of its future, which would mean selling it or relegating it to a smaller niche in the automaker's lineup. [A1.]

PRETEND you're not reading this one if you must; no one is fooled -- you've been eating way too much sugar lately. And if it makes you feel any better, everyone has at some point been romantically hung up on a person whose feelings range from ambiguous (that would be, say, when you've taken him to St. Barts) to indifferent (that would be the rest of the time). Such relationships, when not terminated by the week before Thanksgiving -- the end of the universally accepted no-penalty dump period -- almost always continue for two weeks after New Year's Eve. This means you are obligated to buy this person a present. But what sort?

The NATO secretary general, Jaap de Hoop Scheffer, on Wednesday strongly defended the alliance's decision to begin ''a conditional and graduated re-engagement'' with Moscow, saying that ''Russia is such an important factor in geopolitical terms that there is no alternative for NATO than to engage Russia.'' But Mr. de Hoop Scheffer, speaking in an interview after the end of a two-day meeting of NATO foreign ministers, said Russia's sense of grievance and encirclement, genuine or not, was difficult to assuage.

ROBBINS--Allen B.,Ph.D., age 78, died on December 2, 2008. He retired as chairman of the Department of Physics at Rutgers University and is survived by his wife Alice A. Robbins, his sister Janet Dahlberg, four daughters, three step - children, and twelve grandchildren and step-grandchildren.

Natalie Maines, the lead singer of the country music trio Dixie Chicks, and her band have been sued for defamation by the stepfather of a boy who was killed in a 1993 attack, The Associated Press reported. Terry Hobbs, the stepfather of Steve Branch, one of three 8-year-old boys who were brutally killed in West Memphis, Ark., in May 1993, filed suit against the Dixie Chicks, emphasizing Ms. Maines in the suit. In 2007, Ms. Maines attended a rally and said that the men convicted of the 1993 attack, known as the West Memphis Three, were innocent of the charges, and that evidence implicated Mr. Hobbs; a letter making similar assertions appeared on the Dixie Chicks’ Web site. Mr. Hobbs has said the charges are false, and is seeking compensatory and punitive damages.

While it’s hard to imagine that anyone could effectively imitate the sound of the rock-guitar virtuoso Joe Satriani, Mr. Satriani seems to hear more than just his influence in the music of others. Reuters reported that on Thursday, he filed a copyright infringement lawsuit against the British rock quartet Coldplay, which says that the Coldplay song “Viva La Vida” makes use of “substantial original portions” of his composition “If I Could Fly,” an instrumental track. The suit, filed in federal court in Los Angeles County, is asking for a jury trial, damages, and any profits Coldplay gained from the song. On Wednesday, “Viva La Vida” was nominated for Grammy Awards for song of the year and record of the year.

George O’Dowd, better known to listeners as Boy George, the lead singer of the 1980s-vintage pop group Culture Club, on Friday was convicted of falsely imprisoning a hired escort, The Associated Press reported. The conviction, at a court in London, stemmed from an incident on April 28, 2007, in which Mr. O’Dowd hired Audun Carlsen to come to his apartment in East London; Mr. Carlsen said that Mr. O’Dowd had handcuffed him there to a wall hook, and swung a metal chain at him. Mr. O’Dowd testified that he had restrained Mr. Carlsen, and was trying to determine if Mr. Carlsen had taken files from his computer. Mr. O’Dowd was released on bail; his sentencing is scheduled for Jan. 16.

After months of litigation, a dispute between J.K. Rowling and the author and publisher of a Harry Potter encyclopedia has magically disappeared. On Friday, Steven Jan Vander Ark, the author of “The Harry Potter Lexicon,” a reference guide to Ms. Rowling’s best-selling boy-wizard novels, said that his book would be published on Jan. 12 after amending it to a judge’s specifications, the Associated Press reported. In September, Mr. Vander Ark and his publisher, RDR Books, were ordered to halt publication of the book by a federal judge in New York who said there was “substantial similarity between the Lexicon and Rowling’s novels.” Mr. Vander Ark and RDR Books were also ordered to pay damages to Ms. Rowling and Warner Brothers; in November, they appealed this decision, but Publishers Weekly reported that they have dropped the appeal.

Ryan Kavanaugh, one of Hollywood’s most prominent film financiers, was arrested for drunk driving, speeding, and driving with a suspended license in October, while still on probation for an earlier conviction for driving under the influence of alcohol.

The Birgit Nilsson Foundation announced Friday that it would begin awarding a $1 million prize, which it is calling the largest such prize in classical music. The foundation, established by Ms. Nilsson, the Swedish soprano who died in 2005, will award the prize every two to three years to reward the outstanding achievement of a concert or opera singer, a classical music or opera conductor, or a specific production by an opera company. The foundation said that the name of the first winner had been chosen by Ms. Nilsson herself, been sealed in an envelope and would be announced early next year. For future prizes, the foundation plans to appoint a jury for a three-year term, which will make recommendations to the foundation’s board.

The planned Broadway show “Vanities, a New Musical,” originally scheduled to open on Feb. 26 at the Lyceum Theater, will be postponed until later in the season, its producers said Friday, citing the state of the economy. “Vanities” is a musical adaptation of Jack Heifner’s comedy of the same name, about three female friends whose lives are shaped by the events of the 1960s and 70s. Sue Frost, the lead producer, said in a statement that the show was being rescheduled “out of responsibility to the investors at this complicated economic time, which makes it very hard to support a new musical on Broadway.” A new opening date was not announced.

The curse of “Tristan” continues: Gary Lehman will once again sing the role of Tristan in the Metropolitan Opera’s production of “Tristan und Isolde” at Saturday afternoon’s performance, replacing Peter Seiffert, who is ill, the Met announced. Mr. Lehman replaced Mr. Seiffert on Tuesday and sang two performances of “Tristan” at the Met last season. Mr. Seiffert is still scheduled to perform the role on Dec. 12, 16, and 20.

Citing the global economic downturn, Honda announced Friday that it was pulling out of Formula One racing and selling or disbanding its team, based in Brackley, England. The move will save Honda an estimated $300 million a year, a welcome respite for a company whose November sales in the United States were down 32 percent from the same month last year.

The redoubtable Ingvild Goetz has been collecting for more than 40 years. Her private collection, housed in a Herzog & de Meuron-designed glass pavilion in Munich includes more than 3,500 works and an extensive mix of Arte Povera. Do you believe this year marks the revenge of the Europeans?I really don't understand why American collectors don't attend the fairs when the market is down. They disappear, and yet a lot of them still have money. You just don't have this at the European art fairs. When you are true collectors, you may lose money but you don't care if the art market goes up or down.

For years, we in traditional media have consoled ourselves about the increasing irrelevance of our work. First, we insist that content is king. If a story, image, film or report is compelling enough - a candid photo of Malia Obama, "Slumdog Millionaire," the columns of Maureen Dowd - it will translate into pixels. It will flourish on any platform, dominate every sport. By this logic, creators, producers, artists and journalists should attend only to producing great work and leave the current changes in the distribution and display of information to nerds in suits.

I can't decide if I'm fascinated or horrified by growing older. Some days I look in the mirror and see the gray hair and think, "distinguished." Other times I see the lines around my eyes and think, "Botox?" Photographer Cindy Sherman's latest show at Metro Pictures in New York feels similarly conflicted. Sherman has made a successful career out of photographing herself disguised as various female personae all the while exploring subjects of femininity, sexuality and power. Her new work expands on those subjects by taking on issues of beauty and aging in ways that are both funny and ghastly. Positioned against stately backgrounds, Sherman's women gaze into the camera, challenging the viewer to stare back and face his or her own mortality. The result is both lofty and frank.

Seventy-five years ago today, the 21st Amendment to the Constitution was ratified, ending Prohibition. Some restaurants and tourism agencies have organized events to observe that occasion. Less noticed, in an anonymous storefront on Frederick Douglass Boulevard, is a modern tribute to the Harlem Renaissance, an era when Prohibition spurred nightlife that was fueled by jazz and white patronage from downtown.
As the Detroit automakers teeter and plead for a bailout, many auto dealerships are quietly suffering, as my colleague Clifford Krauss recently reported.

When the latest issue of the Berlin-based art and culture magazine 032c hit our desks here at T, we were ecstatic to discover that the notoriously press-shy photographer Steven Meisel had granted a rare interview request for its "Post-America" issue. Here Victoria Camblin, 032c's assistant editor, discusses scoring a conversation with one of the most important imagemakers in fashion and why Meisel is very much still a plain old New Yorker at heart.

Earlier this week, two students from the Piet Zwart Institute in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, made headlines by releasing a plug-in for the Firefox Web browser that made it easy for people who were browsing books, music and movies on Amazon.com to download the same products free through the Pirate Bay, the illicit BitTorrent site.

I had a look last night at Lagerfeld's Paris-Moscow collection for Chanel. The ornate headpieces and dome-shaped heels (the work of the outside ateliers the house supports), along with the occasionally jarring suit proportions and Cossack trousers, brought to mind the words "bookish" and "displacement." Lagerfeld knows this particular world, its art and its culture, very well, and I love that he considered Coco Chanel's Russian alliances and as well the influences of Russian émigrés in Paris after the revolution. The coats were lovely and romantic, especially #12 on Vlada, and there was a kind of genius in the black and white embroidered evening looks, their effect like scratches on the back of a smoked mirror. Did the collection feel entirely contemporary? Or is that necessary for a special show like this? I'm interested in your thoughts.
Late next year, Microsoft will offer a free anti-virus, anti-spyware program to everyone who runs Windows (code-named Morro). And I am COMPLETELY psyched.

We have statistically significant results from our popcorn experiment, now that two marketing researchers at the Insead business school, Nailya Ordabayeva and Pierre Chandon have finished analyzing your answers. The bottom line is that Lab readers, despite their relative shrewdness (and possibly their tendency to cheat), still fell for the 3D supersizing illusion -- a problem that contributes to our tendency to overeat.

Megumi Sasaki's documentary film " Herb & Dorothy" debuts tonight at The Colony Theater in Miami as part of ABMB's "Art Loves Film" series. The movie is a sweet tale about Herbert and Dorothy Vogel, a postal worker and a librarian, respectively, who amassed one of the most important contemporary art collections to date on a modest budget. (An excerpt from the film is above.) Here, The Moment caught up with Dorothy Vogel about the fluctuating art economy, dealer camaraderie, and advice for collecting in today's market.

This downsized holiday season brings plenty of rationales to have a drink. But one of the most important reasons to clink your glass is also one of the least celebrated. Today marks Repeal Day - a national holiday celebrating the end of Prohibition - a day of remembrance and, perhaps more urgently, a duty to get three sheets to the wind. While you won't find Repeal Day on the December 5 slot of your week-at-a-glance calendar, few would argue with the sobering importance of such an historic occasion. Seventy-five years ago on this very date, the 18th Amendment, the Volstead Act, was repealed, forever ending the crime against spirits.

Avery has already served two games of the ban.

The Windsor Spitfires have closed the book on the storied Windsor Arena, posting a 2-1 victory over the Guelph Storm on Thursday night. The Spitfires will move into the Windsor Family Credit Center next week. The Windsor Arena, which was built in 1924, was the oldest in the Ontario Hockey League. A full report on the final night in what fans have called the Barn is here. And here is a link to a gallery of photographs taken by The Windsor Star on closing night. Back when it was introduced in 1999, the Blue card from American Express was marketed as the first credit card specifically meant to be used on the Internet. It came with a microprocessor chip embedded in the plastic, as well as a smart-card reader that people could plug into their computers for making secure Internet transactions. Not too many people had heard of smart-card readers back then, but a lot of people did like the card's futuristic look - translucent plastic - and the fact that it charged no annual fee.

Last year, my co-op charged a $1 per share fuel surcharge from November through April. At the time, fuel costs were increasing rapidly. Two weeks ago, I received a notice stating that "due to the continued increase in the cost of fuel," the fuel surcharge is being repeated from December to next April at $1.25 per share. According to the latest reports, fuel is at its lowest cost in months. Is this something I can challenge?

Yesterday I asked readers to guess what this dish is -- I wouldn't have known myself, except I cooked it. Arame (seaweed), unreconstituted (that is, dried and not rehydrated), cooked in sesame oil, with a few drops of soy. Not bad. But man, would I love to have a library of good seaweed recipes. They're few and far between, but I (and many others) love the flavor of the stuff.

Last year, two B.U. employees tried to find the exact dividing line between Terrier and Eagle fans. Here's what they came up with.

The news on Monday that the country is officially in a recession, and has been since last December, probably did not come as a surprise to many people. But then, solid economic data take some time to track and compile. Sometime, if you want less specific data sooner, it can be found in less exalted places -- like the bankruptcy law section of the phone book, or in an advertisement on the subway. Local and national bankruptcy statistics are released periodically, of course, and those all indicate that the number of people filing for protection from their creditors has been increasing as the economy swoons.

In a season that's usually long on tradition, the new Holiday edition of T is instead all about fresh starts. Beginning with our cover stars, the Hollywood power couple Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes -- the magazine's print edition has two different covers, half featuring Cruise and half Holmes, both shot by Solve Sundsbo -- it's a riot of redux, from a head-tripping essay on great moments in reinvention (from Jesus to J.F.K.) to articles on the new and improved Princess Gloria von Thurn und Taxis, the ever-changing homes of Karl Lagerfeld, a resort town in Kenya that's gone all dolce vita and dinner with the design remasterer Martino Gamper. Our Originals portfolio spotlights the cultural creatives of Japan, the most innovation-obsessed country on the planet, while the photographer Camilla Akrans chimes in with a new spin on Carmen Miranda, and Erwan Frotin thoroughly retools T's annual gift guide. Now that's change we can believe in.

Jimmy Carter is by far the best ex-president the United States has ever had, and he underscored that again this morning by announcing that Guinea Worm cases have reached an all-time low. For those of you who have never heard of it, Guinea Worm is one of the worst parasites you can get. The worms burrow inside of you, grow to almost three feet long, are incredibly painful, and finally pop out of the skin and have to be reeled out, inch by inch, over many days. They are an ancient affliction in tropical countries, but Carter has led an effort to eradicate them.

Restaurants make such a show of rack of lamb that many people assume there's some trick to cooking it. But all you have to do is trim the excess fat and roast at high heat. Really good lamb needs no more than salt and pepper.

The other night at the Gotham Indepedent Film Awards, the folks involved in "The Wrestler" could not say enough terrible things about a profile of Mickey Rourke that appeared in The New York Times magazine last weekend. Darren Aronofsky, the director of "The Wrestler," was clearly worked up about the piece, written by Pat Jordan, suggesting two things: One, Mr. Rourke's excesses are well-documented and he is easy pickings for a hit job. And two, that the magazine did not do its job in fully reporting out and fact checking disputes over Mr. Rourke's upbringing. The magazine effectively suggested that Mr. Rourke's version of his own history was a fantasy.

It's finally time to start analyzing the fantasy football experts -- I hope you are all as excited about this as I am. Last winter I presented the initial phase of my results about the accuracy of 2007 preseason rankings from fantasy football sites here on the Fifth Down. This year I have joined forces with the Fantasy Sports Trade Association (F.S.T.A.) to run a good old fashioned contest to see which site wins the accuracy award for 2008. I've changed a few things this time around; primarily, I am now analyzing sites based on positional rankings, not overall rankings as I did in the past. This should make the analysis more targeted and hopefully more valuable for fantasy footballers.

An obituary by The Associated Press on Nov. 29 about the astrophysicist Edwin E. Salpeter of Cornell incorrectly described the Salpeter-Bethe equation, which was derived by Mr. Salpeter and his Cornell colleague Hans Bethe in 1951. It describes bound states of a pair of interacting particles in quantum field theory, not how helium nuclei fuse to produce carbon. That reaction, also discovered by Professor Salpeter in 1951, is called the Salpeter process.

A picture caption last Friday with a film review of “Antarctica,” using information provided by the film’s distributor, misidentified the actor shown with Dana Ruttenberg and Yiftach Mizrahi. He is Ofer Regirer, not Guy Zo-Aretz, another actor in the movie.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about competing pressures facing the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission referred imprecisely to the razing of Ward’s Bakery in Brooklyn, which the commission’s staff decided was ineligible for a public hearing on landmark status. The developer Forest City Ratner began demolition in September 2007 and has almost completed it; the bakery was not torn down last year.

A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about Lance Armstrong’s plans for the 2009 Tour de France, using information provided by Agence France-Presse — Getty Images, misidentified the cyclist shown with him. Although it was a fellow rider on Team Astana, it was not Alberto Contador, the 2007 Tour winner. (The Times has been unable to identify the cyclist.).

An article on Thursday about the effect of a global slowdown on outsourcing companies in India misstated the buyer of the British consulting firm Axon Consulting. Axon was purchased by the Indian technology outsourcing firm HCL Technologies, not its rival Infosys.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about an offer by UnitedHealth Group to guarantee to some customers the right to buy an individual health policy in the future regardless of their health status incorrectly included New Jersey and New York, in some copies, among the states in which the offer is available or could be made available. Because UnitedHealth does not sell individual policies in either state, it will not make the offer.

The Big City column on Nov. 24, about Jeff Stark, who publishes an e-mail newsletter listing unusual weekend events in New York, misspelled the surname of two tap-dancing sisters included in a recent listing. They are the Minsky Sisters, not Minsk.

A major disarmament conference concluded in Oslo on Thursday with 94 countries having signed a treaty that commits them never to use, produce, sell or stockpile cluster bombs, whose remnants have been known to explode months or years after conflicts have ended. Several major powers, including the United States, refused to sign, but Britain, France, Germany and most other NATO members did, as did Afghanistan, in what observers said was a surprise show of independence from the United States. Conference organizers said several additional countries were expected to join the list in the near future at the United Nations.

The Big City column in some editions on Monday, about the dedication of an AIDS memorial in Hudson River Park, misstated part of the verse inscribed in a granite bench that is the memorial’s centerpiece. It says, “I can sail without wind; I can row without oars”; not “I can sail without wind, I can sail without oars.”.

A bankruptcy trustee reopened a kosher meat plant in Iowa on Wednesday in a move intended to comfort a town that has been economically crippled since 389 illegal immigrants were arrested at the plant in May.

An article on Nov. 19 about non-Chinese mummies discovered in the Tarim Basin of China’s Xinjiang Uighur Autonomous Region misstated the dynasty that ruled China from the early 7th century to the early 10th century, part of the period reflected in the discovery of Chinese grave sites at a Xinjiang location called Astana. It was the Tang, not the Han.

To the Editor: Gary Andrew Poole’s article about his family’s slide shows (“A Couple of Beers and 140 Views of Yellowstone,” Rituals, Nov. 21) forced me to extract our ancient Viewlex projector from its distant shelf and plan an evening of entertainment for some unsuspecting neighbors. My Philadelphia childhood in the 1940s had many such evenings, not as exotic in content, perhaps, as Mr. Poole’s trips to Yellowstone, but plenty of the Jersey Shore. In fact, my parents so enjoyed seeing their slides that they finally just left the screen and projector up and ready. One Thanksgiving weekend, my mother asked guests to bring along 25 slides that they were thankful they’d taken. It was a long evening, but it was rich with variety, and there was a lot of applause.

BéLA FLECK & THE FLECKTONES: 'JINGLE ALL THE WAY' (Rounder) Growling Tuvan throat singing takes over ''Jingle Bells.'' ''Silent Night'' becomes modal jazz with abstruse harmonies. ''The 12 Days of Christmas'' zigzags through a maze of meter shifts and key changes (perhaps ''The 12 Tones of Christmas''?). And Tchaikovsky's ''Dance of the Sugar Plum Fairies'' pings its melody in harmonics from Béla Fleck's banjo. Those are just four of the virtuosic transformations Mr. Fleck and his band come up with on an album that applies all sorts of musicianly gamesmanship to Christmas songs (and one Hanukkah tune) that can sometimes take an aural squint to recognize. Bluegrass and jazz are the Flecktones' foundations, as can be heard in their nimble version of ''Sleigh Ride.'' But the song choices are eclectic -- Bach, klezmer, Joni Mitchell, ''Linus and Lucy'' from ''A Charlie Brown Christmas'' -- and the arrangements even more so. Give these musicians a musical parameter and they'll toy with it. JON PARELES
CARLOS CRUZ-DIEZ (In)formed by Color

HASSOL--Milton D.,Ph.D., 78, of New York City and Sherman, CT died on December 1, of lymphoma. Adored father of Jeremy Cass Hassol. Beloved brother of Rita Lowenthal of Pembroke Pines, FL. Caring uncle of Richard Lowenthal of Austin, Texas and and Mark Lowenthal of Berlin, Germany. Dedicated scholar, inspirational teacher, compassionate therapist, loyal friend. Dr. Hassol was retired as Chairman of the Department of Philosophy at CW Post Campus of Long Island University, where he had been on the faculty since 1967. He received his Ph.D. in philosophy from Columbia University in 1966 and taught there from 1960 to 1967. In 1973 he received a Post Doctoral Certificate in Psychotherapy and Psychoanalysis from NYU and had practiced until recently. He was a member of the NYU Psychoanalytic Association. His great passion was the study of ethics and morality and its relevance for psychiatry. Since 1985, Dr. Hassol served as President of the Board of the Neustadt Collection of Tiffany Glass, a New York nonprofit organization with a world-renowned collection of Tiffany lamps and glass. Contributions may be made to the Neustadt Collection of Tiffany Glass. A memorial service will be held on December 19, 2008 at 1pm at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, NYC.

'THIS WARM DECEMBER: A BRUSHFIRE HOLIDAY VOL. 1' (Brushfire) Is dissident Christmas music a possibility? Jack Johnson, the surfer turned beach bard who runs the mild-mannered rock label Brushfire and is its marquee act, would like to think so. Here he covers Stevie Wonder's ''Someday at Christmas,'' a somber lament as relevant today as it was in 1967. The rest of this homogenous collection, though, all recorded on four-track machines by artists on Mr. Johnson's label, doesn't muster an ounce of that song's frisson. (Money Mark's cheeky ''Stuck at the Airport'' is a musical, if not thematic, exception.) ''We're finally all together/Feeling fine/Wearing reindeer sweaters,'' ALO's Zach Gill sings on ''Christmas Time''. It's the sound of a band of hippies shruggingly giving in to corporate sentiment. JON CARAMANICA
NIKKI S. LEE Sikkema Jenkins & Company
ART Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

JULIAN KOSTER: 'THE SINGING SAW AT CHRISTMASTIME' (Merge) The whistling, wobbling, sustained tones of bowed musical saws are just about the only sounds on this album by Julian Koster, who was a member of Neutral Milk Hotel before leading his own band, the Music Tapes, both associated with the whimsically experimental Elephant 6 collective. A saw or two play familiar melodies, in harmony or austere two-part counterpoint, to eerie effect. They suggest a forsaken alien creature clinging to a somehow comforting melody, knowing that Santa isn't ever coming to town. JON PARELES

FOR CHILDREN 'THE BEST OF CHRISTMAS REVELS' (Saturday) This is actually an annual celebration of the winter solstice, and in this benefit the performers will offer songs, dances and stories from a variety of cultures. In a preshow workshop children will make animal masks and learn the English song ''There Was a Pig Went Out to Dig.'' If they attend the 3 p.m. performance, they can join the resident children's chorus onstage in the song. Workshop at 1 p.m.; shows at 3 and 8 p.m., Church of the Holy Apostles, 296 Ninth Avenue, at 28th Street, Chelsea, (718) 399-9282, nyrevels.org; workshop, $15; shows, $35.

HASSOL--Milton D. The Board of Directors of the Neustadt Collection of Tiffany Glass mourns the death of its respected President, Milton D. Hassol, who served for 23 years with passion and a deep commitment to the mission of the organization. We will miss his wise counsel, warmth, and humor. As the first president of the museum, Dr. Hassol was instrumental in establishing a vision for the collection, which included an institutional partnership with the Queens Museum of Art, the expansion of the Collection's professional staff and the development of traveling exhibitions. Donations in his memory may be made to the Neustadt Collection of Tiffany Glass. The Board of Directors, Neustadt Collection of Tiffany Glass
Muslims climbed Mount Noor in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, on Thursday during the annual pilgrimage, or hajj. The Prophet Muhammad is said to have received the first words of the Koran there.

Spain and Portugal have a history of fervent Catholicism, but almost a third of the population now turns out to have a non-Christian genetic heritage. Some 20 percent of the present population of the Iberian peninsula has Sephardic Jewish ancestry, and 11 percent bear Moorish DNA signatures, a team of geneticists reports. The genetic signatures reflect the forced conversions to Christianity in the 14th and 15th centuries after Christian armies wrested Spain back from Muslim control.

THE FLESHTONES: 'STOCKING STUFFER' (Yep Roc) Stomping and shouting are what the Fleshtones have been doing since 1976 as prime movers in keeping garage rock alive. Their album of Christmas songs is rowdy and retro, mixing their own songs with novelty oldies and looking past the mid-1960s all the way to '50s styles like rockabilly. In the Fleshtones' own songs ''super rock Santa makes the scene,'' but these rockers aren't infidels; there's piety behind the backbeat in songs like Peter Zaremba's ''I Still Believe in Christmas,'' on which he belts, ''Take a moment to recall the birth that's reason for it all/Now can't we use a little peace on Earth?'' JON PARELES

'JIM JONES & SKULL GANG PRESENT A TRIBUTE TO BAD SANTA STARRING MIKE EPPS' (Koch) Two years ago the Harlem rapper Jim Jones (with assorted hangers-on) released his first holiday album, the surprisingly charming ''Dipset Xmas''; changing times have demanded a follow-up. ''Recession is here, and the gifts cost cheddar,'' Mr. Jones raps on this new album -- finally, a topical Christmas song. For Mr. Jones and his crew -- Juelz Santana, Tom Gist, Noe and others -- Dec. 25 is just another day when the have-nots struggle to have. And so Christmas becomes a fulcrum on which to hinge lighthearted, occasionally clever rhymes about what it might take (robbery, drug dealing) to ensure that loved ones get the au courant gifts (Nintendo Wii, True Religion jeans) they want. ''We dreaming of a white Christmas,'' Mr. Jones raps, about a powder that isn't snow. ''Serving the fiends through the night shift.'' JON CARAMANICA

ELVIS PRESLEY: 'CHRISTMAS DUETS' (RCA Nashville/Sony BMG) 'SOUNDS OF THE SEASON: THE NAT KING COLE HOLIDAY COLLECTION' (NBC/EMI Music Special Markets, available exclusively at Target) The success of posthumous duets is often indirectly correlated to the respect with which the dearly departed is treated: the higher the pedestal, the less convincing the result. Wisely, the female country stars on ''Christmas Duets'' try to match Elvis Presley's mood, whether it's Carrie Underwood's tenderness on ''I'll Be Home for Christmas'' or Wynonna Judd's brawn on ''Santa Claus Is Back in Town.'' On a wild eight-minute ''Merry Christmas Baby,'' Gretchen Wilson saunters up to the song, full of attitude, before giving in; it sounds as if she's flirting with Mr. Presley just across the bar. Trying to get that close to Nat King Cole, though, may be a fool's errand. On this collection his brief vocal snippets are treated like museum pieces. Of Cole's partners, only his daughter Natalie, on ''The Christmas Song,'' and Shelby Lynne, on a lingering ''Silent Night,'' don't sound as if they're harmonizing with a specter they can't quite hear. JON CARAMANICA

THE FLAMING LIPS: 'CHRISTMAS ON MARS' (Warner Brothers)''Are you on something?'' one spaceman asks another in this new B-movie odyssey by the Flaming Lips. The answer to that question bears relevance to anyone plugging into ''Christmas on Mars,'' in either DVD or soundtrack form. An intently weird fantasia of resonant drones, ominous chimes and many yards of duct tape, it features Wayne Coyne, the band's ringleader, as a mute but omniscient presence. (He neither speaks nor sings, except in the DVD's behind-the-scenes featurette.) As for the Christmas connection: there's a Santa suit, a baby, a pair of elf shoes, and plenty of tinsel and blinking lights. NATE CHINEN

TONY BENNETT FEATURING THE COUNT BASIE BIG BAND: 'A SWINGIN' CHRISTMAS' (RPM/Columbia) Tony Bennett last released a holiday album, his classic ''Snowfall,'' 40 years ago. By most measures, then, a sequel was overdue. For ''A Swingin' Christmas'' he enlisted the Basie band and tackled some appropriate songs, half of which also appear on the earlier album. Of course Mr. Bennett is a different singer now -- more avuncular, more casual -- and his genius lies in his phrasing. He and the band recorded live on a concert stage, and it shows: their ''Silver Bells'' feels too loosely urbane to be a studio product. So, yes, this is Tony at his twinkling present-day best. A classic? Check back in 2048. NATE CHINEN

'THE HOTEL CAFé PRESENTS WINTER SONGS' (Epic) This album of women singing for the holidays includes a handful of new songs, mostly forlorn rather than festive. Sara Bareilles and Ingrid Michaelson harmonize over piano and cellos on ''Winter Song,'' dubiously asking the question ''Is love alive?'' A cello returns as Brandi Carlile contemplates a holiday-season breakup on ''The Heartache Can Wait,'' while Lenka smiles through ''All My Bells Are Ringing,'' a deceptively perky girl-group-flavored song about loneliness. Colbie Caillat grows tearful seeing ''Mistletoe,'' while Meiko whisper-boasts about breaking hearts -- ''I've been a bad, a bad girl'' -- in ''Maybe Next Year (X-Mas Song).'' K T Tunstall and Alice Smith go cheerfully sultry on ''Sleigh Ride'' and ''Silver Bells''; Fiona Apple gives ''Frosty the Snowman'' a nicely incongruous anxious quaver; and Priscilla Ahn breaks ''Silent Night'' into brief, pretty, almost abstract phrases of a cappella vocal harmony. JON PARELES

As recession tightens its grip, the holiday season threatens to be less festive than usual. Consciously or not, much of this year's new holiday music expresses some anxiety about whether the old modes of merriment still matter. Dismantle old standards? Create new ones? Even bother celebrating at all? Here, notable holiday albums -- Christmas, mostly, with a little Hanukkah thrown in -- are reviewed by the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times. 'ALL WRAPPED UP' (Hollywood, available exclusively at Target) Any fears that Miley Cyrus is growing up too quickly should be allayed by her version of ''Santa Claus Is Comin' to Town,'' which reveals her to be, appropriately, a bratty, possibly impudent teenager. This EP features artists signed to the Hollywood label, which includes the Disney stable: on ''Joyful Kings'' (a medley of ''Joy to the World'' and ''We Three Kings''), Joe Jonas of the Jonas Brothers sings as if he's petulantly recoiling from good will, and Demi Lovato displays taste by covering, with sass, Paul McCartney's ''Wonderful Christmastime.'' The label's non-Mickey signees need to find a way to distinguish themselves, which might explain Jordan Pruitt's soft R&B groove ''Celebrate Love,'' on which she breathily gives orders: ''Light up the candles/Dim all the lights/Now let the magic begin.'' Hey, wait a minute. ''Everyone's singing a carol/Or saying a prayer.'' Oh, that kind of magic. JON CARAMANICA

'WE WISH YOU A METAL XMAS AND A HEADBANGING NEW YEAR' (Armoury) In his introduction to ''Santa Claus Is Coming to Town,'' Alice Cooper spells Santa's name C-l-a-w-s. That's the tone of this album, which sets holiday tunes to various kinds of peacockish '70s and '80s metal, and is consequently hilarious. Singers include Lemmy Kilmister of Motörhead, Ronnie James Dio (whose wife, Wendy, is the album's producer) and Stephen Pearcy of Ratt; guitarists include John 5, Billy Gibbons of ZZ Top and the mighty Tony Iommi. Everyone appears to be having a good time, though possibly on different days, or in different studios via digital uplink. BEN RATLIFF

SCHECHTER--Jerry, 90, of Brookline, formerly of the Bronx and Croton-on-Hudson, December 2 of illness. DeWitt Clinton High School graduate, garment worker, union activist, Amalgamated ''Cooperator,'' Workmen's Circle Member, sculptor, working class hero. No flowers. Contributions to National Yiddish Book Center. Memorial Service January.
FREUND--Lucas Samuel. To dream is to be dreamed is to be part of a dreaming. Mommy and Charlotte
O'NEIL--Ralph. The Trustees of Freedom Institute express profound sorrow at the death of our friend and supporter Ralph N. O'Neil. We express our deepest sympathy to his wonderful family.
INTERNATIONAL IRAQ COUNCIL APPROVES U.S. PACT

BRIAN MCKNIGHT: 'I'LL BE HOME FOR CHRISTMAS' (Razor & Tie) The romantic R&B singer Brian McKnight hasn't dimmed a bit. He keeps minute pitch control over every detail and passing note, summoning Marvin Gaye, Nat King Cole and Donny Hathaway as he steps up to the most gold-plated of holiday pop songs: ''The Christmas Song,'' ''Let It Snow,'' etc. There are a few trick moves: a country duet with Vince Gill, an orchestral ''Adeste Fideles'' and help from Take 6 on ''Bless This House,'' sung a cappella in broadened harmony. BEN RATLIFF

ENGELBERG--Gusti, 98, of Atlantic City, NJ. Beloved mother of Alfred (Gail) Engelberg and Edith Kramer; beloved grandmother of Michael (Suzanne) Kramer and Debra (Steven) Blum; beloved great-grandmother of Harris, Jenna, Annie, Sam and Chi Chi. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, December 7th, 11am, at Congregation Beth Israel, Northfield, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Gusti's memory may be made to Congregation Beth Israel, 2501 Shore Road, Northfield, NJ 08225. Roth - Goldsteins Memorial Chapel, Atlantic City, New Jersey.

BERMAN--Ralph. Born May 6, 1916, died peacefully on Monday, December 1, 2008. Preceded by his wife Bertha, survived by his three loving daughters, Barbara, Heller and Teena. Devoted fatherin-law to Paul, Owen and Joshua, dear grandfather to Alex and Peter, loving brother to William and brother-inlaw to Rita. Ralph's family will be receiving condolence visits at his apartment from 2-7pm on Sunday, December 7. Contributions in Ralph's memory may be made to your favorite charity.

FRIEDMAN--Daniel J. The Abrams, Gorelick, Friedman & Jacobson, P.C. family sadly notes the untimely passing of our founding partner, Daniel J. Friedman. Dan was an extraordinary insurance attorney who began his law career at the Kings County District Attorney's office, where he excelled at prosecuting arson and other financial crimes. He joined Abrams & Martin, P.C., our predecessor firm, and immediately excelled in defending Lloyd's Underwriters and domestic insurance companies in Federal and State Court litigations. Over the course of his 32 year legal career, Dan's skill and professionalism earned him the respect of his clients and adversaries, one of whom wrote ''A Hole in the Wall'', a novel that detailed a litigation involving a fraudulent insurance claim. The insurer's attorney was fashioned after Dan. Dan exemplified what a ''partner'' in law firm should be -he was a wise counselor, mentor and teacher. His work ethic and dedication to our firm, the law and his clients is revealed in the exhausting schedule he maintained despite his illness, culminating a few weeks ago in an oral argument before the New York Court of Appeals. We extend our love and prayers to Dan's loving wife, Lenni; his children, Holly, Michelle and Robert; sonin-law Danny; grandchildren Ryan and Chelsea who gave him unbounded joy; and brother Richard. Michael E. Gorelick, Glenn A. Jacobson and the Abrams, Gorelick, Friedman & Jacobson, P.C. family.
This young cellist, accompanied by the pianist Inon Barnatan, offers a program that includes works by Beethoven, Kodaly and Chopin on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall.

SHERYL CROW: 'HOME FOR CHRISTMAS' (Hallmark) Although it was recorded in California, ''Home for Christmas'' looks toward Ms. Crow's current home state, Tennessee, for a strong tinge of Memphis soul. Booker T. Jones, the organist who led the Stax studio band Booker T. & the MG's, sits in, and many of the songs have a soul-style horn section nudging Ms. Crow's voice along. It's an album of cozy versions of familiar material; she doesn't sound all that blue on ''Blue Christmas.'' But the tone is right for a new song by Ms. Crow: the hymnlike ''There Is a Star That Shines Tonight,'' which neatly mingles the personal and the political. JON PARELES
This new production of Martha Clarke's 1984 dance drama is at Minetta Lane Theater.

THE BOXMASTERS: 'CHRISTMAS CHEER' (Vanguard) It's not quite the ''Bad Santa'' of the Christmas-album genre, but the Boxmasters -- the alt-country trio led by the actor Billy Bob Thornton, who sings and plays drums -- are wishing you a sneery Christmas. Among the obligatory holiday standards, original tunes like ''Slower Than Christmas'' (''Mama with her wreath/Daddy with his wrath/Granny eating with no teeth/And my sister's mangy cats'') might amuse the Grinch, if the Grinch were really into Buck Owens and early Johnny Cash. BEN RATLIFF

Representatives for Texas Tech Coach Mike Leach have contacted the search firm that Washington is using to hire a coach to inform it that he was no longer interested in the Huskies' head coaching job, according to a person with direct knowledge of the search who spoke on condition of anonymity because no coach has been hired. Leach joins Fresno State Coach Pat Hill as coaches who have interviewed for the Washington job and then pulled out of consideration. There had been multiple news media reports that Leach was on his way back to Washington for a second interview.
FREUND--Lucas Samuel 12/81-6/27/97 HAPPY BIRTHDAY Love Ya, Gran Arlene & Gramps Joel

FRANCHINI--Angela M.,noted lingerie designer residing in New York City passed away at age 92 at her sister's residence in Jersey City. She was born in Jersey City, NJ on October 10, 1916, the daughter of the late Achille and Jennie Franchini. She graduated from Dickinson High School and went on to attend the Traphagen School of Design in New York and the Fashion Institute in New York City. She belonged to the Under Fashion Club and taught classes in Numerology. Her career spanned 40 years of creativity, success and enjoyment. Angela was a woman of many talents. Some of her summers were spent attending the Art Institute at San Miguel Allende in Mexico working and creating Metal Sculptures. Her other vacations were exciting adventures that took her around the world to out of the way places which she enjoyed filming and recording. Her survivors include a brother Achille Franchini on Ridgefield Park, NJ, a sister Rose Franchini of Jersey City and the late Josephine Allbach of Bradford, MA. Her nieces and nephews include Douglas and Debra Allbach, their daughters Amy Samford, Audrey Kershen and three greatgreat-nephews: Jace, Martin and Jack all of Texas. Ronald and Karen Allbach and son Alex residing in Massachusetts. Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Franchini and son Leonardo residing in Damariscotta, Maine. Visitation on Saturday, December 6 from 810:30am at the McLaughlin Funeral Home, 625 Pavonia Ave., Jersey City. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, December 6 at 11am at St. Aedan's R.C. Church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, North Arlington, NJ.

'VERVE REMIXED CHRISTMAS' (Verve) Continuing Verve's ''Remixed'' series, a number of producers have souped up the label's back-catalog Christmas-themed jazz (Louis Armstrong, Ella Fitzgerald, Shirley Horn) into ambient, trip-hoppy cocktail accessories. It's decent fun, especially when the effect isn't the usual faux-sonic luxury: the band Brazilian Girls pares back Dinah Washington's ''Silent Night'' to the words ''Silent night, holy night,'' and loops it over a rocking samba rhythm. BEN RATLIFF

ARETHA FRANKLIN: 'THIS CHRISTMAS' (DMI) Aretha Franklin sings up a storm here, swooping and exhorting, teasing and preaching, yowling and scatting -- not least when she battles herself in ''My Grown-Up Christmas List.'' But too often she's weighed down with reverence, string sections, operatic affectations and sodden medium tempos. Glimpses of her down-home side -- especially on a gospelly performance of ''The Lord Will Make a Way'' -- hint at what the album might have been. JON PARELES

This solar-powered house is on two acres with pine trees and views of the surrounding 14,000-foot peaks. With log-beamed ceilings, the house totals 4,578 square feet and includes three bathrooms and a possible one-bedroom apartment on the lower level. Agent: Gayle Anne Dudley, Pinon Real Estate Group; 719-221-0651; www.pinonrealestate-salida.com.

As part of an effort to retire her still sizable campaign debt, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is peddling a chance for supporters to see her onstage along with Bill Clinton and a celebrity host, America Ferrera, of ''Ugly Betty'' fame. The unusual event, billed as ''A Conversation With Senator Hillary Clinton,'' where she will field questions from the audience, is scheduled for Dec. 15 at Manhattan Center Studios in New York. Ticket prices range from $50 for general admission to $1,000 for a V.I.P. seat and a backstage photo with Mrs. Clinton.

Jets defensive end Shaun Ellis was charged last weekend in New Jersey with marijuana possession, speeding and driving without insurance. Ellis, the team's sack leader, defensive captain and longest-tenured player, will play Sunday at San Francisco, according to a team spokesman. The incident, first reported Thursday by The Daily Record, occurred near Jets headquarters in Florham Park at 8:37 a.m. last Saturday. Ellis was pulled over after he allegedly passed a police car at high speed on Route 287 South while exiting onto Route 24.

HOLCOMB--Alfonso, Sr.,76 passed away on November 30, 2008 after a brief acute illness. Beloved father of Al DeWitt Jr., and Alvin Dennis, cherished grand and greatgrandfather of Alfonso, Alexis, Alan, Alex, Maison. Al joins his deceased wife Gloria who passed away on November 8, 2008. We love you.
MOVIES Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, showtimes and tickets: nytimes.com/movies.

ERRAN BARON COHEN: 'SONGS IN THE KEY OF HANUKKAH' (New Line) There is significantly less leg-pulling in the work of Erran Baron Cohen than in the work of his brother Sacha, creator of Ali G, Borat, Bruno and other characters who dismantle pieties for kicks. Erran scored the ''Borat'' movie and contributed music to ''Da Ali G Show,'' but his own work, with the group Zohar, tends toward ambient lounge music infused with Middle East signifiers. Similarly, this Hanukkah set is weighed down by earnestness. Both the originals and the reinterpreted classics swap holiday clichés for musical ones: light reggae (''Spin It Up''), coffeehouse folk (''Look to the Light''). And the clunky rapping by Y-Love on ''My Hanukkah (Keep the Fire Alive)'' suggests that some traditions might be better left untouched, or at least touched differently. JON CARAMANICA

FRANKEL--Lars Eric. The members of the NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases Department of Orthopaedic Surgery mourn the untimely passing of Lars Eric Frankel of Seattle, WA. He was the dear son of our colleague and former Chairman and Surgeonin-Chief, Dr. Victor H. Frankel and his wife Ruth. Lars, born in Sweden, will fondly be remembered by his family as resembling a handsome Viking, as well as a very kind man who was a loving favorite of his nieces and nephews. He leaves a grieving family and many friends. We mourn his passing as we celebrate his life and extend our heartfelt condolences, at this difficult time, to his parents, his brothers Victor, Jr., Carl and Paul, to his sister Dana and to the entire family. Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D., Chairman William Jaffe, M.D., Vice Chairman

With at least 1.5 million people expected to crowd Washington for Barack Obama's swearing-in at the Capitol, his inaugural committee announced Thursday that the entire Mall would be opened to spectators. In the past, parts of the Mall have been used as a staging ground for the inaugural parade. But on Jan. 20, the entire area, from the Capitol to the Lincoln Memorial, will be open to the public, and the ceremony will be shown on big screens. (Even most of the 240,000 people with tickets to observe the proceedings on the Capitol grounds will have to watch the swearing-in on a screen.)
IRVING NORMAN Michael Rosenfeld

RUBENSTEIN--Sophia ''Sunny'', passed away December 2, 2008. Born in 1913 in New York City. Beloved mother of Barbara Spiegel, NY actress/teacher. Daughter to cherished Lena and William Weinstein, Russian emigres whose love of education resulted in Sophia and her sister Ann Irene Todd's receiving Master's Degrees in Music from N.Y.U. To help pay for college during the Depression she sang and played the Alto Sax with her sister on piano in all girls band 'Sunny Winston and her Rhythm Queens'. After the birth of her only child, Barbara she became a N.Y.C. school teacher in Harlem and ending in Queens. A fifty year resident of Forest Hills and Hollywood, FL with her second husband Charles Rubenstein, past president of the National Showman's Association and owner of NYC arcades. He was the father of deceased commercial agent Bernard Rubenstein. Always a lover of dressing, dancing and laughter, after her retirement from the Board of Education, she began a third career in film. She studied acting with Stella Adler and Gene Frankel. Simultaneously, she achieved success in the bonds and real estate markets. One of a kind, her beauty, humor and strength were apparent to everyone she encountered. She spent her last years residing next door to her adoring daughter. Services Sunday, December 7, 2008. 11:15am at ''The Riverside'' Amsterdam Ave. at 76th St.
ZEITLIN--Richard Henry, 1945-2008. My beloved son, my teacher, my friend, his loss is unsurmountable.

MARY CHAPIN CARPENTER: 'COME DARKNESS, COME LIGHT' (Zoë) Mary Chapin Carpenter takes the road less traveled on this nourishing album, her first Christmas release. Singing in a confidential tone and with minimal accompaniment -- acoustic piano, fingerpicked guitars -- she strikes a chord of sober rumination and reassurance. The material makes the difference: half of these 12 folk hymns bear Ms. Carpenter's songwriting credit, and none countenance a whiff of empty cheer. ''We press our faces to the glass,'' Ms. Carpenter sings softly in one, ''And see our little lives go past/Wave to shadows that we cast/On the longest night of the year.'' NATE CHINEN

NOLAN--Susan Avery, December 1, 2008. Loving mother of Donald and Christopher, grandmother of Szasha, Gwyndolyn and Nochella, wife of Donald, mother in spirit to many. Her vitality, warmth and generosity will be greatly missed. The family will receive visitors 3-7pm on December 5 at the NY Society for Ethical Culture.

BERNSTEIN--Joseph, 86. Retail consultant for many years. Survived by wife of 55 years Joyce and his son Jeb. Services will be held at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Ave. at 70th St., Friday December 5 at 12pm. Donations can be made to Juvenile Diabetes Association.
PUNISHER War Zone

LEDISI: 'IT'S CHRISTMAS' (Verve Forecast) Ledisi's voice leaps and glides all over the songs on ''It's Christmas,'' which is named after one of the four songs on the album she helped write. She's an earth-mother singer along the lines of Dianne Reeves, savoring all that her voice can do as she enthusiastically straddles R&B and jazz. She has Keb' Mo' sitting in on ''Please Come Home for Christmas,'' and she sustains ''Silent Night'' in a wide-open improvisational space over bustling drums and a leisurely bass vamp. Ledisi sounds happiest singing about Christmas as a time for reunions: ''I've got a present that you can't put under a tree,'' she sings with frisky promise. JON PARELES

Helen Suzman, 91, an iconic figure of the anti-apartheid movement, has joined a growing list of well-known South Africans asking for a new inquiry into the so-called ''arms deal'' transactions from a decade ago, according to Thursday's issue of the newspaper The Star. The Nobel laureates Archbishop Desmond Tutu and former President F. W. de Klerk are among those requesting further investigation into the complicated, multibillion-dollar transactions for submarines, frigates and jet fighters completed in the late 1990s. Accusations about kickbacks have since dogged members of the ruling African National Congress, including its current president, Jacob Zuma. The A.N.C. has repeatedly insisted that the deals have been adequately investigated.

KANN--Walter, 85, of New Canaan, CT, and Palm Beach Gardens, FL, on December 1st, 2008. Loving husband of Maryann, devoted father of Michael and Jacqueline, and grandchildren, Sebastian, Claudia, Samantha and Benjamin. He is also survived by his sister Ruth Arieli, and cousins here and in Israel. Emigrating from Germany in June of 1938, he served in the U.S. Army during WWII. After completing courses at Camp Ritchie he served as an MI interrogator in Germany and was honorably discharged as a Tech Sgt. 316th, HQ Intelligence Army Detachment in 1946. Walter graduated Phi Beta Kappa from CCNY in 1948. He thereafter began a dynamic 60-year career in commodity trading, longserving as a high level executive and board member at Philipp Brothers, NY, and its successor companies for 38 years, living in Tokyo heading up Phibro's Japanese operations from 1953 through 1956. In 1985 he helped found Newco AG, Switzerland, serving as chairman through 1999. He remained active in business until his death. He was known and respected worldwide, but particularly in Asia and South Africa. Avid collector of model trains, and lover of classical music, he will be most remembered for his quick wit, integrity, strong determination and generosity to those in need. He is sorely missed by all. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Walter & Maryann Kann Scholarship Fund/Kingsborough Community College Foundation, 2001 Oriental Blvd., Brooklyn, NY 11235 would be most appreciated. The family will be sitting shivah at home through Sunday evening. Funeral services will be held on Friday, December 5th, at 11:00am, at the Riverside Chapel 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue in NYC.

AROUND TOWN

RANDY TRAVIS: 'CHRISTMAS ON THE PECOS' (Image) The solemn Mr. Travis isn't much known for cracking smiles, but that doesn't mean he deserves a DVD this sober, shot like a local public-television special. Even Carlsbad Caverns in New Mexico, site of some of the performances here, appear largely sapped of their grandeur. Yet somehow this ends up a looser affair than Mr. Travis's 1989 holiday album, ''An Old Time Christmas.'' He bares some teeth on versions of ''Christmastime's A Comin' '' and ''How Do I Wrap My Heart Up for Christmas?'' And he even tries cracking a few jokes (''Anybody here know what a snowman eats for breakfast?''), but one moon-faced girl in the audience won't let him have the punch lines (''Frosted Flakes!''). Even funnier: when the girl reveals that the person who fed her the answers is Mr. Travis's wife. JON CARAMANICA
Africa ZIMBABWE: CHOLERA EMERGENCY

BOWIEBALL The economy is tanking, the winter doldrums are setting in, and the tourists and the family are descending, but don't let that bring you down: pull yourself up by your skinny jeans and hit BowieBall, a glittery, wild-haired, wild-eyed party in honor of the Thin White Duke, in all his gender-bending glory.

LOREENA MCKENNIT: 'A MIDWINTER NIGHT'S DREAM' (Quinlan Road) Looking back to a Celtic heritage and outward to Arabic modes, Loreena McKennitt reaches for pan-historical reverence on ''A Midwinter Night's Dream,'' invoking traditionalism with a cinematic polish. Pennywhistles, pipes, Baroque-sounding string ensembles and her own harp accompany her tremulous voice in many songs, mixing ancient instruments with resonant modern production. ''God Rest Ye Merry, Gentlemen'' moves to North Africa with a drone, hand drums and the voice of the Algerian singer Abdelli. It's rich, delicate and convincingly awestruck. JON PARELES

ENYA: 'AND WINTER CAME ...' (Reprise) Here's a holiday nightmare: opening the door to a caroling group only to discover it's actually dozens of multitracked Enyas. This layering effect has been a hallmark of this often grating Irish singer's work for the past two decades, and the wall of politeness persists on this, her winter-themed seventh album. Its precision can be deadly, and surprisingly convincing: ''Trains and Winter Rains'' and ''Dreams Are More Precious'' radiate an anodyne pleasantness. Her music -- part pop-classical, part atmospheric new age -- doesn't vary in deference to the season (except for the slightly burlesqueish ''My! My! Time Flies!,'' which no month would claim). Instead she brings Christmas to her, delivering a hypnotic ''Silent Night'' sung in Gaelic, ''Oiche Chiuin (Chorale).'' JON CARAMANICA
WHAT Beachfront residential resort. WHERE Loreto, Mexico.

Sydney Leroux scored her fifth goal of the tournament and the United States national team held off Germany, 1-0, in Coquimbo, Chile, on Thursday to advance to the final of the FIFA U-20 Women's World Cup. Leroux, the tournament's leading scorer, converted off a cross from Nikki Washington in the game's 21st minute. The American team will play North Korea in the final in Santiago on Sunday. By coincidence, the two nations also played in the final of the U-17 World Cup less than a month ago in Auckland, New Zealand. North Korea won that game, 2-1, in extra time. The N.C.A.A. women's final four may be the strongest field ever. The top four seeds reached the national semifinals for the first time since 1997 and just the fifth time over all. The teams have the most combined victories (92) and are tied for the fewest combined losses (2) of any final foursome in the history of the tournament. Stanford (22-1-1) and Notre Dame (25-0-0) kick off the action Friday at 4:30 p.m., followed by North Carolina (23-1-2) and U.C.L.A. (22-0-2) in Cary, N.C. finalfour (AP)

BARLOWGIRL: 'HOME FOR CHRISTMAS' (Fervent/Curb/Warner Brothers) Like a lost doo-wop curio, the Christian sister act BarlowGirl, from Illinois, specializes in plush, impenetrable harmonies. And after three albums of alluring, secular-friendly rock, the trio has stripped away the guitars for a more austere sound on its first Christmas album. Backed largely by the City of Prague Philharmonic, the sisters Barlow are crisp, especially on the stunning ''Carol of the Bells/Sing We Now of Christmas'' and a sharp version of ''O Come, O Come, Emmanuel.'' But the almost disorientingly pristine vocals verge on robotic; in bulk the effect can be dulling. In places, though -- as on the lone original, the arresting ''Hallelujah (Light Has Come)'' -- the sisters give one another room to breathe and, by extension, to rejoice unfettered. JON CARAMANICA
TYPEFACE RIVALRY On Subway Walls

SHIELDS--Dennis, Ph.D. The faculty, staff, post-doctoral fellows and students of the Department of Developmental and Molecular Biology of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University express our grief at the premature departure of our dearly loved colleague, Dr. Dennis Shields, an outstanding researcher and mentor in our Department since 1982. Dr. Shields was an internationally renowned cell biologist, but we remember most his enthusiasm, wit, deep humanity, and devotion to his colleagues and trainees. We express our deepest condolences to the Shields family.

'DEAR EDWINA' As if her name weren't enough, Edwina Spoonapple is weighed down with woes: they literally fill a wheelbarrow. But fortunately the troubles aren't hers. The shiny cart onstage at the DR2 Theater carries letters from her peers, seeking help for familial and social crises. Edwina, who appears to be in her tweens, an age when puberty and problems make twin arrivals, has a talent for advice, making her in essence a younger, hipper (and much thinner) Ann Landers.

Update | 11:41 p.m. And there you have it. Oklahoma is your Big 12 champion and is likely headed to the B.C.S. title game against Florida. The Sooners did it impressive fashion, especially with the streak of 60-point games. Bradford finished wth 383 yards and 2 touchdowns. In a postgame interview, he makes it clear that the Sooners played with a chip on their shoulder, mentioning several times that they felt they had to prove to people that they deserved to be in the game. They certainly did that. So here are a few questions before I sign off: After today's games, in which both Tebow and Bradford excelled, who is your pick for the Heisman? Tebow is the quintessential all-American-type, putting the Gators on his back and willing them to a hard-fought victory over a tough Alabama team. Bradford is merely the leader of the most prolific offense in major college history. It should make for quite a show on Jan. 8 (assuming the B.C.S. computers watched the same games everyone else did).

Josh Vaughan ran for 133 yards and 3 touchdowns Saturday to help visiting Richmond upset the defending national champion Appalachian State, 33-13, in the Football Championship Subdivision quarterfinals. Richmond (11-3) will play next weekend at Northern Iowa (12-2), which beat New Hampshire, 36-34.
The Baltimore Ravens have come a long way since starting the season 2-3, and that may not be a good thing.

In the 1980's, we in the news media didn't cover HIV/AIDS aggressively enough, and that permitted the complacency in governments that allowed AIDS to spread globally. I'm afraid we may be repeating the mistake with tuberculosis, particularly drug-resistant forms such as MDR-TB and XDR-TB. That's why I wrote my Sunday column on TB

A busy Saturday across the continent, but it was a very special one for a 37-year-old left winger who spent 10 years in North America and has spent another 10 with Frölunda in the Swedish Elitserien:
Pure Corn | From the Kenosha (Wisc.) News:

National Geographic Adventure magazine has an interview with me in the latest issue in which I discuss some of my travel secrets to avoid getting robbed in rough areas. I gave the interview on the assumption that there aren't a lot of bandits in rural Africa who read Nat Geo, but just in case -- if you are a bandit, don't read this interview.

I love the story of ATALANTA. She's beautiful but she doesn't want to marry, and she happens to be one of those fast girls. Suitors must beat her in a footrace in which the outcome is either marriage or death. She never loses. One day, Atalanta falls in love with Hippomenes, of 102 Across, but she still fears marriage. Hippomenes, following a racing tip from Aphrodite, tosses apples onto the track as they race around. This sufficiently distracts Atalanta, who stops to pick each of them up, and Hippomenes wins the race and her hand.

Greg Maddux, a four-time Cy Young Award winner, will announce his retirement Monday at the winter meetings, his agent, Scott Boras, confirmed. Maddux, who turns 43 in April, ranks eighth on the career wins list with 355. He went 8-13 with a 4.22 earned run average last season with the Padres and the Dodgers.

Todd Pletcher, named the nation’s outstanding trainer each of the last four years, faces a possible suspension. A horse he trains, Wait a While, tested positive for a prohibited drug, Procaine, after her third-place finish on Oct. 24 in the Breeders’ Cup Filly & Mare Turf at Santa Anita. The California Horse Racing Board filed a complaint against Pletcher after receiving the positive result from a laboratory. Procaine is a local anesthetic that is found in penicillin. The minimum penalty for use of the drug is 30 days. In a statement, Pletcher said that Wait a While had been treated with penicillin but that he thought it would no longer be in her system by the time she raced in the Breeders’ Cup.

The National Academy, the venerable artist-governed museum and school on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, has quietly sold two Hudson River School paintings from its collection to shore up its finances and enable it to show more of its holdings on a consistent basis, the academy's officials said on Friday. The sale of the paintings, Frederic Edwin Church's ''Scene on the Magdalene'' from 1854 and Sanford Robinson Gifford's ''Mount Mansfield, Vermont'' from 1859, was sharply criticized by the Association of Art Museum Directors, which has a longstanding policy of strongly discouraging museums from deaccessioning artworks unless the money is being used to acquire other works and to enhance a collection -- not to raise operating funds.

Federal immigration officials said on Friday that they would place no more immigration detainees at a detention center in Rhode Island that is under investigation for its treatment of a Chinese computer engineer from New York who died in custody last summer, his body riddled with cancer and his spine broken. The engineer, Hiu Lui Ng, 34, who had overstayed a visa years ago, died Aug. 6 after a year in immigration custody, the last month spent in the Donald W. Wyatt Detention Facility in Central Falls, R.I. A federal investigation was undertaken that month, soon after The New York Times reported that despite Mr. Ng's repeated pleas for help, his extensive cancer and fractured spine were not diagnosed until shortly before his death.

The gridlocked free-agent market is slowly starting to move, and the Yankees are helping push it along. General Manager Brian Cashman traveled to Washington on Thursday to meet first baseman Mark Teixeira, and he will meet C. C. Sabathia this weekend before the start of the winter meetings in Las Vegas on Monday. The Yankees' priority is pitching, and Cashman met with Teixeira and his agent, Scott Boras, who also represents Derek Lowe, Oliver Pérez and Manny Ramírez. Teixeira was visiting family in Maryland and is also being courted by the Washington Nationals.

BLACKBURN--Delores. The Caedmon School community extends heartfelt condolences to our beloved Headmaster, Dr. Greg Blackburn, his wife, Cathy, and their family on the loss of his gracious and elegant mother, Delores Patricia Blackburn of Clarksville, Arkansas.

Judge Marilyn Shafer of the New York State Supreme Court ruled last month that the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission habitually acted in a manner that was ''arbitrary and capricious'' and ordered the commission to conduct its business in a more timely manner. Her conclusions are welcome and frustratingly familiar to New Yorkers. The city plans to appeal. Instead, it should reform the commission, which is all that stands between the enormous pressures for development in this city and its priceless architectural heritage.

WEBSTER IS QUESTIONABLE The Giants' Corey Webster has started every game this season and has become one of the N.F.L.'s better cornerbacks. But Webster has a sore lower back and is listed as questionable for Sunday's game against Philadelphia. Webster said he was injured last Sunday in a 23-7 victory at Washington. ''I have a little stiffness and tightness in it,'' he said Friday. JOE LAPOINTE

She was the wife of the late Dr. Anthony J. Cantore (2007) and is survived by six children, 12 grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

ACKERMAN--A. Bernard, M.D. The Department of Dermatology at SUNY Downstate Medical Center mourns the loss of our distinguished faculty member, colleague, teacher and friend A. Bernard Ackerman, M.D. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Alan R. Shalita, M.D. Edward R. Heilman, M.D.

ZEITLIN--Richard, 63, of New York City and Madison, Wisconsin died on December 3, 2008 after an overwhelming struggle with a rare and terrible cancer. Richard earned his Masters and Ph.D. in U.S. History at the University of Wisconsin. He published several books and was the director of the Wisconsin Veterans Museum. The son of Mildred and Paul Zeitlin, the brother of Dr. Alan Zeitlin, brother-inlaw of Sherri, uncle of Ferrin and Brigitte, father of Sam and Eleanor and dear friend of Jackie Skora. He is loved and will be profoundly missed. Funeral services at Schwartz Brothers in Forest Hills, NY on Sunday. Donations in his memory can be made to the Ferrin Randall Zeitlim Foundation for Sarcoma Research.
