Georgia's prime minister dismissed the defense and foreign ministers on Friday, as the government continued to reckon with the disastrous effects of its war with Russia in August. The prime minister, Grigol Mgaloblishvili, who was appointed in October, announced the shake-up, saying, the government needed to focus on new realities.

As bad as the headline numbers in Friday's employment report were, they still made the job market look better than it really is. The unemployment rate reached its highest point since 1993, and overall employment fell by more than a half million jobs. Yet that was just the beginning. Thanks to the vagaries of the way that the government's best-known jobs statistics are calculated, they have overlooked many workers who have been deeply affected by the current recession.

COLTRERA--Joseph Theodore, M.D.,died December 2, 2008, age 85. Vital, generous, endlessly curious, and engaged in life until the very moment he left it. Joyously lived to see Barack Obama become President and his beloved Giants win the Super Bowl. Warmly loved husband of Peggy, father of Deirdre, Marc, and Francesca, grandfather of Tyrone, Martina, Erin, Colin, Emma, and Kate, and father-in-law to Jonathan, Anne, and Andrew. Private services to be held in Brooklyn Heights. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to St. John's Bread & Life in Brooklyn.

SOLOMON--Sylvia R.,79, of Oceanside, passed away peacefully in her sleep early Thursday morning, December 4th, 2008. Devoted mother of Steven and Onie, and Barbara and Bruce. Beloved Bubbie of Joy, Jonathan, Sarah, Jaclyn and Adam. A wonderful mother, grandmother, friend and always a teacher. She will be missed by all. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman's Inc in Rockville Centre, Sunday December 7th at 10:30am.

Perhaps because he has plastered his work on everything from Louis Vuitton purses to a Kanye West CD cover, the Japanese artist Takashi Murakami is always looking for new ways to update his brand. ''Everything is money,'' he says, adding that ''this is fine for us artists and fine for the gallerist, but it's really bad for the audience.'' His most recent exhibition, the touring ''©Murakami,'' is the most comprehensive retrospective of his work to date; it's on display at the Museum für Moderne Kunst in Frankfurt through January. Looking back on his vividly colored, anime-inspired oeuvre, Murakami finds similarities to another prolific pop-culture heavyweight: ''I understand George Lucas - he makes money, but like me, he makes fantasy.''

Sport | It's not Faulkner, but southern football says a lot about America. [Forbes]

Amaury Leveaux broke the men’s 50-meter butterfly short-course world record, and Coralie Balmy set a record in the women’s 200 freestyle at the French swimming championships in Angers. Leveaux finished in 22.29 seconds, and Balmy finished in 1:53.18.

Gregor Schlierenzauer broke the Granasen hill record in Trondheim, Norway, with a jump of 140 meters (459 feet 4 inches) in the first round and held on to win the World Cup ski jumping meet. Schlierenzauer finished with 285.7 points. Ville Larinto of Finland was second with 278.9 points.

Chris Ellis, a rookie defensive end for Buffalo, has been placed on season-ending injured reserve because of an ankle injury. Ellis, a third-round draft pick out of Virginia Tech, had played the last seven games and was credited with seven tackles. The injury kept him from practicing as the Bills (6-6) prepared to host the Miami Dolphins (7-5) in Toronto on Sunday.

Lee Ho-suk won the men’s 1,000 meters as South Korean skaters dominated the opening day at a World Cup short-track meet in Nagano, Japan, with three victories. Lee clocked a time of 1:26.930. Lee Sung-su won the men’s 1,500 in 2:18.073, edging the American Jeff Simon, who was second in 2:18.173.

The slumping Buffalo Sabres called up the high-scoring rookie center Nathan Gerbe from their A.H.L. affiliate. Gerbe, who is 5 feet 6 inches and 160 pounds, is second on Portland with 24 points (14 goals, 10 assists) in 21 games. The Sabres are 3-9-1 in their last 13 games.

The two-time world and Olympic champion Andre Lange of Germany won his 40th World Cup bobsled race in a two-man competition in Altenberg, Germany. Lange and Kevin Kuske had a combined time of 1:52.60 over two runs. Sandra Kiriasis and Romy Losgsch of Germany won the women’s race in 1:55.7.

The three-time Olympic gold medalist Ryan Lochte won the 200-yard backstroke in 1 minute 38.49 seconds at the U.S. Short Course championships in Atlanta, giving him four titles in three days. Mary DeScenza won five titles after taking the 200 backstroke and butterfly.

An article last Sunday about the Machine Project, an alternative arts group in Los Angeles, misidentified the location of the Andy Warhol Foundation. It is in New York, not Pittsburgh. (The Andy Warhol Museum is in Pittsburgh.).

A review on Nov. 23 about “The Decline and Fall of the British Empire 1781-1997,” by Piers Brendon, misstated the number of British prime ministers since 1945 who have had mustaches (all of whom were, incidentally, former infantry officers). There have been three, not two — Clement Attlee, Anthony Eden and Harold Macmillan.

To the Editor: It was with anticipation that I started reading “39 Reasons to Go to the Caribbean This Year” (Nov. 9) in the Travel section. My anticipation quickly turned to disappointment when I saw the prices for the vast majority of lodgings where prices were given. Of 24 places with prices furnished, only two were under $100 a night, five between $101 and $200 and three between $201 and $300. Almost two-thirds of locations with prices were above $300 a night, nine from $301 to $500 and five above $500. With the economy in the tank and people looking for economical vacations — if they are thinking of vacations at all — one would have hoped that The Times’s Travel section had been more industrious in alerting readers to places to stay where prices weren’t in the stratosphere.

To the Editor: No, the Sloane Rangers have not returned to Sloane Square as stated in your Surfacing column, “Rangers Ride Once More” (Nov. 23). They never left. While there are new stores and restaurants on that delightful intersection at the top of this London neighborhood of Chelsea, Sloane Rangers have been frequenting the Oriel Cafe, with a hint of France, for many, many years. The Oriel Cafe is on the square just across from the Royal Court Theater. And though the Royal Court building may have been around for 120 years, the Royal Court Theater itself came into its own in 1956, when the theater was changed forever with John Osborne’s “Look Back in Anger.” The London neighborhood of Chelsea has long been and continues to be a magnet for its beautiful, wealthy young professionals.

To the Editor: Regarding the “36 Hours” about Seattle (Nov. 23): The term “Skid Road” does not refer to Seattle’s waterfront, but rather to the wooden road down which logs were “skidded” to the waterfront for shipment, now Yesler Way. Otherwise, your article was a lovely accounting of our increasingly exciting downtown, and the excellent food and art culture that we have until recently kept secret.

An article on Tuesday about robotics kits for children gave an incorrect title for the most recent book from NXT STEP, a group that blogs about Lego Mindstorms robots. An article on Wednesday about the resignation of Becky Saletan, publisher of the adult trade division at Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, incorrectly quoted Jeremy Dickens, the president of the Education Media and Publishing Group, which owns Houghton and is also a publisher of textbooks, software, reference works and educational materials, as saying that Houghton had $7 billion in debt. Mr. Dickens said that Education Media carried that debt — not Houghton alone.

A headline with the Digital Domain column last Sunday, about Tesla Motors’ application for federal loans, referred incorrectly to Tesla’s planned use of the money. It is not for the Tesla Roadster, its first model, which has a price tag of $109,000, but for purposes including the development of a sedan that, after tax credits, would cost about $50,000.

The Fair Game column last Sunday, about investors who have been unable to redeem their stakes in auction-rate securities, misstated the terms of a settlement between UBS and the state of Massachusetts on buying back such securities. The settlement covers securities bought from UBS between Oct. 1, 2007, and Feb. 13, 2008, regardless of whether the securities were moved to other firms, and securities held at UBS on Feb. 13, 2008, whether bought there or not. It is not limited to securities still held by UBS.

Jesus reinvents Judaism. Duffy reinvents catchy naïveté. Injections of Juvéderm reinvent the aging face. Thom Browne reinvents the male suit and, thereby, male calves. The beverage industry reinvents the movie theater as high-fructose-corn syrup dump site. Deaf, Beethoven reinvents the sonata. Carmel Snow reinvents Harper’s Bazaar. The roulette wheel spins. John Cage reinvents silence. Talkative Isaac Mizrahi reinvents Target, and Target returns the favor. Biogenetics reinvents chicken. Mark Spitz reinvents the bathing suit. Brooke Shields reinvents eyebrows; Richard Prince reinvents sleaze by appropriating a photo of 10-year-old Brooke, nude. The StairMaster reinvents the schlep. England reinvents tea. Tit for tat: Bollywood reinvents Hollywood. The word processer reinvents the typewriter. We’re supposed to be thrilled. D. H. Lawrence reinvents the sexiness of soot. American Apparel reinvents men’s briefs as penny candy. China reinvents capitalism. Alec Baldwin, leaving a message for his daughter, reinvents the rant. Calm and collected, Marcel Duchamp’s urinal reinvents the museum. Georges Duboeuf reinvents Beaujolais. Like a ripe grape on joy’s tongue, James Dean reinvents sensitivity, anticipating Heath Ledger, who reinvents James Dean. Alice Waters reinvents nearby vegetables. Thomas Alva Edison reinvents kissing. Judy Garland reinvents herself by spawning Liza, and then Liza rejuvenates Judy: chain reaction.

Or, in my case, the Old Gray Lady, who’s curious about cover tunes, the sometimes successful, sometimes tiresome recycling of pop music for love or money. Mostly money.

I’m sitting in front of a long glass desk in the office of the architect Scope Cleaver. It’s quite a place, with undulating concrete walls, sharply angled yellow-tinted windows and long, cantilevered balconies. And then there is Cleaver himself. He has dark shoulder-length hair, he’s about 3 years old, and he can fly. Welcome to the surreal world of architecture in Second Life.

Anyone who still doubts that the worlds of art and fashion are intimately linked should take a look at Comme des Garçons’ mailers. The flyers, which announce store openings and other events, have lately become collectible items, thanks to the intriguing imagery they depict: Little Red Riding Hood engaged in tantalizing play with the wolf, babies giggling contentedly, porn stars doing what porn stars do best. The artwork, courtesy of the Argentine art collective Mondongo, is striking not just because of its thematic diversity but also because the gang works with decidedly unconventional materials like cookies, glass and raw beef. Mondongo — the name comes from a popular Latin American stew made with tripe — was formed in 1999 by Agustina Picasso, Manuel Mendanha and Juliana Laffitte, who were trained as traditional painters at art school in Buenos Aires. (Mendanha and Laffitte are now married and have a child.) Since they teamed up, no one in the group has gone back to painting, nor has any one of them worked alone. Instead, they create computer templates together, using photographs and downloaded images, which they manipulate and assemble to form quirky tableaus. The resulting blueprints are then brought to life with meticulously applied layers of plasticine, thread, mirrors, garbage bags.

You can’t tell a book by its cover — or so they say. But you should be able to judge a gift by its wrappings. I am not talking about Martha Stewart-style origami with brown craft paper, raffia and fresh rosebuds, although I suppose someone out there has the patience to make such noble offerings. But I never cease to be surprised at how few brands have created that shiver of anticipation, the tingling of the skin that comes from recognizing the outside before the inner content is revealed.

‘I set out to write a happy book.” So begins Ludwig Bemelmans’s foreword to “The Best of Times: An Account of Europe Revisited” (Simon & Schuster, out of print), a collection of essays published in 1948, in an attempt to dispel the pall cast by the war.

I’m not going to pretend that I’m as green as I should be, but I try. Although I am still too frequent a flyer, and dither over whether to pop a wind turbine on the roof, I do bicycle whenever possible, seem hellbent on wrecking my Lanvin tote by cramming it with groceries rather than consigning another plastic bag to a landfill and spend much of my time recycling this, that or the other.
Dinner with Martino Gamper is a do-it-yourself affair.

It was perhaps poor timing in August 2007 when Flavio Briatore, the playboy principal of Renault’s Formula One racing team, announced he would build the Billionaire’s Resort in sunny Malindi, his ex-girlfriend and presumptive business partner Naomi Campbell by his side. Kenya’s coastline has never been called trendy, per se, even if Bill Gates and Angelina Jolie have recently played through several of its white-sand beaches. But Malindi’s local M.P., Gideon Mung’aro, was somehow confident the hotel would “attract queens and kings and other world celebrities,” or so he told the press.

ALONG ROUND HILL ROAD in Greenwich, Conn., the newer mansions were built for comfort and show. They are equipped with systems — security systems, illumination and irrigation systems, vacuuming systems and entertainment systems. There is a smoothness to life on Round Hill Road that is apparent even to a stranger. There might be trouble in some of the houses, for there is always trouble somewhere — trouble from debt, trouble from an unhappy marriage — but it seems a feature of new wealth, if not a requirement, that its participants be not too heavily invested in the sort of colossal dreams that built Newport and Houston, places that were built from money made in dangerous work like mining and oil. For whatever else an imitation of a French manor may suggest, it does not suggest, at least on Round Hill Road, danger or a great deal of imagination.

I’ll give ’em the rock legs, Marion,” Alex James says as he poses for a picture. The former bassist for the British band Blur tosses his cigarette in the wet hay surrounding him, lets his bangs obscure one of his eyes and assumes that wide bass-player stance as seven Gloucester cows moo in the background. This shoot is not for Rolling Stone but for The Bisley News (circulation 200 plus), and it’s hard to tell who is the sexier “get”: James or the cows. Gloucester cows have only just grazed their way off the endangered list, and James is thinking of buying one more for his 200-acre farm in the Cotswolds. (Elizabeth Hurley’s brother bought two Gloucesters for her as a wedding gift, and James is on a waiting list for a calf — “like for an Aston Martin,” he says.) The seller is the woman taking his picture: Marion Conisbee-Smith, a veteran cheese crafter moonlighting as The Bisley News’s photographer.
Our lady of the A-list give Horacio Silva and earful.

Where are the girdles of yesteryear? The ones women of all ages once wore as a matter of course, huffing and puffing as they tugged at the reinforced elastic and lace, the better to encase their bodies to trimmest effect. The ones that were so pivotal that the 19th-century sexologist Havelock Ellis felt compelled to weigh in, insisting that girdles were “morphologically essential” because the evolution from “horizontality to verticality” was more difficult for women than for men. (Without them, Ellis grandly theorized, “woman might be physiologically truer to herself if she went always on all fours” rather than try to imitate men by “standing erect.”) How is it, then, as I discovered when I went in quest of a girdle, that this once culturally mandated undie has disappeared from the sartorial landscape like so much melted snow?.

Fashion Conundrum 2008: What does the responsibly minded clotheshorse wear for the End of the World as We Know It? The markets have tanked. The planet’s on a high simmer. The fashion industry has responded to international belt- and guilt-tightening with two solutions: spend green or showcase a black sense of humor while you keep on shopping like it’s 2004. The work of the Los Angeles artist Bettina Hubby offers a third option that combines both greenness and a personalized high-fashion/high-art approach to soup-kitchen thrift. Hubby produces (sculptures may be the better word) new clothing from existing pieces. Specifically, she takes vintage garments by the likes of Issey Miyake and gives them second lives as one-of-a-kind objects. “The canvas is already stretched,” she says of using old designer clothes. “I love recreating things from what they already are.”.

Since founding the influential London fashion label Biba in the 1960s (a young Anna Wintour worked for her as a shop clerk), Barbara Hulanicki has created looks for Cacharel and Fiorucci, done a collecton of children’s clothes, even designed hotels for Chris Blackwell in Jamaica and the Bahamas. Her current gig? Dreaming up wallpaper for the English company Graham & Brown (grahambrown.com).

“Change” is a word we’ve heard too much this year, but Design Miami actually embraced it. The early December showcase housed its 24 dealers in a temporary 43,000-square-foot reusable structure designed by Aranda\Lasch, a smart young architectural firm from New York whose complex, mathematical forms have drawn plenty of attention. The architects reimagined a conventional exhibition tent via an “outer membrane” of translucent vinyl with cutouts to let in light. Ambra Medda, the event’s director, explained that the galleries had outgrown their former space in the Moore Building and that the Aranda\Lasch structure will be transported to other locations. Medda also revealed that when Design Miami opens in Basel next June, it will include dealers in Art Deco and 18th-century furniture. Surprised? It’s not as heretical as it sounds. “I feel like that’s going to empower the show,” Medda said. “It will take a stronger stand and be a little more audacious.” It also provides a hedge against a downturn in the market for contemporary design by offering objects with an established pedigree — as well as, in a welcome development, a broader historical view of design.[?][?][?] PILAR VILADAS.

More maquette than holiday goodie, this gingerbread version of Farnsworth House — Mies van der Rohe’s modern masterpiece in Plano, Ill. — is a (deep-pocketed) design lover’s dream. It took the elves at April Reed Cake Design several days of photo research and about 25 hours to construct the fondant-covered walls, poured-sugar “glass” windows and sugar-paste I-beams and staircases. The project was a natural progression for the Manhattan cake maven, who specializes in stylishly spare confections for weddings and parties. “I tend to pass on overly theme-y cakes, but I have a soft spot for commissions that are intriguing from a design perspective,” Reed says. The house costs $4,320, with 15 percent of the proceeds going to help repair the real Farnsworth House, which was damaged in a September flood. Go to aprilreed.com.[?][?][?] SANDRA BALLENTINE.

If gold is not lining your pockets this season, you might try lining your eyes. François Nars’s holiday collection features a metallic shadow with goldish particles called Silent Night. A generous dusting at the corner and under the eye should add a rich glow, for a mere $22. Too bad about the 401(k), though. Go to narscosmetics.com.[?][?][?] JONATHAN S. PAUL.

For an experimental periodical that has been printed on beer coasters and rubber doorstops, The Thing is aptly named.Founded last year by the Bay Area artists John Herschend and Will Rogan, this quarterly journal takes the form of a text-driven object designed by a different artist each edition and goes out (in a cardboard box) to more than 1,000 subscribers who pay $140 annually. Issue 1 was a cryptically inscribed window blind by Miranda July; Issue 6 (available through Jan. 31; thethingquarterly.com) is a book with blank pages and a shoelace bookmark laced into an actual shoe by Jennifer Allora and Guillermo Calzadilla.[?][?][?] JAIME GROSS.

Artistic reinvention is nothing new, but few explore it as extensively as the Albanian artist Anri Sala. For the American debut of “Anri Sala: Purchase Not by Moonlight,” at the Museum of Contemporary Art in North Miami, Sala has choreographed an ever-changing mix of reverberating drum noises and shifting film projections — from the jazz saxophonist Jemeel Moondoc to truck stops — so that no two visits are exactly alike. Born in Tirana, Albania, and now living in Berlin, Sala, 34, sees himself as the product of “not just political rupture but physical rupture itself.” His show is an exercise in crossed signals, missed connections and the occasionally disorienting intersections between technology, sound and memory, as in the haunting image (right) of a white horse appearing to float on a metal pillar like an undead piece of taxidermy. When it moves on to the Zaha Hadid-designed Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati next May, viewers may discover that the exhibition has been completely overhauled to fit its unconventional new digs. “I’m interested in those gaps where one thing can be seen or heard as something completely different,” Sala says.[?][?][?] LINDA YABLONSKY.

The usual train-and-veil wedding dress may be fine for the average Bridezilla. But Olivier Bobin, the 30-year-old Parisian designer of the cult bridal line Fade, is aiming for something off the beaten aisle. “We’re supposed to have fun at weddings, so we should celebrate with a mad, cool, funny dress,” says Bobin, whose day job is assisting the D.J. and music producer Michel Gaubert. Bobin’s custom-made, heavily embellished collection (in white, his one nod to tradition) includes such silhouettes as a wide Elizabethan skirt cut above the knee and a puffy shirtdress in oversize lace that he made for the stylist Masha Orlov. After reimagining bridal wear — which takes several weeks to make and costs between $2,500 and $13,000 (societesecrete.org) — Bobin says he’d like to design a special line of clothes for bar mitzvahs and even a range of what he calls “divorce dresses.” “Something dark, maybe a little austere,” he says. “But sexy, and graceful when you walk.” Look for Madonna to place an order.[?][?][?] ALEXANDRA MARSHALL.

In Paris, what Pierre Hermé did for the macaroon, Christoph Adam is now doing for the éclair. At the fine-foods purveyor Fauchon, Adam has reworked the classic French pastry into a savory trompe l’oeil treat using creams flavored with mushroom and truffle. And for the holidays, he’s come up with his pièce de résistance: an éclair filled with foie gras cream and glazed with hazelnut icing. Sold individually, they’re ready-made hors d’oeuvres — or just a hotel-room feast. 24-26 Place de la Madeleine; 011-33-1-70-39-38-00. [?][?][?] CHARLOTTE DRUCKMAN.

A bed made up to look like a flattened cardboard box – no, it’s not some un-P.C. attempt at satire. Inspired by a trip to New York City, the Dutch designers Peggy van Neer and Erik van Loo created this printed cotton duvet cover (about $78 for a double) and matching pillow cases ($11 each) and named the set Le Clochard, after the French word for “bum.” The duo will donate up to 40 percent of the sales to organizations that will help get youngsters off the streets and back in school. Says van Loo, “It would be a bit strange to reference homelessness on a duvet if you weren’t doing something good with the money.” Up next: linens that mimic pavement. For more information and to order, go to www.le-clochard.com[?][?][?] MONICA KHEMSUROV.

Not since Napoleon popped a few on his crown have cameos been so chic. They are on rings by Amedeo Scognamiglio set into exotic stones ($1,400 to $3,500; cameos.com); an amulet of butterflies with diamonds at Tiffany & Company ($18,000; tiffany.com); strung together for bracelets by Janis Savitt for Vera Wang ($2,930; verawang.com); and on pendants and more with images of chairs and trees at Alexis Bittar ($325 to $1,195; alexisbittar.com). Lanvin hangs a profile from grosgrain and pearls ($1,805; dightonrhode.com), and Pomellato’s Eva collection is carved with snakes (left; $2,555 to $5,220; pomellato.com).[?][?][?] RIMA SUQI.

Kelley Deal, the lead guitarist and self-proclaimed bad girl of the rock group the Breeders (below), has a new addiction. “I kind of do everything obsessively,” she says. “I smoke obsessively, I took drugs obsessively, and now I knit obsessively.” Her new book, “Bags That Rock” (Lark Books), is part manual, part travelogue, filled with patterns, tips and anecdotes about stitching on the road. (She recommends dyeing yarn with Kool-Aid and soaking purse handles in hotel bathtubs for shape.) Deal has plans to sell her bags online and hopes to pen another how-to — this one about sweaters — next year. “Hobbies are so important,” she says. “Knitting kept me distracted from leaving my hotel room in Amsterdam and doing something bad.”[?][?][?] T. COLE RACHEL.

The gossip-friendly personal lives of Marc Jacobs and Mary McFadden (she’s been married at least four times) and their knack for American luxe (witness his ode to the ’80s for fall) make them kindred fashion spirits. Laura Ashley’s brand hasn’t quite been the same since her death in 1985. Her tea-length Edwardian-style dresses are ready for redux by Roberto Cavalli, who did “Big Love” florals this season.
Contemporary Arts Center.

1976 “THE MUPPET SHOW” makes its debut in prime time with Kermit the Frog as the Woody Allen-esque host and a karate-chopping diva named Miss Piggy. The first human guest star is Juliet Prowse; by 1977, Elton John hosts and performs. Eleven-year-old viewers are so cool they don’t even know it.
For John Galliano, every day is a costume change.
Arianna Huffington.
1. THE OVEN Forbes opened up the entire kitchen to the view of diners. Now, Gray says, “it’s lit like a stage, and the center of that stage is this oven,” which uses two-year-aged hardwood.

“STAR SOCIETY,” BY WILLY RIZZO (1994) This coffee-table book devoted to the work of the glamorati photographer Willy Rizzo has “amazing portraits from the ’60s to the ’80s,” Hall says, including oft-overlooked shots of Yves Saint Laurent and Guy Bourdin. $100.
Chalk it up to a plunging euro, a splurge-worthy resort or just a fondness for the familiar -- destinations of yore are making a triumphant return.

Tartan dinner jackets date to a game-changing moment in the 1950s when color (peacock iridescents and “parfait” tones) and pattern (paisley! batik!) were suddenly authorized for dressing up after dark. Think of one of John Cheever’s well-groomed but morally bankrupt characters at a Westchester dinner party, and the look comes drunkenly alive. By 1963 even Amy Vanderbilt had come around, issuing a qualified endorsement — plaid evening jackets were acceptable on cruise ships only — in her “Complete Book of Etiquette.” Two years later Vanderbilt’s rival Elizabeth Post also gave her assent, also with conditions: the style was welcome on “less formal” occasions, and only in summer. Nearly half a century later, tartan dinner jackets are far more identified with the holidays, with doorbells, sleigh bells and clinking cups of wassail. D&G’s fall collection mined the nerdier possibilities of the item to comic effect: the runway models all wore heavy black glasses, batwing bow ties and worried expressions, as if they had second thoughts about their prom dates. Band of Outsiders’s silk plaid jacket with a grosgrain shawl collar has a fan in the Hollywood photographer Paul Jasmin, who wears it on the label’s Web site with a chunky yellow velvet bow tie. The haberdasher Brioni used to be known for its tartan jackets, but when I called the Manhattan store to see if they were still in production, a salesman sounded almost offended. (He referred me to the Las Vegas branch; none there, either.) Ralph Lauren has been loving them since at least 1989, making the jackets a semiregular part of his holiday line; this year’s model, in cashmere, comes in the green-and-navy Black Watch pattern. One advantage of the “Brown Watch” version in Alan Flusser’s New York shop is that you won’t see yourself coming and going. “With gray flannel trousers, a light blue dinner shi

When Sofia Coppola visited the Louis Vuitton atelier in Asnières, France, she wasn’t planning to redesign its famous handbags. “I had a bag in mind,” she said, “and I couldn’t find it. What I was imagining was chic and classic without tons of hardware and not too show-offy. I didn’t want it too slouchy or too structured and definitely not black — people wear so much black that it’s nice to have a bag that’s a different color.” Since she couldn’t find such a bag, she decided, with Vuitton’s help, to create one; after several prototypes, the SC bag, which combines the utility of a travel duffel with the smaller scale of an everyday bag, was born. Coppola also designed a small envelope clutch that’s perfect for evening and a line of sandals that combine the glamour of the ’40s with the sleek sensibility of the ’70s. Creation is addictive: “I already want a smaller version of my day bag,” Coppola said.[?][?][?] LYNN HIRSCHBERG.

This holiday season, the Los Angeles designer Greg Lynn is conducting a toy drive — of sorts. For its entry in the 2008 Venice Architecture Biennale, Lynn’s firm, Greg Lynn Form, recycled a mountain of plastic childhood relics into blobular furniture, including a bookshelf, a coffee table and various side tables. Don’t laugh: the Koonsian critter piles, which were made using the sort of technology behind buildings like Frank Gehry’s Walt Disney Concert Hall, took home a Golden Lion for Best Installation Project. To donate a gently used Chicco Rock’n’Roll Eggplant or a Little Tikes Classic Whale Teeter-Totter (should you have one) — or to watch a robot dismantle a cheerful yellow duck — go to glform.com.[?][?][?] ALIX BROWNE.

A puzzling new trend is rocking the art world. The fashion photographer Steven Meisel recently unveiled a jigsaw puzzle featuring a highly patterned pinup girl he originally shot for Vogue Italia (above; $750 for signed limited edition; shop.artandcommerce.com). And RxArt, a New York-based nonprofit organization that puts contemporary art in hospitals — think a CAT scan machine remodeled by Jeff Koons to look like a tire swing — has commissioned its own puzzles to raise money for its 2009 projects. Terry Richardson’s limited-edition clown face is definitely not your grandmother’s jigsaw ($250 signed, $75 unsigned; rxart.net).[?][?][?] ALEX HAWGOOD.
ELSIE AND EILEEN: NOBLE MODERN.
The actor Tom Cruise.
Comedy, action, drama, fatherhood - Tom Cruise embraces the wild ride.
The actress Katie Holmes.
CURRENTLY YOU ARE ON BROADWAY in “All My Sons.” Did you dream of doing theater when you were growing up in Toledo, Ohio?.
Rinko Kikuchi | Global Player.

RICK OWENS RECYCLED MINK MONSTER POUCH, $850. GO TO RICKOWENSNY.COM. LOEWE NUTS AND BOLTS HEART PENDANT, $1,200. JEFFREYNEWYORK.COM. ELSA PERETTI FOR TIFFANY & COMPANY 18-KARAT GOLD MESH HALTER, $18,000. CALL (800) 526-0649.

ANGEL, for example, revolutionized the aesthetics of perfumery by reinventing the gourmand school. Thierry Mugler told his creative directors he wanted a scent that recalled the sweetness of youth — chocolate, honey, pralines. Shalimar had been there before: it brought the gourmand school into being in 1925 with the molecule ethyl vanillin (which smells like a thousand vanilla milkshakes), but it took Angel’s perfumer, Olivier Cresp, to restore it. He created a high-wire balancing act based on ethyl maltol, the molecule that gives cotton candy its smell. Against these supersweet atoms he set the chewy-almondy molecule coumarin as well as a natural patchouli that cuts the sweet the way ice cuts Grand Marnier. The result is brilliant. Angel is remarkable technically: stable, diffusive, singular. It is also incredibly divisive. But great art often is. Angel changed the state of the art, and molecule for molecule, it is a masterpiece.
Abalone chandelier by tony Duquette from.

1. THANKS TO MICHAEL BRUNO, who founded 1stdibs.com in 2001, decorators and collectors of all stripes can scour the globe for that perfect Ponti side table with a click of the mouse. The site, which gathers together the wares of antiques and vintage dealers from Paris to Palm Beach, “has become a time-saving tool for decorators, vendors and consumers alike,” Bruno says. “I vetted 500 1stdibs dealers and have a waiting list of 800 more. I do the initial legwork so my clients don’t have to.”.
1. Club Colombia.

For its second annual production of Prokofiev’s “Peter and the Wolf,” the Guggenheim Museum in New York enlisted the Brazilian designers Fernando and Humberto Campana to dream up a suitably whimsical set. The Campanas put their fondness for recycling to work in a landscape of faceted “rocks” made of plastic film over steel frames, and spiky “trees” made of green plastic bottles. The figures of Peter, the wolf and the story’s other characters are made mostly of scrap wood and will be illuminated by Jennifer Tipton’s lighting. George Manahan, the New York City Opera’s music director, will conduct a Juilliard ensemble, and Isaac Mizrahi, who narrated the production last year, had such a good time that he’s coming back for more. If you miss “Peter,” you’ll still be able to see the sets in “Antibodies,” a retrospective exhibition of the Campanas’ work that opens in March at the Vitra Design Museum in Weil am Rhein, Germany. For tickets to “Peter and the Wolf,” which runs from Dec. 13 to 21, call (212) 423-3587.[?][?][?] PILAR VILADAS.
A sampling of holiday music concerts scheduled around Long Island:
Choral performances in Connecticut.
As one of the stars of “Road Show,” Alexander Gemignani continues a theatrical association that is also a family tradition.
Stockard Channing returns to Broadway in the revival of “Pal Joey.”

There is inescapable irony in this week’s entire edition of the magazine being devoted to the subject of screens. Screens are the face, as it were, of the very technology that poses the biggest threat to conventional print media.

I have been ranting about the algorithms that are behind many movie-rating schemes — including Netflix’s — for several years now. It wasn’t “Napoleon Dynamite” that did it for me but the indie smash “Memento” (Clive Thompson, Nov. 23). I hated “Memento,” and it seemed to me that that simple fact, coupled with a few other data points, would allow a computer algorithm to “solve” my movie preferences. Turns out I was wrong. I’m no programmer, but it seems to me that at least two things are wrong with these algorithms. First, they are biased toward positively rated movies more than negatively rated ones; it’s easy to give something three (or even five) stars that you are truly ambivalent about, but much harder to give one or two stars to something you didn’t really dislike. In other words, negative ratings are probably actually more accurate than positive ones. Second, companies that use these algorithms have a pretty big incentive to avoid recommending that their customers avoid certain titles, even though that information would almost certainly be more useful to their customers than the “you’ll probably enjoy” recommendations. Whether the system’s biases are intentional or not, once customers realize that the recommendations are driven by positive ratings, they tend to shy away from giving movies negative ratings. (Or they stop rating movies altogether, as I did.).

It is ironic that Kevin Kelly (Idea Lab, Nov. 23) should expend 3,500 printed words to persuade us that the printed word is dead. While he believes that “technology is nudging the book aside,” he is himself the author of two books, one of them a “coming book on technology.”.

On Thursday, Feb. 6, 1997, around 9 p.m., I went into labor with my first child — right in the middle of watching an episode of “Seinfeld.” (If you must know, it was the “Van Buren Boys” episode.) Now almost 12 years old, my son and I watch “Seinfeld” reruns together — we have even watched the “Van Buren Boys” episode together, side by side on the couch (Rob Walker, Consumed, Nov. 23). I’m sure Sony Pictures Television would be happy to know that these reruns are his favorite thing on TV. Not that there’s anything wrong with that.

Your recent article about calvados (Aleksandra Crapanzano, Food: The Way We Eat, Nov. 23) made me think of my dad, a paratrooper in the 101st Airborne Division who parachuted into Normandy on D-Day. Among his stories from June 1944 was the memory of French farmers sharing calvados with their American liberators. The experience gave him a lifelong affinity for the strong apple brandy. Back in the States, he grudgingly accepted Laird’s applejack as a substitute, but the mark of a truly fine bar or restaurant, to him, was one that could make a Jack Rose cocktail with French calvados, not Laird’s.
The economy’s downhill slide has prompted ski resorts to offer deals.
Deer Valley Resort has a new luxury ski-in ski-out lodge.
A new Web site devoted to cross-country skiing is up and running, and a new book on Nordic ski resorts is available on the site.

SOLOMON--Sylvia R.,79, of Oceanside, passed away peacefully in her sleep early Thursday morning, December 4th, 2008. Devoted mother of Steven and Onie, and Barbara and Bruce. Beloved Bubbie of Joy, Jonathan, Sarah, Jaclyn and Adam. A wonderful mother, grandmother, friend and always a teacher. She will be missed by all. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman's Inc in Rockville Centre, Sunday December 7th at 10:30am.

VINCE PETERSON, sounding authoritative beyond his boyish looks and 27 years, abruptly cut off the voices resonating throughout the First Presbyterian Church of Katonah and sprang up from his stool at the grand piano.

EISEMAN--William C.,84, Jupiter, FL, November 26. Veteran. Retired Senior VicePresident, Morgan Guaranty Trust Co. Husband of the late Jane McKee Eiseman. Survived by his four children and two sisters. Private burial. Memorial gifts to the Gettysburg Foundation, Gettysburg, PA.

THIS WEEK'S RECOMMENDATIONS TEST AND LEARN: I don't know what the future holds, but let's admit that people might not always turn to daily broadsheets for their news. Among the inventive new ways of envisioning information, Newser.com is the one I like best: its images are the right size, and it allows you to set your news preferences from hard (Ben Bernanke) to soft (Suri Cruise). Google's NewsWorldMap.com, which shows news breaking out all over the globe, is addictive. Also interesting: the brilliant experiment under way at tenbyten.org, global live broadcasts at LiveNewsCameras.com and the news-is-candy visual showcase at ThePhotostream.com.

GAUDINE--Elsie, November 12, 2008, age 96. She is survived by her loving sister Rhoda Stahlberg, seven nieces and nephews, and eight grandnieces and nephews. Elsie, a lifelong resident of New York City, graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Hunter College, taught as a French and English teacher for 44 years in the NY school system, traveled the world, loved the arts, folkdancing, and playing bridge. She and her husband, Sascha, shared 23 years of marriage until his death in 1968. Elsie was intelligent, cultured, giving, and she loved life. She will be greatly missed.

Pittsburgh's 34-10 win over Connecticut gave it its first nine-win regular-season since 1982. The Panthers, 5-7 last year, are 10-3 since giving Coach Dave Wannstedt, left, a contract extension. TYRE--Thomas Edward, 82, of Mohegan Lake, NY, Arlington, VT and West Melbourne, FL passed away on November 26, 2008. Born in Pittsfield, MA, he joined the Marines at 16 and served with the 5th Marine Division on Iwo Jima and witnessed the raising of the flag on Mt. Suribachi. A graduate of the University of Maryland, he earned a JD with Distinction from George Washington University Law School and an LLM in Taxation from Georgetown University Law School. He was a practicing attorney for 46 years, a partner in the New York law firm of Casey, Tyre, Wallace & Bannerman and retired in 2001 from his law office in Briarcliff Manor. He was the Legal Officer of the 5th Marine Division Association. He leaves his daughters Patricia V. Tyre and companion Thomas Chiappetta, of Norwalk, CT, Peg Tyre and son-in-law Peter Blauner, of Brooklyn, NY, his sons Daniel M. Tyre and daughter-in-law Amy, of Paradise Valley, AZ, and Thomas E. Tyre, Jr. and daughter-in-law Alaina of Needham, MA, four grandchildren and his long time companion Elisabeth K. Baker.

WE Americans just can't have nice things. THE HARLEY-DAVIDSON MOTOR COMPANY ARCHIVE COLLECTION By Randy Leffingwell and Darwin Holmstrom. 600 color illustrations, 50 in black and white. 408 pages. Motorbooks. $60. The archive collection in this copiously illustrated, shop-manual-size book has more than 460 motorcycles, advertisements, company records and ephemera from Harley-Davidson's 105-year history. Readers get a glimpse of the highlights, including the first Knucklehead engine in 1936 and some of the company's more curious departures, like its entry into the snowmobile market in 1972.

The Baltimore Ravens have come a long way since starting the season 2-3, and that may not be a good thing. The Ravens (8-4) have won six of their past seven games. Baltimore's offense, once the team's biggest question mark, has averaged 34 points in those six wins. And like the unit he leads, the rookie Joe Flacco has hit his stride, with 11 touchdown passes and only 2 interceptions in those seven games.

THE NEWS Conservative leaders in the Episcopal Church broke away to form a rival denomination, the Anglican Church in North America, and said they would seek approval from global Anglican leaders. BEHIND THE NEWS The trouble in the Episcopal Church, the American branch of Anglicanism, stems mainly from a decision five years ago to ordain an openly gay bishop. Some clergy members and churchgoers who opposed the move have affiliated with more conservative bishops in Africa or Latin America, but many wanted a home-grown alternative. The schism threatens the fragile unity of the Anglican Communion, the world's third-largest Christian body.

RACKMAN--Rabbi Emanuel. We share great sadness at the loss of our cherished friend, Rabbi, educator and mentor. As his first name ''Emanuel'' denotes, he taught generations to love and honor Hashem, His Torah, His People and His Land. Together with his dear wife Ruth OBM, he illuminated out ''Chukei Chayim'' and inspired thousands to pursue a life of nobility, integrity, personal growth and courage, scholarship and human concerns. Our deep sympathy goes to his exemplary family, to Michael and Judy, to Rabbi Bennett and Ruth, Joseph and Eliane and their families. May Hashem grant them strength, healing and consolation among the mourners of Zion and Yerushalayim. Leonard & Aliza Kestenbaum Jay & Chani Kestenbaum Jerry & Ruthie Kestenbaum

PLANNING THE NEXT RUN DOWN MAMMOTH MOUNTAIN, MAMMOTH LAKES, CALIF., NOV. 22, 2008 Kristiano Costeniero, 28, a financial planner from Mission Viejo, Calif., with his wife, Christy, 26, a physical therapist. ''We met in college and went probably three or four times a year to Mammoth with college buddies, frat brothers, her friends or whatever. Now we try to make it sort of an annual event. We get along very, very well traveling together. When we go places, we come back more exhausted than when we left. We always want to do everything. Even going to someplace like Mammoth for the weekend, I get there at 10 on Friday night, I want to get up at 6, get breakfast at someplace like the Stove, a real good place with pancakes the size of the plate. Then hit the mountain right at 8 or 8:30. Then go all day until it closes. Then maybe go to a movie afterwards. And she's the same way.'' As told to Seth Kugel

PORSCHE The Fine Art of the Sports Car Original text and photographs by Lucinda Lewis. Updated text and revised chapters by William G. Scheller. 250 color photographs, 120 in black and white. 384 pages. Universe Publishing. $75. Good books about Porsches are on many coffee tables, but there is a new one that deserves a close look, at least for the pictures. ''Porsche: The Fine Art of the Sports Car'' is a reissue of a 1990 edition by the same name that features an artful mix of black-and white images from Porsche archives woven together with spectacular photographs by Lucinda Lewis. The new volume has been updated with 70 additional pages covering recent Porsches, but its list price is half of the $150 original edition.

RANNEY--Mary, RSCJ. The Head of School, Trustees, Faculty and Staff, Students, Parents and Alumnae of Convent of the Sacred Heart, New York City, deeply mourn the passing of an inspirational leader, gifted teacher and treasured friend. Always emphasizing faith and igniting spirit in the lives of children, she inspired countless young women with her compassion and purpose. Sr. Ranney left an indelible mark on the Sacred Heart community with her profound spirituality, her demonstrative love and her contagious joy. A Memorial Mass celebrating the life of this amazing woman will be held in the chapel at Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1 East 91st Street, on January 8 at 5:30pm.

WEILER--George Henry, Jr.,a public relations executive and tireless fundraiser for Yale University, died on November 13, 2008. Mr. Weiler was born July 6, 1916 in Yonkers, NY, to Bessie and George Henry Weiler, Sr. He graduated from Mercersburg Academy and Yale University in 1938. He served as Lieutenant Commander in the U.S. Navy in World War II and was awarded the American Theatre Ribbon and Victory Medal World War II. He served as Vice President of the Pfizer Foundation, a philanthropic arm of Pfizer. On retirement from Pfizer, he was Public Relations Director for the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, where he was responsible for the national campaign ''Athletes vs MS,'' which united virtually the entire sports world to eradicate MS. In 1994, having raised over $72 million for his 70th Class Reunion, he received the Yale Medal, awarded to only a few alumni each year. He is survived by Jeanne Carol Brumbaugh Weiler, his wife of 67 years, five children: George Henry Weiler, III of Bronxville, NY, Wendy Carol Weiler Chappell of Franklin Lakes, NJ, Christopher Lee Weiler of Wyckoff, NJ, Patricia Ann Weiler Thiess of Pittsburgh, PA, and Pamela Jeanne Weiler Colling of Midland Park, NJ.; and nine grandchildren. Another son, Terry William Weiler, predeceased him. A memorial service celebrating George Weiler's life will take place on Saturday, January 3, 2009, 11:00am at St. Elizabeths Episcopal Church, 169 Fairmount Road, Ridgewood, NJ 07450. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to St. Elizabeths Episcopal Church. Services by Vander Plaat Funeral Home, Wyckoff, NJ (www.vpfh.com).
Theater Charles Isherwood

LEWIS--Dr. Clyde, brother of Wright ('Lefty') Lewis of Stowe, passed away peacefully after a long battle with Alzheimer's on November 14, 2008. If Damon Runyon had written about New England characters, Clyde would have been his Sky Masterson. He was larger than life. He is also survived by sister Gail and sister-inlaw Joyce, many nieces and nephews and friends known as the Braintree Bowling Team and an infamous group of fellow sybarites called Rent-A-Group. A memorial service will be held in the spring on Mt. Mansfield in Stowe. Don't bring flowers, Bring Love.

In the three games since his return from injury and suspension, Chiefs running back Larry Johnson, below, has improved his rushing yardage each game. He had 67 yards in his return against the Saints, 81 against the Bills and piled up 92 against the Raiders last week on a punishing 24 carries. This week, he will look to do even more against the Broncos. Johnson's rushing touchdown against the Raiders was his first since Week 4, when he ran over Denver for 198 yards and 2 touchdowns. The last time the Broncos held him to fewer than 125 yards was Sept. 26, 2005, when he was still the Chiefs' second-string running back.

A statement was made by Rutgers during its 63-14 home-field rout of Louisville on Thursday night, but was it a pointed exclamation to a torrid turnaround or a howl of frustration for what could have been a Bowl Championship Series breakthrough season that slipped away too soon? Polls to priorities, to its existential core, college football is a sport defined by time, place and perspective. On one hand, it is the great American spectacle that galvanizes a campus and broadens a university's appeal. On the other, it is a money-draining, values-compromising orgy of indulgence.

ENGELBERG--Gusti. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with deep sadness the passing of Gusti Engelberg, beloved mother of Alfred Engelberg and mother-in-law of Gail. Al and Gail have long expressed their love of the Jewish community and Israel through their commitment to philanthropy. Al's service at UJA-Federation as a past member of our Board of Directors and through our beneficiary agencies Beth Israel Medical Center and the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee is farreaching and helps us to make a profound impact on the Jewish community. As the leading force behind the creation of Plaza Jewish Community Chapel and as its founding and current chairman of the board, he has strengthened our ability to care for those in need. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

MATTHEWS--Henry McEldowney (Harry) Born July 3, 1926 in Pittsburgh, PA of Charles Hale Matthews Jr. and Annabel McEldowney Matthews -Died suddenly November 24, 2008 in New York, NY. Loving husband of Catherine Caldwell Teague Matthews. Loving father of Charles Hale Matthews IV (Chip) of Palm Beach, FL, William Gordon Gibson Matthews (Bill) of NYC, and James Newell Matthews (James) also of NYC. Also survived by his former wife and their mother Sylvia Ondek Hudson of Palm Beach, FL. Proud graduate of Culver Military Academy and Yale University (Class of '51). Veteran of the US Army in the Philippines in 1945. Principal and co-founder of Matthews Mitchell, a member firm of the NYSE. Avid researcher into all things Scottish both here and in Scotland. Could be found collecting books on all phases of Scottish culture or dancing at Scottish Country Dances almost anywhere in the United States, Canada, and Scotland. Officer, trustee, director, and life member of many Scottish and AmericanScottish organizations, including the New York Branch of the Royal Scottish Country Dance Society and Scotia Dancers; the American-Scottish Foundation, the St. Andrew's Society of the State of New York and the New York Caledonian Club; the National Trust for Scotland, the Scottish Tartans Society, the Museum of Islay Life, the West Highland Museum in Fort William, and many others. Very active in he development and concerned with the ultimate progress of Clan Donald USA, the Clan Donald Foundation, and the Clan Donald Lands Trust. Believed you should participate in your heritage and share your culture actively. There is no joy without Clan Donald was not just a poet's declaration to him, it was Harry's lifeline. The highlight of each year was a month-long tour of the west coast of Scotland, each year featuring a different island or two. The museums along the way will remember how he would explore everything, asking questions, chatting about the prospects, and leaving a donation behind. In lieu of flowers, please help continue his educating efforts with donations to the Clan Donald Foundation (PO Box 24008, Milwaukee, WI 53224) or to the Library of the Clan Donald Visitor Center at Armadale (see www.clandonald.info). Memorial services will be held at the Frank E Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Avenue at 81st Street at 3:30pm on Thursday December 11, 20008. His ashes will be interred privately at Homewood Cemetery in Pittsburgh, PA.

FANS of ''All My Children,'' the daytime television soap opera, were stunned recently when Erica Kane, played by Susan Lucci, was stabbed by Annie, the seemingly psychotic bride-to-be. In normal times, there would have been little doubt that Erica would make another miraculous recovery. But times are not normal in the soap opera industry. It seems daytime stalwarts with big salaries are being disposed of in unprecedented numbers.

SCHUSSHEIM--Arnold, M.D.,age 76. A Brooklyn-born graduate of Columbia College, Arnold was a noted Pediatrician in Bayside, NY for 40 years. An avid sailor and ''hole-in-one'' golfer with a convivial wit, he will be sorely missed. The family will be sitting Shiva at home through Thursday evening. Services at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck, NY at 11am Sunday December 7.

The Treasury Department's $700 billion buttress to the financial system was expected to enable banks to make more loans to companies and consumers. But the Treasury has indicated that the 52 banks already funded by the program have mostly used their investments -- $161.5 billion so far -- to bolster their balance sheets at a time when options for raising capital are slim. And analysts expect that the more than 100 banks that have yet to receive money will be similarly cautious.

TEARDROPS AND TINY TRAILERS By Douglas Keister. 200 color photographs. 160 pages. Gibbs Smith, Publisher. $19.99. Teardrop trailers are the ultimate in minimalist travel fare. They are tiny campers, generally equipped with little more than a bed, storage cubbies and the most basic cooking equipment. The trailers are lightweight enough that they can be towed behind just about any vehicle. Most were born of necessity during the Great Depression.

PETERS-DUNAIF--Nancy, M.D. Dr. Nancy Peters Dunaif, age 85, died peacefully on November 18, 2008 of cerebrovascular disease. She was the widow of Samuel L. Dunaif, M.D., a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, who practiced in New York City and White Plains, NY. She used her maiden name professionally. Dr. Peters was born in Seneca Falls, NY, where her parents operated a dairy farm. She graduated from Cornell University College of Arts and Sciences and Cornell University College of Medicine. She received her psychiatric training at the Cornell University Division of Bellevue Hospital. Dr. Peters maintained a private psychiatric practice and was the consulting psychiatrist for the Yonkers public school system for over 30 years. In addition, she supervised the training of child psychiatry fellows at Cornell University College of Medicine's Westchester Division. She was also a consulting psychiatrist for the Hawthorne Cedar Knolls and St. Mary's in the Fields schools as well as for Leake and Watts Services, Inc. She retired from practice in 2001. She is survived by her children, Andrea, Matthew, Alexandra and Anthony, her sister, Elaine Hemmer, and her grandchildren, Emily, Andrew, Anya and Griffin. A memorial service will be held Saturday, January 3 2:00pm at Trinity Episcopal Church, Ossining, NY. Donations to American Ballet Theatre are suggested in lieu of flowers.

RUBENSTEIN--Sophia ''Sunny'', passed away December 2, 2008. Born in 1913 in New York City. Beloved mother of Barbara Spiegel, NY actress/teacher. Daughter to cherished Lena and William Weinstein, Russian emigres whose love of education resulted in Sophia and her sister Ann Irene Todd's receiving Master's Degrees in Music from N.Y.U. To help pay for college during the Depression she sang and played the Alto Sax with her sister on piano in all girls band 'Sunny Winston and her Rhythm Queens'. After the birth of her only child, Barbara she became a N.Y.C. school teacher in Harlem and ending in Queens. A fifty year resident of Forest Hills and Hollywood, FL with her second husband Charles Rubenstein, past president of the National Showman's Association and owner of NYC arcades. He was the father of deceased commercial agent Bernard Rubenstein. Always a lover of dressing, dancing and laughter, after her retirement from the Board of Education, she began a third career in film. She studied acting with Stella Adler and Gene Frankel. Simultaneously, she achieved success in the bonds and real estate markets. One of a kind, her beauty, humor and strength were apparent to everyone she encountered. She spent her last years residing next door to her adoring daughter. Services Sunday, December 7, 2008. 11:15am at ''The Riverside'' Amsterdam Ave. at 76th St.

HASSOL--Milton D.,Ph.D., 78, of New York City and Sherman, CT died on December 1, of lymphoma. Adored father of Jeremy Cass Hassol. Beloved brother of Rita Lowenthal of Pembroke Pines, FL. Caring uncle of Richard Lowenthal of Austin, Texas and and Mark Lowenthal of Berlin, Germany. Dedicated scholar, inspirational teacher, compassionate therapist, loyal friend. Dr. Hassol was retired as Chairman of the Department of Philosophy at CW Post Campus of Long Island University, where he had been on the faculty since 1967. He received his Ph.D. in philosophy from Columbia University in 1966 and taught there from 1960 to 1967. In 1973 he received a Post Doctoral Certificate in Psychotherapy and Psychoanalysis from NYU and had practiced until recently. He was a member of the NYU Psychoanalytic Association. His great passion was the study of ethics and morality and its relevance for psychiatry. Since 1985, Dr. Hassol served as President of the Board of the Neustadt Collection of Tiffany Glass, a New York nonprofit organization with a world-renowned collection of Tiffany lamps and glass. Contributions may be made to the Neustadt Collection of Tiffany Glass. A memorial service will be held on December 19, 2008 at 1pm at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, NYC.

COLE--Mary Myers. The Board of Directors of the Fire Island Pines Arts Project mourns the loss of our devoted fellow Board member, Mary Myers Cole. Mary served on the Board for many years as secretary and president, always contributing to the growth and success of the organization artistically and administratively. A caring and loving friend to all, Mary's dedication, generosity, and life-long support of the Pines' community will always be remembered and cherished. A memorial service is planned for Spring 2009 in Fire Island Pines. Contributions in her name may be made to the Fire Island Pines Arts Project, c/o Laura Hartstein, 135 West 70th Street, #

HERTZ--Charles Goldberg. Pediatrician and Health Care Advocate, Charles Goldberg Hertz, 74, of Stamford, CT on November 7, 2008 of cancer. Beloved pediatrician in Philadelphia for more than 20 years, and avid musician, composer, and traveler, with a passion for art, calligraphy, and architecture. Dr. Hertz founded Penn Urban Health in 1973. After working in health care management in Chicago from 1986-1993, he became Chief Medical Officer of MetLife in New York, and Editor of the Statistical Bulletin. Following retirement from MetLife, he became Medical Director of Medicover, working in Eastern Europe. He played the trombone from age eight until well after his 74th birthday. He led the marching bands in high school and college. He was the President of the Westport (Connecticut) Community Band and collaborated with Norwegian composer Jens Wendelboe on Fanfare and Anthem, the signature piece of the band. His sense of community and volunteerism was reflected in his 1960s production Benjamin Brittens ''Noyes Fludde'' in the University City area of Philadelphia, involving many children and adults. He helped create the University City Arts League. After retirement, he volunteered at the Darien Book Aid Plan, AmeriCares, and the Stamford Symphony. He was Vice Chair of the Board of Directors of ARI (Always Reaching for Independence) in Stamford. Dr. Hertz is survived by his wife, Lee Combrinck-Graham, his former wife, Adele Hertz Gray, his brother Robert G. Hertz, of Sunnyvale, CA, his sister, Lois Adler, of Austin, TX, his four children, Sara Anne Hertz, of Ambler, PA, Adam Elliott Hertz of Swarthmore, PA, Theodore Hertz of Lower Gynnedd, PA, Mark Philip Combrinck-Hertz of Stamford, CT, and seven grandchildren. A memorial celebration will be held from 25pm on Sunday, December 14, at the Ethical Humanist Society of Philadelphia 1906 South Rittenhouse Square Philadelphia, PA 19103. In lieu of flowers, it is requested that donations be made to Friends of ARI of Connecticut, 174 Richmond Hill Ave, Stamford, CT 06902.

ROBINSON--Dorothy Fay. On December 2nd, 2008, died peacefully at home after a long battle with cancer and Parkinson's disease which she fought with exceptional grace and courage. The daughter of Dorothy Mein Fay and Charles Fay, Dorothy was born in 1937 in San Francisco, CA. After graduating from the Garrison Forest School, Dorothy worked in the office of Vice President Richard Nixon in Washington, D.C. before coming to New York where she was a contributing editor of the magazine Art Voices. Later she was a founding member of the junior committee of Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital and was the events coordinator at the Natural Resources Defense Council for nearly 10 years. She had a lifelong interest in photography, started a Monday night cooking school for men, volunteered in the soup kitchen of the Church of Heavenly Rest and created a successful line of costume jewelry. But of all her accomplishments Dorothy's unique ability for friendship is what she will best be remembered for. Her charm, humor, loyalty and affection both in person and over the telephone endeared her to everyone who knew her. She is survived and will be greatly missed by her children, Gardner and Victoria; her sisters, Frances Bowes and Victoria Leonard; and three beloved grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Church of Heavenly Rest in New York at 3:30 on December 17th. Another service will take place in San Francisco in February. Donations in her memory may be made to National Resources Defense Council or The Parkinson's Stem Cell Research Fund at UCSF. 415-476-3953.

Citadel Investment Group, the U.S. hedge fund giant that has racked up hefty losses this year, is closing its Tokyo office and its Asia principal investment operations by the end of this year, according to press reports.

Vampires, according to lore, don’t show up on film, and the director Catherine Hardwicke won’t be showing up for the next installment of the vampire-romance film franchise “Twilight,” Variety reported. Ms. Hardwicke, whose previous films include “Thirteen” and “Lords of Dogtown,” was the director of the first “Twilight” film, adapted from Stephenie Meyer’s popular novels. That movie has grossed more than $138 million domestically, and Summit Entertainment, the studio that produces the films, wanted to start quickly on its sequel, “New Moon.” Ms. Hardwicke said in a statement cited by Variety that she wanted more time to develop the script. In a statement, Summit president Eric Feig said: “We are able to pursue an aggressive time frame as we have the luxury of only adapting the novels into screenplays as opposed to having to create a storyline from scratch.”

After resolving a labor strike days before its annual gala opening, La Scala opera house found itself embroiled in another controversy when it abruptly replaced the lead tenor in its opening-night production with his understudy, The Associated Press reported. The Italian tenor Giuseppe Filianoti was to play the lead role in Verdi’s “Don Carlo” on Sunday night in Milan, but was replaced by the American tenor Stuart Neill after Mr. Filianoti made mistakes at a dress rehearsal. According to the Milan newspaper Corriere della Sera, Mr. Filianoti said he had been “stabbed in the back at the last minute,” adding that he was in “perfect condition, ready to engage myself in a role in which I feel secure.” After his performance, Mr. Neill told The A.P., “Tough crowd, but no, I wasn’t nervous at all.”

The Slamdance Film Festival, the annual event in Park City, Utah, for independent moviemakers who feel that Sundance isn’t independent enough, announced a 2009 lineup that leans heavily on dark themes and dark laughs. The opening-night film will be “I Sell the Dead,” a horror comedy that stars Dominic Monaghan (of “Lost” and the “Lord of the Rings” movies) and Ron Perlman (“Hellboy”), and is written and directed by Glenn McQuaid. Other films in competition include “City Rats,” a Dickensian film about haunted people, and “Rosencrantz & Guildenstern Are Undead,” a comedy about a theater director who uncovers an ancient conspiracy involving vampires and Shakespeare. A list of films will be posted at slamdance.com; the festival runs from Jan. 15 through 23.

Try to remember the kind of December when you were watching the finale of the CBS reality series “The Amazing Race,” and thought one of its champions looked familiar: sure enough, Nick Spangler, who was a winner of the show’s $1 million prize on Sunday night, is a star of the current Off-Broadway production of “The Fantasticks,” in which he plays Matt. Mr. Spangler shared the prize with his sister, Starr, a former Dallas Cowboys cheerleader, after the siblings won a worldwide race that brought them to Cambodia, India, Kazakhstan and Russia. Replying to questions sent via e-mail, Mr. Spangler said that the prize money would help him continue to pursue a career in which “the salary is not exactly illustrious. “I’ve truly had to learn how far I can stretch a dollar to pay my absurd New York rent and eat absurdly priced New York food,” Mr. Spangler wrote. He is scheduled to make his first post-victory performance in “The Fantasticks” at the Snapple Theater Center on Wednesday afternoon.

For all the parents of authors who have later appeared as characters in their children’s memoirs, this one’s for you: a memoir written by Margaret Robison, the mother of the memoirists Augusten Burroughs and John Elder Robison, will be released by the Spiegel & Grau imprint of Random House, the publisher announced Monday. In a release, Random House said Mrs. Robison, 73, a writing teacher and poet, would write about her abusive marriage, raising her sons and her recuperation from psychosis and a stroke in a memoir tentatively titled “A Place to Come Home To.” Mr. Burroughs has written about his childhood in books like “Running With Scissors” and “A Wolf At the Door,” while Mr. Robison wrote about his battle with Asperger’s syndrome in “Look Me In the Eye.”

Apparently “Beatles For Sale” isn’t just an album title; it’s also a never-ending business proposition. A contract signed by the Beatles in 1962, in which the Fab Four agreed to a five-year arrangement with their manager, Brian Epstein, sold for $211,597 at an online sale, the Web site LiveAuctioneers.com said. The contract, in which the Beatles agreed that Epstein would receive 25 percent of their gross earnings, handle their publicity and advise them on their presentation, includes the signatures of George Harrison’s and Paul McCartney’s fathers (both performers were under the age of 21) and is twice signed by John Lennon, who originally signed in the wrong place. The document was sold at auction on Nov. 27; the winning bidder was not disclosed.

Sibling teammates Nick and Starr Spangler won the million-dollar prize on the latest edition of "The Amazing Race" on Sunday, as ratings for the reality show's thirteenth finale showed modest growth over last season. According to Nielsen's estimates, 10.6 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. for this season's final installment, up from 9.8 million who watched the series' twelfth conclusion in January.

A reader asked the question: "How did the Giants clinch the NFC East yesterday? The way I calculate it, if the Giants lose out and the Cowboys were to win out, then both teams would have identical 11-5 records, both would have identical 8-4 conference records, and both would be 1-1 in terms of head-to-head. So, what tie-breaker criteria was used to determine that the Giants have clinched the division?"

LAS VEGAS - Bernie Williams has not officially announced his retirement from baseball, but that is just a technicality. Williams has not played since 2006 and there are no rumors floating around about him at the winter meetings. Nor should there be. Besides, he has an album to promote in 2009.

I had the pleasure of moderating a talk by Helene Cooper, a Times colleague who has written a lovely and moving memoir that begins with her childhood in Africa. The book is The House at Sugar Beach," and it recounts Helene's youth in a rich and pampered elite family descended from the slaves who founded Liberia in the early 19th century. Later, Helene moves to America and becomes a reporter and writes indignant articles about racial oppression in Mississippi -- and realizes that it's an echo of the system she grew up with in Liberia, when she was on top.

LAS VEGAS - The Yankees' courtship of C.C. Sabathia took another step today when General Manager Brian Cashman had his second meeting with Sabathia and his agents. Speaking with the Yankees' beat reporters in his Bellagio suite this afternoon, Cashman revealed that he had met with Sabathia at the Wynn hotel for an hour at noon.

A few weeks ago, Olympus sent me its waterproof Stylus 1050 SW snapshooter and a pair of bulky ski gloves. Why the gloves? The 1050 SW is weatherproof down to 14 degrees, and has a tap-control feature that enables you to control a limited number of features by tapping on the top, sides, and back of the camera. So if you're skiing and want to snap off some photos without taking off your gloves, you can.

Economics | Name a "science" for which the Nobel Prize is "regularly awarded in close succession to winners who directly contradict each other," a columnist says. Answer: the pliable pseudo-science of macroeconomics. "Today's politicians collect favored economists the way princes of yore gathered court astrologers. But princes of yore never had handmaidens of media to amplify their special wisdom." [RealClearMarkets]

One of the great and sometimes burdensome aspects of the Minimalist column is that there is often food left over from testing sessions. In the last few weeks there has been an abundance of turkey parts, especially thighs. As you may have noticed I'm not the world's biggest turkey fan, but I don't believe in throwing food out and in any case in this particular instance I was curious to see if I could further build on my repertoire. Two turkey thighs feed four people -- even six, even maybe eight -- so I had ample opportunity.

The news that Mark Green, the former public advocate and onetime Democratic mayoral nominee, is considering running for his old job has shock waves across the city's political landscape, particularly in the crowded race for the city's second-highest elective office. Mr. Green is a seasoned politician who is certainly able to put together a well-financed campaign. And the prospect of his entering the race for public advocate -- the job he held from 1994 until 2001 -- is certain to cause candidates to revisit their strategies going into the 2009 Democratic primary.

One of the reasons that "Milk" is in the thick of things during this year's Oscar race is that the Gus Van Sant biopic is one of the few movies that has nailed an authentic romantic moment. "Australia" was shooting for the kind of romantic fireworks that made Hollywood such a cultural force to begin with, but to the Bagger's very eye, the opening subway scene was so unexpected and so full of yearning that it served as reminder that the well-done, meet-cute love scene is increasingly rare on the screen.

I have a lingering sentimental affection for Gertrude Stein - my bohemian great-grandfather participated in her Paris salons, and played matchmaker for her brother Leo and his wife - but the plain fact is that I've never had much patience for Stein's willfully obscure prose. That's O.K. Were she alive today, the feeling would no doubt be mutual. This year, the British Library released a three-disc set of its "Spoken Word" series devoted to American writers, and it leads off with a 1934 interview Stein granted to promote the opera "Four Saints in Three Acts." Even in speech, Stein is Stein (is Stein):

Kate Galbraith and Matt Richtel have a story about how the economic implosion has killed the market for recycled materials, as happens consistently in economic downturns. Basically, in communities with recycling programs -- which often have marginal economics in the best of times -- the flow of paper, plastic, and metals doesn't slow in sync with market prices for the stuff. The result is growing mountains of what begins to look like waste again, instead of a resource.

Kris Tapley at InContention surmises that Bruce Springsteen is the man to beat in this year's best song contest for his tune "The Wrestler." He explains that Darren Aronfsky, the film's director, never really understood the whole "Bruuuuuuuce!" thing until Mickey Rourke took him to a show. And more touchingly still, a large part of Mr. Springsteen's decision to write the cinematic ode had to do with his desire to help Mr. Rourke get up off the mat career wise.

Universal Pictures finally rolled out "Frost/Nixon" in limited release, and we do mean limited, with the film only playing in three theaters in Toronto, New York and Los Angeles. The studio hyperbole: "This is a tremendous launch."

For decades, people in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, have lived with the possible health hazards from oil spills in their industrial waterfront. Up to 30 million gallons of petroleum - almost three times the amount dumped off the Alaskan coast by the Exxon Valdez in 1989 - made their way into Newtown Creek and surrounding neighborhoods from dozens of refineries in more than a century.

Va., who refused to stop recycling -- even after the county said it would stop accepting anything but paper.

South Korea's money-losing Hynix Semiconductor is making progress toward raising new capital from creditors and direct backing from the government is not being considered, officials said Monday.

Ryan Kavanaugh, one of Hollywood's most prominent film financiers, was arrested for drunk driving, speeding and driving with a suspended license in October while still on probation for an earlier conviction for driving under the influence of alcohol, The New York Times's Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes report.

McClatchy, burdened by debt and a steep slide in newspaper advertising, wants to sell one of its most-prized properties, The Miami Herald, The New York Times's Richard Pérez-Peña reported, citing people briefed on the company's plans.

Marc Stuart Dreier, a high-living New York lawyer who has a gaggle of celebrity clients and a large firm that bears his name, was released from a Canadian jail on Friday after promising to return to court to face charges that he impersonated another lawyer on Tuesday at the offices of a large Canadian pension fund, The New York Times's Alison Leigh Cowan and William K. Rashbaum reported.

Finance | Today's bank bailout has ancient biblical echoes, a Jewish scholar writes. Back 2,000 years ago, in the time of King Herod, Rabbi Hillel the Elder had such trouble: a "liquidity crisis" brought on by the Book of Deuteronomy's dictate of debt forgiveness. Not to worry: Let's nationalize private debts! The difference today is the bailout is "not for the poor among us, but rather for Wall Street bankers." [Wall Street Journal]

Monday, 7:30 p.m. The hipsterish obsession with nostalgia (homburgs, knitting circles, jump-rope competitions) is partly a rejection of vapid modern culture, but also a distinctly wistful craving for a more authentic past. And what more authentic past to crave, in the throes of an unsatisfied adulthood, than the second grade? Thus, the finals of the Williamsburg Spelling Bee, where city sophisticates can forget their urbane worries by P-R-E-T-E-N-D-I-N-G to be 10-year-olds in a B-A-R. Across the Philippines, there were celebrations of Manny Pacquiao’s victory over Oscar De La Hoya. The president, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, congratulated Pacquiao (48-3-2, 36 knockouts) by telephone. De La Hoya (39-6), who was stopped for only the second time in his 16-year pro career, declined to come out of his corner after the eighth round in their bout in Las Vegas late Saturday night.

Eric Staal broke a tie for host Carolina with 4 minutes 9 seconds left, and Ray Whitney scored twice to help give Paul Maurice his first victory in his second coaching stint with the Hurricanes, 3-1, over Washington. Michael Leighton finished with 38 saves.

Benjamin Raich of Austria captured a World Cup giant slalom title, edging Ted Ligety of the United States by one-hundredth of a second. Raich won in a combined time of 2 minutes, 24.61 seconds on the Birds of Prey course in Beaver Creek, Colo. Bode Miller skidded off the course.

MELL--William Harvey, Jr. We deeply regret the sudden passing of William Harvey Mell Jr., 71, of Estero, FL, formerly of NJ on December 1, 2008. A 1958 Yale graduate, Harvey enjoyed a long and distinguished career in the investment community specializing in Municipal Bonds. Harvey headed Dillon Reads Fixed Income Department and became Partner under Nicholas F. Brady. In 1971, Harvey founded W.H. Mell Associates Inc. and remained Chairman of the Board until his death. Besides a successful bond business career, Harvey had various outside business interests such as The Sandpiper Inn of Spring Lake, NJ which he owned and operated with his wife Rosemary from 1994 to 2005. He had a passion for sports including tennis, gold and hockey for which he initiated the Delbarton hockey program. He is survived by his wife Rosemary DeCicco Mell, his three sons, William H. III, Courtney and Bradley, four grandchildren, four step-children, Michael, Andrew, Mark, Lisa and four step-grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held Wednesday December 10, 2008 at 10:00am at Christ the King Church in New Vernon, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Step Ahead 54 Main Street, Ste. 201 Succasunna, NJ 07876.

CNN has been testing a newspaper wire service in some 30 publications, and it held a meeting in Atlanta last week to introduce the service to more newspapers. The CNN brand is doing very well online: during the week ended Nov. 29, for example, it was second in visitor share only to Yahoo News in the news and information category. All of this is fed by the strength of the cable network news division. On election night, CNN led all cable networks in household ratings from 8 to 11 p.m. E.S.T., and all networks except for ABC from 8 p.m. to 12:30 a.m. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Mr. Obama had said he quit smoking at the beginning of his campaign for president, in early 2007.
