RACKMAN--Rabbi Emanuel. We share great sadness at the loss of our cherished friend, Rabbi, educator and mentor. As his first name ''Emanuel'' denotes, he taught generations to love and honor Hashem, His Torah, His People and His Land. Together with his dear wife Ruth OBM, he illuminated our ''Chukei Chayim'' and inspired thousands to pursue a life of nobility, integrity, personal growth and courage, scholarship and human concerns. Our deep sympathy goes to his exemplary family, to Michael and Judy, to Rabbi Bennett and Ruth, Joseph and Eliane and their families. May Hashem grant them strength, healing and consolation among the mourners of Zion and Yerushalayim. Leonard & Aliza Kestenbaum Jay & Chani Kestenbaum Jerry & Ruthie Kestenbaum

LENESS--George C.,on November 15, 2008 at the age of 72. Born on October 10, 1936, in New York City. Graduated from Harvard College, Magna Cum Laude, in 1958 and from Columbia Law School in 1961. Upon graduation he joined the law firm of Simpson, Thatcher & Bartlett. Subsequently became a partner in the firm of Hale, Russell & Stentzel, and then a partner at Winthrop, Stimpson, Putman & Roberts, from which he retired in 1992. He is survived by two brothers, John and Anthony, three nephews and three nieces. A Mass will be celebrated in his memory on December 10, 2008, 11:00am at Saint Jean Baptiste Church, Lexington Avenue at 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, a gift in his memory may be made to St. Bernard's School, 4 East 98th Street, New York, NY 10029.

GINSBURG--Miriam. Born in 1909 to Louis and Rose Halperin; wife of the late Meyer Ginsburg, M.D. Cornell University and Adelphi College (BA); Columbia University (MA). Books, theater, travel, music, and politics were lifelong interests. Her keen intellect, humor, and pragmatism will be missed by her daughters and their husbands: Laura and Peter Strauss and Alice and Gerald Padwe; her grandchildren and their families: Carolyn Strauss and son Owen Meyer Strauss; Diana Strauss Norwood and Kevin Morris; Jonathan Padwe, Jenny Grimm and sons Moses and Charlie; Elizabeth Padwe Muhlbaum, David Muhlbaum and daughters Sarah and Lily; nephews Lawrence and Daniel Horowitz. Gifts in her memory may be made to the Miriam Halperin Ginsburg Fund at the New Children's Center, New York Public Library at 42nd St.

Before, you could be green by being greedy. Now you've really got to rely more on your notions of civic participation. JIM WILCOX, a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, on the slump in the recycling market caused by the economic downturn.[A18]

ROBINSON--Dorothy Fay. On December 2nd, 2008, died peacefully at home after a long battle with cancer and Parkinson's disease which she fought with exceptional grace and courage. The daughter of Dorothy Mein Fay and Charles Fay, Dorothy was born in 1937 in San Francisco, CA. After graduating from the Garrison Forest School, Dorothy worked in the office of Vice President Richard Nixon in Washington, D.C. before coming to New York where she was a contributing editor of the magazine Art Voices. Later she was a founding member of the junior committee of Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital and was the events coordinator at the Natural Resources Defense Council for nearly 10 years. She had a lifelong interest in photography, started a Monday night cooking school for men, volunteered in the soup kitchen of the Church of Heavenly Rest and created a successful line of costume jewelry. But of all her accomplishments Dorothy's unique ability for friendship is what she will best be remembered for. Her charm, humor, loyalty and affection both in person and over the telephone endeared her to everyone who knew her. She is survived and will be greatly missed by her children, Gardner and Victoria; her sisters, Frances Bowes and Victoria Leonard; and three beloved grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Church of Heavenly Rest in New York at 3:30 on December 17th. Another service will take place in San Francisco in February. Donations in her memory may be made to National Resources Defense Council or The Parkinson's Stem Cell Research Fund at UCSF. 415-476-3953.

SCHER--Steven, died suddenly on Sunday morning. He leaves behind his wife Aimee, his son Hudson, his mother Myra, his brother Bob (Amy), his nephew Jackson and nieces Mo and Eliza. Services Tuesday 11:45am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Overshadowed in Oklahoma's 62-21 rout of Missouri in the Big 12 championship game Saturday night was that Sooners tailback DeMarco Murray injured his left knee on the opening kickoff and did not return. But his 30-yard kickoff return set a single-season team record for all-purpose yards at 2,171. Quentin Griffin had the previous record of 2,148 yards, set in 2002.

TREVOR--Florance (Floy) Rumbough, on December 2, at age 82. Lovingly remembered by son Thomas and his wife, Julie; son Henry and his wife, Elizabeth; grandsons Gareth, Kyle, Reece, and Colin; brother Wright and his wife, Missy; devoted caregivers Elisabeth and Zabeeda; and numerous nephews and nieces. She was predeceased by her husband, Paul, and her sister, Gay Lawson. Services will be held 11:00am Monday, December 15, at St. James Episcopal Church, St. James, L.I. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Trevor Day School in New York City.

DOPPELT--Minnie, of Whippany, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, died peacefully in her sleep Saturday December 6, at the age of 90. With her husband Jacob Doppelt, she was active in support of the Yeshivah of Flatbush, and served as President of its Ladies Auxiliary. She was a life member and officer of AMIT. She is survived by her brother, Rabbi Abraham Feldbin of Brooklyn; her devoted children Ira Doppelt of Charlottesville, VA, Sheila and Daniel Kurtzer of Princeton, NJ and Joyce and Arthur Miltz of West Orange, NJ. She was the proud grandmother of Jacob Kurtzer, Yehuda Kurtzer and Stephanie Ives, and David and Lucy Kurtzer-Ellenbogen and the doting great-grandmother of Gabri and Molly Kurtzer - Ellenbogen and Noah and Jesse Ives-Kurtzer. Funeral Service Monday 11am at Weinstein, Garelick & Kirschenbaum, 1153 Coney Island Avenue (corner Avenue H), Brooklyn. Shiva at the home of Sheila and Daniel Kurtzer, 19 Southern Way, Princeton through Thursday night and Saturday night and Sunday morning and at the home of Joyce and Arthur Miltz, 182 Zeppi Lane, West Orange, Friday Morning, Saturday evening and Sunday morning.

Quarterback Gus Frerotte left the Vikings' win over the Lions with a back injury. Vikings defensive end Jared Allen left briefly after Lions tackle Gosder Cherilus cut him down away from the ball with a block below the knee. Pirates of the Amazon Abandon Ship Last week, two students from the Piet Zwart Institute in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, devised a way for people who were browsing books, music and movies on Amazon.com to download the same products free through the Pirate Bay, the illicit BitTorrent site.

Funeral Services in New York City at 11am, Tuesday December 9, 2008 at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street.

Bring Your Dictionary Monday, 7:30 p.m. The hipsterish obsession with nostalgia (homburgs, knitting circles, jump-rope competitions) is partly a rejection of vapid modern culture, but also a distinctly wistful craving for a more authentic past. And what more authentic past to crave, in the throes of an unsatisfied adulthood, than the fourth grade? Thus, the finals of the Williamsburg Spelling Bee, where city sophisticates can forget their urbane worries by pretending to be a T-E-N-year-old in a B-A-R. A victory by the Buccaneers would give them a one-game lead in the N.F.C. South and a season sweep of the Panthers, in case the division race comes down to tie breakers. Tampa Bay cruised in the first meeting, 27-3, holding Carolina to 40 yards rushing and intercepting Jake Delhomme three times. It was a forgettable game for Panthers running back DeAngelo Williams, who was held to 27 yards, his lowest total of the season, and Tampa Bay's Warrick Dunn ran for 115. But that game might have been a turning point for each player: Williams has four 100-yard games and nine touchdowns since, and Dunn has averaged only 50.8 yards a game. ANDREW DAS

COUDERT--Frederic R. III, of New York City and Oyster Bay, NY died on December 5, 2008, age 76, after a valiant fight. Survived by his loving wife Marge, sister Paula Rand, daughters Cynthia and Sandra, as well as his grandchildren, Hailey, Bennett and Caroline Coudert - Morris. Fritz, a former partner of Coudert Brothers, was the President of the Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club and devoted his later years to many organizations connected to his beloved community of Oyster Bay, including The WaterFront Center, the Doubleday Babcock Senior Center, and the Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary & Audubon Center, among others. Funeral Services St. Dominic's Church, 93 Anstice St., Oyster Bay, NY, Tuesday December 9th at 11am. Wake visiting hours: Sunday December 7 and Monday 8, 2-4pm and 7-9pm, Beney Funeral Home, 79 Berry Hill Rd., Syosset, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club in the Bronx, NY or The WaterFront Center in Oyster Bay, NY.

Video: Selling Luxury and Cutting Costs In a video, Nelson Schwartz profiles Bulgari, the luxury goods maker, as it tries to sell its wares to a global public increasingly worried about its fiscal future. The first recession in luxury-goods sales in nearly 20 years has forced companies like Bulgari, Burberry, Cartier and Montblanc to modify their traditional focus on glamour and glitter, and start thinking about cutting costs.

While the spotlight was firmly trained Monday on Jay Leno, his NBC late-night colleague-in-training Jimmy Fallon was busy making some news of his own. In the first installment of his official video blog, Mr. Fallon, the former “Saturday Night Live” star, announced that he would take over hosting duties of NBC’s “Late Night” franchise on March 2. He also confirmed the rumor that the hip-hop group the Roots would be the house band of his new show, introducing them on his blog as “the greatest band in late night.” Mr. Fallon’s “Late Night” predecessor, Conan O’Brien, is scheduled to take over “The Tonight Show” on June 1. On Tuesday, NBC is expected to announce that Jay Leno will remain with the network in a new 10 P.M. show.

John Malkovich playing a serial killer? Ho-hum. John Malkovich playing a real-life Austrian serial killer in an experimental play that will have its debut in Austria? Now you’re talking. Agence France-Presse reported that Mr. Malkovich, the protean actor, would portray Jack Unterweger, an Austrian criminal, in a play called “The Infernal Comedy.” In the play, written and directed by Michael Sturminger, the Unterweger character recounts his life, during which he murdered 12 prostitutes and committed suicide in prison, while two sopranos representing his victims sing arias by Haydn, Mozart and Vivaldi. The play, which ran earlier this year in Santa Monica, Calif., under the title “Seduction and Despair,” is scheduled to have its Austrian premiere at the Ronacher Theater in Vienna on July 1.

Facing falloffs in ticket sales and donations, the Baltimore Opera Company was expected to file for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday, The Baltimore Sun reported. The company, which has been in operation for 58 years, has canceled its two remaining productions of the season, “Porgy and Bess” and “The Barber of Seville,” and has released its singers from their contracts, but plans to continue fundraising efforts. In October, The Sun reported, a shortfall of more than $200,000 in ticket sales for the company’s season-opening production of “Aida” led to a significant shortage of cash; last month, a board member had to guarantee performers’ salaries for a production of Bellini’s “Norma.” In a statement cited by The Sun, the company’s board said it was pursuing these steps “in order to preserve one of the region’s most significant cultural institutions.”

Even when Coldplay responds to accusations that they have plagiarized someone else’s music, gosh darn it if they aren’t the most polite rock stars in the business. Last week, the guitarist Joe Satriani sued the band for copyright infringement, saying that Coldplay had taken “substantial original portions” of his song “If I Could Fly” for their song “Viva La Vida.” In a statement reported by The Associated Press on Tuesday, Coldplay said, “If there are any similarities between our two pieces of music, they are entirely coincidental, and just as surprising to us as to him.” The statement added: “Joe Satriani is a great musician, but he did not write the song ‘Viva La Vida.’ We respectfully ask him to accept our assurances of this and wish him well with all future endeavors.”

A commencement speech given by David Foster Wallace will be released as a book in April, Publishers Weekly reported. The speech, which Mr. Wallace gave at Kenyon College in May 2005, was a commentary on the value of a liberal arts education as well as a send-up of commencement-speech clichés, beginning with a parable about two fish that seem not to understand what water is. The book, titled “This Is Water,” will be released by Little, Brown and Co., which published many of Mr. Wallace’s novels and non-fiction collections before his suicide in September. The book, with illustrations, is expected to run about 150 pages, and Little, Brown has said its initial print order will be about 40,000 copies.

Trivia question: How many players have won the Heisman Trophy and an Associated Press or Bowl Championship Series title in the same season? Think about this one for a moment. By definition, the Heisman is meant to reward college football's most outstanding player, not the best player on the nation's best team. And, by and large, the Heisman has maintained that separation throughout its history - though critics of the award's recent history may claim otherwise (see below).

Mickey Rourke may not be the best actor of the year, according to the Los Angeles Film Critics Association, which gave that honor to Sean Penn for "Milk." But while a runner-up in L.A., last night at a private screening for "The Wrestler" in New York, he was the object of much gushing.

Last week, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Justice accused William "Boots" Del Biaggio, a former Silicon Valley venture capitalist, with defrauding investors of $65 million. Such crimes could have been prevented with fairly simple background checks, argues Ken Springer. A former F.B.I. special agent who specialized in white-collar crimes, he now runs Corporate Resolutions, a firm that conducts investigations and background checks for venture capital and private equity firms, hedge funds and banks.

I love wine lists, both reading them and thinking about them. I especially love when a restaurant puts its wine list online so I can read it before a visit. That way I don't have to face the dilemma of chatting with my guests and not studying the selection or ignoring them to immerse myself in the list. I don't think restaurants realize how powerful a marketing tool this can be. Either that, or I care a lot more about wine lists than most people.

LAS VEGAS - After collecting and analyzing 2,232 bats broken during games last season, Major League Baseball and the Players Association have accepted the nine recommendations made by the Safety and Health Advisory Committee to combat the rise in broken bats. The recommendations will be implemented for the 2009 season.

Perhaps the most gratifying thing to happen since the start of this blog was the outpouring of advice to Aimee last week, when she wrote to describe her struggles with her 13-year-old daughter. Readers came back with caring, smart, in-depth, supportive answers, and she has checked in periodically to tell us things are getting better as a result.

There's rejoicing in Burbank and Emeryville today. "Wall-E," this year's Disney/Pixar release, was named best picture by the Los Angeles Film Critics Association, the first time the group has bestowed such an honor on an animated film.

For days now, Malcolm A. Smith, the State Senate's top Democrat, had been insisting to the public and to other Senate Democrats that he made no deal to win the support of three dissident party members who had threatened to back a Republican as the chamber's leader.And for just as many days, those three dissident members -- Senator-elect Pedro Espada Jr. and Senator Rubén Díaz Sr. of the Bronx, joined by Senator Carl Kruger of Brooklyn -- have insisted that Mr. Smith agreed to a long list of changes in the Senate, including appointing them to important committee spots and making Mr. Espada the Senate majority leader, a powerful position that would make him perhaps the top Hispanic-elected official in New York.
Anyone who has ever tried to lose weight knows it's tough to stay motivated. Researchers at the University of Pennsylvania wondered if cold, hard cash might do the trick.

The entrance to Oventic, a village in the Chiapas highlands about an hour north of San Cristóbal de las Casas, is easy to miss. It's a simple metal gate with nothing in particular to distinguish it. Cargo trucks and Nissan taxis roll by as they do anywhere else in the state, and in the cold fine mist of an October morning, Oventic seemed to vanish behind the gate into thick fog.

Foundation slabs were missing. Records of required safety tests on concrete were never produced. The Buildings Department repeatedly bungled inspections. But now the city's Board of Standards and Appeals has spoken in the case of 1610 Avenue S in Brooklyn, and it has said, "You may build." On Tuesday, the board voted that construction on a stalled six-story, 25-unit condominium in Sheepshead Bay, a lightning-rod for community opposition, could proceed, putting an end -- for now -- to a three-year tale that often seemed to unfold in a sort of bureaucratic twilight zone.

The two-hour series finale of "Boston Legal" attracted 10.2 million viewers on Monday as the dark comedy on ABC, concluding its fifth and final season, earned its largest audience of the fall, according to Nielsen's estimates.

President-elect Barack Obama met with former Vice President Al Gore for about 45 minutes this afternoon to discuss global warming and energy policy. Neither man shared much about their talks, but Mr. Obama said he was fully in agreement with Mr. Gore on both the science of climate change and the need to take aggressive action to combat it.

As icons of Corporate America struggle to stay afloat, they would do well to revisit the rules of private-equity investing -- that's the view of Jonathan F. Foster, founder and managing director of the private equity firm Current Capital. Mr. Foster was previously co-head of diversified industrials and services investment banking at Wachovia Securities and spent more than 10 years at Lazard, where he established a financial sponsors group that works with private equity firms.

An article in The New Republic argues that the Obama administration should help laid-off old media types (hey, don't look at me) by launching a new-style Federal Writers Project, modeled on the New Deal-era program that put the likes of John Cheever, Richard Wright and Zora Neale Hurston to work on oral histories, sociological studies and legendary guides to the 50 states.

Women | More women are drinking, and lately the women who drink are drinking more, an article says. "At the same time, men are reining in their drinking, meaning that the gender gap of alcohol consumption is narrowing all the time." The piece considers the roles of the workplace, college, feminism and marketing in the trend. "This is the kind of equality nobody was fighting for." [New York]

Eating well for less is the theme this week. Frank Bruni writes that on a recent week, "I ate out with dollar signs instead of stars in my eyes, choosing and using five restaurants over five nights with the aim of dining very well without spending profusely'' -- $99 for two, to be precise, including tax and tip, but no drinks.

Two professors in the Harriman Institute faculty in Columbia's School of International Affairs, Prof. Alexander Cooley of Barnard College and Prof. Lincoln Mitchell of SIPA, recently published an article in The Washington Quarterly, "No Way to Treat Our Friends,'' on the need to depersonalize and restructure U.S.-Georgian relations.

Greenwich Financial Services brought a purported class-action lawsuit against the Countrywide Financial Corporation in New York state court last week. The lawsuit challenges Countrywide's attempts to modify and reduce payments on as many as 400,000 subprime and pay-option adjustable-rate mortgages with borrowers who are seriously delinquent or about to become seriously delinquent.

Pragmatic: it's probably not the first adjective you would use to describe fashion's ubiquitous shoes-on-steroids, so overwrought that sometimes even veteran models can't operate them. As Suzy Menkes points out in a new IHT video interview with the shoe designer Giuseppe Zanotti, some of the latest designs are "on that borderline between something you'd find in a sex shop and something you'd find in a shoe shop." But for Zanotti, who apparently has 800 styles in his spring collection, it's not about the fetish - it's about striking a balance.

Education | An economist's case for merit pay, via Malcolm Gladwell: "The students of a very bad teacher will learn, on average, half a year's worth of material in one school year. The students in the class of a very good teacher will learn a year and a half's worth of material." And the school doesn't matter: "Your child is actually better off in a 'bad' school with an excellent teacher than in an excellent school with a bad teacher." [New Yorker]

Creating commercially useful power with fusion, in which small atoms are combined to produce energy, always seems to be decades away -- and too costly. Hedge fund managers are bracing themselves for some serious changes to their industry, according to Investment Dealers' Digest. The industry is suffering though its toughest period in years, and the fallout might include tighter regulation, lower leverage ratios, higher costs and longer lock-up periods, investment professionals and others who work with hedge funds told the Digest.

Someone bought the SUV. At factory price.

Cookies are always easy, but around the holidays, with time short and demand high, even they can use streamlining. One solution is to whip up a single batter and finish it in different ways. Just divide the dough into four parts and add lemon juice and zest to one quarter, chopped walnuts to the second, raisins to the third and coconut to the fourth. The variations are infinite -- post your ideas or suggestions in the comments section below -- but this basic batter is great plain too.

Updated, 11:30 a.m. | The Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, just concluded a news conference on the indictments of the officers charged in the Michael Mineo assault case. Mr. Hynes was flanked by a number of people from the district attorney's office and the Police Department. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly was not present because he had to attend a funeral, Mr. Hynes said.Mr. Hynes said that Officer Richard Kern was charged by a Brooklyn grand jury with aggravated sexual abuse in the first degree, assault in the first degree, and hindering an investigation, among other charges. A conviction on the most serious charge could result up to 25 years in prison. Officers Andrew Morales and Alex Cruz were also charged with hindering the investigation, he said. The arraignments are scheduled to take place this afternoon.

Since 2000, the Dominican Republic, China and Mexico have sent the most people to New York. First- and second-generation Africans and Caribbean immigrants now account for about 4 in 10 of the city's black residents. The number of young children living in parts of Lower Manhattan has nearly doubled. The poverty rate declined in all but one New York City neighborhood. And the number of white people living in Harlem more than tripled, helping to drive up median household income there by nearly 20 percent - the fourth-highest jump in the city. These details were revealed by the first detailed snapshot of New York neighborhoods released by the Census Bureau since the 2000 census.In almost every category, the results demonstrated the city's diversity and dynamism. In Sunset Park, Brooklyn, for example, the proportion of residents who do not speak English at home declined by more than 17 percent - an indication of gentrification in a heavily Hispanic and Asian area. But on the southern part of Staten Island, the share rose by 26 percent because of an influx of Chinese and Spanish speakers. (The area already had a significant number of Italian and Russian speakers.)

For weeks, there's been a growing chorus -- from the incoming Obama team to community-welfare campaigners and environmental bloggers -- pushing for building the economic revival around "green jobs." So far the focus seems to be mainly on rebuilding physical infrastructure: insulating leaky low-income housing, building wind turbines, improving the clunky electrical grid and the like. These are, by almost any measure, logical starting points for an effort to cut America's energy bill and carbon dioxide emissions while restoring prosperity.

Environment | The International Conference on Climate Change on March 8 in New York is a climate meeting with a difference, a columnist writes. The scientists and scholars attending are not "members of the gloom-and-doom chorus." Rather, these skeptics believe "science is not settled by majority vote, especially in a field as young as climate science." Further, "those who insist that dissent be silenced or even punished are not the allies of science, but something closer to religious fanatics." [Boston Globe]
Edward L. Glaeser is an economist at Harvard.

Ivory Tower | The real culprits in the meltdown were risk-management methods that "did not work and could provide undue comfort by hiding risks," two writers argue. So why do they continue to be taught to students in business schools? It's as if universities were airlines putting more aircraft in the skies "crash after crash." [Financial Times]

Few subjects have generated more interest here than long-term care insurance. And I've found myself both alarmed and amazed at how many of you think that such a policy is the all-purpose solution to exorbitantly expensive nursing homes, assisted living facilities, home health aides and other forms of "custodial care'' for the frail, demented or otherwise incapacitated elderly.

Language | John Milton, born 400 years ago today, was not just "the sublime English poet" but also the language's greatest word coiner, an article says. His 630 words make him England's top neologist, ahead of Ben Jonson (558), John Donne (342) and Shakespeare (229). Without him "there would be no liturgical, debauchery, besottedly, unhealthily, padlock, dismissive, terrific, embellishing, fragrance, didactic or love-lorn." Alas, there is no "opiniastrous," which the opinionated among us may rue. [Guardian]

San Francisco’s Golden Gate Yacht Club decided Monday to take its chances with a last-ditch appeal in a New York court rather than meet next week’s deadline for entering the next America’s Cup. The club, which backs the software tycoon Larry Ellison’s sailing team, BMW Oracle Racing, has been in court for more than a year fighting the two-time defending America’s Cup champion Alinghi of Switzerland over what it says are unfair rules for the next regatta.

Paul Azinger will not return as the United States captain in the Ryder Cup after leading the Americans to their only victory this decade. The P.G.A. of America will announce the new captain Thursday, with all indications that it will be Corey Pavin. The Americans have not had a captain repeat in consecutive competitions since Ben Hogan in 1949. ¶Harrison Frazar finished a memorable week that included a 59 by reaching his ultimate goal, closing with a five-under 67 at the PGA Tour qualifying tournament in La Quinta, Calif., to lead 28 players who earned their cards for next season. Notah Begay, a four-time winner on the tour, was one of only two qualifiers who faced the tougher TPC Stadium course in the final round. Two shots below the cut line with four holes to play, Begay ran off three birdies for a 67 to make it by one shot. qschool.

Sancho Lytle was the first player chosen in the W.N.B.A.’s dispersal draft of Houston Comets players, going to the last-place Atlanta Dream. The Washington Mystics chose Matee Ajavon, a former Rutgers player, with the second pick, and the Chicago Sky took Mistie Williams with the third selection during a conference call. Teams drafted in inverse order of their regular-season finish this past season. The Houston franchise announced last week it would disband because it could not find new ownership. Lytle, a 6-foot-4 forward, averaged 8.2 points last season.

Weston Naef, a curator who over the last two decades helped build the J. Paul Getty Museum’s photography collection into one of the most significant in the world, has said he will retire in January, the museum said Monday. Mr. Naef, 66, moved to the Getty from the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1984 after the Getty acquired several of the most important photography collections still in private hands. (Mr. Naef and the photographs arrived together: he served as a courier, accompanying 60 crates holding 18,000 images on an overnight flight to Los Angeles.) During his tenure Mr. Naef oversaw a quadrupling of the Getty’s photographic holdings, including the building of catalogs of work by pioneers like William Henry Fox Talbot, Julia Margaret Cameron, Roger Fenton, Gustave Le Gray and Carleton Watkins. The museum said it would begin a search for his replacement.

For all the parents of authors who have later appeared as characters in their children’s memoirs, this one’s for you: a memoir written by Margaret Robison, the mother of the memoirists Augusten Burroughs and John Elder Robison, will be released by the Spiegel & Grau imprint of Random House, the publisher said Monday. Random House said that Ms. Robison, 73, a writing teacher and poet, would write about being in an abusive marriage, raising her sons and recuperating from psychosis and a stroke in a memoir tentatively titled “A Place to Come Home To.” Mr. Burroughs has written of his childhood in books like “Running With Scissors” and “A Wolf at the Door”; Mr. Robison wrote of his battle with Asperger’s syndrome in “Look Me in the Eye.”.

After resolving a labor strike days before its annual gala opening, the Milan opera house La Scala found itself in another controversy when it abruptly replaced the lead tenor in its opening-night production with his understudy, The Associated Press reported. The Italian tenor Giuseppe Filianoti, above left, was to play the lead role in Verdi’s “Don Carlo” on Sunday but was replaced by the American tenor Stuart Neill, above right, after Mr. Filianoti made mistakes at a dress rehearsal. According to the Milan newspaper Corriere della Sera, Mr. Filianoti said he had been “stabbed in the back at the last minute,” adding that he was in “perfect condition, ready to engage myself in a role in which I feel secure.” After his performance, Mr. Neill told The A.P., “Tough crowd, but no, I wasn’t nervous at all.”.

CLUBS In Argentina, three teams -- San Lorenzo, Boca Juniors and Tigre -- are tied for the lead in the Clausura (closing tournament), all with 36 points and one match to play. Lanús, with 34 points, remains in striking distance. Since goal differential is not used as a tie breaker, a playoff will be used if two or more teams finish tied after Sunday's games.

The Tampa Bay Buccaneers and Carolina Panthers have developed one of the nastier rivalries in the N.F.L. And when they met on Monday night at Bank of America Stadium, they not only had a national stage to display it but a pair of 9-3 records and the National Football Conference South division lead on the line to add to the intensity. With so much to play for -- including a chance to move within a game of the Giants for the best record in the conference -- the game lived up to the hype until the fourth quarter, when the Panthers scored three touchdowns to run away with it.

SCADUTO--John. The partners of Nixon Peabody LLP mourn the loss of their esteemed colleague and friend, John Scaduto. John, senior counsel in the law firm's Long Island office, joined Nixon Peabody's public finance practice in 1992 upon his retirement as Nassau County Treasurer and Chief Financial Officer, a position he held since 1971. John was instrumental in the financing of countless public facilities and projects that enhanced the lives of millions of persons in New York and throughout the United States. We will miss John's wise counsel, warmth and humor. We extend our deepest sympathies to John's wife, Jeanne, and the entire family. Nixon Peabody LLP

DOPPELT--Minnie. Devoted wife of the late Jacob Doppelt, she leaves behind her children Ira Doppelt, Joyce and Arthur Miltz and Sheila and Daniel Kurtzer, five unique grandchildren and four joyous great-grandchildren. Aunt Minnie in her great and tender way was always there to lend support and counsel. She taught us with dignity, her great skills as a hostess and how to volunteer not just with money but with time devoted to charity work. For me, her niece Elissa, she was a second mother, she didn't take on that role after my mother's death, her sister Esther, she just always was there to share a laugh, wipe off the grass and the mud, and she gave the world's best hugs and kisses. She extended these gifts onto each new generation, I know Michael will truly miss her. I plan to always let her wisdom guide me and I will always keep her memory tucked within my heart. Elissa Sommer

MARTIN--Leslie, 71, a long time resident of Greenwich, CT, passed away peacefully in Hospice Care at Academy Point, Mystic, surrounded by her family and friends following a courageous 40 year battle with cancer on Wednesday, December 3, 2008. Born December 20, 1936 in New York, NY, she was the daughter of the late Robert R. Martin and Veronica Fisher Martin, grew up in Greenwich, graduated from the Greenwich Academy and Mount Holyoke College and earned her Master's Degree in Dance from NYU. Leslie spent her life in the pursuit of the Arts. She studied dance under Martha Graham, Robert Cohan, Merce Cunningham and Mary Anthony, and taught dance as Director of Dance at Greenwich Academy as well as Geneseo State and Hofstra Universities in New York State, and in her own studios in New York City, Holyoke, MA and Essen, Germany. She was a longtime Board Member and Editor of the Newsletter of The American Dance Guild and traveled to China, Hong Kong, Japan and Hawaii with several of its productions of the American Dance festival. She was an accomplished performer, choreographer, newspaper reviewer and critic of dance performances, a published writer and an interior designer. In 1995 she retired to her cottage. Leslie's Lair, in the Silvermine District in Norwalk. Leslie and her family were long term members of Larchmont Yacht Club where Leslie sailed in Lightenings and Atlantics. She and her sisters presented the Lipton-Martin Trophy to the Club on behalf of their father, who won the Trophy when it was originally offered by Sir Thomas Lipton and the Trophy continues to be awarded annually to the LYC cruising class yacht having the best performance during the Season. In addition to sailing, Leslie most enjoyed other spirited activities of swimming, skiing and driving responsive automobiles. Her classic 1964 Mercedes Benz 230SL Roadster was purchased new and restored in the 1990s, providing her with manv happy hours of touring throughout New England. She was predeceased by her sister, Mary Louise Martin Knapp, late of Portsmouth, NH and is survived by her sister Vera Martin Crawford, of Dorset, VT, six nieces and nephews and her Maine coon cat, the redoubtable Beasley. lnterment will be private: a memorial service will be held at 11am Saturday, January24, 2009 at St. Paul's on the Green, 60 East Avenue, Norwalk, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to Mount Holyoke College Class of 1958, 50 College Street, South Hadley. MA 01075 or to Beacon Hospice-Mystic, 12 Roosevelt Avenue, Mystic, CT 06355.

Just days after it appeared he might become prime minister, Stéphane Dion said instead on Monday that he would accelerate his previously announced departure as leader of the Liberal Party of Canada. The move increases the likelihood that Michael Ignatieff, a former director of a human rights center at Harvard University, could assume control of the party as soon as Wednesday.

The public appears somewhat torn over how far President-elect Barack Obama should go in celebrating his inauguration. More than 500 readers of nytimes.com responded to a question about how Mr. Obama should honor the start of his presidency. The responses brimmed with those who want a big celebration. ''This country needs a lift,'' one wrote. And, wrote another, ''People do want to feel good about this historic moment of change in America and be able to feel part of it.'' Another pointed out, ''Our brave men and women in uniform did not demand that we cancel the Super Bowl or the World Series or the Thanksgiving Day Parade.'' Another noted, ''If we can afford 700-billion-dollar bailouts, we can afford a proper celebration for this joyful, historic, hopeful, grand and glorious inauguration.''
Dot Earth From Andrew C. Revkin's blog, nytimes.com/dotearth.

He is survived by his best friends, Robin, Remy, Steven, and Zachary Arnold, and his loving dogs -Topaz and Happy (Mo, Paris, Luca, and Bruno too). Services will be held at noon, December 9, 2008 at: Riverside Memorial Chapel. 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY 10552. Gifts in Gary's memory should be made out to MDA/Augie's Quest and can be mailed to: 6 Lincoln Woods, Purchase, NY 10577.

After a month of heated debate and more than a week of official deliberation, the International Sailing Federation announced its support of a kiteboarder's claim to the outright sailing speed record. Three kiteboarders had broken the 50-knot barrier in Namibia in late October during an event sanctioned by the World Sailing Speed Record Council. The Sailing Federation contested the claim citing an outdated policy against kite-powered craft. After the announcement, the Record Council retroactively ratified Frenchman Alex Caizergues' 500-meter average speed of 50.57 knots. speed CHRIS MUSELER

Here is all you need to know about the esteem in which Greg Maddux is held in major league baseball: when he announced his retirement Monday in a conference room at the Bellagio hotel, Ned Colletti, the general manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, stood behind the rows of reporters, taking a photograph with his cellphone. ''I'm just here, really, to say thank you -- thank you to everybody in baseball,'' Maddux said, after an introduction by his agent, Scott Boras. ''I appreciate everything the game has given me. It's going to be hard to walk away, obviously, but it's time. I still think I can play this game, but not as well as I would like to. So it's time to say goodbye.''

BETTER MAPLE FOR BATS The manufacturers who make maple bats for major league players will be charged with making better and safer bats next season. Major League Baseball is expected to announce new regulations Tuesday at the winter meetings that are intended to decrease the number of shattered bats. Six months ago, Sam Holman, a batmaker who is considered the pioneer of maple bats, said that the breakage was caused by inferior wood. After collecting 1,500 broken bats and consulting wood experts, manufacturers and statisticians, baseball officials basically agreed. They will now require batmakers to start with better maple.

POMERENE--James Her bert, 88, of Chappaqua, a Computer Pioneer passed away on December 7, 2008. He was born in Yonkers, New York on June 22, 1920 to Joel Pomerene and Elsie Bower. A graduate of Northwestern University with a BS in Electrical Engineering, Pomerene worked with John von Neuman at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, NJ on the IAS machine, a prototype stored-program computer. Pomerene was Chief Engineer of the project from 1951 to 1956. He then joined IBM and began development of the Harvest machine, an early supercomputer for the government. In 1965, he headed a team that created a highly available memory system later known as Cache memory. Pomerene was named an IBM Fellow in 1976. He was a Life Fellow of the IEEE and a member of the Computer Society. Pomerene received the Computer Pioneer award in 1986, the prestigious Edison Medal in 1993 and the Eckert-Mauchly award in 2007. He was selected for the National Academy of Engineering in 1988 and was a mamber of Sigma Xi and Tau Beta Pi. A prolific inventor and holder of 37 patents related to computer architecture Pomerene retired from IBM in 1993. James is predeceased by his wife, Edythe (Schwenn) Pomerene, who passed away on January 22. 2008. They were married for 63 years. He is survived by his three children: James, Katherine and Andrew and his six grandchildren: Laura, Kathryn, Heather, Andrew, Austen and Paige and his two greatgrandchildren: Ayden and Logan. The family will receive friends at the Beecher Funeral Home in Pleasantville on Wednesday from 5-8pm. A funeral service will be held at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills on Thursday at 10am. Interment to follow at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla.

DONIGER--Beatrice. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Beatrice Doniger, beloved wife of the late William Doniger. Beaty was a dear friend, longtime supporter, and inspirational leader, who put her commitment to social and humanitarian causes into action as founding president and co-chair of the J.E. & Z.B. Butler Foundation, named after her late sister, Zella Bronfman. For nearly two decades, the Butler Foundation has collaborated with UJA-Federation and our network of agencies to build and expand a human-service system for people with disabilities and their families, helping to create a supportive and inclusive community. Beaty's commitment to UJA-Federation lives on through her generous Lion of Judah Endowment, which provides support to the Jewish community in New York, in Israel, and around the globe. We extend our deepest condolences to Beaty's sisters, Ruth and Mildred; to her children, Bruce and Allyson Doniger, Peter and Diane Doniger, David and Lisa Doniger, and Patricia and Richard Goldman; to her grandchildren, Debora and Greig Isdale, Pamela and John MacAffer, Andrew and Lisa Goldman, Jeffrey and Susan Goldman, Michael and Jeanne Doniger, Nicole Doniger, Sarah and Greg Parent, Scott and Rachel Doniger, and Perrin, Cynthia, and William Doniger; to her 10 greatgrandchildren; and to the entire family. COONS--Richard Foster, of New York City, Southampton, NY, and Palm Beach, FL died peacefully at home in Florida late Friday night, December 5, 2008, after a long and valiant fight against cancer. Dick received a BA from Princeton College and a MBA from Harvard Business School, and went on to become a highly successful international investment banker. Dick served as President of Baring Securities, Inc., Executive VP at J. Henry Schroder Bank & Trust Co., and Senior Manager of the International Department at Kidder, Peabody. He currently was a Founding Director of an Egyptian company, Coral Growth Investments, Limited. He was a member of the Royal Yacht Squadron in Cowes, England, the Knickerbocker Club in New York, The Meadow Club of Southampton, The Southampton Club, and the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, where he served as Commodore. Dick leaves his beloved wife of 27 years, author, and former WPIX-TV anchor and reporter, Kristi Witker, who also wrote the Beachcomber column for The Southampton Press, and their 24 year old son, Foster Morrell Coons. He also leaves his two sisters, Marian Coons Lacy of Longwood, FL and Ellen Coons Goble of El Cajon, California. Dick will always be remembered for his generous heart, thoughtfulness, integrity, warmth, and courage. He was loved by all who knew him and he will be greatly missed by his loving family and friends. A Memorial Service will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church in Southampton, NY at 11am on Saturday, December 13th. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Animal Rescue Fund (ARF), A.S.P.C.A. or The Humane Society would be greatly appreciated.

BERGER--Charles Martin, on December 8, 2008 at the age of 72. Served as chairman and chief executive officer of The ScottsMiracle-Gro Company from 1996 through 2001. Born in 1938 in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania to Edward and Sadie Berger. Graduated from Princeton University in 1958 and Harvard Business School In 1960. Married Jane Purdy of Newport, Arkansas in 1960. Started his career in marketing management at Procter & Gamble. He then enjoyed a 32-year career at the H.J. Heinz Company. Initially managing the Heinz ketchup brand, he later served in several executive roles with Heinz: including running Heinz's Italian operations from 1972-1979, serving as chairman and chief executive officer of Weight Watchers International from 1979-1994, and running its Indian operations from 1994-1 996. He was chairman of the Board of Directors of the Naples Botanical Garden; a member of the executive committee and board of directors of the Philharmonic Center for the Arts in Naples; the North Shore Hospital System in Long Island, NY; the southwest Florida chapters of the Worlds President's Organization and the Princeton Club; as well as the Harvard Club of Naples. He was previously a director of the Columbus Symphony Orchestra in Columbus, Ohio; the National Board of World Presidents' Organization; Buckley Country Day School in Roslyn, NY; the American School of Milan and the Harvard Business School Club of Milan. He maintained residences in New York City, NY, Sands Point, NY and Naples, FL. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Jane Purdy Berger. He is also survived by one brother, Sheldon Berger, and two sisters, Judy Tawil and Marcia Harris, three children, Cary, Elizabeth and Valerie, three grandchildren, Hazel, Eleanor and Cooper, and five nieces and three nephews. Services will be held Wednesday, December 10, 2008 at 10:30am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65 Street.

8 P.M. (BBC America) MY FAMILY The seventh season of this popular British sitcom begins with the 2006 Christmas episode. Ben (Robert Lindsay, left), the dispirited West London dentist, tries to get out of holiday obligations by pretending to be sick. But his wiseacre wife, Susan (Zoe Wanamaker), insists that he go to the doctor, who decides to run tests. Ben's private hospital room isn't too shabby, but he can't say the same for the crowded ward where he's sent when it's discovered that his health insurance has expired. 1 A.M. (13) DOC Harold L. Humes, right, known as Doc, went to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology at 16; founded The Paris Review with George Plimpton and Peter Matthiessen; wrote the political novels ''The Underground City'' and ''Men Die''; helped create the New American Cinema Group; championed the use of medical marijuana; designed a paper house that was both fireproof and waterproof; managed Norman Mailer's 1961 run for mayor of New York; and, after becoming mentally ill in the 1960s, reappeared as a hippie philosopher and paranoid, who insisted that the government was keeping tabs on him. Turns out it was. The filmmaker Immy Humes tells the story of her father.

MUNROE--John, Jr.,died on November 9, 2008 in Montego Bay, Jamaica after a long illness. He was born in Paris, France, May 8, 1924 where his father was associated with Munroe & Co., a private bank. His mother, Adelaide Sedgwick, was descended from many early founders of the United States. On his father's side he was descended from both early American stock and persons prominent in the French business community. Partly raised in Paris, he was educated in this country at the Buckley School in New York: St. Mark's School in Southborough, Massa chusetts: and Harvard College in Cambridge, Massachusetts. He was loyal to these institutions as well as Brantwood Camp in Peterborough, New Hampshire, the St. Mark's School camp for those who might not have had a camping experience otherwise, where he served as counselor and for many years as trustee. Entering Harvard in the fall of 1942, he soon like so many of his generation was in the Armed Forces. He ended his military career as a Lieutenant in charge of Gen. Hap Arnold's staff at the Potsdam Conference in 1945. Graduating from Harvard in 1949, he taught briefly at St. Mark's School. He lived frequently at Montego Bay in Jamaica where he was an early advocate of its delights, and where he dealt in real estate. He was a raconteur of note, a writer and reciter of a wide variety of limericks, and he enlivened every event to which he went and invariably raised the tone. He was loyal to those he was close to and to the institutions of which he had been part. He is survived by his wife Linda, daughter Adel Edwards of Phoenix, AZ and grandchildren David, Stephen, Deirdra and Christianna. Funeral services will be held at Grace Episcopal Church, Millbrook, NY at 11am Thursday, December 11.

BUDOFF--Penny Wise, M.D. Dr. Budoff died in her home in Delray Beach, Florida on December 6th, 2008. Wife, mother, physician, author, medical researcher, Dr. Budoff practiced on Long Island for 33 years. After suffering with rheumatoid arthritis from 1987-2007, she contracted ALS, (Lou Gehrig's disease) which caused her death from respiratory failure. She leaves Sy, her loving husband of 46 years, their son Jeff (a hand and upper extremity surgeon in Houston and editor of five surgical textbooks), his wife and their son and infant daughter. Dr. Budoff is predeceased by her beloved beautiful daughter, Cindy, died June 5, 2007 at 39 from diabetic ketoacidosis. In the 70s, her seminal research to alleviate menstrual pain was published in JAMA and later in the NEJM. Prior to her research, menstrual pain was thought to be a psychological affliction. This breakthrough established a biochemical basis for cramps. It brought instant television appearances in the U.S. as well as lectures in London and South Africa. Her first book was No More Menstrual Cramps and Other Good News (1980). The New York Times on September 16, 1982, called her ''a pioneer in women's health.'' Her second best selling book was ''No More Hot Flashes and Other Good News'' (1983). It cautioned women against radical mastectomy and unnecessary hysterectomies, giving them the detailed medical information they needed to question their doctors and share the decisions that affected their lives. Her first two books started a quiet revolution helping end the paternalism in women's medical care. In 1985, Dr. Budoff founded the first independent women's health center. Employing mostly women doctors, the center became a model for hospitals and other physician groups. It was featured in multiple women's and business magazines, including Time and Business Week. Gynecology, family practice, gastroenterology, cardiology, endocrinology, podiatry, dermatology, breast surgery and radiology were onsite. All doctors shared one chart so that there was no confusion about medications or blood work. Although she was not a surgeon, Dr. Budoff spent much of her time giving second opinions to women who were told they needed a hysterectomy or breast cancer surgery. In the 80s, she advised many of her patients to have a new procedure called a lumpectomy, rather than a radical mastectomy or mastectomy. Because of her expertise about hormones, she successfully treated many women who were told they needed a hysterectomy for bleeding problems, saving them major surgery. In 1982, Dr. Budoff formulated the first vitamins for women. Initially available only to her patients, the vitamins were expanded into a small mail order business named Bonne Forme. Dr. Budoff continued to supervise all product formulations. Her last book was ''No More Hot Flashes and Even More Good News'' (1998).

The widow of an assistant to the punk-rock musician Travis Barker filed suit against several companies involved in a plane crash that killed her husband, as well as the estates of the two pilots killed in the crash, The Associated Press reported. In September, Chris Baker, Mr. Barker’s assistant, was among four people killed when a chartered jet carrying Mr. Barker and the DJ Adam Goldstein home from a concert in South Carolina crashed on a runway. Otilia Villar Baker, Mr. Baker’s widow, has filed a suit against the companies that owned the jet, two charter companies that arranged the flight, and Goodyear Tire and Rubber. Mr. Barker filed suit against these same companies in November.

Jurors ruled Tuesday in favor of Tyler Perry, the writer, actor and producer, in a lawsuit filed by a playwright who said that Mr. Perry had stolen her material for his movie “Diary of a Mad Black Woman,” The Associated Press reported. Donna West, the author of a play called “Fantasy of a Black Woman,” had argued in a federal court in Marshall, Tex., that Mr. Perry could have seen the script when he presented his plays at the Dallas Black Academy of Arts and Letters in 1998. Mr. Perry testified last Wednesday that his script was an original work. In an email message to the A.P., a lawyer for Mr. Perry said, “We are very pleased that the jurors understood that Tyler Perry is an incredibly talented person who has no need to copy the work of others.”

It’s not all gloom and doom on the Los Angeles museum front: The J. Paul Getty Museum announced Wednesday that it had acquired a rare landscape by the 17th-century Flemish painter Roelandt Savery and a drawing by the sculptor Auguste Rodin. The Savery work, “Landscape With the Temptation of St. Anthony,” was painted in 1617 and depicts the saint reading in a rustic cell, obvious to demons frolicking around him. The Rodin work, probably from around 1898, is a brown wash and graphite drawing titled “Sphinx,” and depicts a naked female figure in what appears to be a desert landscape. Both works will go on view in the Getty’s East Pavilion on Tuesday.

Lucky for Judith Regan she left a big publishing house when the book business was relatively flush with cash. Ms. Regan, the outspoken publisher, was fired from her eponymous ReganBooks imprint of HarperCollins in 2006. She received $10.75 million to settle a wrongful termination lawsuit she filed against News Corporation, the parent company of HarperCollins, Bloomberg News reported. The settlement was disclosed in a legal filing by Dreier LLP, a New York law firm that Ms. Regan had retained for the suit. Dreier is now suing her, saying that Ms. Regan fired it to avoid paying her legal fees, including a portion of her settlement. Ms. Regan was fired from her book imprint for supposedly making anti-Semitic comments, after two books she planned to publish, including one by O.J. Simpson called “If I Did It,” aroused controversy. Dreier LLP’s founding partner, Marc S. Dreier, was recently arrested in what federal authorities allege is a $100 million fraud scheme.

Moviegoers waiting to see Benicio Del Toro with a thick layer of fur around his face — thicker than he wears in “Che,” anyway — will have to wait a few more months: Universal Pictures has delayed the release of its remake of “The Wolfman,” in which Mr. Del Toro stars as the hirsute monster, from April 3 to Nov. 6, Variety reported. The release was postponed so that more time could be spent on special effects. Universal will release “The Fast and the Furious 4″ on April 3 instead. The studio will also delay the Ridley Scott movie “Nottingham,” in which Russell Crowe is scheduled to star as both Robin Hood and the Sheriff of Nottingham, until 2010.

The comeback is officially complete: Britney Spears’s new album, “Circus,” (Jive/Zomba) hit the No. 1 slot on the sales chart in its first week of release, Billboard reported. “Circus,” Ms. Spears’s sixth album, sold 505,000 copies, making her the first artist since Nielsen Soundscan began tracking sales data in 1991 to have four albums make their debut with sales of 500,000 or more. (2Pac, 50 Cent, Garth Brooks and Jay-Z have each had three albums reach that mark.) Taylor Swift‘s “Fearless” (Big Machine) remained in second place with sales of 193,000, while Beyoncé‘s “I Am … Sasha Fierce” (Music World/Columbia) took third with 153,000. Kanye West’s “808s & Heartbreak,” which opened at No. 1 last week, fell to fourth with 142,000. The Guns N’ Roses album “Chinese Democracy” dropped out of the top 10, to No. 18, with sales under 57,000.

If anything can help us forget the dreary economic climate, it’s…the hilarious, good-time antics of Neil LaBute? The play, to be directed by Terry Kinney, is scheduled to begin previews at the Lyceum Theater on March 612 and open on April 2, making it Mr. Labute’s first show to be performed on Broadway. “reasons to be pretty,” about a group of friends thrown into turmoil by one member’s comments about a female co-worker, played Off-Broadway earlier this year at the Lucille Lortel Theater. That production starred Piper Perabo, Alison Pill, Thomas Sadoski and Pablo Schreiber; a cast for the Broadway transfer has not been announced.

My Thursday column calls for Barack Obama to forget about choosing a "Secretary of Agriculture" and instead pick a "Secretary of Food." Whenever I say nasty things about farm subsidies I feel as if I'm betraying my farmboy roots, but the truth is that subsidies and industrial farming have been bad for agriculture, bad for small towns like mine (Yamhill, Oregon) and bad for the environment. And when industrial farmers help determine the school lunch program, it's no wonder we have an obesity crisis.

Years ago, I had had a run of terrible luck in my life. My career was going nowhere. I thought about going to see a shrink, but I was totally broke and I didn't want to get myself involved in anything that was going to cost me lots of time and money. So I went to see a psychic. In my mind, it was just like seeing a shrink, only instead of wasting all that time mulling over my past, I could set some totally arbitrary goals and navigate my life through them, moving forward.

The current issue of AutoHebdo, the French motor racing magazine, which was published today, adds an interesting layer to the theories of exactly why Honda may have pulled out of Formula One. A story by Patrick Camus, who has reported on the sport for some three decades, quotes Takeo Fukui, the president of Honda, speaking to a select group of journalists off-mic after his official statements. The story says that Fukui said, in my translation from the French: "It is not only the financial crisis that forced us to decide this way [to withdraw from F1], but the huge change in the auto industry that the crisis will bring about. The industry has worked well for 100 years, but it will work in a different way henceforth. It will be necessary to restructure our manner of thinking, including technically. And Honda will have to redistribute its budgets differently, not only to get over this crisis but to advance more quickly than the others in certain fundamental sectors between now and five years from now. This is the way we will pass ahead of those who do not follow our lead. .... F1 had a huge impact for Honda in terms of business. We must henceforth think about other things."

The Mets and Francisco Rodriguez first came to terms on the numbers that matter to his paycheck -- three years and $37 million -- and now they've settled on which number he will wear on his back.
If we want our children to be scientifically literate and get good jobs in the future, why are we spending precious hours in school teaching them to be garbage collectors?
Few people know if their phone has stereo Bluetooth, which may explain why sales of wireless stereo headsets lag behind the mono models clipped on ears nationwide.
From the sublime (see item below on Harman's $1,000 PC speakers) to the sort-of silly: iHome's iPod speaker dock goes Nano-chromatic.
Continuing an occasional feature in which we quote Kris Jenkins, the voluble defensive tackle for the Jets.

A slip of the tongue by British P.M. Gordon Brown who, at Prime Ministers Questions, instead of saying "We not only saved the banks " said "We not only saved the world ."
A look at holiday shows that are short and sweet.
A bankruptcy judge in Delaware allowed the Tribune Company on Wednesday to make some payments to employees, vendors and others as it works through a Chapter 11 reorganization.

When gas prices hit their peak earlier this year, you could hardly glance at the news without seeing a report about the growing shift toward two-wheeled transportation. This media trend embraced scooters, motorcycles and bicycles. (More examples here, here, here and here.)
Houses on the market in Alpine, Wyo.; Liberty, Me.; and St. Helena Island, S.C.

It's been a few days since American Banker's Banker of the Year Awards were handed out. But the topics discussed at the black-tie gala, held at the Plaza in midtown Manhattan, are still very much on people's minds.

Warner Brothers has not been shy about pushing "The Dark Knight" in the Oscar race, and the early (huge) numbers on its DVD release can only help convince voters to take another, closer look at the box-office juggernaut and critical darling.

Moviegoers remember its cameo in the 1998 romance "You've Got Mail." But the real-life shop around the corner, Maya Schaper Cheese and Antiques, is closing.It has been a fixture on West 69th Street since the mid-1990's, with cheese at the front counter and furniture, small silver collectibles and movie posters in the rest of the shop (including one, not for sale, for "You've Got Mail," in which the cheese and coffees were replaced by books, and the words on the awning out front were changed to "Shop Around the Corner").

LAS VEGAS - At a long news conference here Wednesday morning to promote the World Baseball Classic, USA Baseball formally announced that Davey Johnson would manage its team at the tournament in March and that Derek Jeter would be on the roster.
UPDATE: Audi has not yet disclosed the subject of the commercial; it may or may not be the R8, the model advertised last year.
Did John A. Thain, the chief executive of Merrill Lynch, really deserve a bonus this year? That question has caused quite a ruckus over the last few days -- especially on CNBC.

The scramble to replace Senator Hillary Clinton is still in tryouts, and that means a lot of people besides professional politicans are asking for the job. Only one, however, appears to be publicly whining for it. That would be Fran Drescher, the television nanny whose trademarks are her industrial strength Queens accent and a laugh that might be particularly useful against glass ceilings.
You've got questions?
I was standing on Lexington Avenue and East 71st Street a few days ago and saw a man in raggy clothes pushing a cart of belongings up the avenue.

After months of discussion on whether and when to ask its membership for strike authorization, the Screen Actors Guild made the move official on Wednesday, announcing that ballots to the membership will go out on Jan. 2. The timing means the Golden Globes won't have to worry about re-living last year's debacle of an event, but a strike (or even a strike authorization) could wreak havoc with the Academy Awards. Brooks Barnes offers this look at the jockeying going on inside SAG.
Perfect selections for the man looking for timeless classics made to last.
A New York couple is betting on the idea that at least one thing is recession-proof: demand for a convenient and clean public toilet.
