Incoming | From Laugh Lines reader Norm M:
Where is the Expedia or Amazon.com of local news?
They wrote songs about the "Streets of Philadelphia" and "The Sidewalks of New York." But as Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich demonstrated this morning, Chicago is a city where the alleys rule.
Nuts are a big part of many holiday celebrations, whether it's pecan pie, chestnut stuffing or just a handful of cashews grabbed at the office party.
In this 17th-century brick house, located 70 miles from Buenos Aires, concrete floors, bordered in ceramic tiles, run throughout the common areas.

Sageworks, a firm that tracks financial information on privately held companies, recently sent Economix some data on the bottom 35 industries by sales growth (or declines) over the last 12 months. The list of hardest-hit industries is at the end of this post.
The Federal Trade Commission has removed the last regulatory hurdle for Verizon Wireless's acquisition of the Alltel Corporation, in a deal that will create the country's largest wireless carrier.
Through Eric Musselman's blog, coaches share stories and tips on how to motivate, how to teach, how to win. He has agreed to plug us into his network periodically.
“Dearest Mumma, I’m reading North and South by Mrs Gaskell at the moment. Some of it is very good — and the acid humour is most pleasant.”
In Marrakech, Morocco, this 19th-century palace has been under renovation for 18 months. It now includes two master suites and eight guest suites, all with one or two bathrooms.
LAS VEGAS -- Omar Minaya was in his hotel suite at 3 p.m. on Tuesday, and he looked exhausted. "Late night," he explained.
Oshawa forward John Tavares and Tri-City goaltender Chet Pickard have been selected as the players of the week in the Canadian Hockey League.
From our friend at the Dot Earth blog:

ZSC Lions Zurich of Switzerland and Salavat Yulaev Ufa of Russia, each leaders of their domestic leagues, moved one step closer to being crowned Europe's best club by winning the first legs of their Champions Hockey League semifinals on Wednesday.

Updated, 4:30 p.m. | The exterior of the Greek Consulate on East 79th Street was defaced with black graffiti and a rock was thrown through one of the windows some time before dawn, the police said on Wednesday. There have been no arrests, the police said.
Barack Obama plans to use his full name, Barack Hussein Obama, at his inauguration.

The estimable Robb Walsh claims to have discovered the best barbecue sandwich in Texas. In the course of telling the world about it, he also manages to take a swipe at Calvin Trillin's recent New Yorker article on, yes, the best barbecue in Texas. In Trillin's piece, that honor goes to Snow's Barbecue in Lexington. Walsh has something to say about that:

United States Attorney Patrick J. Fitzgerald took a fairly unusual legal step on Tuesday by deciding to arrest Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois and his chief of staff, John Harris, based on the information in a criminal complaint, rather than waiting for a grand jury to indict them.
The drums are beating once again for a deal between Yahoo and Microsoft.

Lemmesee, the Los Angeles critics fall for a love story between two darling heterosexual robots in an animated futuristic fantasy, while the New York critics go for a visceral biopic about a lion of the gay rights community. Hard to reconcile those picks, although there is one (small) connection between the two movies: many of the more fervent fans of "Milk" may share Wall-E's love of the song and dance numbers from "Hello Dolly."

Updated, 4:55 p.m. | Ouch. Again. For the second time in about three months, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is ordering all city agencies to trim their spending. The additional cuts of 7 percent, or $1.4 billion, would commence in July, the start of the 2010 fiscal year, and continue indefinitely, the city's budget director said this week.They would come on top of the previously demanded 5 percent cuts, or $1 billion, from Mr. Bloomberg in late September. Those cuts are set to begin on a prorated schedule in January.

Among other findings from a survey released today by the Consumer Electronics Association, an industry group representing computer and gadget manufacturers, 89 percent of consumers said that energy efficiency would be a factor in choosing their next television -- even as less than half of the 960 people surveyed said they're generally able to make sense of the environmental attributes attached to electronics on the market.

Sigi Schmid has shown time and again during his career that he is a supremely competitive person. And after winning the M.L.S. Cup with the Columbus Crew, the second team he has taken to the top of Major League Soccer, Schmid will seek a new challenge.

Yahoo began laying off 1,500 workers on Wednesday as part of a plan, announced in October, to slash expenses by $400 million a year. The cost cutting, however, may have to go deeper in the coming year.
If the governor refuses to step aside, the Illinois Legislature should move to bypass him by removing his appointment power, impeaching him or scheduling a special election.
The editors of T Magazine present What Gives, a guide to holiday gifting.

Crime | How F.B.I. wiretaps work: It's a "point-and-click surveillance system" that "connects F.B.I. wiretapping rooms to switches controlled by traditional land-line operators, Internet-telephony providers and cellular companies," released documents show. "It is far more intricately woven into the nation's telecom infrastructure than observers suspected." [Wired]

A central question of the Blagojevich case is the extent to which it ultimately touches Barack Obama and his top aides. The prosecutor, Patrick J. Fitzgerald, took pains to say that Mr. Obama was not implicated in the case. But some conservative commentators and right-leaning websites are using the scandal to highlight the president-elect's ties to Chicago's often-maligned political culture and to question the extent of contact between Mr. Obama's team and Gov. Rod Blagojevich and his aides. Here's a sampling of the commentary:

Is a rent-stabilized tenant obligated to inform the landlord that it is time for a renewal lease? I am a longtime rent-stabilized tenant and don't intend to leave my apartment, so I don't want to do anything foolish. Doesn't the law require that the landlord offer a new lease to a rent-stabilized tenant in good standing? If I have read correctly, the landlord also cannot begin charging the new rental rate until at least 90 days after the tenant receives the new lease offer. Is this correct?

While I understand the fundamental differences between a co-op and a condominium, I am curious about the monthly charge. If one were to compare the maintenance charge in a co-op with the condo's common charge (plus real estate taxes) in identical buildings, would the maintenance and common charges be different, and, if so, why?

In political circles and on op-ed pages, among top politicians and ordinary citizens, a single question seemed to dominate the conversation across Illinois on Wednesday: what to make of Governor Rod R. Blagojevich and the explosive, expletive-laden criminal complaint against him?

Nora S. Anderson, who last month won the election for Manhattan Surrogate's Court judge, was indicted Wednesday on charges that she concealed the source of $250,000 deposited into her campaign account to make it appear as though the payments came from herself.

Based on the Mets' (relative) bargain deal with Francisco Rodríguez, and after listening to Omar Minaya and Jerry Manuel on Tuesday, I think it's pretty clear that they feel they'll have a decent shot at re-signing Oliver Peréz and that the likelihood of Luis Castillo's returning improves each day.

Environment | Will it be real or artificial for this year's tree? A green columnist says: better to kill trees! The polyvinyl chlorides used in fake Christmas trees "are just too worrisome, and so is the disposal issue." But best to buy your real tree locally to cut transport-fuel costs. Even better yet (if available): a potted live tree that can be replanted. [Slate]

Frederick Douglass was never more misguided than when he declared in an 1876 address that "no man can say anything that is new of Abraham Lincoln." By at least one count, more has been written about Lincoln than about any other historical figure except Jesus. Nonetheless, we are being deluged with books on him this year, and we can expect the waters to keep rising into the next. The reason is that 2009 is Lincoln's bicentennial. No facet of his life, it appears, is too small to be allowed to rest in peace.

Following is the first set of responses from Paul LeClerc, the head of the New York Public Library, who is answering selected readers' questions about the library, its services and its future in an era of changing information needs. Sorry, we are no longer taking questions for this feature.
XL Capital, the big Bermuda-based insurer, is reported to be seeking a buyer, but Wall Street appears to have doubts that it will readily find one.
Celebrity shenanigans make headlines. But do we need a blog devoted to their mental health issues?

In Manhattan, they're asking what happened to the "Pepsi-Cola" sign. In Queens, they're asking what happened to the "aloC-ispeP" sign. In both cases, the answer is that it has been temporarily dismantled and will be reinstalled nearby. In any case, the Hunters Point waterfront will not lose this distinctive, ruby-red, 120-foot-long, 72-year-old presence.
The worst-case scenario of the current economic downturn: Great Depression Two.
On Tuesday, I wrote that one of the advantages of biodiesel made from algae is that it can be easily piped -- unlike ethanol, which is transported by other means.

The N.H.L.'s Board of Governors meeting concluded Tuesday in Palm Beach, Fla., (Times story here) and the headlines concerned the salary cap, which is expected to hold relatively steady next season but will probably plummet in 2010-11. That means teams with lucrative long-term contracts will either have less cap space for remaining players or have to buy out some of those deals.
There's a mythology about the glamorous life of a White House correspondent that often bears no resemblance to real life.

Independent movies dominated the New York Film Critics Circle Awards, whose winners were announced Wednesday by the 73-year-old organization, with "Milk" claiming three awards. Gus Van Sant's biographical film about the politician Harvey Milk was named best picture; its star Sean Penn won best actor, and co-star Josh Brolin won best supporting actor.

The optimism of global leaders for clean energy technologies appears to be slipping a bit in the face of the global financial situation and the sheer scope of the climate problem -- at least as it is reflected in a survey released this week at the global summit on climate change in Poznan, Poland.
Every year at this time I struggle with the idea of stuff. How much is too much? And do the people I give it to in the name of the holidays (my children, in particular) really need any more?
The question making the rounds: What about Weiner?

President-elect Barack Obama said Wednesday that Gov. Rod Blagojevich should resign from office, adding his voice to a long list of Illinois political leaders who have called on Mr. Blagojevich to step down.

With the buzz circulating around baseball's winter meetings that the Red Sox are hot for Mark Teixeira, it's interesting to note that this isn't the first time the two sides have negotiated on a contract.
Why was the mouse - the one I'm using to help write this - not called a squirrel? Or the computer rat?
Go for Broke is a column about big purchases worth rationalizing.

Finance | Bailouts around the world could lead to yet another massive shock, a columnist writes -- a widespread collapse of currencies, and a new inflation. After all, investors lost trust in banks -- why not currencies? "This is the one and only one, and probably last, shock that the credit crunch has yet to impose on a still unsuspecting world." [Spectator]

--Nina Lentini reports in MediaPost on Discover's new biodegradable credit card, which the company says is the only one on the marketplace. We applaud any attempt to recycle, but is a card that disappears before its average user's balance does such a good idea?
Just in time for holiday gift-giving, a pair of computer desktop speakers that cost twice the price of my first car.

A few weeks ago I spoke with a sales rep at a Best Buy retail store in New York who predicted that the compact Flip videocamera would be the breakout hit of the holiday season. Then a few days ago I got a press release from the marketing director of a Web site called Fixya.com, a tech-tip hang-out with 10 million members that has already crowned the new Flip MinoHD is the hottest gadget of 2009.
I can't wait to see reader comments about the ridiculously easy sorbet recipe that is the core of this week's Minimalist column and video. Post them below.
Updated 1:20 p.m.
What's that line about necessity being the mother of invention? It looks like the major TV manufacturers all must have the same parents.
Will Blu-ray survive? With sales at a fraction of standard DVD players, and prices still five to six times more than DVD machines, it's a question worth asking.

City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. underscored that he was serious about running for mayor, when his campaign site, Thompson2009.com went live on Wednesday morning. (In an interview published on Tuesday on City Room, Mr. Thompson said he still intended to run for mayor.)
Ah, bribery in the age of the Internet. This sort of feels like a Shouts & Murmurs piece.
A favorite winter pie in the northern regions of Greece, this dish is worth every minute it takes to prepare.

Though a handful of other contenders are already eying his job, Republican National Committee chairman Mike Duncan announced his re-election bid on Wednesday, vowing a return to the party's "core conservative principles."
Update | 3:25 p.m.
Protesters marched on parliament during a union strike on this fifth day of violence in Greece.

Barack Obama and Joseph R. Biden Jr. will be joining a national day of service on Monday, Jan. 19, the day before they are sworn in as president and vice president. This event, reported earlier in The New York Times, comes from an official outline of their schedule, which was just released.
John Doyle, an Irish-born TV Columnist for The Globe and Mail in Canada, is writing a book about soccer. "All The Rambling Boys of Pleasure," will be published by Doubleday Canada in 2010.

History | This year marks the 75th anniversary of a holocaust that the West has largely forgotten, an article says -- the great famine Ukrainians call Holodomor, "murder by starvation." Untold millions died in 1932-33 as Stalin tried to bend the peasantry to forced collectivization. "Indeed, the West has its own inglorious history with regard to the famine, starting with the deliberate cover-up by Pulitzer Prize-winning New York Times correspondent Walter Duranty." [Weekly Standard]
From the New York Times bureau in Cairo:

The State Senate leadership deal reached late last week has collapsed, Senator Malcolm A. Smith, the current minority leader, said on Wednesday morning. That means that Mr. Smith, a Queens Democrat, may not become the president pro tempore of the Senate when the new legislative session begins in January.

Books | How the Web gives non-fiction books happy endings: more and more authors are setting up blogs -- "blooks" -- to supplement and update published work. "Alex Ross's blook for his outstanding work of criticism, 'The Rest Is Noise,' amounts to a voluminous and hugely illuminating appendix to the published work." Similarly, "Freakonomics." [Guardian]
The number of adults suffering a common cause of blindness will triple by 2050, according to a new study.
Nearly 15,000 people went to see college basketball's leading scorer Tuesday night at the Jimmy V Classic and saw a guy who missed 18 shots and committed 8 turnovers.

This cod dish from Liguria, Italy -- whose seafood I've raved about before -- should be eaten with pepper, not lemon. In fact, a friend insists a waiter there once grabbed a piece of lemon out of his hand, substituting a pepper mill.
The latest health news from around the Web.

The police shot and killed a man wielding a bat in a Bronx apartment building on Tuesday night, officials said. The authorities did not immediately release the name of the dead man, but people at the scene, including the man's wife, identified him as Alex Figueroa.

The point man for the government's $700 billion financial rescue package said Wednesday that the program is working, even as he faced a phalanx of lawmakers expressing anger about how the plan is being handled.

The Bagger interviewed Meryl Streep for a forthcoming bit in the dead tree version of his universe. She may have been battling a vicious cold, but she just hacked her way through the press opportunity with grace and alacrity.
A two-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bathroom, former Jesuit monastery, near Lobos, on five acres for $400,000.

You can already hear the ESPN jingle, can't you? "It's the most wonderful tiiiiime, of year." Ah, the sweet music of bowl season. With the bowl gauntlet being announced on Sunday night, here is a look at the five matchups that I'm most looking forward to.
Three numbers, courtesy of Howard Silverblatt of Standard & Poor's, shed some light on what companies did with their cash during boom times:
David Carr, the Carpetbagger, gives his own daily take on awards season news.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich is now in Federal custody on corruption charges. They say he conspired to sell the U.S. Senate seat held by Barack Obama. Remember he left it vacant? Blagojevich was trying to sell it to the highest bidder. Yeah, now, I don't want to say he was brazen about it, but he did it on eBay. Come on!
What we're looking at on the Web today ...
Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: I love New York City, especially at the holidays. And speaking of the holidays, today, Sarah Palin went out and shot a Norway spruce.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Our government right now is still trying to work out a bailout for the auto industry. Yesterday, President Bush said, "It's hard to tell if a deal with the automakers is imminent." Then Bush said, "It's also hard to tell if the big hand's on the 11 or the 12."

I met the sociologist Fred Block at a recent symposium in Washington, D.C., exploring how to ensure that the Obama administration's planned burst of government spending to revive the economy, while rebuilding roads and insulating leaky buildings, also invigorates the country's eroding "intellectual infrastructure."

LAS VEGAS - If you've spent the off-season trying to configure the Yankees' starting rotation, it is safe to finally put C.C. Sabathia at the top of the list. General Manager Brian Cashman has everything but an official, signed contract in place after meeting with Sabathia and his agent in San Francisco overnight. There are no obstacles remaining to a deal.
Ramius, the activist hedge fund, has followed through on its threat to seek the ouster of four directors of Orthofix International, a maker of orthopedic equipment.

Updated, 1:40 p.m. | The unresolved contest between State Senator Frank Padavan, a Republican, and his Democratic challenger, James F. Gennaro, is moving closer to resolution. In a hearing on Wednesday, a State Supreme Court judge ruled that about 2,000 disputed paper ballots be counted. At the moment, Mr. Padavan, a longtime incumbent, is leading by about 580 votes. And the issue of the validity of a number of paper ballots has been a matter of bitter contention between Democratic and Republican lawyers.
Charles Bock is the author of "Beautiful Children," a novel.

A scant hour ago, the New York Film Critics Circle began the voting for its awards. If history is any indication, there will be sturm, drang, speeches, subcaucuses and intrigue. And voting. There will be voting. Some time around noon East Coast, there will be results as well. Will the New York film critics fall into step behind their peers in LA and pick the cuddly robot?

Debevoise & Plimpton has become the latest white-shoe New York law firm to slash bonuses for its associates. In an internal memo sent to associates Tuesday evening that was obtained by Dealbook, the firm's presiding partner, Rick Evans, thanked the associates for their hard work but offered no explanation as to why their bonuses had been cut in half from last year's levels.
Google provided a list of search queries made by people sitting at computers in New York City (and across the country) as part of their annual tradition of the zeitgeist-in-review.

Los Angeles can be a disconcerting place for the rest of us, particularly the Bagger. For one thing, the whole city is buried in billboards at this time of year for movies and television shows. A visitor can't help but wonder if Los Angeles really consumes that much more culture than the rest of the nation. On a single block in West Hollywood, the Bagger saw Clint, Cate and Brad, Will, with a little Britney thrown in for good measure.

The little robot continues to pile up the treasures. As the Baguette wrote yesterday, the Los Angeles film critics, a pretty serious-minded bunch, picked "Wall-E" as best picture. The Broadcast Film Critics Association included it among the nominated best films. Time magazine chose it as its No. 1 movie of the year. Roger Ebert and Anthony Lane also love the little guy, as does our own A.O. Scott.
When she started wearing hearing aids, journalism instructor Grace Lim discovered the toll her hearing loss had taken on family and friends.

Even as Washington considers whether or not to extend a lifeline to Chrysler, another company controlled by the powerful private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management has hit a serious bump in the road.

Among the more readily adopted methods for securing landfill waste is the installation of compacted clay caps. A new study, however, argues that using soil and plants instead of clay is both more cost efficient and eco-friendly.

The corruption scandal involving Illinois Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, who federal prosecutors said tried to sell Barack Obama's vacant Senate seat, presents some tricky problems for Mr. Obama who sought on Tuesday to distance himself from the governor.

Stephen Brunt, a sports columnist for The Globe and Mail, responded to a few questions via e-mail about the future of Bills games in Toronto. We ran a quotation from him in a print article this morning but have more room here for his full thoughts.Here were my e-mailed questions to him (I asked Dave Perkins of The Toronto Star the same questions, in the post below): Can you explain the conflicted feelings in Toronto about hosting occasional Bills games? Or are reports of angst overblown? Would a majority of fans be in favor of a permanent move to Toronto, and do you think such a franchise would be successful?

We ran a quotation from him in a print article this morning but have more room here for his full thoughts.Here were my e-mailed questions to him (I asked Stephen Brunt of The Globe and Mail the same questions, in the post above): Can you explain the conflicted feelings in Toronto about hosting occasional Bills games? Sullivan & Cromwell said Wednesday that it has hired Donald L. Korb, the chief counsel for the Internal Revenue Service for the last four and a half years, to lead its tax controversy team.
Well, a defiant Rod Blagojevich intends to stay on as governor of Illinois and, apparently, to select Barack Obama's replacement to the Senate, but he might have to move very quickly on the latter.
Simmons Bedding is resting a little easier.
James O'Shaughnessy, a top stock-fund manager who left Bear Stearns in early 2007, said he expressed concern about the firm's use of leverage but "was politely told to mind my own business."

Religion | How can the Bible support the conservative case for "traditional" marriage when the Old Testament features polygamists and philanderers and the New Testament features Jesus, who was single (along with Paul)? A Newsweek cover story presents the scriptural argument for gay marriage based on what the Bible teaches about love. [Newsweek]
The Federal Reserve is considering issuing its own debt for the first time, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

Arun Sarin, the former chief of mobile-phone giant Vodafone, has been approached about filling the slot left by Jerry Yang, the Yahoo chief executive who resigned last month, The Financial Times reported.

Congressional Democrats and the Bush administration on Tuesday night were on the brink of an agreement on a taxpayer rescue of the American automobile industry, with a vote in the House expected as soon as Wednesday afternoon, The New York Times's David M. Herszenhorn reported.
A report that Ford Motor is in talks sell Volvo to its Chinese partner Changan Automobile Group may have been a bit hasty, according to new press reports.

American International Group, once the world's largest insurer, owes around $10 billion to Wall Street's biggest firms for trades that have gone sour, the Wall Street Journal reported in its online edition on Tuesday.

The bankruptcy filing of the Tribune Company on Monday is just the latest, largest evidence that the American newspaper industry is suffering the hangover from an immense buying spree in 2006 and 2007 at what turned out to be the worst possible time for the buyers, just as the business was about to enter a drastic decline, The New York Times's Richard Perez-Pena writes.

Och-Ziff Capital Management, the hedge fund that went public last year, has cut at least 10 jobs in Asia, including that of partner Raaj Shah, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the matter.
Creditors of the Tribune Company are leaving a margin for error, Breakingviews says.

Nortel Networks has sought legal advice to study a bankruptcy protection scenario in the event that its restructuring plan fails and has also been exploring potential assistance from the Canadian government, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.
William Ackman, the hedge fund manager who runs Pershing Square Capital Management, has raised the stakes in his bet on mall owner General Growth Properties.
New Star Asset Management, the United Kingdom-based fund manager, has been put up for sale by the syndicate of banks that now control it, The Times of London reported.

Like others who got caught up in the recent commercial real estate frenzy, Joseph Moinian, the owner of 20 million square feet of office towers, apartment buildings and hotels throughout the country, sought to take advantage of the huge run-up in values as banks feverishly competed to make loans with exceedingly generous terms.

SAIF Partners, the investment firm backed by Japan's Softbank, has raised 1.6 billion yuan ($233 million) for its first yuan-denominated private equity fund, Reuters reported, citing sources with direct knowledge of the matter.

The lone Republican on a Congressional panel overseeing the $700 billion financial rescue plan has voted against its first advisory report, setting up a possible partisan rift as it is delivered to lawmakers on Wednesday, The New York Times's Diana B. Henriques reported.

Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac engaged in "an orgy of junk mortgage development" that turned the two mortgage-finance giants into vast repositories of subprime and similarly risky loans, a former Fannie executive testified on Tuesday.

Citigroup will slash some 1,000 jobs at its Japanese brokerage unit as part of the ailing U.S. banking giant's efforts to survive the financial meltdown, a report said Wednesday, according to The Associated Press.

Chubby fingers stretched upward to the drifting whiteness. Bodies twirled. Tongues extended to catch the falling flakes. Children's voices cried out: "Mommy! It's snowing!" Well, sort of. The wonderment was real, but the snow was not. The flakes disappeared upon contact, dissolving into faint nontoxic bubbles, which were 90 percent water and 100 percent biodegradable. The scene took place, not under a cold winter sky, but in the warm indoor atrium of the Time Warner Center at Columbus Circle, under the glow of the Williams Sonoma, J. Crew and Borders stores.
Move over Big Three. Little Biotech is joining you in seeking federal assistance.

There has been no shortage of opinions throughout the debate over a federal bailout for Detroit's struggling automakers. But, The New York Times's Micheline Maynard writes, one group has been notably silent: foreign car companies.

The aftershock of the financial earthquake that hit Wall Street late in the summer is rattling two major suburban markets north of Manhattan. As elsewhere, office vacancy rates have been climbing in Westchester County, N.Y., and Fairfield County, Conn., which sit side by side, The New York Times's Elsa Brenner writes.
Hynix Semiconductor's creditor banks have reached a provisional agreement to pump cash into the money-losing memory chip maker, a newspaper reported Wednesday.

From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:
In this economy, a lot of people need help finding work. That includes plenty of workers who make over $100,000 a year.
Ernst & Young has released its Global I.P.O. update and it should come as no surprise that the numbers are dismal.

Politics | Bobby Kennedy was the last politician to risk criticizing the American people and get away with it, one of his chroniclers writes. Since then, few have tempted the voters' wrath. But when Obama delivers his inaugural, "he will have another opportunity to tell Americans what many of us already know but are loath to admit: that we all bear some measure of responsibility for what has happened on Wall Street and Main Street, and in Iraq and at Guantánamo." A brief note on real economic issues. Everyone here seems to be talking about two things: the fate of the auto industry, which is in almost as much trouble in Sweden as it is in the United States, and the German problem. At a time when expansionary policies are desperately needed, the leaders of Europe's largest economy seem to have their heads in the sand. This is a huge problem: there are large spillovers in fiscal policy among EU nations -- that is, a significant fraction of, say, French fiscal expansion ends up promoting employment in Germany or Italy rather than France. So there's a crying need for a coordinated policy. But the Germans aren't participating.

-- an Englishman living in Russia -- what New York means to me. I have visited the city many times, but I see it most in my dreams. The dreams are not precise: they are sketches filled with the city's symbolism, iconography, multiculturalism. One important thing about New York is that it is not a capital city. I have lived in some of the great European capitals: London, Rome, Paris and, since 2003, Moscow. But they are a touch too patriotic to be shared. New York is an American city, of course, but it is also ours, the world's.

DANE--Nelson Brientnall, Jr. of Sarasota, Florida and Quogue, New York died of heart failure on December 6 at the Sarasota Memorial Hospital at the age of 81. Born on May 15, 1927 in Short Hills, New Jersey, he graduated from Princeton University in 1949, served in the navy for three years and was honorably discharged with the rank of Lt. Junior Grade. Mr. Dane was a real estate investor for over 20 years in New Jersey and founded the Nelson B. Dane Real Estate Investment Co. His favorite activity was golf, and since 1973 he was a member of Pine Valley Golf Club in New Jersey, where he maintained a residence on the club's grounds for over 15 years. Mr. Dane was also a member of the Sara Bay Country Club in Sarasota, the Field Club in Sarasota, the Quogue Beach Club, and the Quogue Field Club. Mr. Dane was survived by his wife of nine years Nancy Greeff Sartorius Dane, his four children, Grant, Scott, Nelson III, and Kate, and one grandchild, Danielle. A Funeral Service will be held on Saturday, December 13, 2008, at 12 noon at the St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Westhampton Beach, NY. lnterment will follow in the Quogue Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be sent to the Sarasota Memorial Healthcare Foundation, 1515 S. Osprey Avenue #

Pennington Sparkles Last Sunday, Chad Pennington, above, became only the second Dolphins quarterback not named Dan Marino to pass for more than 3,000 yards in a season. Pennington's passer rating, 93.7, is the second best by any Miami quarterback who started at least 13 games. His total of 3,062 passing yards is the 15th-highest single-season total in team history, and he still has three regular-season games left.

President-elect Barack Obama met with former Vice President Al Gore for about 45 minutes on Tuesday to discuss global warming and energy policy. Neither shared much about their talks, but Mr. Obama said he fully agreed with Mr. Gore on both the science of climate change and the need to take aggressive action to combat it. He repeated his declaration that the United States can no longer afford delay or denial in confronting the climate challenge. ''We all believe what the scientists have been telling us for years now, that this is a matter of urgency and national security, and it has to be dealt with in a serious way,'' Mr. Obama said. ''That is what I intend my administration to do.''

Creditors of the Tribune Company are leaving a margin for error. The company's senior buyout loans are trading at about 35 cents on the dollar. Assuming that is a proxy for Tribune's enterprise value, the total of its market capitalization and debt, the company is worth a paltry $3.6 billion -- a far cry from the $12 billion Sam Zell paid for it a year ago.

Arthur R. Kantrowitz, a physicist and engineer whose research on the behavior of superhot gases and fluid dynamics led to nose cones for rockets, heart-assist pumps and the idea of nuclear fusion in magnetic bottles, among many other things, died in Manhattan on Nov. 29. He was 95. His death was announced by his family.

Th American International Group said Tuesday the $150 billion government assistance package it received last month was incomplete, and that it still had to find a way to quarantine about $10 billion worth of troubled financial contracts. The insurer said the contracts were credit default swaps, the same insurance-like type of contract that was at the heart of its liquidity crisis in September. But these contracts were insuring a different type of asset than the ones covered by the federal assistance package.

Correction Appended Though a handful of other contenders are already eying his job, Republican National Committee chairman Mike Duncan announced his re-election bid on Wednesday, vowing a return to the party's ''core conservative principles.'' In an e-mail to members of the R.N.C., Mr. Duncan expressed optimism about the future of the party and pledged to roll out a 10-point plan to strengthen it. But in a YouTube video on his Web site, MikeForChairman.com, he acknowledged what may be his biggest liability his leadership of the party during a period of stinging electoral defeats. ''As you can imagine, I share the disappointment of all Republicans around the results of the presidential election,'' he said. But he went on to tout the party's accomplishments in fund-raising (as of November, the R.N.C. had raised more than $320 million) and his efforts to expand its database of supporters (he said the R.N.C. had collected over 10 million e-mail addresses). ''You might remember that for almost two years the pundits were predicting gloom and doom for the Republican Party. They said we wouldn't be able to raise money, they said our base wouldn't be motivated, they said the Republican brand had lost its luster,'' Mr. Duncan said. ''Well I'm here to report that when it comes to the Republican National Committee, they were very wrong.'' Other candidates in the running to unseat Mr. Duncan include, Katon Dawson, the chairman of the South Carolina Republican Party, Saul Anuzis, the chairman of the Michigan G.O.P., Chip Saltsman, who managed Mike Huckabee's presidential campaign, Michael Steele, the former lieutenant governor of Maryland, and Ken Blackwell, the former secretary of state of Ohio. The election of the next R.N.C. chairman will take place at the party's winter meeting in late January. And while he still has his job, Mr. Duncan is offering every indication that he will use his bully pulpit to criticize President-elect Barack Obama. Just today he released a statement characterizing Mr.Obama's comments about his contact with Illinois Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, who was arrested on allegations of corruption on Tuesday, as ''carefully parsed and vague.'' ''Considering the severity of the allegations against Governor Blagojevich, the President-elect should immediately disclose any and all communications his transition team has had with the governor's office along with any Service Employees International Union officials involved in the matter,'' Mr. Duncan said. ''Obama's promise of transparency to the American people is now being tested.''

MUNROE--John, Jr.,died on November 9, 2008 in Montego Bay, Jamaica after a long illness. He was born in Paris, France, May 8, 1924 where his father was associated with Munroe & Co., a private bank. His mother, Adelaide Sedgwick, was descended from many early founders of the United States. On his father's side he was descended from both early American stock and persons prominent in the French business community. Partly raised in Paris, he was educated in this country at the Buckley School in New York: St. Mark's School in Southborough, Massa chusetts: and Harvard College in Cambridge, Massachusetts. He was loyal to these institutions as well as Brantwood Camp in Peterborough, New Hampshire, the St. Mark's School camp for those who might not have had a camping experience otherwise, where he served as counselor and for many years as trustee. Entering Harvard in the fall of 1942, he soon like so many of his generation was in the Armed Forces. He ended his military career as a Lieutenant in charge of Gen. Hap Arnold's staff at the Potsdam Conference in 1945. Graduating from Harvard in 1949, he taught briefly at St. Mark's School. He lived frequently at Montego Bay in Jamaica where he was an early advocate of its delights, and where he dealt in real estate. He was a raconteur of note, a writer and reciter of a wide variety of limericks, and he enlivened every event to which he went and invariably raised the tone. He was loyal to those he was close to and to the institutions of which he had been part. He is survived by his wife Linda, daughter Adel Edwards of Phoenix, AZ and grandchildren David, Stephen, Deirdra and Christianna. Funeral services will be held at Grace Episcopal Church, Millbrook, NY at 11am Thursday, December 11.

DOROT extends deepest condolences to her sisters, Ruth and Mildred; her children, Bruce and Allyson Doniger, Peter and Diane Doniger, David and Lisa Doniger, and Patricia and Richard Goldman and her many grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Freddi S. Finegood, President Vivian Fenster Ehrlich, Executive Director

From all accounts, the first N.F.L. regular-season game in Canada was a bore. Organizers had trouble filling Rogers Centre in Toronto on Sunday, the atmosphere was lifeless, and the game was a field-goal festival (Miami beat Buffalo, 16-3). The real drama played out behind the scenes, where the N.F.L. has stirred concern that it will eventually muscle out the Canadian Football League. The issue is one of Canadian identity.

Citing security concerns, two senators who sit on the Congressional committee in charge of inaugural ceremonies appealed Tuesday to Mayor Adrian M. Fenty and the Washington City Council to reverse a decision to keep bars in the city open until 5 a.m. during inauguration week. Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, the committee chairwoman, said she had ''grave concerns about the unintended consequences'' of the plan approved last week to extend the hours that bars and restaurants can sell alcohol.

As Stephen Curry ran the floor at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, his bright-red mouth guard spent as much time hanging out of his mouth like an oversized piece of gum as it did protecting his teeth. Each time he posted up near the basket, there it was again, turning under every bite. It was not designed to be a chew toy. Then again, Curry was not designed to be a point guard. As West Virginia bullied him around during No. 23 Davidson's 68-65 victory in the first game of the Jimmy V Classic, it was hardly a stretch to think that Curry is most effective in his original role -- shooting guard -- much like the mouth guard. But in the final minutes, all that mattered was that he had the ball in his hands.

Cardinals Making History Kurt Warner of Arizona has thrown a touchdown pass in 21 consecutive games, the longest active streak in the league, but he remains nearly two full seasons from the league record of 47 in a row, set by Johnny Unitas from 1956 to 1960.

COONS--Richard Foster, of New York City, Southampton, NY, and Palm Beach, FL died peacefully at home in Florida late Friday night, December 5, 2008, after a long and valiant fight against cancer. Dick received a BA from Princeton College and a MBA from Harvard Business School, and went on to become a highly successful international investment banker. Dick served as President of Baring Securities, Inc., Executive VP at J. Henry Schroder Bank & Trust Co., and Senior Manager of the International Department at Kidder, Peabody. He currently was a Founding Director of an Egyptian company, Coral Growth Investments, Limited. He was a member of the Royal Yacht Squadron in Cowes, England, the Knickerbocker Club in New York, The Meadow Club of Southampton, The Southampton Club, and the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, where he served as Commodore. Dick leaves his beloved wife of 27 years, author, and former WPIX-TV anchor and reporter, Kristi Witker, who also wrote the Beachcomber column for The Southampton Press, and their 24 year old son, Foster Morrell Coons. He also leaves his two sisters, Marian Coons Lacy of Longwood, FL and Ellen Coons Goble of El Cajon, California. Dick will always be remembered for his generous heart, thoughtfulness, integrity, warmth, and courage. He was loved by all who knew him and he will be greatly missed by his loving family and friends. A Memorial Service will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church in Southampton, NY at 11am on Saturday, December 13th. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Animal Rescue Fund (ARF), A.S.P.C.A. or The Humane Society would be greatly appreciated.

BERGER--Charles Martin, on December 8, 2008 at the age of 72. Served as chairman and chief executive officer of The ScottsMiracle-Gro Company from 1996 through 2001. Born in 1938 in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania to Edward and Sadie Berger. Graduated from Princeton University in 1958 and Harvard Business School In 1960. Married Jane Purdy of Newport, Arkansas in 1960. Started his career in marketing management at Procter & Gamble. He then enjoyed a 32-year career at the H.J. Heinz Company. Initially managing the Heinz ketchup brand, he later served in several executive roles with Heinz: including running Heinz's Italian operations from 1972-1979, serving as chairman and chief executive officer of Weight Watchers International from 1979-1994, and running its Indian operations from 1994-1 996. He was chairman of the Board of Directors of the Naples Botanical Garden; a member of the executive committee and board of directors of the Philharmonic Center for the Arts in Naples; the North Shore Hospital System in Long Island, NY; the southwest Florida chapters of the Worlds President's Organization and the Princeton Club; as well as the Harvard Club of Naples. He was previously a director of the Columbus Symphony Orchestra in Columbus, Ohio; the National Board of World Presidents' Organization; Buckley Country Day School in Roslyn, NY; the American School of Milan and the Harvard Business School Club of Milan. He maintained residences in New York City, NY, Sands Point, NY and Naples, FL. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Jane Purdy Berger. He is also survived by one brother, Sheldon Berger, and two sisters, Judy Tawil and Marcia Harris, three children, Cary, Elizabeth and Valerie, three grandchildren, Hazel, Eleanor and Cooper, and five nieces and three nephews. Services will be held Wednesday, December 10, 2008 at 10:30am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65 Street.

BERTRAM--H. Henry, 91, died peacefully on December 6 in Vero Beach, Florida. He was born in Montclair, New Jersey and graduated from The Taft School in 1936 and Princeton University in 1940. At Princeton he was a member of Cottage Club and Triangle Club, where his love and passion for amateur acting began and continued throughout his life. He served as a Major in the Army in World War II under General George Patton. He retired as Director of Personnel at the New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center in 1982. At the time of his retirement he and his wife Lesley maintained residences in Englewood, New Jersey and Amagansett, New York. In 1986 he moved full time to Sea Oaks in Vero Beach, Florida. He was a member of the Vero Beach Country Club, Maidstone Club, Devon Yacht Club, Coral Beach Club and the Amagansett Beach Association, where he served as president. His wife of 48 years, the former Lesley Smith of Hastings, New York, died in Vero Beach on November 10, 1996. He is survived by their son, Henry Lawrence Bertram, of Fairfield, Connecticut; four grandchildren: Gregory Bertram of Bridgeport, Connecticut; Mia Bertram of Boulder, Colorado; Lindsay Bertram of Boulder, Colorado; and Devon Bertram of New York City; one great-granddaughter, Rose Camille Bertram of Bridgeport, Connecticut; and his beloved canine companion, George. A memorial service will take place in the Chapel at Trinity Episcopal Church, 2365 Pine Avenue, Vero Beach, Florida on Tuesday, December 16 at 10:00 am. He will be interred at St. Luke's Church Memorial Garden in East Hampton, New York at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to VNA Hospice, 901 37th Street, Vero Beach, Florida 32960. We will miss his easy, infectious laugh and his love of people and life. We love you, Goompah! Services are under the direction of the Thomas S. Lowther Funeral Home and Crematory, Vero Beach. Condolences may be sent to www.lowtherfuneral home.com.

Slope of grain is a common term among wood experts. It is unknown among most baseball fans. But the wood terminology intersected with the baseball world on Tuesday when Major League Baseball explained why it believed so many bats broke last season and how it will try to address the problem. After collecting and analyzing 2,232 broken bats from two months of games, M.L.B. and the players' union have adopted nine recommendations from baseball's Safety and Health Advisory Committee. The recommendations require manufacturers to produce better, safer bats and will be implemented for the 2009 season.

After acknowledging for the first time that Canada is entering a recession, the Bank of Canada cut its key interest rate on Tuesday by three-quarters of a percentage point, to 1.5 percent, a 50-year low. The lack of a mortgage and banking crisis in Canada had shielded the country somewhat from the economic downturn. But a sharp drop in exports to the United States, particularly of automobiles and auto parts, combined with a collapse in energy and commodity prices has brought it into the point of a recession.
In Los Angeles, Brooks Barnes reports:

Let the babysitter search begin: New York’s hippest stay-at-home parents, Maggie Gyllenhaal and Peter Sarsgaard, will soon be sharing a home and stage together when they join the cast of Classic Stage Company’s coming production of “Uncle Vanya,” the company announced. Ms. Gyllenhaal will be playing Yelena and Mr. Sarsgaard will play Astrov; it’s the first time the two have worked together outside of the 2007 short film “High Falls.” They join a cast that includes Denis O’Hare as Vanya, Mamie Gummer as Sonya and Louis Zorich as Waffles. The production, directed by Austin Pendleton, is scheduled to begin previews on Jan. 17 and end its limited run on March 1; an opening date has not been announced.

The state of New Jersey was well-represented on the roster of 2008’s top-grossing tours (measured from Nov. 14, 2007 through Nov. 11 of this year), Billboard reported: Bon Jovi claimed the No. 1 spot, grossing $210.6 million and drawing 2,157,675 fans for its Lost Highway tour, while second place went to their fellow Garden Staters Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band, whose Magic tour grossed $204.5 million. The top 10 was rounded out by Madonna ($162 million), the Police ($150 million), Celine Dion ($91 million), Kenny Chesney ($86 million), Neil Diamond ($81.2 million), the Spice Girls ($70 million), the Eagles ($56.6 million) and Rascal Flatts ($55.8 million). The touring industry’s total grosses were just under $4 billion, the highest ever, though total attendance was flat compared to last year.

Citing its hometown’s recent decision to cut grants to local art groups by 50 percent, the Louisville Orchestra has canceled a concert in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., The Courier-Journal reported. The orchestra said that it was expecting $220,000 from the city before the cut in grants was announced, and that it had already spent $70,000 on a series of performances at the Louisville Zoo. Robert Birman, the chief operating officer for the orchestra, told The Courier-Journal that the orchestra needed city financing to hire musicians and rent space for the King concert, a free performance scheduled for Jan. 18. Mr. Birman said the orchestra still planned to go ahead with two King concerts for area schoolchildren, scheduled for Jan. 16.

The cookbook writer Missy Chase Lapine hasn’t let her legal dispute with Jerry and Jessica Seinfeld discourage her from her literary pursuits. Ms. Lapine has sold a new book to Running Press, the publisher of her best-selling “Sneaky Chef” series, which suggests, among other things, that parents purée healthy foods and hide them in their children’s meals. The sale was confirmed by Joëlle Delbourgo, Ms. Lapine’s literary agent. In January, Ms. Lapine filed suit against Ms. Seinfeld, saying that her book, “Deceptively Delicious,” plagiarized from “The Sneaky Chef,” and against Mr. Seinfeld, who called Ms. Lapine “a wacko” during a talk-show appearance. Ms. Delbourgo declined to discuss the details of Ms. Lapine’s new book, except to say that it would continue Ms. Lapine’s “sneaky approach,” adding: “Each book has to have its own flavor.”

The title of her show notwithstanding, Liza Minnelli was most definitely not at the Palace on Wednesday night. The scheduled performance of her one-woman Broadway show, “Liza’s at the Palace….”, was canceled just before its 8 P.M. start; the show’s producers said that Ms. Minnelli was suffering from dehydration. In a statement, John Scher, a co-producer, said, “This past opening week has been a marathon run for Liza–which unfortunately has led her to dehydration and her doctor has insisted she get some extra rest.” The statement said that ticket-holders for Wednesday’s show can exchange their tickets for any future scheduled performance, though some ticket-holders said they were given automatic refunds. The next scheduled performance of “Liza’s at the Palace….” is Friday night.

Google made a splash when it announced its new Web browser, Chrome, in September. Like many of Google's new products, Chrome first appeared in a beta, or test, version. That limited its appeal, as corporate users in particular tend to shy away from using software that is still in test mode. Perhaps as a result, Chrome's share of the Web browser market is less than 1 percent. In the new browser wars, that's a rounding error compared with Internet Explorer's nearly 70 percent market share.

Okay, so there are a lot of conceptual collections out there. There's Etat Libre d'Orange, whose concept is hardcore, often brilliant, art-for-art's-sake, mercilessly-destroy-the-concept-of-traditional-perfume radicalism. There's Frédéric Malle, whose marvelous, admirable concept is the pushing to the foreground of individual artists - great perfumers with visions and talent - whom the house publishes as Knopf might publish great novelists; these are perfumes as more traditional scent, art that seduces through beauty. There's Biehl. Parfumkunstwerke, which is a happy medium: works by talented perfumers that are challenging yet wearable.

As popular as spaghetti alla carbonara may be, most American cooks don't realize that its essential element is meat. The crispy bits of cured pork that elevate the eggy sauce are actually the building blocks for three of the great classic pastas made in and around Rome. The most basic of them, pasta alla gricia, contains no more than the meat and grated sharp cheese. With eggs added to the sauce, it becomes the familiar spaghetti alla carbonara, and if you add the sweetness of cooked onions and the acidity of tomatoes, you have pasta all'amatriciana.

Lawyers for New York City and for the thousands of ground zero workers suing the city over health claims have agreed to begin trials in the spring of 2010, The Times reports this morning. The lawsuits claim that workers were not given proper breathing equipment during the operation and suffered illnesses as a result of their exposure to dust at the site. After a hearing on Wednesday, lawyers said they were moving forward with 50 to 60 cases, involving people with the most severe health problems.Nearly 10,000 firefighters, police officers, construction workers and others have sued the city and its contractors, saying they suffered respiratory and other illnesses because they were not given breathing masks during the nine-month rescue and recovery operation. The potential liability is $1 billion or more.

The chief executive of U.S. insurer American International Group, which is looking to shed assets around the globe as part of a $152 billion U.S. government rescue package, said that difficult markets may delay the sale plans, though certain units have attracted heavy interest.

From Bard's president: Wealthy universities have "endless tiers of overlapping management" where "you never subtracted, you added." From a student to alumni: "By subsidizing the irresponsible financial decisions of your old school, you're helping it keep tuition costs out of reach for all but the richest of students." There's an extraordinary -- and extraordinarily depressing -- interview in Newsweek with Peer Steinbrueck, the Germany finance minister. The world economy is in a terrifying nosedive, visible everywhere. Yet Mr. Steinbrueck is standing firm against any extraordinary fiscal measures, and denounces Gordon Brown for his "crass Keynesianism."

World | Obama needs to work on his sticky wickets rather than his jump shot, a scholar says. Yes, he ought to take up cricket because it's truly a world sport, played in flashpoints like India, Zimbabwe, and Pakistan, and requires "patience and discipline." The latter qualities Bush did not have. He tended to "swing for the fences." Or, dare we say, throw the bomb? [Financial Times]

Tim Tebow will go for two against two talented quarterbacks from the Big 12 when the Heisman Trophy is awarded Saturday night in Manhattan. Sam Bradford from Oklahoma and Colt McCoy from Texas joined Tebow as Heisman finalists announced Wednesday. The last time all the Heisman finalists were quarterbacks was 2001, when Nebraska’s Eric Crouch won the award and quarterbacks held the first six spots.

The governing body of British tennis approved an agreement allowing Wimbledon organizers to buy back control of the All England Club. The agreement calls for the Lawn Tennis Association to get $83 million in installments over a five-year period. It will take effect in 2013 and last until 2053. Besides buying back half of the club they gave away in 1934, the Wimbledon organizers also will be allowed to keep 10 percent of the profits instead of giving it all to the association.

Manny Pacquiao’s technical knockout of Oscar De La Hoya on Saturday night generated 1.25 million pay-per-view purchases and $70 million in revenue. It is the fourth nonheavyweight bout to break one million buys in boxing’s pay-per-view history. “While it’s a tough economy, and that may have dampened the results somewhat, it’s still a strong number,” said Mark Taffet, a senior vice president of HBO Sports. “For us, one million buys is a mega fight.".

It’s not all gloom and doom on the Los Angeles museum front: the J. Paul Getty Museum announced Wednesday that it had acquired a rare landscape by the 17th-century Flemish painter Roelandt Savery and a drawing, right, by the sculptor Auguste Rodin. The Savery work, “Landscape With the Temptation of St. Anthony,” was painted in 1617 and depicts the saint reading in a rustic cell, oblivious to the demons frolicking around him. The Rodin work, probably from around 1898, is a brown wash and graphite drawing titled “Sphinx”; it depicts a naked female figure in what appears to be a desert landscape. The Rodin will go on view at the Getty on Tuesday and the Savery later this winter.

The comeback is officially complete: Britney Spears’s new album, “Circus” (Jive), hit the No. 1 slot on the sales chart in its first week of release, Billboard reported. “Circus,” Ms. Spears’s sixth album, sold 505,000 copies, making her the first artist since Nielsen SoundScan began tracking sales data in 1991 to have four albums make their debut with sales of 500,000 or more. Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) remained in second place with sales of 193,000, while Beyoncé’s “I Am ... Sasha Fierce” (Music World/Columbia) took third with 153,000. Kanye West’s “808s & Heartbreak” (Roc-a-Fella), which opened at No. 1 last week, fell to fourth with 142,000. The Guns N’ Roses album “Chinese Democracy” (Geffen) dropped out of the Top 10, to No. 18, with sales of less than 57,000.

Otilia Villar Baker, the wife of an assistant to the punk-rock musician Travis Barker, filed suit against several companies involved in a plane crash that killed her husband, The Associated Press reported. She is also suing the estates of the two pilots killed in the crash. In September her husband, Chris Baker, was among four people killed when a chartered jet carrying Mr. Barker, Mr. Baker, the D.J. Adam Goldstein and Mr. Barker’s bodyguard home after a concert in Columbia, S.C., crashed on takeoff. Mr. Barker and Mr. Goldstein were injured but survived. Mr. Baker’s widow has sued the companies that owned the jet, two charter companies that arranged the flight, and Goodyear Tire and Rubber. Mr. Barker sued the same companies in November.

Lucky for Judith Regan she left a big publishing house when the book business was relatively flush with cash. Ms. Regan, the outspoken publisher, was fired from her Regan Books imprint of HarperCollins in 2006. She received $10.75 million to settle a wrongful termination lawsuit she filed against the News Corporation, the parent company of HarperCollins, Bloomberg News reported. The settlement was disclosed in a legal filing by Dreier LLP, a New York law firm that Ms. Regan retained for the suit. Dreier is now suing Ms. Regan, saying that she fired the firm to avoid paying her legal fees, including a portion of her settlement. Dreier LLP’s founding partner, Marc S. Dreier, was recently arrested in what federal authorities allege is a $100 million fraud scheme.

Independent movies dominated the New York Film Critics Circle Awards, whose winners were announced Wednesday by the 73-year-old organization, including “Milk,” which claimed three awards. Gus Van Sant’s biographical film about the politician Harvey Milk was named best picture, Sean Penn won best actor and Josh Brolin won best supporting actor. Mike Leigh was named best director and Sally Hawkins best actress for “Happy-Go-Lucky.” In other categories, Jenny Lumet won best screenplay for “Rachel Getting Married,” Penélope Cruz was named best supporting actress for “Vicky Cristina Barcelona” and “4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days” was selected as best foreign film. On Tuesday, “Wall-E,” above, was named the year’s best film by the Los Angeles Film Critics Association. This is the first time the organization has given that honor to an animated movie.

Jurors ruled Tuesday in favor of Tyler Perry, right, the writer, actor and producer, in a lawsuit filed by a playwright who said that Mr. Perry had stolen her material for his movie “Diary of a Mad Black Woman,” The Associated Press reported. Donna West, the author of a play called “Fantasy of a Black Woman,” had argued in a federal court in Marshall, Tex., that Mr. Perry could have seen the script when he presented his plays at the Dallas Black Academy of Arts and Letters in 1998. Mr. Perry testified last Wednesday that his script was an original work. In an e-mail message to The Associated Press, a lawyer for Mr. Perry said, “We are very pleased that the jurors understood that Tyler Perry is an incredibly talented person who has no need to copy the work of others.”.

To the Editor: Your article, ''Wrinkles Disappear, as Does a Company'' (Thursday Styles, Dec. 4) describes the demise of Artes Medical, the company that brought us the permanent wrinkle filler, Artefill. The public should be thankful for the removal of Artefill from the cosmetic landscape. The market has corrected the Food and Drug Administration's lapse in judgment in 2006; Artefill should never have been approved. As a permanent filler, it violates one of the basic principles in plastic surgery: any foreign substance that doesn't dissolve must be removable. Artefill can't be removed without cutting it out. Swiss plastic surgeons warned us years ago about Artefill and now consumers have voted with their wallets.

BERTRAM--H. Henry, 91, died peacefully on December 6 in Vero Beach, Florida. He was born in Montclair, New Jersey and graduated from The Taft School in 1936 and Princeton University in 1940. At Princeton he was a member of Cottage Club and Triangle Club, where his love and passion for amateur acting began and continued throughout his life. He served as a Major in the Army in World War II under General George Patton. He retired as Director of Personnel at the New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center in 1982. At the time of his retirement he and his wife Lesley maintained residences in Englewood, New Jersey and Amagansett, New York. In 1986 he moved full time to Sea Oaks in Vero Beach, Florida. He was a member of the Vero Beach Country Club, Maidstone Club, Devon Yacht Club, Coral Beach Club and the Amagansett Beach Association, where he served as president. His wife of 48 years, the former Lesley Smith of Hastings, New York, died in Vero Beach on November 10, 1996. He is survived by their son, Henry Lawrence Bertram, of Fairfield, Connecticut; four grandchildren: Gregory Bertram of Bridgeport, Connecticut; Mia Bertram of Boulder, Colorado; Lindsay Bertram of Boulder, Colorado; and Devon Bertram of New York City; one great-granddaughter, Rose Camille Bertram of Bridgeport, Connecticut; and his beloved canine companion, George. A memorial service will take place in the Chapel at Trinity Episcopal Church, 2365 Pine Avenue, Vero Beach, Florida on Tuesday, December 16 at 10:00 am. He will be interred at St. Luke's Church Memorial Garden in East Hampton, New York at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to VNA Hospice, 901 37th Street, Vero Beach, Florida 32960. We will miss his easy, infectious laugh and his love of people and life. We love you, Goompah! Services are under the direction of the Thomas S. Lowther Funeral Home and Crematory, Vero Beach. Condolences may be sent to www.lowtherfuneral home.com.

FAULL--Ellen. New York City Opera mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague Ellen Faull, for three decades (1947-1978) a leading soprano of our company and a loyal friend until her death. Beginning with her 1947 City Opera debut as Donna Anna in our companys first Don Giovanni, she lent her generosity of voice, spirit, and presence to leading roles in The Marriage of Figaro, Der Rosenkavalier, Der Meistersinger, Madama Butterfly, Bohme, and Faust. She is especially remembered for her portrayals of leading roles in the the company premieres of Love for Three Oranges, Regina, The Four Ruffians, Trovatore, Capriccio, Dialogues of the Carmelites, Albert Herring, and particularly for the role of Abigail in City Opera's 1965 world premiere of Lizzie Borden, the role of her final performance here in 1978. Becoming one of the nation's most distinguished singing teachers, she went on to mentor several generations of City Opera company members. We offer our sincere condolences to her family and her vast extended family of friends, colleagues, and students. Susan L. Baker, Chairman New York City Opera

DANE--Nelson Brientnall, Jr. of Sarasota, Florida and Quogue, New York died of heart failure on December 6 at the Sarasota Memorial Hospital at the age of 81. Born on May 15, 1927 in Short Hills, New Jersey, he graduated from Princeton University in 1949, served in the navy for three years and was honorably discharged with the rank of Lt. Junior Grade. Mr. Dane was a real estate investor for over 20 years in New Jersey and founded the Nelson B. Dane Real Estate Investment Co. His favorite activity was golf, and since 1973 he was a member of Pine Valley Golf Club in New Jersey, where he maintained a residence on the club's grounds for over 15 years. Mr. Dane was also a member of the Sara Bay Country Club in Sarasota, the Field Club in Sarasota, the Quogue Beach Club, and the Quogue Field Club. Mr. Dane was survived by his wife of nine years Nancy Greeff Sartorius Dane, his four children, Grant, Scott, Nelson III, and Kate, and one grandchild, Danielle. A Funeral Service will be held on Saturday, December 13, 2008, at 12 noon at the St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Westhampton Beach, NY. lnterment will follow in the Quogue Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be sent to the Sarasota Memorial Healthcare Foundation, 1515 S. Osprey Avenue #

COONS--Richard Foster, of New York City, Southampton, NY, and Palm Beach, FL died peacefully at home in Florida late Friday night, December 5, 2008, after a long and valiant fight against cancer. Dick received a BA from Princeton College and a MBA from Harvard Business School, and went on to become a highly successful international investment banker. Dick served as President of Baring Securities, Inc., Executive VP at J. Henry Schroder Bank & Trust Co., and Senior Manager of the International Department at Kidder, Peabody. He currently was a Founding Director of an Egyptian company, Coral Growth Investments, Limited. He was a member of the Royal Yacht Squadron in Cowes, England, the Knickerbocker Club in New York, The Meadow Club of Southampton, The Southampton Club, and the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, where he served as Commodore. Dick leaves his beloved wife of 27 years, author, and former WPIX-TV anchor and reporter, Kristi Witker, and their 24 year old son, Foster Morrell Coons. He also leaves his two sisters, Marian Coons Lacy of Longwood, FL and Ellen Coons Goble of El Cajon, California. Dick will always be remembered for his generous heart, thoughtfulness, integrity, warmth, and courage. He was loved by all who knew him and he will be greatly missed by his loving family and friends. A Memorial Service will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church in Southampton, NY at 11am on Saturday, December 13th. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Animal Rescue Fund (ARF), A.S.P.C.A. or The Humane Society would be greatly appreciated.

TIME waits for no man, including he who must change his watch between trips to the office, health club and happy hour. But fortunately, for the fit professional, gone are the days requiring two personal timepieces -- a generic black-rubber digital for athletic endeavors and a classic stainless-steel analog for more social pursuits. Today's sports watches are fashionable and functional, and stylish stopwatches sophisticated enough for office wear account for a rapidly growing sector of the wristwatch industry. ''Over the past several years, there's been a tremendous explosion in sports watches, or the really cool-looking pieces that have a variety of functions for whichever sport you play,'' said Joe Thompson, editor in chief of the bimonthly magazine WatchTime. ''As a result, you now see a lot more people wearing sports watches to work -- you don't need a dress watch anymore.''

Though a handful of other contenders are already seeking his job, the Republican National Committee chairman, Mike Duncan, announced his re-election bid on Wednesday, vowing a return to the party's ''core conservative principles.'' In an e-mail message to members of the committee, Mr. Duncan, right, who had been expected to seek the chairmanship again, expressed optimism about the future of the Republican Party but acknowledged what might be his biggest liability -- his leadership of the party during a period of stinging electoral defeats.

“Hannity & Colmes” is being replaced by Sean Hannity, period. Mr. Hannity, the conservative half of the popular 9 p.m. program on the Fox News Channel, will become the sole host of the hour, now called “Hannity,” beginning Jan. 12, the network confirmed Thursday. The move was expected after Alan Colmes, the liberal counterweight on the political talk show, announced last month that he would leave the program at the end of the year. Bill Shine, a senior vice president at Fox, said the network had chosen not to undertake the “monumental task” of replacing Mr. Colmes. The new program will include commentary, interviews, and a “Great American Panel” consisting of a liberal, a conservative, and an “x-factor” guest. The program will represent the first change to Fox News’s 9 p.m. hour since the network started in 1996.

An actor performing a suicide scene in a play in Austria accidentally stabbed himself in the neck after his prop knife was replaced with a sharp blade, The Associated Press reported. Daniel Hoevels, of the Thalia Theater company from Hamburg, Germany, was performing the role of Mortimer in Friedrich Schiller’s “Mary Stuart” on Wednesday when the accident occurred at Vienna’s Burgtheater. He was treated at a nearby hospital and resumed performing in the show Thursday. The theater company told The A.P. that a prop knife for the scene had been damaged; the replacement knife was supposed to be blunted, but those instructions were “carelessly” disregarded. The Vienna police said they were investigating “bodily injury caused by negligence.”

The declining economy doesn’t seem to have dampened buyers’ interests in purchasing artifacts from popular movies, and science-fiction gadgets that don’t really work. On Thursday, a lightsaber wielded by Mark Hamill in the “Star Wars” sequel “The Empire Strikes Back” sold for $240,000, and the helmet of the android C-3PO worn by Anthony Daniels in “Return of the Jedi” sold for $120,000 in an auction of Hollywood memorabilia held by Profiles in History, an auction house based in Calabasas, Calif., the company reported. In all, the one-day sale grossed $3.5 million (including buyers’ premiums) for more than 500 items, which included the black leather battlesuit worn by Hugh Jackman in “X-Men” (sold for $90,000), Marlon Brando’s costume from “Superman” ($72,000) and a miniature flying saucer from “Forbidden Planet” ($78,000).

For the cineastes who appreciate dark comedies and bleak dramas, and can’t wait to find out what happens next to Inspector Jacques Clouseau, the 2009 Berlin Film Festival should satisfy all of their needs. The annual Berlinale, which runs next year from Feb. 5 through 15, has announced its lineup, which includes events celebrating “The Reader,” Stephen Daldry’s adaptation of the Bernhard Schlink novel, and “The Pink Panther II,” starring Steve Martin as the bumbling Clouseau. Among the films in competition will be “Rage,” a black comedy about a New York fashion company, starring Jude Law, Judi Dench, Dianne Wiest and Steve Buscemi; Rebecca Miller’s film adaptation of her novel “The Private Lives of Pippa Lee,” starring Robin Wright Penn, Keanu Reeves and Julianne Moore; and Lukas Moodysson’s “Mammoth,” starring Michelle Williams and Gael Garcia Bernal as a couple in crisis.

The Australian actor Hugh Jackman, who has portrayed everyone from the comic-book hero Wolverine to the songwriter Peter Allen, can add another credit to his resume: Oscars host. Mr. Jackman, 40, will be the host of the 81st Academy Awards, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced Friday.

The coming revival of Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein II’s “Music in the Air,” which will be produced at the New York City Center as part of its Encores! series, has announced its cast. The revival will star Sally Ann Howes (the original Truly Scrumptious, of film’s “Chitty Chitty Bang Bang”), Sierra Boggess (of Broadway’s “The Little Mermaid”), Marin Mazzie, Dick Latessa (a Tony Award winner for “Hairspray”), Tom Alan Robbins and Douglas Sills. “Music in the Air,” with music by Kern and book and lyrics by Hammerstein, tells the story of a Bavarian music teacher, his daughter and her suitor, who encounter chaos and unusual characters when they travel to Munich. The Encores! production will run at City Center from Feb. 5 through 8.

Q. Lincoln loved to tell stories, and is himself the subject of countless stories and anecdotes. What is one of your favorites?

I love that Lincoln is the only United States president ever to be awarded a patent --for a device that would lift flatboats over shoals. And one of my favorite images from James M. McPherson's new book, "Tried by War: Abraham Lincoln as Commander in Chief," is Lincoln test-firing new rifles on the White House grounds. Like a lot of autodidacts, he was a restless self-improver, always studying and tinkering. But not all his learning came from books; he also learned from experience and, unlike some more recent occupants of the White House, he was not afraid to change his mind or admit mistakes. As Ed points out, he was, in the beginning at least, antislavery but by no means an abolitionist. Nor did he think that slavery was an issue worth going to war over; it was the union he wanted to defend, and to preserve it he was willing to allow the South to carry on as it had. (A very instructive book here is George Frederickson's "Big Enough to be Inconsistent," discussed by Barry Gewen in a recent post on The Times's Paper Cuts blog.)

At 8 a.m., I was on Broadway and 110th Street when I saw a group of runners heading east on 110th Street. They were dressed in gray sweats and the first runner was carrying a torch. They had a police escort and were being followed by a several cars adorned with Mexican flags and pictures of the Virgin Mary -- more precisely, Our Lady of Guadalupe. The driver of one of those cars said runners had carried the torch in a relay from Mexico and were headed for St. Patrick's Cathedral. I figured if some people ran here all the way from Mexico with a burning torch to show up at St. Pat's, it might be worth a look, even it if meant forgoing a leisurely Friday breakfast.

As Ed says, Lincoln was far from perfect, and to me, in my belated journey of rediscovery, that's part of the appeal. Far from the alabaster saint that was presented to us in school, he was endearingly, touchingly human. He was awkward with girls. He loved dirty jokes. Why didn't they tell us that in high school? And even before he got to the White House he carried with him an immense weight of loss and unhappiness: a difficult marriage, the death of his mother, his distant relationship with his father, whose funeral he didn't bother to attend. In this last respect, he reminds me a lot of Samuel Johnson, another awkward, self-created genius who didn't get along with his father and who in later life felt so bad about it that he once visited his father's grave and stood all day there in the rain. In both cases, you feel, these young men -- Lincoln and Johnson -- had to triumph over diminished or uncomprehending parental expectation for them, and the victory came not without psychic cost. But even more than Johnson, Lincoln turned these wounds to advantage. He mastered his temper. (The archives are full of letters he wrote but did not send. Probably just as well he did not live in the age of e-mail.) He learned to get along with his enemies. He so understood human frailty that it made him impassioned about the other, better side of our nature.

The question about why Lincoln is so fascinating is a dangerous one for me right now, since I'm finding very little about him that isn't. When I was a child, before I even knew who Lincoln was, I remember being posed one of those "brain teasers": how many Lincolns can be found on a penny? One, obviously. But no, look at the Lincoln Memorial on the tail side. There between the central pillars can be glimpsed an outline of the imposing statue. Two.

The employees greeting customers at the door of Saigon Grill, on Amsterdam Avenue on the Upper West Side, were as crisply polite as ever. The service was fast and the food was cheap. In short, if you didn't know that the owners had been arrested a week earlier and charged with more than 400 counts of underpaying workers and defrauding the government, you wouldn't have guessed it from the lunchtime scene. But David Trang, a taxi driver who is a regular customer - very regular; he said he eats there four or five times a week - said he could tell something was amiss on Wednesday. A dispute between the restaurant's owners and some of its employees first became public more than a year and a half ago, when there were regular protests on the sidewalk outside.

von BULOW--Martha. The Board of Directors of the NeuroTrauma Foundation mourns the passing of Martha ''Sunny'' von Bulow and expresses its deep sympathy to her children Ala Isham, Alexander von Auersperg, and Cosima Pavoncelli. Sunny von Bulow, the inspiration for the establishment of the NeuroTrauma Foundation, was a generous benefactor of innovative brain injury research and the development of brain injury treatment guidelines. Her family's support raised awareness and advanced the field of brain injury treatment for thousands of people around the world. Peter C. Quinn, Director NeuroTrauma Foundation
