SMART BROOKLYN GALLERY HOP That Brooklyn has a thriving arts scene is hardly news. Review-circuit destinations like Dumbo Arts Center on Washington Street, Pierogi in Williamsburg and countless other galleries have sprouted up in recent years at a breakneck pace. But what is probably news to many who live outside Brooklyn's borders (and inside them, for that matter) is that there is plenty of art beyond the neighborhoods usually pitched to intrepid Manhattanites as ''just the first stop in Brooklyn.''

A heated 2,292-square-foot hangar is attached to this 3,486-square-foot house in Lake Aero Estates, about 20 minutes' flying time from Chicago. The community's runway is adjacent to the LaSalle Fish and Wildlife Area. The house, built in 2000, has French doors, large windows and a terrace, all of which face the runway. There are three and a half bathrooms and an attached two-car garage. Agent: Patrick Carron, Apex Realty; (219) 477-7038; www.chicagohangarhome.com.

Chosen for: Secretary of veterans affairs Will bring to the job: A 38-year career in the Army and a reputation as a hero to troops in Iraq and Afghanistan for having told the Senate Armed Services Committee, more than a month before the invasion of Iraq, that occupying that country would take ''something on the order of several hundred thousand soldiers.'' That was far more than the defense secretary, Donald H. Rumsfeld, said were needed. The testimony effectively ended General Shinseki's military career; the Pentagon named his replacement more than a year before his scheduled retirement. But as Iraq descended into chaos, his estimate became one of the most-quoted observations of the war.

SACHS--Edra Miriam, died December 2, 2008, age 85, in East Meadow, NY. Vibrant, generous, socially conscious and engaged in life until the very moment she left it. Beloved mother, grandmother, and friend, she will be missed by all. A private memorial service will be held on Long Island. She was a dedicated teacher of the visually impaired. In ''The Prosodic Body,'' a research project by the choreographer Daria Faïn and the architect and poet Robert Kocik, the collaborators attempt ''to draw attention to the interdependency of art and health in our everyday lives.'' What that appears to mean is that if you have art in your life, your life will improve. Or at least you'll feel better. Ms. Faïn and Mr. Kocik presented a theatrical element of their project, a dance installation called ''The Extent to Which'' at the Center for Performance Research on Wednesday night. Prosody refers to the rhythm and intonation of speech. ''The Extent to Which'' incorporates unintelligible vocals and sound to establish a throbbing, sensory environment, designed by Mr. Kocik to represent the structure of a human cell.

WALLACE--Richard, 51, of Stamford, CT, passed away on Sunday, December 7, 2008 at Stamford Hospital after a brave battle with cancer. Richard was born in London, England in 1957. He started his copywriting career in Birmingham before moving to Ogilvy & Mather in London and later in Hong Kong. He then joined TBWA/AMC in South Africa before moving to New York in 2000 to work at Ammirati, Bozell, and Saatchi & Saatchi. Richard created campaigns for The African National Congress, The Economist, Verizon Wireless, Datek, Intel, The New York Times, and Milk. His work won awards at Cannes, The One Show, Clio, Addys and Communication Arts. Loved as an easygoing, gentle and generous man, Richard is survived by his wife Vanessa of Stamford, CT, and his mother Primrose and brother Mick, of the U.K. The funeral will be held at noon on Saturday, December 13, 2008 at The Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, CT.

von BULOW--Martha Crawford (''Sunny''), 77, died on December 6, 2008 at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home in New York City. Raised in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and New York City, our mother was the only child of the late Annie Laurie Aitken and the late George W. Crawford, founder of Columbia Gas and Electric and Lone Star Gas Company. Our mother touched the lives of many. She will be warmly remembered, first and foremost, as a devoted, loving and caring mother. She was also a generous patron of the arts in both New York City and Rhode Island. Our mother is survived by our spouses, Ralph H. Isham, Nancy Auersperg and Ricardo Pavoncelli, and nine grandchildren: Sunny Kneissl, Alexandra Kneissl, Nicolas Isham, George Isham, Anna von Auersperg, Alfi von Auersperg, Nicholas Pavoncelli, Marina Pavoncelli and Antonia Pavoncelli. She was married to the late Prince Alfred von Auersperg and Claus Von Bulow. Both marriages ended in divorce. For the past 28 years, our mother remained in a persistent vegetative state and was cared for at New York Columbia Presbyterian Hospital and Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home. We are grateful to her private duty nurses and the staff of both facilities for caring for her all these years. A private memorial service for family and friends will be held at Brick Presbyterian Church at 62 East 92nd Street, New York, NY on January 14th 2009 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, our family requests that donations be made in our mother's memory to the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association. Ala Isham, Alexander von Auersperg and Cosima Pavoncelli

My Sunday column argues for bailing out the auto companies. It's not that I think the arguments against a bailout are wrong -- in general, businesses should have to have the freedom to fail -- but conditions are so precarious right now that we just can't afford another huge blow to employment and consumer demand. It may well be cheaper for taxpayers to sustain General Motors than to pay for the clean-up and burial if it expires.

Last evening around 6 o'clock I was on the phone with Tommy Hilfiger, thanking him for some flowers he'd sent, when I mentioned how much I liked his girlfriend Dee Ocleppo, whom I met over dinner at his house in Greenwich. "We're getting married in 45 minutes!" Hilfiger suddenly announced, plainly a happy man. The couple was supposed to marry last August at Hilfiger's home on Mustique, but life got a little complicated, and they decided to put things off for a bit. They certainly managed to keep last night's wedding, presumably in Greenwich, a secret. She's lovely, he's lucky, and warmest congratulations to both.
I didn't see that coming.

I called Midge Silvio, the town clerk in Stoneham, Maine, from my office in Boston on Friday to get a western Maine weather report. I caught her in the middle of preparing the town's annual Christmas party. On Friday, townspeople decorate the community space in the town fire station, and on Saturday all of the children in town are invited to get gifts from Santa and eat holiday treats. (About 35 are expected, and Santa looks a lot like planning board member George Allen.) As I build the cabin, Midge is always helpful when I call with questions about building permits, town ordinances and local contractors but I could tell I was pulling her away from important work. She put resident Patty Pitman on the phone. Patty makes a batch of cookies for the party, which the children decorate with sprinkles and colored frosting. Patty gave me her recipe for Christmas cookies:

Politics | For years, pundits have leveled veritable forests touting the impotence of the Bush lame duck presidency (a recent example here). But is the exact opposite the case? Charles Krauthammer on Fox: "This is the most active and important lame duck presidency in American history. Huge interventions in the markets, the signing of an agreement with Iraq of tremendous importance, the status of forces agreement, and now the intervention on the issue of the [auto] bailout. I mean, this is a duck that roared ..." [RealClearPolitics, Guardian, Nation]

Language | Westerners derive much jollity from Asians' foreign-language malapropisms (see Engrish.com), but comes now evidence the derision cuts both ways. Case in point: the Max Planck Institute in Germany, which wanted classy Chinese calligraphy for a special issue on China, but unfortunately used the text of a flyer extolling "hot housewives" in a brothel. [Independent]

To the Editor:.

Christmas markets are in full swing in Germany. Which makes it all the more important to bear in mind some advice when visiting.  The German Christmas market ­ Weihnachtsmarkt ­ has turned into a global export hit, with variations popping up in Britain, China and places where German immigrants have struck roots, notably the United States. The allure is not hard to understand once you have a hot cup of Glühwein (mulled wine) and Lebkuchen (gingerbread cookie) in your hand. I especially like the roasted-candied almonds. The lovely Christmas tree ornaments go down well as gifts.

An obituary last Sunday about Martha (Sunny) von Bülow, the American heiress at the center of two sensational trials in which her second husband, Claus von Bülow, was charged with trying to murder her, misstated the relationship of her daughter Cosima von Bülow Pavoncelli to two children by Mrs. von Bülow’s first marriage, Alexander von Auersperg and Annie-Laurie von Auersperg Kneissl Isham. As noted elsewhere in the obituary, Ms. Pavoncelli is their half sister, not their stepsister.

A picture caption on Page 10 in the Travel section this weekend with an article about restaurants in Helsinki, Finland, misidentifies a chef and his restaurant. He is Marko Jaakkola, the sous chef at Grotesk restaurant — not Marko Palovaara, the executive chef at Nokka.

An article on page 68 of The Magazine this weekend about innovations in health care sponsored by the Positive Deviance Initiative at Tufts University reports on the institute and its director, Jerry Sternin, and includes his detailed description of the initiative’s work. SANDS--Donna Lynn. The staff of Minskoff Grant Realty & Management Corp. express their heartfelt sympathy to Jeannie Minskoff Grant and her family on the loss of her daughter, Donna Lynn, after a long illness. May her memory be eternal and her youthful spirit be forever in their hearts.

SANDS--Donna Lynn, 44. Beloved daughter of Jeannie Minskoff Grant and Augustus DeCrescenzo, sister of Michael Sands (Svetlana) and Richard Sands, stepdaughter of Francis C. Grant III, stepsister of Francis C. Grant IV, step-granddaughter of Jack Schleifer, passed away peacefully at the residence in Harrison, New York. She was an aspiring actor in her years at Peddie School and is remembered very fondly by all who knew her. Donna Lynn was the light of our lives, that light has been sorely missed in the family. Donna's spirit will live forever in our hearts and memories. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to the Donna Sands Scholarship Fund c/o The Sam & Esther Minskoff Cultural Center/ Park East Day School.
GANS--Jerome. Hard to believe it's 17 years. Miss you. Love, Mona, Larry, Jamie, Andy, Sarah, Kyle and Casey

GELLER--Dorothy ''Dotty'', on December 10, 2008 at age 92. Beloved wife of the late Mark Geller. Loving sister of the late Leo and Theodore Zeichner. Survived by her nephews, Daniel Zeichner, MD, Jonathan Zeichner, DDS and Steven Zeichner, MD. Dotty was a splendid amalgam of intellect and compassion. A scientist who became an educator in the NYC Public School System. Up until the end of her long life, she endeavored to make everyday a meaningful one. As per Dotty's request a private graveside service was held on Friday, December 12.

FURTH--Ada. Born December 24, 1930, Warsaw, Poland. Passed away peacefully December 9, 2008. Predeceased by cherished parents Leon and Liba Turko. Beloved mother of Susan of Bedford, NY and Hugo (Lori), Manhattan Beach, CA. Adored ''Oma'' of Eric, Joel and Daniel. Mom, we will miss you and have you forever in our hearts. Rest in peace with your beloved parents. Graveside services Friday, December 12th at 1:45pm, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Donations appreciated, made to UCLA Neuro-Oncology Department or Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale.

MOND--Natalie, on December 11 in Stony Brook, NY. A retired Brooklyn school teacher, she relocated to Boca Raton, FL. She was a captain in the Palm Beach Sheriff's Volunteer Office. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Stanley Mond, mother of Valerie (and Edward), Gregg (and Lauri), and Jeffrey (and Debbie), and grandmother of Alissa, Samuel, Jarrett, Carolyn, Nicollette, Noah, and Jenna. Funeral services at Shalom Memorial Chapel, 760 Smithtown Bypass, Smithtown, 10am, Sunday December 14, followed by interment at Mt. Hebron.

GINSBURG--Milton, passed away peacefully in Surfside, FL, originally from the Bronx. He worked as a Commander for the Maritime College in New York. Service will be at the Beth David Cemetery, Long Island, Sunday, December 14th, 10am.

EISEN--Marc Sollar. We mourn the loss of our beloved nephew, Marc Sollar Eisen. He fought valiantly and we are proud of him. We loved him and we will miss him. Aunt Siema, Uncle Arnold, David Sollar, Marilyn, John, Phoebe McCormack

PALMER--Lon T. Beloved husband of 56 years to Roberta Boyer Palmer, devoted father to sons Jason and Shelly Palmer and his wife, Debbie, adoring grandfather of Brent and Jared Palmer and Alexis and Andrew Zinberg and great-grandfather to Emma Zinberg. He was born in Manhattan, son of the late Martha and Maxwell Palmer and brother of the late Stan Palmer. After being graduated from Brooklyn College, attending the Juilliard School of Music and receiving a Masters Degree in Music Education from Columbia Teachers College, ROTC Bandmaster/1st Lieutenant Palmer commanded the 504th Air Force Band out of Kansas City, MO. As a young man Lon volunteered many hours as a Boy Scout leader and established a Drum and Bugle Corps at the Brooklyn Navy Yard Boys Club. A consummate music teacher, he led numerous bands and many drum and bugle corps and taught Orchestral Music at Springfield Gardens Junior HS. He was the founder of the Palmer Music Center and Music School in Belrose, NY and the owner of Freeport Music, the oldest music store on Long Island. He was a pioneer in the musical instrument mail order business, was president of musicalinstruments.com and the owner of US Regulation Bugle. Services Sunday, December 14, 11:30am at The Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to: The Lon T. Palmer Music Education Fund at Rockefeller Philanthropy Advisors, 6 W 48th Street, NYC 10036
SIDEL--Nancy J. 12/13/07. One year has gone by. We will always miss that sparkle in your eye, infectious smile, and boundless enthusiasm. Patrick

Bettie Page, a legendary pinup girl whose photographs in the nude, in bondage and in naughty-but-nice poses appeared in men's magazines and private stashes across America in the 1950s and helped set the stage for the sexual revolution of the rebellious '60s, died Thursday in Los Angeles. She was 85. Her death was reported by her agent, Mark Roesler, on Ms. Page's Web site, bettiepage.com.

PISTRONG--Philip, age 94, on December 12, 2008, in Fairfield, CT. Widower of Amelia, uncle of Dolores Ward and David Strong. Longtime Officer with NYPD, WWII Navy Veteran. Services Sunday, December 14, at 11am at Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield Gardens, NY.

Kelly Slater concluded the most dominant season in the history of competitive surfing with a win at the Billabong Pipeline Masters in Sunset Beach, Hawaii, the final event of the 2008 season. It was Slater's record sixth Pipeline title, but his first in nine years at the famed barreling break on the North Shore of Oahu. No other surfer has won the Masters more than four times. Slater, 36, clinched the 2008 Association of Surfing Professionals World Tour championship in October. It was a record ninth title for Slater.

The Senior Knockout Teams at the Fall Nationals in Boston was a strong event, with many well-known players competing. The final, played on Nov. 26, featured Richard DeMartino of Riverside, Conn.; Geoffrey Brod of Naples, Fla.; Pat McDevitt of Brookline, Mass.; and John Stiefel of Wethersfield, Conn., playing against Reese Milner of Los Angeles; Matthew Granovetter of Cincinnati; Fred Chang and Sam Lev of New York; John Carruthers of Toronto; and P. O. Sundelin from Sweden. The 64-board match was close throughout, but the Milner team won by 113 international match points to 97.

Arouh of West Palm Beach, FL, cherished grandson of Jean J. Arouh, devoted brother of Russell A. (Dara) Arouh, and adored uncle of Micah J. Arouh. Temple services will be held Sunday, December 14, 2008 at 12:00pm at Westchester Jewish CenterRockland and Palmer Ave. Mamaroneck, NY 10543. Memorial contributions in his memory may be made to Westchester Jewish Center, the Lonnie A. Arouh Memorial Fund.

LOMBAER--Forest R. The Board of Directors, staff and volunteers of the Carter Burden Center for the Aging note with profound sadness the passing of Forest Lombaer, father of our esteemed Board member, Susan L. Burden. LIEBERMAN--Florence (Adler), died December 4, 2008. Loving wife of 65 years of Herman. Beloved mother of Adele Tauber, Vivian Lieberman and the late Frances Lieberman. Devoted grandmother of Daniel, Miriam, Michael and Elizabeth and great-grandmother of Flora. She was born in Jerusalem in 1920 and immigrated to the United States at age nine. She was pious, loving and kind. She will always be remembered with love by her family.

PACK--Howard M.,of Scarsdale, NY died of heart failure on December 9, 2008, at age 90. He graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Columbia University in 1939. He served in WWII as a cryptanalyst in the US Coast Guard, working to break the code on the German Enigma machine. Howard was an entrepreneur, cofounding Seatrain Lines in 1951. The company operated tankers and container ships, and constructed supertankers in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. At the time of his death he served on the board of directors at Emisphere Technologies, Inc., a biopharmaceutical company he co-founded in 1986. He was an avid golfer, and played year-round at Old Oaks Country Club where he was a member for 70 years. Howard was predeceased by his first wife Nancy and his son Daniel R. Pack, M.D. He is survived by Dorothy, his wife of 47 years, his sister Ethel, his brother Jay and his wife Nancy Dunnan. Also surviving are his son Warren, his daughters Susan, Loren and Ellen, his daughters-in-law Rusti and Maggi Pack, Ph.D. and his sons-in-law Robert Klinek, Rob Beyer and Jeff Williams. He was cherished grandfather to: Marcy, Nancy, Samantha, Benjamin, Savanna, Lily, Bliss, Belle and Maya. Memorial services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison at 81st, at 5pm on Saturday, December 13. No flowers, please.

von BULOW--Sunny. 1932-2008. The Staff and Board of Directors of the National Center for Victims of Crime honor the memory of Sunny von Bulow and are deeply grateful for the support of her children, Ala Isham and Alexander von Auersperg, who founded the National Center 25 years ago. Their vision and generosity have given a much-needed voice to crime victims and have helped millions of victims rebuild their lives. Victim Helpline: 1 - 800 - FYI - CALL; www.ncvc.org.

KNICKS GET REINFORCEMENTS Nate Robinson (strained groin) and David Lee (bruised back) are expected to rejoin the Knicks' rotation Saturday in Sacramento. The Knicks play the Suns on Monday. It will be Coach Mike D'Antoni's first game against Phoenix since joining the Knicks. HOWARD BECK

von BULOW--Martha Crawford (''Sunny''), 77, died on December 6, 2008 at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home in New York City. Raised in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and New York City, our mother was the only child of the late Annie Laurie Aitken and the late George W. Crawford, founder of Columbia Gas and Electric and Lone Star Gas Company. Our mother touched the lives of many. She will be warmly remembered, first and foremost, as a devoted, loving and caring mother. She was also a generous patron of the arts in both New York City and Rhode Island. Our mother is survived by our spouses, Ralph H. Isham, Nancy Auersperg and Ricardo Pavoncelli, and nine grandchildren: Sunny Kneissl, Alexandra Kneissl, Nicolas Isham, George Isham, Anna von Auersperg, Alfi von Auersperg, Nicholas Pavoncelli, Marina Pavoncelli and Antonia Pavoncelli. She was married to the late Prince Alfred von Auersperg and Claus Von Bulow. Both marriages ended in divorce. For the past 28 years, our mother remained in a persistent vegetative state and was cared for at New York Columbia Presbyterian Hospital and Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home. We are grateful to her private duty nurses and the staff of both facilities for caring for her all these years. A private memorial service for family and friends will be held at Brick Presbyterian Church at 62 East 92nd Street, New York, NY on January 14th 2009 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, our family requests that donations be made in our mother's memory to the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association. Ala Isham, Alexander von Auersperg and Cosima Pavoncelli

Cardinal Avery Dulles, a son of diplomats and Presbyterians who converted to Roman Catholicism, rose to pre-eminence in Catholic theology and became the only American theologian ever appointed to the College of Cardinals, died on Friday at Fordham University in the Bronx, where he had taught. He was 90. His death, at the Jesuit infirmary at the university, was confirmed by the New York Province of the Society of Jesus.

But their trip to Dallas on Sunday night should provide a reprieve. The Cowboys have their own receiver controversy to fill headlines and color commentary.

von BULOW--Martha. The Board of Directors of the NeuroTrauma Foundation mourns the passing of Martha ''Sunny'' von Bulow and expresses its deep sympathy to her children Ala Isham, Alexander von Auersperg, and Cosima Pavoncelli. Sunny von Bulow, the inspiration for the establishment of the NeuroTrauma Foundation, was a generous benefactor of innovative brain injury research and the development of brain injury treatment guidelines. Her family's support raised awareness and advanced the field of brain injury treatment for thousands of people around the world. Peter C. Quinn, Director NeuroTrauma Foundation

Alcatel-Lucent, the struggling telecommunications equipment maker, said it would cut 1,000 jobs as part of a plan announced by its new chief executive to save 750 million euros ($1 billion). The job cuts will affect 1.3 percent of Alcatel-Lucent's 77,000-person global work force, disappointing some analysts who expected a more fundamental revamping from Ben Verwaayen, a former chief executive of the BT Group, who took the helm of Alcatel-Lucent in September. In addition to the 1,000 cuts, the company will trim 5,000 contract workers. The company, created in November 2006 with the merger of Lucent Technologies and Alcatel, has struggled since its inception, losing about 5.4 billion euros ($7.2 billion) through September.

A capsule summary on Friday about a review of an exhibition of jewelry made by Alexander Calder misidentified the museum where the exhibition is on display. It is the Metropolitan Museum of Art, not the Whitney Museum of American Art. (The Whitney currently has a different Calder exhibition.)

BUSH--Dianne Colhoun, passed on December 10th at Select Specialty Hospital in Augusta, GA after complications from surgery. She will be remembered with love by her husband Monroe Bush and son Monroe, her mother Rosalie Hook, her sisters Lynn, Julie, Jillian Colhoun, Lisa Jeffery, and brother Steve Colhoun, as well as numerous friends from her 64 years of Benevolence and Joy. Di Di was raised in Connecticut and lived in New York City until 2001. Service is December 13 in Augusta.

EISEN--Marc Sollar, passed away December 11, 2008 (pm). Loving husband of Justine. Beloved son of Elaine Sollar Eisen and Edwin Roy Eisen. Cherished nephew of Arnold and Siema Sollar. Sonin-law of Anthony Ciringione. Loved cousin of David Sollar, Marilyn, John and Phoebe McCormack. Devoted brother-in-law of Anthony and Camilla Ciringione. Uncle to Anthony Ciringione, Jr. Brotherin-law to Anna and Matthew LaPorte, and Francesca Ciringione. Marc's loving ways, family devotion, clever wit and generous nature will live in the hearts of his family and all he touched. We will all miss you. Funeral Services will take place 11:45am on Sunday, December 14th at: Riverside Memorial Chapel (212)362-6600, 333 Amsterdam Ave. (between West 75th and West 76th Streets.)

Von BULOW--Martha. The Board of Directors of the International Neurotrauma Research Organization, based in Vienna, Austria, expresses its sympathy to the family of Martha von Bulow. Financial support from her has underwritten seminal research in the field of head injury and trained physicians which has directly improved the care of brain-injured patients worldwide. Johannes Orsini Rosenberg, President of the International Neurotrauma Research Organization

Add “Gypsy” to the growing list of Broadway shows that will shutter in January as a result of the faltering economy. The production, which led to Tony awards for its stars Patti LuPone, Boyd Gaines and Laura Benanti, will play its final performance at the St. James Theater on Jan. 11, its producers announced on Sunday. “Though we originally announced that “Gypsy” would play its final performance on March 1, 2009, due to these uncertain financial times my partners and I have made the difficult decision to close instead on January 11, 2009,” said Roger Berlind, one of the show’s producers, in a statement. For the week ending Dec. 7, the show filled just over 64% of the seats, and the week before was at less than 52% capacity. Come Jan. 11 the musical, directed by Arthur Laurents with a book by Mr. Laurents, music by Jule Styne and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim, will have played 27 previews and 332 regular performances.

As you've probably heard on the news, its been raining a lot in Rome of late, swelling the Tiber (or Tevere, in Italian) River to a point where the arches under some of the famous bridges are mostly submerged. For visitors wandering Rome's historic piazzas and monuments, there's really no distruption or risk -- although there are reports that an Irish visitor fell in and drowned while leaning over to observe the roiling waters. Although the Tiber was prone to regular flooding in the 19th century, since an early 20th century construction project it is now contained within high cement banks that are still meters higher than the current water level.

Dallara, the Indy Racing League chassis builder, will be charging teams less for spare parts during the 2009 IndyCar season. An article on Page 68 of The Magazine this weekend about innovations in health care sponsored by the Positive Deviance Initiative at Tufts University reports on the institute and its director, Jerry Sternin, and includes his detailed explanation of the initiative’s work. An article last Sunday about a new report debunking a theory that the United States heard a coded warning about the Pearl Harbor attacks misspelled the surname of the German chargé d’affaires to the United States at the time, who was quoted in a government memorandum from November 1941 predicting that war between the United States and Japan was inevitable. He was Hans Thomsen, not Thoman.

An article last Sunday about credit ratings assigned by Moody’s Investors Service misattributed the content of an e-mail message that said the firm did not do enough to alert investors to mortgage risks. Christopher Mahoney, a former vice chairman of Moody’s, copied the statement from an online message board and sent it to the firm’s chief executive by e-mail; the comment was not by Mr. Mahoney.

It was pretty much inevitable that Alex Kuczynski’s article on surrogacy (Nov. 30) would inspire contempt and ridicule in the blog­osphere. After all, she is beautiful, slim, wealthy and cheerfully unapologetic about it all; she does not try very hard to deflect envy. But grief is grief no matter how much money you have, and I can say with certainty — having struggled with infertility myself, and having been criticized for being a privileged New Yorker who threw lots of money at the problem (and wrote about it) — that Kuczynski’s sadness and feelings of emptiness could not be washed away by her millions. Yes, ultimately money did help her solve her problem — most of us, myself included, could not have afforded innumerable rounds of IVF and, when all else failed, gotten a womb for hire. And yes, she could have adopted, she could have been child-free, she could have done many things.

Why does Mickey Rourke still grab us? His acting talent, his temper, his lost marriage, his boxing, his Chihuahuas (Pat Jordan, Nov. 30)? To the Editor: Your recent article “Florence, Then and Now” (Nov. 30) was a source of such pleasure to me. I spend October there each year, in a tiny apartment just off Piazza Salvemini, and at day’s end often stroll down Via Dante, spend an hour sitting outside near the very spot pictured in your article, sip a cup of coffee and watch the “show.” Heaven only knows if I will be able to return next October, but if not, I will just pull out your article and enjoy Firenze again vicariously. Many thanks.Charlsie Harris.

DELSON--Dorothy Haupt, of New York City and Lenox, MA, died December 2, in Palm Beach, FL, in her hundredth year. Beloved mother of Mary D. Silverman of New York City and Amy L. Delson (m. Frank Kaplan) of Atherton, CA; cherished grandmother of Sarah K. Delson (m. Larry D. Kramer) of Stanford, CA, Benjamin Silverman of Los Angeles and Jennifer Kaplan of Chicago; great-grandmother of Veronika Kramer. Dorothy, born September 1, 1909, youngest of four children of Adolph and Mary Haupt, began her century-long journey on the cobblestones of Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn. Her 51-year marriage to fair labor and international lawyer Max Delson, who died in 1988, was a true partnership. She shared his dedication to civil rights and equal justice, values they passed to their children. The couple traveled the world in the course of his work on behalf of developing nations. In 1972, devastated by the early death of their son, Arthur, they found joy in seeing their grandchildren grow and thrive. In widowhood Dorothy maintained an active interest in the social and cultural life of New York City, wintering in Palm Beach and traveling often, including a world cruise in her late 80's. A valued mentor and gracious hostess, she had a gift for making lifelong friends wherever she went, and relished her role as adored grandmother and great-grandmother. Dorothy was an enthusiastic supporter of many causes, especially The Morgan Library. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Morgan at 225 Madison Avenue NY, NY 10016 in her name are suggested. Dorothy Delson was privately interred in Stockbridge, MA.

Sonin-law of Anthony Ciringione. Loved cousin of David Sollar, Marilyn, John and Phoebe McCormack. Devoted brother-in-law of Anthony and Camilla Ciringione. PACK--Howard, maritime industry entrepreneur, was a friend, role-model and generous benefactor to the students of P.S. 86. The faculty of The Kingsbridge Heights School, The Bronx, extends its heart felt condolences to the Howard Pack family.

MURPHY--Jean C. Triolo of Glen Cove, LI, NY passed away peacefully and surrounded by love in her home on December 11, 2008. Beloved mother of Mimi and the late Marty Murphy. Loving sister of Sadie Irwin, Salvatore Triolo and the late Nat Triolo. The family wishes to extend their gratitude to Dr. Sarwat Kamal whose compassion, generous spirit and kindness to both Jean and Mimi was monumental in their greatest time of need. Jean was a graduate of Immaculata High School and Pace University. She dedicated her professional life to the North Shore University Hospital at Manhasset as the Finance Supervisor of five departments. Jean will always be remembered as a leader in her field and a mentor and inspiration to those who had the pleasure of knowing her. Jean was a pure person, a woman of great depth, integrity, honor and old fashioned values. She had a great sense of humor. A voracious reader, Jean had a encyclopedic knowledge on a broad range of subjects and loved crossword puzzles, all of nature and her favorite four pawsPenni Nuggets. Jean will be forever cherished and remembered for a courageous full life lived extraordinarily well. Rest well Mommy-my heart is broken. A funeral mass was held at St. Boniface Martyr Church, Sea Cliff, L.I. officiated by Father Fred. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery.

WITH more than 10,000 high-end designer pieces and 7,000 pairs of drool-inducing shoes (including, apparently, every style Manolo Blahnik has ever made), Irene Albright, the owner of an eponymous fashion library and lending showroom, had no choice but to open a store. Her apartment, which is adjacent to the showroom, was being threatened with overspill. ''I envisioned myself living in the park across the street, pointing up to my window and saying, 'That used to be my home,' '' she said. Her new store, several doors down from the showroom, is where all the excess Dolce & Gabbana cocktail dresses, Chloé runway shoes and Narciso Rodriguez shearling coats from seasons past (as well as some current designs) are now relegated, at 70 to 80 percent off their original prices. Called Mina, after her daughter, the store is a dream come true not just for shoppers, but also for Ms. Albright (with her daughter, left). The front of the space functions as an art gallery, a venture Ms. Albright, a former artist, always wanted to undertake. (A show of large-scale paintings by Monica Serra is now on view.) ''The intention was to create a fun environment to display works of art,'' she said, ''whether it's fashion or paintings.''

MARIO RICHARD, 42, A PILOT FROM MOAB, UTAH, BASE JUMPS OFF NEARBY TOMBSTONE CLIFF, AUG. 8, 2008 ''In skydiving, you're in a flying craft. There's no real effort involved to get up there. In BASE jumping, you're always involved in bringing your own self up. So it's not just the jump, it's the whole adventure you put together. You see a cliff you're into, you figure out how to get there. Is it a good spot to jump? Is there a good place to land? Can I do this safely? The risks are pretty obvious; BASE jumping is all about stacking the odds in your favor. When you know your own limit and limits of your gear, it can take you amazing places to do amazing things. There's stuff to jump off everywhere. If I go to New York, I'll try to get hooked up with the local jumpers; Germany, same thing. I did Angel Falls in Venezuela. Its a good complement for travel: you get to see all the sights, literally from a different perspective.'' As told to Seth Kugel

Is there no limit to the inventive mind? Seemingly not. Just when you feel it has been stretched to its ends, well, along comes something like a vending machine for crows, inducing man's least-favorite birds to deposit coins in exchange for peanuts. Or a hockey player who devises a novel way to confuse the opposing goalie. Or a dog-poop forensics squad. Or students who figure out the optimal strategy for waiting for the bus. Or the Tokyo construction company that has turned traditional demolition on its head, starting with the bottom floors and working its way upward. Welcome back to the Year in Ideas issue. For the eighth year in a row, we have compiled an alphabetical digest of ideas, from A to Z (almost), that helped make the previous 12 months, for better or worse, what they were. While we have tried to maintain the light and puckish tone of the issue, we have also included a fair number of entries about economics and finance, in acknowledgment of the global crisis, which would benefit from as much thinking as it can get. (We have marked these entries with a dollar-sign light bulb.) We hope you will also enjoy the whimsical creations built and photographed by Vik Muniz (who also did the cover art), as well as the alphabetical lettering, created by Yeohyun Ahn and Ricard Marxer using Caligraft, a software program for ''computational calligraphies.'' And as for next year, who knows? But you can be sure that someone someplace is even now hatching a new idea that will make us scratch our heads in awe. Look out for this icon for ideas about the economy.

YNTEMA--Lois Elizabeth Hite, 82, died November 7, 2008. The cause of death was a heart attack. Lois Elizabeth Hite was born in 1926 to Omar and June Barker Hite of Glen Rock, NJ. Lois taught English at the Washington School of the Ballet, Madeira School and American School in Liberia. Lois married Hessel Edward Yntema, Jr. in 1952. Hessel was a lawyer for USAID and the UN. They lived in Washington, DC, Liberia, Thailand, Vietnam, Egypt, and Kenya. Lois is survived by her son, Hessel Edward Yntema III of Albuquerque, NM and his wife Patricia, daughter Elizabeth Yntema Craig of Wilton, CT. and her husband John and four grandchildren, Hessel, Douwe, John, and Rebecca. Lois was predeceased by her husband and daughter Mary Loomis Yntema Orchid.

UNKNOWN to many, Louise Bourgeois, the French sculptor famous for her spider structures, also designed jewelry: a brooch and a necklace, made for herself in 1948. Ten years ago, she recreated the steel collar in an edition of 39, one of which is on view at ''Zerocarat,'' a show of rare and one-off artist-designed jewelry at the Friedman Benda gallery. There are also coiled earrings by Ron Arad, based on his Hot Ingo lamp; etched pendants by Kiki Smith; a gold necklace by the British pranksters Tim Noble and Sue Webster that spells out an indecency; a sterling silver clutch cast from termite-bored wood by the sculptor Michele Oka Doner; and 20 never-before-seen brass-and-painted-wood pendants made by Louise Nevelson as gifts for friends. Most of the pieces in the show are signed, and they range in price from $1,500 to $24,000. ''It's a nice surprise when you find out an artist you admire for his or her painting or sculpture also made jewelry,'' said Sara Benda, the curator of the show and the founder of Afsoun, an online retailer of such artist-designed jewelry. ''But you also don't have to be an art connoisseur to appreciate them. They're all beautiful, wearable pieces.''
Art Randy Kennedy

HEATH--Fenno Follansbee, Jr. 81, beloved husband and father, passed away peacefully December 5, 2008 at his home in Hamden, CT following a long illness. He was born in Hampton, VA on December 30, 1926 to the late Fenno F. and Dorothy Jones Heath. Professor Heath was the Director of the Yale Glee Club from 1953-1992, a longtime conductor of the Litchfield County Choral Union and of the University Glee Club of New Haven, CT. Widely respected as a composer, teacher and choral conductor, Professor Heath was a mentor to generations of young singers, and was active as a composer, guest lecturer and conductor long into his retirement years. Raised in Hampton, Virginia, he graduated from Newport News High School and attended Loomis School before entering Yale University. His college career was interrupted by service in the U.S. Army during WWII. He graduated from Yale with the Class of 1950 during which he conducted the Apollo Glee Club and sang with the Yale Glee Club, the Spizzwinks and the Whiffenpoofs. At the Yale School of Music he received his Mus.B. in 1951 and Mus.M. in 1952 as a student of Quincy Porter and Paul Hindemith. He remained at Yale to pursue a lifetime in music, eventually becoming the first Marshall Bartholomew Professor of Choral Conducting. Through the many tours he led nationally and worldwide he helped to bring international recognition to the Yale Glee Club. Yale's new Alumni Chorus (YAC) is a direct outgrowth of Mr. Heath's success in creating a life-long love of song in his former singers. Over the years, he has received numerous commissions for choral compositions and has received many awards including the Yale Medal, the Sanford Medal, The Yale Glee Club Medal, the University Glee Club of New York City Medal, the Mory's Cup, and the Vernon Prize for composition. Among his works are the score for the play ''John Brown's Body'', a Mass for Chorus with Brass, and collections of choral arrangements of traditional spirituals. Major works were written for four Presidents of Yale. Texts were chosen by each President and set to music by Fenno Heath. They were sung by the Yale Glee Club at the inaugurations of Presidents Kingman Brewster, A. Bartlett Giamatti, Benno Schmidt and Richard Levin. He is survived by his wife, Carol Quimby Heath of Hamden, CT, his children and extended family: Sarah Heath and Franz Douskey of Hamden, CT, Lucy (Heath) and Robert McLellan of Lebanon, NH, Marguerite Heath Ogilvy and Daniel Hertzler of Windsor, VT, and Fenno F. and Paris (Stamos) Heath III of Woodbridge, CT, and six grandchildren: Heather, Sedgwick and Benjamin Ogilvy, Max Heath, and Quinby and Eliza McLellan. Beecher & Bennett, 2300 Whitney Ave., Hamden, will handle Memorial Services to be announced at a later date. Contributions in memory of Fenno may be sent to the North Congregational Church, P.O. Box 307, New Hartford, CT 06057. To send a condolence see obits at beecherandbennett.com

von BULOW--Martha Crawford (''Sunny''), 77, died on December 6, 2008 at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home in New York City. Raised in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and New York City, our mother was the only child of the late Annie Laurie Aitken and the late George W. Crawford, founder of Columbia Gas and Electric and Lone Star Gas Company. Our mother touched the lives of many. She will be warmly remembered, first and foremost, as a devoted, loving and caring mother. She was also a generous patron of the arts in both New York City and Rhode Island. Our mother is survived by our spouses, Ralph H. Isham, Nancy Auersperg and Ricardo Pavoncelli, and nine grandchildren: Sunny Kneissl, Alexandra Kneissl, Nicolas Isham, George Isham, Anna von Auersperg, Alfi von Auersperg, Nicholas Pavoncelli, Marina Pavoncelli and Antonia Pavoncelli. She was married to the late Prince Alfred von Auersperg and Claus Von Bulow. Both marriages ended in divorce. For the past 28 years, our mother remained in a persistent vegetative state and was cared for at New York Columbia Presbyterian Hospital and Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home. We are grateful to her private duty nurses and the staff of both facilities for caring for her all these years. A private memorial service for family and friends will be held at Brick Presbyterian Church at 62 East 92nd Street, New York, NY on January 14th 2009 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, our family requests that donations be made in our mother's memory to the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association. Ala Isham, Alexander von Auersperg and Cosima Pavoncelli

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Vote For Change Long Overdue,'' Dec 7: If, as president, Barack Obama were to intervene in college football reform and bring about a real playoff system, sports fan would be ecstatic. But if reform involved capping coaches' salaries to levels equivalent to those of distinguished faculty, this would not only speak volumes concerning presidential leadership and national priorities, it would provide far greater long-term benefit to public education, college sports and national security. Jerry Frankel

SAMUEL--Berelle Katz, died on December 10th surrounded by her loving family and wonderful caregivers. Despite her prolonged, debilitating illness she was elegant, warm and generous to the end. She leaves behind her three daughters, Wendy B. Samuel, Patricia Steele and Pamela S. Heckel, son-in-law Tom, her adored grandchildren Kate and John Heckel, and her brothers Irwin and Robert. EVANS--Michael Lewis, passed away peacefully at home in NYC on Saturday morning, December 13th. Michael was 65 years old and lived with his wife Joyce in NYC and Amagansett, NY. Born 1943 in Brooklyn, to Frances and Edward Evans, he leaves his devoted and heartbroken mother, and brother, Glenn Evans. Michael was the beloved husband of 44 years of his high school sweetheart, Joyce (Garrett) Evans; cherished father of Dr. Nancy Miller and husband Kurt Miller, Dr. Adam Evans and wife Dr. Alison Gruen; adored Pop Pop to Chloe and Zachary Miller and Tess Evans. Michael also leaves his loving mother-inlaw, sisters and brothers-inlaw, nieces, nephews, and an extended family of aunts, uncles, and cousins. He was a loyal friend to many. Affectionately known as ''The Zoneman'' in both his professional and personal lives, Mike was a partner in SBWE Inc., a commercial real estate company located in New Jersey. Prior to becoming a real estate broker, Mr. Evans worked for the Bank of New York, Goldman Sachs, and Instruments Systems Corporation. Mike was a graduate of Syosset high school and New York University. He was a ''two letter man'' at NYU and a brother in the Zeta Beta Tau fraternity. Mike won the 1963 state championship of the American Bowling Congress. He was also a long time camper at Camp Green Lane, in Pennsylvania. In his career, Mike was a creative and brilliant broker, member of S.I.O.R., and mentor to many salesmen and brokers. He was the proud recipient of numerous awards in New Jersey for his real estate dealings. Mike will be remembered for his tremendous passion for life and his dedication to his family, friends, and business associates. Mike's loves included sports, music, golfing at Montauk Downs, playing cards, collecting wines, world-wide travel, and great dance moves. He was a valiant four and a half year survivor of lung cancer. The family wishes to thank Dr. Vincent Miller and colleagues at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in NYC and Hospice of New York for their compassionate and loving care. Services will be held on Monday, December 15th, at Gutterman's Chapel in Woodbury, NY, at 12:00 noon. Interment will be at New Montefiore Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY directly following services. Shiva will be observed immediately following interment as well as on Tuesday, December 16th starting at 12:30pm at the home of Nancy and Kurt Miller. Contributions in Mike's memory may be made to KIDS of NYU, contact Peter Wunsch at 212-889-8790, or to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center or Hospice of New York.

ANDERSON--Alvin Powers. Born February 9, 1948, Alvin Anderson set off on a new adventure unexpectedly November 28, 2008. A longtime resident of Williamsburg, VA, Alvin graduated from the College of William & Mary in 1970, and in 1972, earned his J.D. at the William & Mary Marshall-Wythe School of Law. He practiced law with Anderson, Franck & Davis, P.C. and with Kaufman & Canoles, P.C. Instrumental in establishing Kaufman's Williamsburg office, Alvin served as the Managing Partner until January 2008, and on the firm's Executive Committee. Despite his professional accomplishments, he would frequently remark ''I'm just a country lawyer.'' Alvin's civic commitment inspired all who knew him. Most recently, he sat on the Boards of Riverside Health System, TowneBank, and on the Board of Trustees for Hampton Roads Academy. Alvin served as President of the William & Mary Alumni Society, a member of the MarshallWythe Law School Foundation Board, and on the College's Board of Visitors. In 1998, Alvin received the Alumni Medallion, the highest honor bestowed by the William & Mary Alumni Association. Above all, Alvin was devoted to his family. He met his wife, Betsy, during their freshman year at William & Mary. Married in 1969, they raised their two daughters, Mary Beth Sherwin and Sara Paris Huddleston. Adored and loved by his wife and daughters, he will be terribly missed. Alvin once said: ''I'm proud of two things in life. One is my family and the other is my college. I told someone the other day, this makes me feel like the person my dog thinks I am.'' There never was a finer gentleman. In addition to his wife and daughters, Alvin is survived by his father, brother, sister, mother and father-inlaw, brother-in-law, two sonsin-law, and other family and friends too numerous to count. Memorial gifts may be made to the Alvin Anderson Fund for the William & Mary Alumni House (Checks should be made out to the College of William & Mary Foundation P.O. Box 2100, Williamsburg, VA 23187) or to the William & Mary Law School, where a scholarship is being established in Alvin's name. (Checks should be made out to the MarshallWythe School of Law Foundation. Note Alvin P. Anderson Scholarship in the memo and put to the attention of Sally Kellam, William & Mary Law School, P.O. Box 8795, Williamsburg, VA 23187.)

LANG--Leslie Emmet Simpkins, 74, died peacefully November 23 in Allentown, PA, daughter of Jane Grenville Lapsley and Willard Sears Simpkins. Born with cerebral palsy in Bedford, NY, Leslie lived for over 30 years in Germany, where she married Dieter Lang in 1974; he died in 1991. She returned to the US in 1997 to live in the Good Shepherd Home in Allentown, spending six happy summer vacations on Fishers Island, NY. With a zest for living, a love of music and an infectious laugh, Leslie courageously made the most out of life with a severe handicap. Remembered with affection by her brother, Rick Simpkins of Yarmouth Port, MA, three sisters: Nat S. Workum of Calgary, Alberta, Anne Simpkins of Cape Breton, NS and Jane S. Rush of Somers, NY; her stepmother, Jacqueline N. Simpkins of Barnstable, MA and numerous cousins. Memorial service at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY on December 20 at 11am. Contributions in Leslie's honor welcomed by Good Shepherd, 601 St. John's St., Allentown, PA 18103.

HELENA CHRISTENSEN, the Danish supermodel turned fashion and art photographer, is probably the only person complaining that the iPhone takes quality photos. ''I'll shake it as much as I can,'' she said, a note of disdain in her voice. ''But it still comes out perfect.'' Her photography, which has appeared in French and Italian Vogue and will go on view Monday at the Dactyl Foundation, is decidedly less perfect. ''It's the blurriness and imperfection that I love,'' she explained. ''And that strange feeling that the light can create.'' Shot mainly in Denmark and upstate New York, the landscape images, soft-focus abstractions of light, color and form, have an eerie, ethereal beauty, as if the viewer had witnessed a sublime moment in nature before putting in his or her contact lenses. Some of the photos were in fact taken with an archaic camera phone. ''I'll see something and react to it, and sometimes it's the only thing I have on me,'' Ms. Christensen said, adding that every photo printer hates her. ''They're like, 'What am I going to do with these?' ''

The Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Atlanta Falcons enter their game at the Georgia Dome after frustrating losses that came at an inopportune time in the tight race in the National Football Conference South. Atlanta (8-5) had a chance to gain ground on Carolina or Tampa Bay but could not capitalize against last-place New Orleans. Tampa Bay (9-4) was annihilated by Carolina's DeAngelo Williams on Monday, and the task does not get easier with Michael Turner this week.

ON the subject of her love for white tailored shirts, the designer Carolina Herrera once remarked that ''a woman always looks well in white.'' From her appearance alone, we would have to agree. White clothing imparts a luminosity and air of optimism to the wearer -- a sense of the good life, so to speak. And right now, amid all the dark clothes and all-pervading gloom, it looks and feels especially right. Just check out Alexandra and Theodora Richards (right). Wearing winter white dresses at a party last month, the sisters fairly glowed. The dominance of black coats is not to be blamed on the grim news from Wall Street. Working women who are juggling families and careers need a uniform that calls for few decisions at 5:30 a.m. Many of these coats represent investment dressing and date back a few years. What makes them exciting to the eye is the variety of silhouettes. Accents include wind-blocking gauntlet gloves and black shoes dripping over a wedge sole.

THE bailout plan for the automobile industry continued its Congressional roller coaster ride last week, and as of Thursday afternoon the bill appeared to be dead. Congressional critics, like Senator Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, senior Republican on the banking committee, say that any Detroit bailout would be ineffective unless the automakers can quickly cut costs and produce more compelling, fuel-efficient cars.

To the Editor: I was appalled to see the enormous article and consumer guide on Nov. 30 highlighting, applauding and endorsing the discount shopping malls! We are in the worst economic situation of the century, which stretches from the cities to main streets in every community. I have been in business in Darien for 31 years and have never seen a time like this. I am a ''Mom and Pop'' store that has weathered many storms. However, with 10,000 customers on my mailing list, I have virtually no one coming into shop.

To the Editor: While ''Florence , Then and Now'' offers the vision of a relaxed stay in Florence, a la E. M. Forster, one should not delude oneself into thinking that this overtouristy city is necessarily going to cooperate. Unlike 19th century (or even later) tourists, if you don't have reservations well ahead of time for the Uffizi and the Galleria dell'Accademia, you'll probably miss out completely on these must-see sights. Be prepared! Susan Goldhor

IF you're looking for an inexpensive alternative to four-wheeled travel, and want to turn a few heads in the process, you might like the Velosolex. The Velosolex is a French-built moped, essentially a single-gear bicycle with a two-stroke engine mounted above the front wheel. The unique design allows the rider to use the engine for assistance while pedaling, or to putter along on engine power alone.

Economists have been trying for decades to understand the considerable gap in wages between men and women, but they have not paid enough attention to our psychological attitudes toward breadwinning, according to Timothy Judge and Beth Livingston, organizational psychologists at the Warrington College of Business Administration at the University of Florida. What if the real difference isn't between men and women but between men who think women belong at home -- and everyone else? On average, according to ''Is the Gap More Than Gender?'' which was published in September in The Journal of Applied Psychology, men who say they believe in a traditional role for women earned a stunning $8,549 more per year than men who profess egalitarian values. Egalitarian-minded women earned $1,330 less than their male counterparts, and traditional women earned another $1,495 less.

THE NEWS Investors wary of taking on any risk actually bid down the yield on short-term Treasury notes to zero and briefly even below zero, meaning they were paying more to buy the notes than they will receive in principal and interest when the notes mature. BEHIND THE NEWS You know the financial markets are deeply nervous when a guaranteed loss on three-month Treasuries is seen as a better idea than taking a chance on any alternative investment, from stocks to bonds to commodities to bank deposits. Economists worry that such caution could slow a recovery by choking off investments in stocks and corporate bonds that businesses need to finance their operations.

von BULOW--Martha. The Board of Directors of the NeuroTrauma Foundation mourns the passing of Martha ''Sunny'' von Bulow and expresses its deep sympathy to her children Ala Isham, Alexander von Auersperg, and Cosima Pavoncelli. Sunny von Bulow, the inspiration for the establishment of the NeuroTrauma Foundation, was a generous benefactor of innovative brain injury research and the development of brain injury treatment guidelines. Her family's support raised awareness and advanced the field of brain injury treatment for thousands of people around the world. Peter C. Quinn, Director NeuroTrauma Foundation

SAMUEL--Berelle Katz. Sarah Lawrence College mourns the loss of Berelle Katz Samuel, a graduate and former trustee whose support and involvement with the College has left a lasting mark. She served on the Alumnae Board from 1978-82, then the Board of Trustees from 1982-86. Mrs. Samuel and her family established the Frank M. Katz Scholarship Fund for Architecture and the Visual Arts, in honor of her late father, as well as the Donald C. Samuel Fund for Economics and Politics, in honor of her late husband, who had also served as a trustee. John A. Hill Chairman of the Board Karen R. Lawrence President

HOROWITZ--Bernice (Bunny), vivacious, warm, loving wife, mother, grandmother, philanthropist, fashionista and activist died in New York City December 10, 2008 from complications due to pneumonia. She was 84 years and widow of Arthur Horowitz, founder of Juniors Restaurant in Miami Beach. Born in New York City, Bunny lived in Miami for nearly sixty years and was a communal force. She and Arthur supported local and national arts organizations. In recognition of their generosity, Jacques DAmboise dedicated a ballet he choreographed to Stravinskys Symphonetta, which premiered at the NYC Ballet, to Bunny and Arthur. Avid art collectors, they built a distinctive collection with works by Picasso, Matisse, Chagall, Hans Hoffman, Archipenko and Andy Warhol. She had a sharp eye for fashion and founded Berenaka, a boutique of one-of-a kind art to wear and was ahead of her time in championing artists who worked in this genre. A passionate and fiery supporter of Israel, Bunny was, in 1994, named Woman of Valor. In 1999, Taffy Gould, philanthropist, honored her by naming the administration building of Alexander Muss High School in Hod Ha'Sharon, Israel, The Bunny Horowitz Administration Building. Bunny adored dance and won awards for ballroom routines. She was a natural hostess. Bunny and Arthur's homes in Florida and Aspen were gathering places where friends, politicians, artists and family were feted with fabulous food, flowers and music which ranged from classical to jazz. A service will be held in New York City, December 18, 3pm, Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 St. A memorial service will be held in Miami at a date soon to be announced. Bunny is survived by three sons, Jeffrey and Steven who live in New York City, James, who lives in Aspen and five grandchildren, Jesssica, Zoe, Will, Adam, Jake and Simon.

PERT --Rev. Dr. Florence W. The first woman ordained in the 360-year history of the Collegiate Churches of New York and the first woman to preach from the pulpit of the renowned Marble Collegiate Church, died of cancer on December 9. As Senior Associate Minister Emerita of Marble Collegiate Church since 2002, she continued her involvement in ministerial activities both there and throughout the country until a few months before her death. She was 78. Born in Birmingham, AL, Dr. Pert attended Ward-Belmont School in Nashville, TN (now Harpeth Hall School), and was graduated from BirminghamSouthern College in 1951. Moving to New York in 1953, she was employed by PanAmerican World Airways, where her responsibilities included supervising travel arrangements for UN Secretary-General Dag Hammarskjold. Her decision many years later to apply to seminary was inspired by her deepening involvement in young adult activities at Marble Collegiate Church, whose minister was the internationally known Dr. Norman Vincent Peale. There she met George H. Pert, of Tenafly, New Jersey and they married in 1957. Within a few years she left Pan-Americian to become Director of Leadership Development for Guideposts magazine, and together she and her husband conducted workshops around the country on the dynamics of small groups and lay ministry. The Perts divorced in 1974 but remained friends until his death in 2007. In 1973, Dr. Peale named her Director of Lay Activities at Marble Collegiate Church, where she created a host of activities still in place today, including small groups, adult education, women's groups, and a program for ushers and greeters, and new members. Along with Dr. Pert's preaching, such broad-based congregational involvement has inspired hundreds of laypersons to undertake leadership roles in Marble Church and in churches throughout the country. Upon receiving her M.Div. degree from New York Theological Seminary, she faced the challenge of gaining approval for ordination in a denomination with four centuries of all-male ministry. Widespread support from many quarters reversed this policy, and she was ordained at Marble Collegiate Church in 1987 and named its senior associate minister. Dr. Pert's ministry centered on increasing the role of laity and especially of women. As a board member of the ecumenical ministry Faith@Work, she spearheaded a national effort to foster leadership positions for women in ministry and in lay activities. Through workshops around the country under the auspices of Dr. Peale's School of Practical Christianity, she and others trained hundreds of clergy in spiritual renewal. Honors granted to Dr. Pert included a community service award from the Harlem Interfaith Counseling Service; a BUDDY award from the Legal Defense and Education fund of NOW; citation as Trustee Extraordinaire and Distinguished Alumna of New York Theological Seminary, which also awarded her an honorary Doctorate of Divinity degree in 1998; Distinguished Alumna and Member of the National Advisory Board of Harpeth Hall; and Distinguished Alumna of Birmingham-Southern College. A newly constructed meeting room for the Board of Elders and Deacons of Marble Collegiate Church is to be dedicated to her memory and named in her honor. Dr. Pert is survived by her sister, Dr. Roye E. Wates, of Boston. A memorial service will be held at Marble Collegiate Church, January 10 at 2:00pm, with interment in Birmingham to follow. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in her name to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York or to a memorial fund to be established in her name at Marble Collegiate Church.

LERNER--Judge Joseph H.,of South Orange, NJ and Sunny Isles Beach, FL died on November 22, 2008. As far as his family was concerned, Judge Lerner died a premature death at the age of 94. His sharp mind, his keen sense of humor, his boundless love of his family, and his unfailing support for President-Elect Barack Obama were with him until he died. Born in Newark, NJ, to Russian immigrant parents, Judge Lerner received a Bachelor's degree from Upsala College and a law degree, with honors, from Rutgers Law School. He went on to become an attorney for the Draft Board in World War II, a Municipal Judge in Newark and Director of the Alcoholic Beverage Control, a cabinet position, in the Administration of Governor Brendan Byrne of New Jersey. A renowned civic leader, he rose to be a National Vice President of the Zionist Organization of America, he was a member of the Board of Trustees of Congregation Beth El of the Oranges and Maplewood in South Orange and President of its Men's Club. He also served on the board of The Anti-Defamation League. In 1947 he traveled to Palestine with the ZOA on a mission to secure statehood for Israel. Israel officially became a state in 1948. Judge Lerner with his first wife, Bea, spearheaded many Democratic events, including The Governor's Ball for then candidate John F. Kennedy which attracted nearly 100,000 supporters to the Newark Armory. Noted guests included Frank Sinatra, Sammy Davis Jr., Peter Lawford, Joey Bishop, Tony Curtis, Janet Leigh and Adlai Stevenson. President-Elect Kennedy attributed much of his win in New Jersey, a crucial swing state, to this decisive event. Judge Lerner's first wife, Bea, succumbed to Alzheimer's in 1992. He is survived by his second wife, Joyce; his son, Rabbi Michael Lerner, the activist and Editor of Tikkun in Magazine, who resides in Berkeley, CA with his wife Rabbi Debora Lerner; his daughter, Trish Vradenburg, a TV comedy writer, Playwright and Alzheimer's Activist who resides in Washington, DC with her husband, George Vradenburg, philanthropist and former chief counsel of CBS, FOX, and AOL-Time Warner; three grandchildren and their spouses: Alissa Vradenburg and Michael Sheresky of LA, Akiba and Sunny Lerner of San Francisco and Tyler and Jeannine Vradenburg of Chicago; and five great-grandchildren: Ellie, Jeremiah, Maxine, Gavin, and Harrison. Donations in his honor may be made to The Alzheimer's Association/Rally for Research c/o Meryl Comer at 9826 Connecticut Avenue, Kensington, MD 20895 or Tikkun Magazine, 951 Cragmont Ave., Berkeley, CA 94708.

HYDE--Liza Piper, (nee Lisa Prokoff), on December 11 at her home in Manhattan. Beloved wife of the late Henry Baldwin Hyde and Eugene Stanton Piper. PROOF There's something in the alone-in-the-crowd-ness of the holiday party circuit, the forced pleasantries and laughter, the charge to be friendly and engaging -- but only in a superficial way -- that is very much like the existential condition of the alcoholic psyche. So the holidays not only remind me of drink; they remind me of how it felt to be a drunk. In fact, I have frequently been overheard to explain to the sort of person who still finds it good sport to ask me how I came to be addicted to alcohol and what it's like now to be stone cold sober: ''You know how you feel at Christmas at the umpteenth family gathering or company cocktail party. You really need that drink, right? That's the way I used to feel all the time.''

HOPKINS--James D.,died on November 26, 2008 at home in Tucson, Arizona. He was 82. Survived by wife, Elenore J. Hopkins (nee Kosciuk-Gerlak), her children John Gerlak and Andrea Clemens (Conrad) and three grandchildren. Born in Chicago, Illinois; was graduated from St. George High School in 1944, and Loyola University in 1948. Served in the United States Navy in World War II. Owner and Chief Executive of Chicago Temporary Staffing Services and Gold Star Staffing in Phoenix, Arizona. Nature lover, outdoorsman, recreational pilot, accomplished sailor and scuba diver, and golfer. The family is grateful to Carondolet Hospice for their loving care, and to Dr. Terry Carden, trusted friend.

I would like to do a combination trip of Jerusalem and Petra. Could I fly to Jerusalem, stay three nights and then cross the border to Jordan and stay another three nights? I will then get back to Tel Aviv to catch my flight. Would crossing the border be a problem? -- Rebecca Vilas ''Since Jordan and Israel have diplomatic relations, there is, in principle, no problem,'' said Steven Erlanger, the Paris bureau chief for The Times, who previously led the paper's bureau in Jerusalem. Mr. Erlanger wrote ''Jerusalem, Now'' (April 16, 2006) in Travel. In an e-mail message, he explained that it is possible to drive across the Allenby Bridge, the closest border crossing from Jerusalem . You would then take a Jordanian taxi to Petra, a drive he described as ''fairly long, windy and hot.''

The declining economy has claimed the season of another regional performing arts group. The Santa Clarita Symphony, of Santa Clarita, Calif., about 20 miles north of Los Angeles, said in a statement on its Web site that it was canceling its 2009 season due to drops in ticket sales as well as individual and corporate donations. The cancellation was reported by the Web site of The Los Angeles Times. In a statement, John Dow, the symphony’s marketing director, said: “We are not going away. However, it is unlikely that we will putting a symphony orchestra on the stage anytime soon.” The symphony said that it would have to withdraw from a concert with Art Garfunkel at the Santa Clarita Performing Arts Center in January, but that it planned to offer performances with smaller groups of musicians in more intimate settings.

While Broadway battles the recession like a Beckett character struggling with a stuck boot, the Roundabout Theater Company’s coming revival of “Waiting for Godot” has made two additions to its cast: the company announced that John Goodman, the “Roseanne” and “Big Lebowski” star, will play Pozzo, and David Strathairn, of “Good Night, and Good Luck” and “The Bourne Ultimatum,” will play his taciturn slave, Lucky. They join the play’s previously announced stars, Nathan Lane, who is playing Estragon, and Bill Irwin, who is playing Vladimir. Additionally, the show will feature set design by Santo Loquasto, costumes by Jane Greenwood and lighting by Peter Kaczorowski. The play, directed by Anthony Page, is scheduled to begin previews at Studio 54 on Apr. 10 and open on Apr. 30.

“Dexter” ended its third season Sunday night in true form, like a nicely wrapped Christmas package. And I’m glad because now I don’t have to spend the holidays trying to figure out how Dexter was going to extricate himself from that ugly situation on the Nicaraguan serial killer’s chopping block. Ginsu knives? The order was sure to get backed up in the mail.

While audiences paid about $19 million to watch Guy Ritchie’s most recent movie, “RockNRolla,” Madonna will be paying at least four times to end her marriage to him. The Associated Press reported that Madonna would settle her divorce with Mr. Ritchie, the film director, for at least $76 million; the pop singer’s publicist, Liz Rosenberg, told The A.P. that the settlement would be in the range of $76 million to $92 million, a figure that included a country home in England, and a pub that the couple owned in London. Madonna and Mr. Ritchie were married in 2000, and granted a preliminary divorce in November that will become final in January. They have a son, Rocco, 8, and an adopted son, David Banda, 3. Madonna also has a daughter, Lourdes, 12, from a previous relationship.

The drumbeat of grim news from the publishing industry continued on Monday as Macmillan, the company that operates imprints including Farrar, Straus and Giroux, St. Martin’s Press and Henry Holt, laid off about 4 percent of its staff and restructured its children’s book division.

Its newest installment hasn’t opened in theaters yet, but the “Terminator” movie franchise has already declared, “I’ll be back.” The producers behind “Terminator Salvation,” the fourth entry in the long-running film series about humanity’s battle with killer robots from the future, announced that they would make a fifth film in the series, Variety reported. “Terminator Salvation,” scheduled to open on May 22, is the first of three planned films that will star Christian Bale (of “The Dark Knight”) as John Connor, a human freedom fighter battling the robot forces. The Halcyon Company, which owns the rights to the “Terminator” series, announced the fifth film at the Dubai International Film Festival; no title or start date was given, but the movie is expected to be released in 2011.

Fans of “American Idol” who tune in primarily (if not solely) to watch unqualified contestants make fools of themselves will have fewer audition episodes to savor this season, as Fox announced several changes to the “Idol” format on Monday. Among the alterations for the show’s eighth season: “American Idol” will have only three weeks of auditions instead of four, and will now bring 36 contestants to Hollywood instead of 24; of the top 12 finalists, 9 will be chosen by audience votes, and the remaining three will be selected by the show’s judges. The coming season, which begins on Jan. 13, will also omit the annual “Idol Gives Back” charity episode, but the fundraiser is expected to return in 2010.

The woes of the Canadian dance company Ballet BC grew deeper when a bank froze about $13,750 of its funds, The Globe and Mail reported. At a news conference Friday, Graeme Barrit, the board chairman of the Vancouver-based troupe, said that Scotiabank froze the money to pay off about $13,500 in debt on the company’s credit cards. “It really is a very dramatic hit to our ability to function,” Mr. Barrit said, according to The Globe and Mail. In November, the ballet laid off 38 employees, including its dancers and creative director. Its production of “The Nutcracker,” featuring the Moscow Classical Ballet, was able to proceed after the company received a grant from the Vancouver City Council and an anonymous donor bought 1,000 tickets to the shows.
The tables are still set at the Park Avenue home of William F. Buckley Jr.
A battle is unfolding in northern Niger between a band of Tuareg nomads and an army that calls the fighters drug traffickers and bandits.
American prosecutors met with victims' families and survivors of the 2007 shootings of Iraqi civilians by private security guards. In Nisour Square, Tareq Maher interviews Iraqi police.
We have already seen how the loss of Plaxico Burress and Brandon Jacobs has hurt the Giants, and several other playoff contenders received bad news on the injury front Monday.

For the past five weeks, Dana Jennings, an editor at The New York Times, has shared his story of life as a prostate cancer patient. We've heard how the disease is often wrongly referred to as "the good cancer,'' and learned about the emasculating side effects of treatment. He has shared stories about lessons learned, the intimate and often difficult changes in a man's sex life and the surprising emotional toll of the disease.

Jack Balkin of Yale and Ann Althouse of the University of Wisconsin debate whether marriage should be replaced with civil unions for both gay and straight couples.
