Fred Beckey began climbing as a boy in the Pacific Northwest.  One of the world's most accomplished mountaineers, he is now 85 and still climbing.
The lowly shoe and the Iraqi who threw both of his at President Bush were embraced as symbols of rage at a still unpopular war.
"In Service for the Girls of the World" is a great slogan. I wonder why the YWCA ever changed it. According to its Web site, the mission now seems to be "eliminating racism" and "empowering women."

What can we learn from the potlatch ceremonies of Indians in the Pacific Northwest? In my Tuesday Findings column, I suggest some lessons for holiday shoppers, and I'd be glad to hear any more ideas from Lab readers. I argue that the potlatchers have long been ahead of the rest of society in recognizing the social utility of gift-giving -- and they were certainly far ahead of the missionaries and agents of the Canadian government who tried to stop these ceremonies in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

Among the many camps convinced that human-caused climate change requires an aggressive response, there is still a big split on how best to cut the odds of dangerous outcomes, and this split is represented in the energy-climate-environment team that President-elect Barack Obama formally introduced this evening in Chicago. Can Mr. Obama mediate between those putting regulation or innovation first?Carol M. Browner, the new White House coordinator for climate and energy, is a seasoned environmental regulator and campaigner who has focused on cap-and-trade legislation, which would steadily raise the cost of unfettered fossil-fuel use, and rule-making as driving the necessary change (as they did with the 20th-century basket of air pollutants).

The average sports fan doesn't know Joe Posnanski, columnist for The Kansas City Star, probably because he doesn't often appear on television shout shows. But among his sportswriting peers, he's considered among the very best.

As dessert ended, the woman in the red dress got up and stumbled toward the bathroom. Her husband, whose head had been sinking toward the bûche de Noël, put a clumsily lecherous arm around the reluctant hostess. As coffee splashed into porcelain demitasse cups, the woman in the red dress returned, sank sloppily into her chair and reached for the Courvoisier. Someone gently moved the bottle away. "Are you shaying I'm drunk?" she demanded. Even in the candlelight I noticed that the lipstick she had reapplied was slightly to the left of her lips. Her husband, suddenly bellicose, sprang from his chair to defend his wife's honor. But on the way across the room he slipped and went down like a tray of dishes. "Frank! Are you hurt?" she screamed. Somehow she had gotten hold of the brandy. "S'nothing," he replied, "just lay down for a little nap. Can I bum a smoke?"

A Saudi reportedly has offered $10 million for just one of the shoes thrown at President Bush in Iraq. That got me thinking. The journalist who threw the shoes no longer possesses them, of course, but hopefully some member of the White House staff picked them up and will do a deal with the Saudi buyer. The second one could be put on Ebay to defray the White House travel costs.
Two offshore wind farms proposed along the East Coast are running into some turbulence.

In talking Monday to some people involved in a potential deal, I get the feeling the Yankees are backing away from a potential Melky Cabrera-for-Mike Cameron trade with the Milwaukee Brewers, at least for now. The Yankees' main question is baseball-related, not financial.

Searching for new ways to make computers that run faster and use less power, the chip industry is once again eyeing some exotic materials that can offer great speed, but have been more costly and difficult to manufacture than silicon.
An item from The Associated Press:
In his first interview since announcing that he would remain with NBC, Jay Leno talks about David Letterman and Howard Stern, and why it might have been safer to stay in late night.
East Africa bureau chief Jeffrey Gettleman reports offshore on an Italian warship on efforts to combat piracy in the Gulf of Aden.
The Jets beat the Buffalo Bills, and kept their playoff hopes alive in another victory that did not come easily.

The Tremont Group, a hedge fund investment firm, had $3.3 billion in exposure to the now-collapsed money manager run by Bernard L. Madoff, making it one of the largest "feeder funds" that steered investors into the scheme.
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said Monday that it will appoint new leadership to oversee its asset-management businesses, including KKR Financial, a troubled debt affiliate.

To call it a surprising first half of the college hockey season would be an understatement, and last weekend featured more of the topsy-turvy hockey we've come to expect this semester. In the only clash between two Top 10 teams, No. 2 Minnesota and No. 9 Colorado College split a series in Minneapolis. But not everything was topsy-turvy: No. 1 Notre Dame continued to be the hottest team in the country, sweeping Bowling Green to extend its unbeaten streak to 14 games.
If you've been wondering when 3-D programming will finally be possible on TV, the answer is now. But don't expect to see it in your home right away.

The Securities Investor Protection Corporation announced Monday that it would be liquidating the investment firm run by Bernard L. Madoff, the trader accused of running a $50 billion Ponzi scheme, in an effort to return cash and securities to the firm's clients.

In all the chatter of the last couple of weeks about Caroline Kennedy's interest in Hillary Clinton's senate seat -- The Times reported today that it's for real -- there is one voice we have yet to hear: Ms. Kennedy's.

I am frequently asked to recommend earphones, and while sound quality is always a matter of personal taste, there are two brands that I find myself suggesting often. Both companies now make earphones with mics so they can be used with mobile phones.
Call me Scrooge---ten days early-but what are you gonna do with the three pairs of earbuds, or the two iPod nanos, you get for Christmas?

Still looking for the perfect personalized gift? Your time is running out, but here's a suggestion: An item on the PMA Foresight blog notes that photo books are gaining in popularity. The post says that sales of photo books will climb to $389 million this year, up from $165 million in 2006.
Carol M. Browner was named to the new position of White House coordinator for energy and environment. Barack Obama also said that he was nominating Steven Chu as Energy secretary.

Last week was a busy one in the world of hockey, with the Sean Avery controversy and the usual back-and-forth over what Mats Sundin will do. Some stories were overlooked, and it's our job here to tell them to you ... in pictures, for each one is worth a thousand words.

The Boston Red Sox are pining for Mark Teixeira, a switch-hitting first baseman who is patient and powerful at the plate and slick on defense. But the Red Sox want Teixeira at their price, not Scott Boras's price. Boras, Teixeira's agent, will wait and wait until he secures the amount he thinks his client deserves.
President Bush got a huge chuckle out of Sunday's shoe-throwing incident in Baghdad.
The matchmaking show produced by Ryan Seacrest invites a trio of mothers into a typical reality TV mansion full of eager singles.
The following is the transcript of President-Elect Barack Obama’s Energy and Environment team announcement as provided by CQ Transcriptions.

Let's not lose sight of this: There really is a war going on between the phone companies and Google over the way Internet traffic will be priced. And both sides want their self interest to appear to be morally superior.

If you are the parent of a high-school senior (or if you have even passing acquaintance with a high-school senior) you know that these weeks can bring the first waves of rejection. Rolling admission schools have started to send out their decisions.
John Harwood and Tamryn Hall discuss Caroline Kennedy's bid for a Senate seat, the scandal surrounding the governor of Illinois and President Bush's trip to Iraq with New York Times reporters.

As executives of the three Detroit automakers sat before Congress to plead their respective cases for federal financial help, they appeared a bit like the Three Men in a Tub -- all lumped together in the same boat, trying to stay afloat in stormy seas.

As newspapers lose readers and advertisers, local news seems to be dying a long, slow death. The debate over what to do about it took on new urgency last week, when the Tribune Company filed for bankruptcy protection.
First Park Slope, and now Riverdale.

Blagojevich or his staff, but Mr. Obama has agreed to a request by federal prosecutor's to withhold the review until next week.

President-elect Barack Obama will name Arne Duncan, the superintendent of schools in Chicago, to be his Secretary of Education, a senior Democratic official and a second person close to the decision said.
A. O. Scott looks back at what he considers to be the best of the film adaptations of "A Christmas Carol."
A new television spot from the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.
Free agent center Mats Sundin's agent has said that the field of suitors has been reduced to the Rangers and Canucks, according to news reports.
Finding the best value in phone services usually takes a spreadsheet, several hours at the computer, a magnifying glass for fine print and a law degree to understand it.

The final results are in, and one prediction from the campaign has come to pass - voter turnout in 2008 was the highest in recent history. As the Electoral College officially elects Barack Obama as the 44th President of the United States today, the Associated Press reports that more than 131 million Americans voted in this year's presidential election - exceeding the turnout for all presidential elections since 1968.
A few months back, I blogged about how our 1995 Toyota Corolla, now 13 years old, is ready for a new life in somebody else's garage. It's had a long, happy life in our house.
For MacBook owners who might be feeling somewhat unstable these days, the fix is in.

The Swedish Elitserien is incredibly tight: only 15 points separate first from last in the 12-team league. In Monday's only game -- the final one before everyone takes off for an 11-day Christmas break -- Luleå beat Linköping, creating a three-way tie at the top between those two clubs and Skellefteå.
Warning: I read this article on a screen.

The Supreme Court today killed off a libel suit against me and The Times that has been kicking around for years. It was brought for columns I wrote back in 2002 about the anthrax cases after 9/11: Dr. Steve Hatfill sued me and the Times for defamation and the case wound its way through the courts. A federal district court dismissed the case, the circuit course agreed, and now the Supreme Court has denied review, meaning that it's over. In August, I offended some in the journalistic community by apologizing to Dr. Hatfill, once the FBI had fingered somebody else.
The Boston Society of Film Critics announced its winners for 2008 this afternoon, and the organization was in a sharing mood.
Given the focus on cooking and eating during the holidays, this is a time of year when any deficiencies in your kitchen will quickly become apparent, says New York Times food writer Mark Bittman.
The Bush administration’s last-minute overhaul of the visa program for temporary farm workers threatens to make a flawed program worse.

Updated, 6:30 p.m. | A police officer who was caught knocking a man off his bicycle in Times Square over the summer in a video that was distributed widely on YouTube has been indicted by a grand jury, according to lawyers involved in the case.
Just in time for the economic slowdown: a new luxury train direct from New York to Atlantic City.
From our friends at the Green Inc. blog:

Yahoo has been talking about opening up its Web sites and services to outside content and applications ever since Jerry Yang became chief executive in June of 2007. In a major speech at the Consumer Electronics Show last January, Mr. Yang gave what may have been the most detailed peek at what a more open -- and social -- Yahoo Mail would look like. But it was only a demo.
Updated: One major question in the scandal surrounding Bernard L. Madoff is how one man could fool even highly sophisticated investors for decades.

BAGHDAD -- The criminal case in the September 2007 shootings of Iraqi civilians by private security guards employed by Blackwater Worldwide took another step forward this weekend when American prosecutors met Saturday with victims' families and survivors. Katherine Zoepf and Anwar J. Ali interviewed several Iraqi victims.
Hollywood has the Oscars. Broadway has the Tonys. Now Twitter has the Shorty Awards?

The Football Scientist, KC Joyner, a Fifth Down contributor, supplied three thoughts on Week 15. His latest book is "Blindsided: Why the Left Tackle is Overrated and Other Contrarian Football Thoughts."

A while ago I wrote about the fried olive-bread balls Jackie and I had eaten ages ago in Italy, but the other week we were, again, in London and ran into something just as irresistible and more intensely flavorful: deep-fried olives. A first for us, though they're really not all that uncommon. These were served with drinks at the new restaurant tacked onto the side of Grosvenor House hotel: Corrigan's Mayfair, which -- at least in wintertime -- specializes in game. My hare and Jackie's steamed game pudding (a real old-fashioned one glistening with suet) were both terrific.
Cloud computing, if you listen to Mark Benioff, is all grown up and ready for some action.

Ever since 1917 -- when Marcel Duchamp turned a urinal upside down, signed it with the fake name "R. Mutt," and called it art -- toilets (and urinals) have had a special relationship with art world. Think, for instance, of Willem de Kooning's painting on a used toilet seat, or Jonathan Hartshorn, who placed some of his drawings in a bathroom at MoMA and photographed them for a performance piece called "Down to Nature."

Every parent of a school-age child has heard the warnings about nut allergies. Some schools ban nuts entirely, while others set aside special nut-free tables. Parents are often quizzed about the ingredients and preparation methods for birthday treats they send to school. One parent told me she was asked whether a clean knife used to cut brownies had ever been used to spread peanut butter.
Auburn's hire of Iowa State Coach Gene Chizik as its new football coach certainly raised some eyebrows. It also raised the ire of the former N.B.A. star Charles Barkley, who is an Auburn alum.

More victims of Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities continue to emerge on Monday. The JEHT Foundation, a charity that supports reform of the criminal and juvenile justice systems, said that it would stop making grants and close its doors next month because its donors, Jeanne Levy-Church and Kenneth Levy-Church, were investors in the Madoff firm.

Africa | To solve the food crisis, politicians have to drop their biases against big commercial farms and genetically modified crops and do away with farm subsidies, a professor of African economies at Oxford writes. Western "romantics" dismayed by their hierarchical, specialized economies embrace small-scale farming because those very economies can afford it. Peasants have no such luxury, he says. [Foreign Affairs]
John Goodman and David Strathairn will join Bill Irwin and Nathan Lane in Roundabout Theater Company’s revival of “Waiting for Godot.”

Among the best-known boldface names who has become a victim of the Bernard L. Madoff scandal is Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the real estate magnate who owns The Daily News. Mr. Zuckerman's charity trust potentially has lost more than 10 percent of its worth after it was invested in the alleged Ponzi scheme.

A couple of weeks ago, The Village Voice asked writers to name their favorite obscure book. David Remnick chose Venedikt Erofeev's "Moscow-Petushki" ("the comic high-water mark of the Brezhnev era"). Harold Bloom mentioned John Crowley's novel "Little Big." Joseph O'Neill, the author of "Netherland," picked David Winner's "Brilliant Orange," a cultural history of Dutch soccer. Nell Freudenberger selected Austin Coates's memoir "Myself a Mandarin." Robert Pinsky chose "Caelica," by Fulke Greville - "the greatest poet unknown to many readers." Stephen L. Carter voted for Bertrand Russell's "In Praise of Idleness." And Dale Peck went with "The Zombie Pit," a collection of stories by Sam D'Allesandro.

That Bernard L. Madoff may have bilked $50 billion out of investors is shocking. But according to Eric Dezenhall, the head of the crisis public relations firm Dezenhall Resources, it is nowhere near as shocking as his purported confession.

Our sibblog, City Room, looks at the news that Caroline Kennedy will ask Gov. David A. Paterson to consider her for Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate seat, and it examines how this will likely ripple across New York politics.

Terror | Torture's unnecessary, says the former head of an interrogation team that hunted down the terrorist Zarqawi in Iraq. "The methods my team used are not classified ... We got to know our enemies, we learned to negotiate with them, and we adapted criminal investigative techniques to our work (something that the [Army] Field Manual permits, under the concept of 'ruses and trickery'). It worked." [Washington Post]

Sebastien Loeb, the 2008 WRC champion, won the Race of Champions, an annual year-end all-star event that brings together 16 drivers from different disciplines to compete on a small stadium circuit at Wembley Stadium in London.
Bankruptcy filings are accelerating in the New York metropolitan region at a faster pace than in the rest of the nation, according to figures released on Monday by the federal bankruptcy courts.
Steven J. Hatfill, a former government scientist, contended that he was defamed by a series of New York Times columns about the anthrax mailings of 2001.

No two players have dominated hockey news in the past nine months as have Sean Avery and Mats Sundin. And today we find both at critical junctions in their lives and careers.

The fallout from the scandal surrounding Bernard L. Madoff could have major repercussions for the already troubled hedge fund industry. Even before Mr. Madoff was accused of a multibillion-dollar fraud late last week, the industry was bracing for a renewed push for more government oversight. That push could gain momentum as throngs of angry investors in Mr. Madoff's funds demand recompense for their losses.

It looks as if Caroline Kennedy is indeed interested in the United States Senate seat being vacated by Hillary Rodham Clinton. Will Gov. David A. Paterson, whose decision it is, go along? What does this mean for others who have been mentioned as possible successors to Mrs. Clinton, like State Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo; Representatives Kirsten Gillibrand and Carolyn B. Maloney; Nassau County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi; and Mayor Byron W. Brown of Buffalo? And what would it mean for Ms. Kennedy, a lawyer who is close to President-elect Barack Obama, to assume the seat once held by her uncle Robert F. Kennedy and join another uncle, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts? Stay tuned.
Major League Baseball has authorized the use of team logos on a line of funeral caskets for people who want to carry their fandom unto eternity.

Jaromir Jagr is proving to be a keen observer of the contrasts between life for a hockey player in Russia and in the United States. On Sunday he gave another intriguing interview, a long and perceptive one, with Sovietsky Sport's P. Lysenko. Among the topics he discussed were his observations on the real Sean Avery, how an older North American like his waived Avangard teammate John Grahame would have trouble adjusting to Russian life, as well as Jagr's own sense of sense of comfort playing in the K.H.L.

Women | Is "crazy cat lady" the last acceptable sexist stereotype? "According to my nascent theory, there's a crucial reason why it's perfectly O.K. for a woman to prattle on endlessly about baby [poop] without being labeled a crazy baby lady; she's upholding the status quo, repopulating the earth with humans." [Pop Matters]

Hundreds of thousands of people in six states across the Northeast remained without power on Monday, as utility crews, expecting some help from warmer temperatures, worked to repair the damage wrought by a severe storm that struck on Friday.
Winter squash can seem daunting to work with, but it’s worth the effort. This savory pale orange potage makes a comforting winter meal.

Language | Take that, all you doomsayers of the English language in the age of texting. Comes now word that the 517-page French novel "Zone," by Mathias Enard -- consisting of one 150,000-word sentence -- will be published in English. Told from inside some guy's mind as he takes a train trip, the story "has a lot of commas." To which we can only add, exclamation point! [Chicago Tribune, Brainstorm]
This post follows Monday's developments concerning Rod R. Blagojevich, the Illinois governor who last week was arrested on corruption charges. The latest news appears at the top.

Investing | You've heard of penny stocks -- welcome to the age of "zero" stocks. One analyst slaps "a target price of zero" on Nortel Networks; another thinks Sirius XM is "headed for bankruptcy"; another says G.M. shareholders "will have worthless stock certificates within 12 months." Wallpaper, on the other hand, isn't cheap. At least not until now. [Business Week]

There was so much comment on my pathetically small kitchen that I wrote more on the subject, and discussed kitchen size with people like Mario Batali and Marcella Hazan, in the Week in Review.
Images from several productions of “The Nutcracker” around New York.

With several teams, including the Flyers and Blackhawks, publicly saying that they have neither the salary-cap space nor the desire to create it to sign free-agent center Mats Sundin, the Rangers have fewer competitors for Sundin's services as his decision grows closer.
Q & A with Stuart Elliott.

The Golden Globe nominations were barely announced last week before Hollywood started assigning favorites in every category. Now professional odds makers are weighing in. Betonline.com, a sports book and virtual casino based in Panama (of all places), has issued odds in every major category, with factors like other nominations and wins factoring into the formula. (These wagers are much less exotic than some of the others available on the site, like whether Mary-Kate Olsen is pregnant or not.)
Webdenda.
Are the tough economic times visible in the city's restaurants? And how?
The country’s largest nonprofit home health care provider has begun an ad campaign that asks people to imagine how they would respond to vexing medical situations.
A New York couple is betting on the idea that at least one thing is recession-proof: demand for a convenient and clean public toilet.
From the Times blog on politics, The Caucus:

The weekend was a good one for cabin work but end-of-semester responsibilities kept me close to home and the university, mostly marking up papers. I found a few hours, though, for a trip to Walden Pond in Concord, Massachusetts, where Henry David Thoreau built his cabin.

This twist on the classic Turkish shish kebab takes a great idea and makes it easier. First of all, this dish can be made indoors, although in good weather the initial browning could certainly be done on a grill. Second, it makes its own sauce, a combination of yogurt and the juices exuded by the meat and roasted vegetables.

Peter J. Henning, a colleague of Steven M. Davidoff, offers this view of the scandal surrounding Bernard L. Madoff. Mr. Henning is a professor at Wayne State Law School in Detroit where he specializes in white-collar crime. He is a former editor of the White Collar Crime Law Prof Blog.
It's rare that one finds a current-generation Apple iPod product discounted, but Best Buy stores have made an end run around that policy. Indirectly.
T Magazine's Senior Editor Sandra Ballentine opens up her little black book of tips on where to go, what to buy and whom to know.
Whether or not a bailout for Detroit comes through, battery makers are anticipating a rosy future for electric cars.

While researching Sunday's collecting piece on the largely unsuccessful first generation of American compact cars, I came across a quote about one that could go a considerable way toward explaining the rather unique world view of avant-garde jazz-rock musician Frank Zappa.

Britain | Across the pond, critical mass seems to be forming around the idea that Obama's relations with Britain will not be particularly warm. Why: His Kenyan grandfather was tortured under British colonial rule during the Mau Mau insurgency; and in Obama's recent memoir, as one columnist puts it, the British come across as "ill-dressed, pasty-faced, and racially arrogant; cramped, spotty, and joyless." [Times of London, here and here; Guardian]

As many had suspected, Canada's entry in the World Junior Championship tournament later this month will have a distinct western flavor with 12 players from the Western Hockey League on the national roster.
Huntsman and Apollo Management have settled their spat over their failed $6.5 billion deal. But the markets seem to think that only one party came out ahead.
Update | 4 p.m. Barack Obama and his family will make their way into Washington for his inaugural next month by train, with a whistle-stop procession that will begin with an event in Philadelphia.
Dust off those political science textbooks - the day has come for the Electoral College to meet and formally select the next president of the United States.

Bernard L. Madoff allegedly confided in colleagues that his investment fund was "a giant Ponzi scheme" that had bilked some $50 billion from investors. Many are already calling it the biggest Ponzi scheme in history.

The Jets' comeback on Sunday evoked an even more improbable victory in East Rutherford, N.J., in 1978. In what has become known as the Miracle at the Meadowlands, the Giants Joe Pisarcik botched a hand-off to Larry Csonka instead of taking a knee to run out the clock. Eagles cornerback Herman Edwards, who later coached the Jets, picked up the ball and ran 26 yards for the winning touchdown. As painful as the loss was for Giants fans, it marked a nadir before the rise to two championships under Bill Parcells.
South Koreans who report sub-standard food vendors for reward. (A portmanteau of the Korean for food, sik, and paparazzi.)

Buzz at the Pentax forums predicts a new Pentax K20D with built-in GPS capabilities. Pentax has not yet returned an e-mail message seeking confirmation, but speculation is that an announcement could come as early as Tuesday. The rumors stem from a leaked press release on a Greek site that provides details of the camera.
In the digital age, it seems that no Wall Street debacle is complete without domain speculators trying to get a piece of the action.
David Carr, the Carpetbagger, gives his own daily take on awards season news.

It took Jerry Ley three years and, he said, hundreds of thousands of dollars to move his restaurant, Cambodian Cuisine from a tidy space in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, to a more spacious and more conspicuous location on the Upper East Side.
The last week of the calendar year, when office workers who are obliged to work struggle to keep themselves occupied.

Writing in the Huffington Post, Elizabeth Drew, a contributor to The New York Review of Books and the author of a Watergate history, "Washington Journal: The Events of 1973-1974," reveals that she is not a huge fan of "Frost/Nixon":

If only I'd had the 800 number for Compassion & Choices in the last difficult months of my mother's life. She was paralyzed, incontinent and unable to speak. I watched the light leave her eyes and her body crumple like a rag doll's, and I knew that one day soon she would say, "Enough.''

Another day, another government plan to change the way Americans eat: The New York Times reports that Governor David Paterson will propose a special tax on calorie-laden soft drinks made by Coca-Cola and Pepsi. People familiar with the plan call it an "obesity tax."
Some big guns have jumped on the energy efficiency bandwagon, which President-elect Barack Obama has laid out as a top priority.

Nikki Finke got a nice bit of scoop on Friday, revealing that Hugh Jackman will host the Oscars. She relates that Mr. Jackman's people don't want him sullying himself with a joke-telling monologue. To the Bagger's ears, that's Oscars sacrilege. You have to have jokes. You can't enjoy the sight of the big parade balloon of the Oscars unless someone lets a bit of air out of it over the course of the evening. And as the clip above demonstrates, Mr. Jackman can tell a joke or two in a pinch.
Health news from around the Web.
HSBC, the giant European lender, put a number Monday on its potential exposure to the recent scandal involving Bernard L. Madoff. And that number had nine zeros in it.

The battery company Boston-Power has existed for just three years, but last week Hewlett-Packard -- one of the largest technology companies in the world -- said it will offer the startup's earth-friendly lithium-ion batteries in notebook computers in early 2009.

The Hollywood Reporter does a nice profile of Nick Schenk, a Minnesotan who came up with a script that caught the eye of Clint Eastwood. "Gran Torino" is currently being taken out for a spin by many critics and Oscar ninnies, and Mr. Schenk is promising that if he gets to the promised land, he will give a shout out to Grumpy's, a bar in Northeast Minneapolis.
From Tom Zeller Jr. at Green Inc.:

A silver lining for Illinois in the Blagojevich scandal? "With the unmasking of Gov. Rod Blagojevich as a kleptocrat of Paraguayan proportion, Illinois now has a real chance - its first in more than a generation - to defeat Louisiana in the N.C.A.A. finals of American political corruption," Jacob Weisberg writes at Slate.

If you ignore the critics' polls of the year's best movies - and the Bagger often does - the tea leaves that remain are telling us something. Sure, the American Film Institute, the Broadcast Film Critics Association, the National Board of Review and the Golden Globes all have shortcomings that you could ram a craft service truck through, but in the aggregate, they have deep meaning. Well, not deep, but significant. Um, maybe significant is going too far. How about plain old meaning?

President-elect Barack Obama plans to hold a press conference to formally announce members of his energy and environment team today. The rollout is expected to include Steven Chu, Mr. Obama's choice for energy secretary, Lisa Jackson as head of the Environmental Protection Agency, Carol Browner to lead the policy council on environment, energy, and Nancy Sutley to direct the White House Council on Environmental Quality.

An "obesity tax" of about 15 percent on nondiet drinks is among the taxes and fees ina $4 billion tax plan that Gov. David A. Paterson plans to introduce on Tuesday to close the now $15 billion budget deficit.

A downturn in financing for alternative energy start-ups has been relentlessly forecasted since the economic crisis took hold and oil prices plummeted. Law | There are now more fake judges on TV than real ones on the Supreme Court. What is the message sent by this "justice porn"? "Instead of making us more responsible citizens, more inclined to rely on our own good judgment rather than public institutions, justice porn popularizes the idea that the court system is a legitimate venue for mending friendships, punishing moral (but not criminal) transgressions, and seeking inspirational hugs from stern but caring authority figures." Your honor, this writer objects! [Reason]

Monday, 7:30 p.m. Comedy is the art of the available and, much to the chagrin of working comics, not-so-funny things have a tendency to abound. A chart last Tuesday with an article about the proliferation of the atomic bomb, showing the exchange of nuclear information and technology between countries, misidentified the type of reactor that India acquired from Canada, which allowed India to make fuel for its first nuclear test. It was a CIRUS reactor, not a Candu reactor.

An article on Friday about a bail hearing for Marc S. Dreier, a New York lawyer accused of stealing $380 million from hedge funds and investors using bogus identities and documents, referred incorrectly to one of the parties who had agreed to guarantee a $10 million bond that Mr. Dreier’s lawyer offered in arguing for house detention. The guarantor was Mr. Dreier’s 19-year-old son; he does not have a stepson. (The request was denied, and Mr. Dreier remains held without bail.).

HERZBERG--F. Peter M.D. passed away on December 13, 2008. Beloved husband of Monica Herzberg and the late Beatriz Herzberg. Loving father of William, Karen and Wendy. Adored by his loving grandchildren. Services today 2pm at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Tpke. Woodbury, LI.

FOX--Gerard Francis of Garden City and East Hampton, NY died December 12, 2008. Born 1923 in Manhattan, graduated LaSalle Academy and served in the Army Air Corps in WWII. Graduated from Cornell University (civil engineering) with distinction (1948), elected to Tau Beta Pi and Chi Eplison, member of Sigma Phi Epsilon. He was a bridge designer at HNTB Corp for 40 years retiring in 1988 having been a Partner for 21 years. A renowned expert in bridge design, he continued to consult on major bridge projects for Caltrans including the SF-Oakland Bay Bridge until 2007. His designs for the Rio-Niteroi Bridge in Brazil and the Dames Point Bridge in Florida were awarded the ACEC Grand Conceptor award. He received the ASCE Howard and Roebling awards for innovation in long span bridges. Other notable projects: the Delaware Memorial Bridge, Penang Malaysia Bridge, NJ Turnpike and the Newark Bay Bridge. A mentor to many engineers, taught bridge design at Columbia University for 20 years and active in Cornell Engineering Alumni. Received a Hon. Dr of Science from NJIT (1995). Elected to membership in the National Academy of Engineering (1976). Very active in professional organizations throughout his career receiving many awards and honors ASCE and IABSE (honarary member); AREMA, SSRC, and Moles (life member). He loved surf-fishing at Montauk Point. Beloved husband for 59 years of Jeanne McNulta. Loving father of daughters Patricia (deceased 2002), Maureen (Rodney VenJohn), Catherine (Genaro Lozano) and Elizabeth. Devoted grandfather of Madeline and Joseph. Brother of Grace McCabe and Donald Fox. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Friends welcome at Fairchild Sons Funeral Chapel in Garden City Wednesday from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass at St. Joseph's Church, Garden City Thursday at 10am. Donations appreciated to Cornell University (note for Gerard Fox) Box 223623, Pittsburgh PA 15251-2623.

BONDY--Eugene L. Jr. (December, 14, 1920 -December 13, 2008). Eugene L. Bondy, Jr., of Mamaroneck, died on Saturday December 13, 2008, one day shy of his 88th birthday. A former senior partner of law firm Rogers & Wells in Manhattan (now Clifford Chance) was a New Rochelle native and a magna cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Harvard. Following overseas service as a Captain in the Army Air Corps during WWII, he graduated from Columbia Law School and began his legal career at Sullivan & Cromwell in 1948, joining Dwight, Royal, Harris, Koegel & Kasky (later, Rogers & Wells) in 1956. He was a longtime chairman of the corporate department and a member of the executive committee. Following his retirement in 1990, Mr. Bondy traveled extensively with his wife, the former Anne Lawrence and read voraciously. He leaves his wife of 58 years, daughter Elizabeth Bondy of Gainesville, FL and her husband William Dunn and their children Charles, Samuel and Margaret; daughter Priscilla B. Dube of Burlington, VT and her husband Joel and their children Carolyn and Simeon; son David A. Bondy of Brooklyn, NY and his wife Debra and children Nathaniel and Lillian. He also leaves his brother, Philip K. Bondy, M.D. of North Branford, CT and his sister, Ruth Lowy of Larchmont. A memorial gathering will be held in the Spring. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

SEAN CONLY ''Re:Action'' (Clean Feed) The bassist Sean Conly reveals his hand right away on ''Re:Action,'' his small but sturdy new quartet album. Opening with ''Gazzelloni,'' a klaxon of a theme by Eric Dolphy, he invokes not only that great multireedist but also the mid-1960s generally, claiming kinship to the era's headlong entanglement between hard bop and the avant-garde.

Who says that money is tight for venture capitalists? Accel Partners, the venture capital firm in Palo Alto, Calif., behind companies like Facebook, Glam Media and MetroPCS, announced Thursday that it had raised two new funds for a total of $1 billion. Accel raised that money in just two months, an impressive feat during a time when many of the investors in venture funds are unable to come up with the money they have already committed. Many of these limited partners have told venture firms that they will not be ready to commit new money until 2010.

THE ALL-AMERICAN REJECTS ''When the World Comes Down'' (DGC/Interscope) Tyson Ritter, the singer and bassist of the All-American Rejects, is 24 now. Two years ago he said in an interview that he had seen only four concerts in his life, other than ones he'd played in. It's best not to believe a handsome rock star from Oklahoma when he says something like that -- it's like saying he was raised by wolves -- but the claim seems to fit his band's kind of rock-ribbed emo.

HOROWITZ--Bernice (Bunny), vivacious, warm, loving wife, mother, grandmother, philanthropist, fashionista and activist died in New York City December 10, 2008 from complications due to pneumonia. She was 84 years and widow of Arthur Horowitz, founder of Juniors Restaurant in Miami Beach. Born in New York City, Bunny lived in Miami for nearly sixty years and was a communal force. She and Arthur supported local and national arts organizations. In recognition of their generosity, Jacques DAmboise dedicated a ballet he choreographed to Stravinskys Symphonetta, which premiered at the NYC Ballet, to Bunny and Arthur. Avid art collectors, they built a distinctive collection with works by Picasso, Matisse, Chagall, Hans Hoffman, Archipenko and Andy Warhol. She had a sharp eye for fashion and founded Berenaka, a boutique of one-of-a kind art to wear and was ahead of her time in championing artists who worked in this genre. A passionate and fiery supporter of Israel, Bunny was, in 1994, named Woman of Valor. In 1999, Taffy Gould, philanthropist, honored her by naming the administration building of Alexander Muss High School in Hod Ha'Sharon, Israel, The Bunny Horowitz Administration Building. Bunny adored dance and won awards for ballroom routines. She was a natural hostess. Bunny and Arthur's homes in Florida and Aspen were gathering places where friends, politicians, artists and family were feted with fabulous food, flowers and music which ranged from classical to jazz. A service will be held in New York City, December 18, 3pm, Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 St. A memorial service will be held in Miami at a date soon to be announced. Bunny is survived by three sons, Jeffrey and Steven who live in New York City, James, who lives in Aspen and five grandchildren, Jesssica, Zoe, Will, Adam, Jake and Simon.

A long and intense primary campaign, the chance to elect the first African-American or the first woman to the Oval Office, a general election played out as the country fought wars on two fronts while mired in a recession. All these events, and the coming 200th anniversary of Lincoln's birth, combined to form the right climate for books about American presidents and politics. Readers sought insight in many places, from books about candidates Hillary Rodman Clinton and John McCain to those about Presidents Eisenhower and Roosevelt.

RUBIN--Dr. Leon Eli, of New York City, beloved by his family and friends, passed away peacefully on December 13, 2008. He was born April 24, 1921 in Winthrop, MA to Dr. Maurice Rubin and Celia Markell Rubin. Loving brother of Barbara, Irma and Solomon. After graduating from MIT in 1942, he enlisted in the Army and served with distinction in WWII in the Pacific, receiving a battlefield commission as a 2nd lieutenant, as well as a Purple Heart. Leon received an MS from Boston University and a Ph.D. from Columbia University in Chemistry, and then had a long career at Polaroid, where he contributed substantially to the development of instant photography. He was a loving husband to Laura Solomon, who passed away in 1968 and to Claire Dexter Robbins, his devoted wife who survives him. He is also survived by his loving sons Kenneth, Howard and Jonathan, daughters-in-law Marlene, Mary and Sheri, stepchildren Jill and Dale, sons-in-law Dan and Aaron, grandchildren Laura, Haley, Molly, Emma, Nicholas, Annalee and Jay, and greatgranddaughter Cayla. The family wishes to extend its gratitude to the doctors, nurses and staff of Mt. Sinai Hospital who showed remarkable care and dedication. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell Chapel in NYC at 1076 Madison Ave. at E. 81st St., Tuesday, December 16 at 3:30pm. Reception after service at Howard Rubin's, 120 East End Ave at 85th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, send donations in Leon's honor to the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024.
WAGREICH--Alan W.,DDS. Truly a man for all seasons. Friend extraordinaire. Our condolences to the family. Deanna and Ron Friedman

SLIDESHOW: THE SPOILS: NIGER STRUGGLES OVER EARTH'S RICHES There is wealth buried in African soil. Niger's northern desert caps one of the world's largest deposits of uranium, which could provide the country with enough cash to pull itself out of poverty. Or it could spark a war that would leave Niger more destitute than ever. An interactive graphic shows the history and geography of Africa's abundant natural resources, and a slide show of Niger Movement for Justice fighters, who want the government to give the people a share of the wealth buried beneath their homeland. Above left, a group of fighters pray in the early morning. A gun truck carries a monkey caught in the bush.

GIBSON-MALOSH--Marilyn. Oct. 3, 1951-Dec. 15, 2006. 2 years have passed since you left us. You will always be remembered and loved. Tim, your family, all of your many friends and your pets, who miss you very much.

HOWARD--Fred, on December 13, 2008. Beloved companion of Bonnie Kaye, husband of the late Fay Howard, father of John and Ron Howard and dear grandfather to Eliza, Molly, Ali, Zach and Jackson Howard. Fred's passion for everything made his life anything but ordinary. There were no constraints in his mind or actions, nothing that inhibited his enormous energy and creativity, or his appetite for life. He was a creator of ideas, of products, of companies. He inspired others to think out of the box. He was born in Germany on June 16, 1922. He fled the Nazi's and emigrated with his mother to the United States as a young man, bravely serving in the US Army during WW II in key intelligence positions with other German-born soldiers in a unit called The Ritchie Boys. After the war he founded what became the largest merchandising and point-ofsale display company in the world and was responsible for many famous merchandising icons; from Timex watch displays to the Leggs egg. Fred's devotion to improving Arab-Israeli relations spanned his entire adult life. Based on principles of tolerance and fairness, he devoted much of his energy, resources and passion to fostering a just peace in the Middle East for Jews and for Arabs. We are all diminished by the loss of his blazing intellect and provocative rascally ways. He was never boring. He died peacefully in his sleep in New York, the place he loved most on this earth. It was ''his kind of town''. Services Wednesday, December 17, 1:15pm at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

LITOFF--Ruth, on December 12, 2008. Beloved daughter of Ronald and the late Carole Litoff, adored sister of Hope (Todd), dear aunt to Charlie and treasured friend to many. Services Monday, December 15, 9:30am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Uncle to Anthony Ciringione, Jr. Brotherin-law to Anna and Matthew LaPorte, and Francesca Ciringione. Marc's loving ways, family devotion, clever wit and generous nature will live in the hearts of his family and all he touched. We will all miss you. She was pious, loving and kind. She will always be remembered with love by her family.

ANTHONY HAMILTON ''The Point of It All'' (Mister's Music/So So Def) A Southern soul singer in a hip-hop world, Anthony Hamilton flaunts his cultural differences. ''Cool,'' the first single from his new album, ''The Point of It All,'' has a guest appearance by the Mississippi rapper David Banner to share Mr. Hamilton's latest endorsement of basic pleasures over conspicuous consumption. It mixes down-home acoustic guitar and programmed drums as Mr. Hamilton sings, ''If we ain't got enough for a movie, we can just sit at home.'' In ''She's Gone,'' he goes to his mama for relationship advice, and when he falls in love with one woman, he announces, over gospelly hand claps and tambourine, that he's ''prayin' for you.''

MIDDLETON--David. Physicist and pioneer of modern Statistical Communication Theory. Age 88, on November 16. His career was devoted to the study of how information is transferred from one point in space-time to another, with numerous applications in radar, underwater listening devices, satellite technology, and wireless communications. Born April 19, 1920 in New York, he graduated from Deerfield Academy (1938) and Harvard College (1942). During WWII, as a research scientist at Harvard's Radio Research Laboratory, he refined the analysis of aluminum ''chaff'' used to jam enemy radar, protecting American aircraft from detection. He received his Ph.D. from Harvard in 1947. In 1960, he published ''An Introduction to Statistical Communication Theory''. Widely translated and reprinted, it remains the seminal text for the field. For 50 years he taught, inspired and occasionally confounded his graduate and doctoral students at Harvard, RPI, Columbia, Johns Hopkins, Texas, Rice, and URI. He was a consultant to various goverment agencies, advisory boards, and served on the U.S. Naval Research Advisory Committee (1970-1977). He was a Life Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers, and Fellow of the American Physical Society, the Acoustical Society of America, and American Association for the Advancement of Science. He was a member of the Explorers Club, Cosmos Club, and the Dutch Treat Club. Precise in speech, quick with humor, teller of outrageous puns, he was an avid reader of history, philosophy, and biography. Possessing a unique intellect, he had a deep appreciation for the arts expressed in drawing and his un-ending devotion to playing classical piano. The Cape Cod seashore, slamming tennis balls, brisk walks around New York, and popovers at the HC were among his many passions. His first marriage to Nadea Butler ended in divorce. He is survived by his second wife of 37 years, Joan; his children, Susan, Leslie, Blake and George Middleton; his step-sons Christopher, Andrew, and Henry Reed; and three granddaughters. He expected a send-off with a full orchestra playing Beethoven and 100 dancing girls, but until that can be arranged, donations in his memory may go to the IEEE History Center (www.ieeefoundation.org).
NEW YORK DAYBOOK

Back in the days when Microsoft was trying to buy Yahoo, Yahoo executives devised a plan to retain employees after a merger or change in control at the company. The plan, which would have given generous benefits to employees fired or reassigned after a merger, quickly became a flash point of controversy. Critics said the broadly worded plan would have allowed just about anyone who was unhappy to leave and claim severance benefits. Microsoft said it would have added hundreds of millions of dollars to the cost of buying Yahoo and pointed to the plan as one of the reasons it walked away from its $47.5 billion offer to buy Yahoo.

BANGKOK -- Parliament voted for the leader of Thailand's opposition Democrat Party, Abhisit Vejjajiva, on Monday to become prime minister, following months of political instability in government and on the streets. Mr. Abhisit's victory, on a 235-198 vote, ended seven years of dominance of electoral politics by parties loyal to former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra.

Though there are some performers who would probably pay to get their hands on an Academy Award, a verdict by a Los Angeles jury may prevent a set of Oscar statuettes won by the actress Mary Pickford from being sold, The Associated Press reported. Pickford, the silent movie star who was a founder of the United Artists studio as well as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, won two Oscars, and her third husband, Buddy Rogers, received an honorary award. The prizes were passed on to Rogers’s heirs, who hoped to sell them to raise money for charity. The academy sued the heirs, citing a rule instituted in the 1950s that forbids the sale of Academy Awards. On Monday, a jury decided that the Rogers heirs were bound by this arrangement. A judge will rule next week on whether the sale of the statuettes can proceed.

As the marketplace for their albums continues to dry up, more bands are lending their song libraries and likenesses to video games. Metallica confirmed on its Web site, metallica.com, a longstanding rumor that it would be featured in its own version of the Guitar Hero video game franchise. Calling it “the worst-kept secret in rock ‘n’ roll,” the band said that the game, Guitar Hero: Metallica, would allow players to jam along to 28 Metallica songs, as well as tracks by Alice in Chains, Foo Fighters, Slayer, Machine Head and Queen. The Web site said the game would be released in the first half of 2009. An edition of Guitar Hero centered on Aerosmith was released in June, and in October, the creators of the game Rock Band announced they were developing a game around the music of the Beatles.

The Los Angeles Times has announced that one of its longtime editors, Betsy Sharkey, will become a film critic. Ms. Sharkey, who joined The Los Angeles Times in 1998, has worked at different times as a television editor and an entertainment editor at the paper, and is a co-author of Faye Dunaway’s memoir “Looking for Gatsby” as well as a coming memoir by the actress Marlee Matlin. She has also written for The New York Times. Ms. Sharkey will join The Los Angeles Times’s veteran film critic, Kenneth Turan. She is replacing Carina Chocano, who was one of 75 staff members laid off by the newspaper in October.

The rock band Fall Out Boy had promised a special acoustic performance in Washington Square Park on Monday afternoon to promote its new album, “Folie à Deux.” The show did turn out to be special, in a way, and did not involve electricity, but it was quashed by the police because the band had not received the proper permits for a public performance. Pete Wentz, the bassist, apologized to the crowd — “We’re not allowed to play right now,” he said before the group performed a quick a cappella version of its song “Where Is Your Boy.” In a review, The Village Voice praised the lead singer Patrick Stump’s voice as “forceful and splendid.” Fall Out Boy is scheduled to play Tuesday night at the Nokia Theater in Times Square.

Carnegie Hall announced that a holiday concert scheduled for Tuesday night featuring the soprano Deborah Voigt and the Orchestra of St. Luke’s has been canceled. The hall said that Ms. Voigt was unable to perform because of a throat infection. The concert, “Deborah Voigt: Let it Snow!,” will not be rescheduled, and all ticket holders will receive refunds. Purchases made by phone or online will be automatically refunded. Those who bought tickets in person can return them to the Carnegie Hall Box Office for a refund.

Got a hankering to see hundreds of jazz, rock and R&B musicians perform in a bayou-proximate location over two weekends? The New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival has announced the lineup for its 2009 events, and it’s almost easier to list the artists who aren’t performing than those who are. The roster includes headliners like Wynton Marsalis, Aretha Franklin, the Dave Matthews Band and James Taylor, as well as the country duo Sugarland, the soul singer Solomon Burke, the Southern rock band Drive-By Truckers and Mr. Music himself, Tony Bennett. The festival runs April 24-26 and April 30-May 3, and the full lineup can be found online at nojazzfest.com. Tickets can be purchased at that Web site or at ticketmaster.com, or by calling (800) 745-3000.

The Paterson administration's proposal to charge an 18 percent sales tax on sugary sodas and juice drinks -- an effort that state officials said would reduce obesity while raising more than $400 million a year for health programs -- has already touched off a vigorous debate among New Yorkers, nutrition experts and officials from the beverage industry, which vowed to fight the proposal.The 18 percent sales tax, which would be on top of regular sales taxes, would apply to sugary sodas and fruit drinks containing less than 70 percent natural fruit juice. The tax would not apply to bottled water, diet sodas, coffee, tea or milk.

A proper steak: thick -- preferably prime and dry-aged -- and cooked so it's deeply, crustily browned, almost (but please, not quite) blackened on the outside and juicily red on the inside. People say, and indeed I used to believe, that you need thermonuclear temperatures and, therefore, industrial-strength fire and ventilation to achieve this ur-steak.

Sharp drops in the cost of fuels and electricity caused the biggest decline in consumer prices in the New York metropolitan region in more than 68 years in November, the federal Labor Department said on Tuesday. The index of consumer prices in the region - the main gauge of inflation - fell by 1.6 percent in November, according to the department's monthly index report [pdf]. That drop pushed the local inflation rate for the past year down to 2.2 percent, the lowest rate for any 12-month period since 2002, said Michael L. Dolfman, the regional commissioner of labor statistics.

Music | Was Beethoven responsible for the length of the standard audio CD? As the story goes, back in 1979-80, when Sony and Philips negotiated a single standard for the compact disc, it was agreed that one CD should be able to hold all of the composer's Ninth Symphony. From there the tale gets a bit murky -- rather like the composer's birthday, which is presumed to be today. Happy 238th, Ludwig! [Wired]

BAGHDAD -- Late Monday night, as the international chattering classes were discussing the finer points of the Bush Shoe Throwing Incident, Lt. Jamen Miller's platoon was on a six hour patrol in one of the world's less Bush sympathetic neighborhoods, Sadr City.

In a cross between academic analysis and an update to the "man-catching" guide "The Rules," researchers at the University of Maryland in College Park have found that the "best chance of 'reeling-in' an unmarried father and building the foundations for a stable family life are the critical months of pregnancy," according to the school's own analysis of the research.

BAGHDAD -- The shoe-hurling Iraqi journalist has brought out the puns in readers. More than 1,000 people have sent in their comments so far and most are guaranteed to make you groan out loud. Web sites have been launched allowing readers to throw a virtual shoe. While many American commentators appeared to take delight in the incident, a number of readers expressed disgust that people were laughing about it. If President Bush hadn't moved so quickly to avoid the flying footwear the scene in the news conference could have been much more serious.

Peter J. Henning, a professor at Wayne State Law School, is writing posts for The Deal Professor blog while Steven M. Davidoff is away. Mr. Henning specializes in issues related to white-collar crime and is a former editor of the White Collar Crime Law Prof Blog.
Dell takes hand-crafted bamboo very seriously.

In another sign that members of the old Clinton White House are infiltrating the Obama team, Peter Baker reports that Betty Currie, the devoted secretary to Bill Clinton, is answering the phones these days for Mr. Obama's transition co-chairman, John D. Podesta. And as an interesting side note, she has been taking care of Socks, the Clintons' cat from the White House years.
Exchange-traded funds, also known as E.T.F.’s, have surged in popularity in recent years, and the number and types of products have proliferated.
The editors of T Magazine present What Gives, a guide to holiday gifting.
Mutual funds are the building blocks of your investment portfolio.
Would you pay $250 for a sandwich? Are you the sort who buys clothes, cars and electronics at full price, and considers sales to be a form of cheating? Do you wish your blender had gold plating?
Fox "is making a musical comedy, a somewhat unusual project for prime-time television," the Associated Press notes.
This is part of a series of posts this week on happenings in the sprawling but always succinct world of Twitter.
Through Eric Musselman's blog, coaches share stories and tips on how to motivate, how to teach, how to win. He has agreed to plug us into his network periodically.

Update | 11:56 a.m., December 16: Updated to include new plans from Claudia Goldin, Ann Dryden Witte, Edward L. Glaeser, Nancy Folbre, Laura Tyson, Lori Kletzer and Len Burman, and an update to the plan from Raj Chetty.

Instead of making several small latkes, my Grandmother Helen's solution was to make a single potato nik, essentially a bowlful of latke batter cooked in the form of a cake. (The image of her calmly roaming her kitchen in Queens while one or two of her niks fried on the stovetop is one of my earliest cooking memories.) The attractions of this method are many: you can cook a huge one -- the equivalent of probably 20 latkes -- in 40 minutes; it can be made in advance by a half-hour and still be warm when you serve it; and it isn't bad cooled off, either.

Energy prices may have fallen, but the energy crisis is still lurking in the background. That's the message many energy experts repeat, even as some oil and gas companies slash their spending programs to deal with the economic downturn, as I wrote in an article today.

Updated, 5:27 p.m. | The Metropolitan Transportation Authority continues to find new ways to rent its subway real estate to advertisers. Joining the tunnels, station stairs, columns, subway insides, subway outsides, station turnstiles: subway windows.

If imitation is the highest form of flattery, then Zipcar ­-- the popular car-sharing company for auto-less urbanites ­-- should be flattered. Hertz is starting a strikingly similar service called Connect by Hertz in New York and the company's hometown of Park Ridge, N.J., as well as London and Paris. As with Zipcar, customers will pay an annual fee so they can rent cars by the hour without some of the hidden and not-so-hidden fees lumped onto typical rental cars.
Autosport is reporting the stunning news that Subaru has pulled out of the World Rally Championship, a racing series that the company has competed in for 20 years.
David Carr, the Carpetbagger, gives his own daily take on awards season news.
After three years of negotiations among the brothers who own the Pittsburgh Steelers, team owners are expected to consider the sale of the majority share of the team.
T. L. Stanley at The Hollywood Reporter caught Meryl Streep on "The View," where she was having her cake and insulting it too.
Monologue | Aired Monday night on NBC: Well, folks. Looks like we finally found something President Bush is good at: Dodgeball!

NASA's Goddard Institute for Space Studies, the World Meteorological Organization, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, and Britain's Hadley Center have all issued recaps of the past year's temperature patterns today.
It has been three years since Maurice R. Greenberg was forced out of the executive suite at American International Group, the insurance giant he created.
Monologue | Aired Monday night on CBS: I hope things go better for Santa Claus this Christmas. Remember what happened last year? He was shot down over Alaska by Sarah Palin.
Can you recommend any destinations where Christmas is celebrated in an especially festive or unique way, aside from the obvious choices like New York, London, Nuremberg and Vienna?
With the World Junior Championship tournament coming up a week from Friday, the talk is on who has made the team and what to expect when the world's top teenagers compete in Ottawa.

Monologue | Aired Monday night on NBC: Yesterday at a press conference in Baghdad, an angry Iraqi threw his shoes at President Bush's head. Yeah, when he saw the shoes, President Bush said, "See, I knew you guys had weapons of mass destruction."

If you are a little behind on your Oscar research, few pieces of work could help as much David Edelstein's seasonal blowout in the latest issue of New York magazine. Read his round-up of nine new movies closely and the next time the Oscar season comes up around the water cooler, you can fake it better than the most bored suburban housewife. Speaking of which, Mr. Edelstein loves, loves "Revolutionary Road," which is going to take some lifting. Sort of like titled art, once you know what it is, or what it is supposed to be, you like it more.

Monologue | Aired Monday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: You know who it is a great day for? Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich, who still has his job. He didn't resign. Everyone thought he would. Looks like his plan is to keep hanging on, even though the game is over. Political experts call this strategy "the Hillary Clinton."
From a colleague writing for the Wheels blog:
Who says jury duty is dull?
Goldman Sachs is known on Wall Street for paying its workers particularly well. But the firm's legendary largess took a hit this year.
The Boston Film critics, as the Baguette pointed out yesterday, did not want to split their hearts in two, so they gave both "Slumdog Millionaire" and "Wall-E" honors for best film of the year.

Free the shoe-thrower: An editorial in The Wall Street Journal embraces Muntader al-Zaidi for hurling his shoes at President Bush. "Congratulations, Iraq: You really are a free country," the editorial states.
As a sitting president and a president-elect maneuver over how to bail out Detroit, there may be some lessons in the Middle East peace process.

Can't a movie have a little fun, especially one about a fake sport built on pretend antipathies bolstered by faux nationalism? That answer would be no, according to the film critics in charge of Iran.

President-elect Barack Obama is moving quickly to fill the remaining vacancies in his cabinet, selecting Arne Duncan, the Chicago public schools chief as his secretary of education, and Ken Salazar, a Colorado senator as secretary of the interior.
President-elect Barack Obama has rounded out his energy and environment team by tapping Senator Ken Salazar of Colorado to head the Department of the Interior.

Music | Why you can't get "The Little Drummer Boy" out of your head: because we're all descended from ancestors who used music with a mnemonic quality to encode important information. Since we now live in an age of iPods -- "a time of unprecedented nonsocial access to music" -- holiday tunes are one remaining way to link to our ancient musical origins. And you thought it was just mall fatigue. [Wall Street Journal]

It sounds like the cast of a really monster blockbuster - George Clooney, Tom Hanks, Cameron Diaz, Charlize Theron, Matt Damon and Morgan Freeman - but it's actually a partial list of A-listers who have no interest in launching a strike into the headwinds of a brutal recession.

Caroline Kennedy ended weeks of silence with a series of rapid-fire phone calls to the state's leading political figures, including Gov. David A. Paterson, in which she emphatically and enthusiastically declared herself interested in the Senate seat being vacated by Hillary Rodham Clinton. Ms. Kennedy's decision came after she wrestled with whether to give up what has been a lifetime of avoiding the spotlight. She has quickly emerged as a front-runner for the job, and Mr. Paterson is said to look favorably on her, provided she withstands the public scrutiny now focused on her. (See related blog post.)
If imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, then Zipcar, the popular car-sharing company for carless urbanites,­ should certainly be flattered.

Goldman Sachs reported a $2.1 billion loss for its fourth quarter, its first quarterly loss since going public in 1999, as even the firm hailed for skillfully navigating the credit crunch proved unable to continue dodging the ongoing turmoil.

"The cheese crisis" - the effect of the economic downturn on Italy's parmigiano industry.

Designated lanes for V.I.P. drivers.

In a clear signal of how much the fraud allegedly perpetrated by Bernard L. Madoff may have hurt the hedge fund industry, the Credit Suisse/Tremont Hedge Fund Index fell 4.15 percent in November, far more than the preliminary estimation of a 0.7 percent decline issued last week, as the index included funds exposed to Bernard L. Madoff in the finalized numbers.
Aozora Bank, a midsize Japanese bank, said Tuesday it has up to 12.4 billion yen ($137 million) in indirect exposure to the massive Ponzi scheme run by Wall Street money manager Bernard Madoff.
In the wake of the Bernard L. Madoff scandal, investors are looking for someone, anyone to blame.
As part of a global restructuring, Citigroup will sell its Japanese trust banking unit to Mitsubishi UFJ Trust and Banking, the U.S. firm's Japanese subsidiary said Tuesday.

When Jeanne Levy-Church created the JEHT Foundation in 2002 to promote justice, equality, human dignity and tolerance, she tapped into investments run by Bernard L. Madoff.
HSBC's Asian private equity arm has closed a new $1.5 billion fund amid tough fundraising conditions, the British bank said Monday.

Meltdown. Collapse. Depression. Panic. The words would seem to apply equally to the global financial crisis and the effect of that crisis on the human psyche, Dr. Richard A. Friedman writes in The New York Times.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, a once-proud agency with an impressive history as Wall Street's top cop, finds itself increasingly conducting autopsies of leading financial institutions after failing, in the first instance, to perform adequate biopsies, The New York Times's Stephen Labaton writes.

Electricite de France is close to an agreement to buy half the nuclear power business of Constellation Energy Group for $4.5 billion, Bloomberg News reported, citing people familiar with the situation, in a deal that would stymie a plan by Warren E. Buffet to buy the U.S. power company.

For the past couple of weeks, the European Union has been putting the finishing touches on vast swath of eco-laws that cap greenhouse gases, mandate new efficiency standards and require more renewable energy.

BlueKai, an advertising start-up that hopes to convince users to actively manage their online privacy settings and sell better intent-based advertising information based on such actively managed accounts, has raised $10.5 million in second-round funding from Battery Ventures and return investor Redpoint Ventures, GigaOm said.
From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:
Bank of America, which is set to complete its acquisition of Merrill Lynch this year, has dismissed about 20 senior executives, The Wall Street Journal reported.

The American International Group, the insurer bailed out by the federal government in September, said on Monday it sold $39.3 billion of assets to a fund established by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A year ago, Dow Jones shareholders voted to sell their company, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, to Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. At the time, there was much teeth-gnashing among members of the Bancroft family, descendants of The Journal's founder, who controlled Dow Jones. The price Murdoch paid, $5 billion, stifled most of these groans.

City Room took the city gently to task last week over the "Walk" sign pictographs that are gradually disappearing all over town as their light-emitting diodes give out. But we allowed that this wasn't among the more critical problems facing New York, since the signals were still legible and unambiguous (as they are designed to be), even with 10 or more LEDs missing. The Department of Transportation explained that many signals were coming to the end of their seven-year life expectancy and said that they would be replaced.

J. Ezra Merkin took three brief paragraphs last Thursday to notify investors in his Ascot Partners fund that nearly all the $1.8 billion they had given him to invest had instead been entrusted to Bernard L. Madoff, a Wall Street wizard who is now accused of running a huge Ponzi scheme, The New York Times's Alison Leigh Cowan reports.
GMAC investors holding about $10.5 billion in bonds agreed to sweetened terms of a debt swap, bringing the company closer to its goal of becoming a bank and getting a federal bailout.

Siemens, the German engineering giant, agreed Monday to pay a record total of $1.6 billion to American and European authorities to settle charges that it routinely used bribes and slush funds to secure huge public works contracts around the world, The New York Times's Eric Lichtblau and Carter Dougherty reported.

Wall Street slumped on Monday as investors continued to favor the safety of government debt, pushing the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds to its lowest level in 30 years, The New York Times's Jack Healy reported.
For the legions of investors who appear to have been swindled in Bernard L. Madoff's giant Ponzi scheme, there may be a little relief.

These are difficult days for Elizabeth I. McCann, the longtime theater producer, who has been able to raise only $3 million so far for the $6.5 million transfer of "Hair," the '60s musical that is scheduled to start rehearsals on Broadway next month, The New York Times's Patrick Healy writes. Even her most dependable investors, Ms. McCann said, are sitting on their money.

Global stocks were mixed Tuesday in cautious trading, as investors awaited the outcome of a meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers in Washington, The New York Times's David Jolly reported. The Federal Open Markets Committee, the Fed's policy board, will announce its decision at 2:15 p.m. Washington time.

State water managers on Monday began their final review of a proposed $1.34 billion deal in which Florida would buy 181,000 acres of land to help restore the Everglades. But with a vote expected Tuesday, criticism was already flowing like the swiftest of rivers, The New York Times's Damien Cave reported.

As Dell finds itself playing catch-up in one of the most difficult economic times in its history, what was once the world's largest PC vendor is planning plans a run of acquisitions to restore growth, The New York Times's Ashlee Vance writes. Its strategy hinges just as much on big bets as precise execution.

The chief executive of National Lampoon, Daniel S. Laikin, was charged on Monday with conspiracy and securities fraud in what prosecutors said was an attempt to raise the value of the company's stock artificially, The New York Times's Rita K. Farrell reported.

Business | Give the Nobel Peace Prize or even sainthood to Wal-Mart, a columnist argues. After all, it's "impossible to argue" that past prize winners like Muhammad Yunus (the micro-credit pioneer) or Jimmy Carter have done more than Wal-Mart to alleviate poverty. And you want saintly? How about executives who fly "cattle class" and empty their own trash? "How much more saintly can a corporate entity get?" [Vancouver Sun]
Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard, and Joseph Gyourko is a real estate and finance professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

Finance | Wall Street's collapse was brought on largely by an over-reliance on financial risk software crafted by physics and math Ph.D.'s, an article says. After the government lifted debt ceilings and cash-on-hand requirements in 2004, self-policing firms relied on the faulty risk models of these geeks, known as "quants," on the road to ruin. [Scientific American]

Religion | Religious people in America and Europe are outbreeding non-believers -- but not just for the obvious reasons, a researcher finds. It's not simply that the faithful heed religious teachings or that non-believers pay more heed to the rhythms of modernity. Rather, "having a large family might itself sometimes make people more religious, or make them less likely to lose their religion." It stimulates an "intensity of purpose." [More Intelligent Life]
Leonardo DiCaprio is reportedly moving forward with plans to build an eco-resort on an island he owns off the coast of Belize.

Monte Kiffin, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers’ longtime defensive coordinator, ended weeks of speculation by confirming on Monday that he would leave the N.F.L. at the end of this season for a position on the staff of his son Lane Kiffin at the University of Tennessee. Monte Kiffin is in his 13th season of running the Bucs’ defense. The unit has ranked among the best in the N.F.L. for most of that tenure. ¶Ball State Coach Brady Hoke has resigned to accept the same position at San Diego State. Ball State, Hoke’s alma mater, has gone 12-1 this season, with its only loss coming against Buffalo in the Mid-American Conference championship game. Hoke went 34-38 in six years at the university. hoke.

The three-time gold medalist Usain Bolt is considering a run at Michael Johnson’s 400-meter world record. Bolt cruised to world-record victories in the 100 and 200 at the Beijing Olympics. Johnson set the 400 record of 43.18 seconds in 1999. “There are no major championships in 2010, so I could go for the 400-meter record that year,” Bolt said in a BBC interview. “The training for 400 meters is so much harder, but I’m thinking about it.”.

Kentucky woefully trails other major horse racing states in the money dedicated to regulating the sport, and a report produced by a state task force suggested its claim as the horse capital of the world could be at risk without more cash soon. Owners of Kentucky-bred thoroughbreds are increasingly racing their animals outside of the state because of larger purse sizes and better funding of the regulations designed to keep races fair.
Jordan Leopold scored on a penalty shot and added an assist, and Andrew Raycroft made 34 saves as Colorado held on for a 3-2 win over host Detroit.

Hugh McCutcheon was named the coach of the United States women’s volleyball team less than four months after guiding the men to an Olympic gold medal following the fatal stabbing of his father-in-law at the Beijing Games.

Padraig Harrington, who won two majors, was voted player of the year by the Golf Writers Association of America, receiving 75 percent of the vote and ending Tiger Woods’s three-year run of winning the award. Lorena Ochoa was the overwhelming choice for female player of the year, and Jay Haas became the first golfer to win the senior player of the year award three times in a row.
A storm poured rain and snow across Southern California, flooding coastal streets and forcing hundreds of people to evacuate homes in Yorba Linda, which was charred by fire last month.
A contractor who bribed a former congressman, Randy Cunningham, was sentenced to 30 months in prison by a federal judge.
The leader of an apocalyptic religious sect, Wayne Bent, has been convicted in Taos of a count of criminal sexual contact involving one of two under-age sisters.
Representative Peter Hoekstra said he would not seek re-election in 2010 and is considering a run for governor.
The former chairman of a Massachusetts tribe agreed to plead guilty to violating campaign finance laws while working with the convicted lobbyist Jack Abramoff.
Federal investigators said an accelerant was poured around the exterior of Gov. Sarah Palin’s home church in Wasilla before it was heavily damaged by a fire.
Greg Bishop, who covers the Jets for The Times, answered questions from readers Tuesday night.

Two Canadian diplomats working for the United Nations in Niger have been missing since Sunday night, United Nations officials said Monday. A car that had been carrying the diplomats — Robert Fowler, the United Nations’ special envoy to Niger, and Louis Guay, his assistant — and that bore lettering identifying it as a United Nations vehicle was found abandoned about 30 miles northeast of Niamey, the capital. The driver was also missing. Mr. Fowler served previously as Canada’s ambassador to the United Nations and ambassador to Italy.
Mr. Robbins’ purchase of a carved-wood figure in a German antiques shop became the seed of the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of African Art.
The Suns won the first showdown with Mike D’Antoni, their former coach, when Steve Nash hit a late 3-pointer to secure a victory against the Knicks.
Electors gathered in state capitals across the country to take part in a quadrennial ritual: formally selecting the next president of the United States.
