Scientists have learned how giardia dodges the immune system and are applying the knowledge to develop a potential vaccine.
Scientists at the University of Nevada, Reno, have made diesel fuel from used coffee grounds.
NBC is breathing easier since Jay Leno agreed to stay at the network, but questions about his new show remain.
The ripple effects of the recession and Wall Street’s slide have now fully engulfed the New York theater.
Thomas Middleton’s sizzling brew of adultery, incest and murder has been spruced up, juiced up and set scampering across the stage by the Red Bull Theater.
“Bottle Rocket,” directed by Wes Anderson, is part of the first batch of Criterion titles to be released in Blu-ray.
Michael Sragow puts Victor Fleming, the director of “The Wizard of Oz” and “Gone With the Wind, " in perspective, giving him his rightful due without falsely exaggerating his importance.
A popular screening test failed to detect far more colorectal cancers than expected.
In January, the Met will integrate the Brooklyn collection, widely considered one of the best in the world, into its Costume Institute.
On Sunday, Reinbert de Leeuw took the Philharmonia Orchestra of Yale to Carnegie Hall to play the “Turangalila-Symphonie,” as part of the Yale in New York series.
Studio blockbusters and smaller independent releases enjoyed equal billing on the American Film Institute’s list of the best movies of the year.
NBC led the night over all with the highest-rated “Sunday Night Football” broadcast this season.

The woes of the Vancouver dance company Ballet BC grew when a bank froze about $13,750 of its funds, The Globe and Mail reported. At a news conference on Friday, Graeme Barrit, the chairman of the troupe, said that Scotiabank had frozen the money to pay off about $13,500 in debt on the company’s credit cards. “It really is a very dramatic hit to our ability to function,” Mr. Barrit said, according to The Globe and Mail. In November the ballet laid off 38 employees, including its dancers and creative director. Its production of “The Nutcracker,” featuring the Moscow City Ballet, was able to proceed after the company received a grant from the Vancouver City Council and an anonymous donor bought 1,000 tickets to the shows.

While audiences paid about $19 million to watch Guy Ritchie’s most recent movie, “RocknRolla,” Madonna, above right, will be paying at least four times that much to end her marriage to him. The Associated Press reported that Madonna would settle her divorce with Mr. Ritchie, above left, the film director, for at least $76 million; her publicist, Liz Rosenberg, told The A.P. that the settlement would be in the range of $76 million to $92 million, a figure that included a country home in England and a pub the couple owned in London. Madonna and Mr. Ritchie were married in 2000 and granted a preliminary divorce in November that will become final in January. They have two sons, Rocco, 8, and David Banda, 3. Madonna also has a daughter, Lourdes, 12, from a previous relationship.

The declining economy has claimed the season of another regional performing arts group. The Santa Clarita Symphony in Southern California said in a statement on its Web site (scsymphony.com) that it was canceling its 2009 season because of a decline in ticket sales and individual and corporate donations. The cancellation was reported by latimes.com. In a statement, John Dow, the symphony’s marketing director, said: “We are not going away. However, it is unlikely that we will be putting a symphony orchestra on the stage anytime soon.” The symphony said that it would have to withdraw from a concert with Art Garfunkel at the Santa Clarita Performing Arts Center in January, but that it planned to offer performances with smaller groups of musicians in more intimate settings.
The Roundabout Theater Company’s coming revival of “Waiting for Godot” has made two additions to its cast.

Fans of “American Idol” who tune in primarily (if not solely) to watch unqualified contestants make fools of themselves will have fewer audition episodes to savor this season. Fox announced several changes to the “Idol” format on Monday, and among the alterations for the show’s eighth season are these: “American Idol” will have only three weeks of auditions instead of four, and will bring 36 contestants to Hollywood instead of 24; of the top 12 finalists, 9 will be chosen by audience votes, the rest by the show’s judges. The coming season, which begins on Jan. 13, will also omit the annual “Idol Gives Back” charity episode, but that fund-raiser is expected to return in 2010.

After almost 20 years in storage, the steel sculpture “Slat,” by Richard Serra (above, with the work), was re-anchored on Monday in La Défense, a Parisian business district. The sculpture spent five years in a nearby Paris suburb, Puteaux, but in 1989 vandalism and graffiti prompted that town’s mayor to remove it. “Slat” has five 25-ton steel plates that lean on one another to form a tall, angular tepee. Because of its weight, officials chose to ground it in a traffic island behind the Grande Arche in La Défense.

Its newest installment hasn’t opened in theaters yet, but the “Terminator” movie franchise has already declared, “I’ll be back.” The producers behind “Terminator Salvation,” the fourth entry in the long-running film series about humanity’s battle with killer robots from the future, announced that they would make a fifth film, Variety reported. “Terminator Salvation,” scheduled to open on May 22, is the first of three planned films that will star Christian Bale (of “The Dark Knight”) as John Connor, a human freedom fighter battling the robot forces. The Halcyon Company, which owns the rights to the “Terminator” series, announced the fifth film at the Dubai International Film Festival; no title or start date was given, but the movie is expected to be released in 2011.
The assembly factory had been scheduled to open in 2010, but the downturn interfered.
Schools and small troupes in Manhattan and Brooklyn accounted for at least five local productions of “The Nutcracker” presented last weekend.
On Sunday, Daniel Barenboim gave the first piano recital presented in the Metropolitan Opera house since Vladimir Horowitz’s 22 years ago to the day.
If the holiday season feels less festive than in years past, it may be because some athletes — and former athletes and caddies, even — are littering the season with unpleasantness.
By agreeing to the record fines, the German engineering conglomerate closes the book on wide-ranging criminal investigations in the United States and Germany.
A new study hints at a connection between family stress and heart disease in women.
Among the challenges that Elliott Carter has faced during a long, distinguished career as a composer, popular approval might be the one he least expected to grapple with.
Reviews of concerts by the Clarion Music Society and the Canadian pianist Angela Hewitt and the German cellist Daniel Müller-Schott.
For the 48 minutes of a National Basketball Association game, the relationship between coaches and officials goes from chummy to combative and back in a flash.
The currency may fall even further against the dollar and the euro unless oil prices rebound soon.
An American security consultant who has helped negotiate the release of scores of kidnap victims in Latin America was himself kidnapped last week in northern Mexico.
Using paper and double-sided carpet tape, researchers have developed a prototype that could lead to inexpensive diagnostic tools.
“Later the Same Evening” is a one-act opera inspired by five of Edward Hopper’s paintings.
For older people alcohol has the potential to be a health benefit or a life-shortening hazard.
A test that has proved highly accurate in identifying older people with alcohol-related problems.
“A Celebration of the Humphrey-Weidman Legacy,” performed on Sunday afternoon at the 92nd Street Y, brought some early gems back to the stage.
Fewer teenagers are smoking now than at any time in the past decade, according to a new survey.
William F. Buckley Jr.’s apartment, where he frequently welcomed friends and colleagues, is up for sale.
Is it dangerous for children to go through metal detectors?
Caroline Kennedy is launching a public effort to demonstrate that she has both the ability and the stomach to perform the job.
Israeli authorities said Richard Falk was unwelcome because of what the government regards as his hostile position toward Israel.
Adm. Mike Mullen, halfway through a two-year term, must pivot from one commander in chief to another in the middle of two wars.
A new study suggests that while heavier children are no more likely than others to be injured in car accidents, they are much more likely to hurt their arms and legs.
A new report suggests that only ambulatory blood pressure can predict a future heart problem.
For chronic headaches the best treatment may be one of the oldest: acupuncture.
Sunday’s games proved a corollary of parity: Sometimes it’s as important to be lucky as it is to be good.
The Iraqi journalist who threw shoes at President Bush has stirred emotions across the Arab world.
The Supreme Court revived a lawsuit brought by former prisoners at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, against former Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and other officials.
The new prime minister of Thailand has not cultivated ties to a decisive electoral bloc: the rural and urban poor.
The oil cartel has been stunned by the stunning speed of the downturn, which has created a sudden nightmare for producers.
After watching his defense flatten the Giants, Jerry Jones embraced the notion of his somewhat dysfunctional Cowboys as a candidate to become this season’s wild card to watch out for.
The country’s output of cars, automotive goods, home electronics, appliances and furniture tumbled in November in the face of declining orders.
Authorities said they recovered 23 victims who drowned after huge waves overturned the Maejan, a ferry carrying 102 passengers, just off the shore of Cagayan Province.
Defendants are often abused in custody and held for months or even years before being referred to a judge, according to a report by Human Rights Watch.
Stocks ended lower on reports that industrial production continued to slide in the last months of the year.
Australia announced plans to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by between 5 and 15 percent by 2020, angering environmental groups that had lobbied for much deeper cuts.
An 80-minute flight across the Taiwan Strait marked the first regular cross-strait traffic since the end of the civil war in 1949.
The vote followed the end of months of protests against pro-Thaksin parties that culminated in a weeklong shutdown of Bangkok’s two airports.
A key measure of business sentiment released on Monday foreshadowed more bad news ahead for the Japanese economy.
Scientists are forecasting that in the next several decades there will be another major earthquake off Sumatra like the one that spawned the tsunami in 2004.

RUSH--Florence, author of The Best Kept Secret, published in 1980, and the first feminist theorist to call the sexual abuse of children a political and patriarchal issue, died on Tuesday, December 9, at her home in Manhattan, just short of her 91st birthday. Married with three children she moved from the Bronx to Westchester where she worked as a psychiatric social worker and a community activist in the civil rights movement. After moving to Greenwich Village she electrified a New York Radical Feminist Conference on Rape in 1971 with her theory which identified male relatives and family friends as the major sexual abusers of children. When her son, Matthew, contracted AIDS, she formed a mothers' support group. She worked with Women Against Pornography and NOW to oppose exploitation of children in the media. For many years Florence enjoyed a weekly poker game with neighbors and friends who warmly recall her gracious hospitality in New York and Fire Island, and will never forget her original mind, her singular contribution to feminist theory, her impossible platform shoes, and her lasagna. She is survived by her son, Thomas, her daughter, Eleanor, and two grandchildren. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

One development in the transition says as much about the state of journalism as about the kind of government Barack Obama is creating. Jay Carney, Washington bureau chief of Time magazine, is resigning to become communications director for Vice President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. Mr. Carney, a Time employee for 20 years and bureau chief since 2005, is an established figure in Washington political journalism. He is a regular television commentator and is part of one of the city's better-known journalism couples: his wife, Claire Shipman, is the senior national correspondent for ABC News.

Lawrence Fane, a sculptor known for using steel, bronze, concrete, wood and other materials to create Expressionistic forms, died on Nov. 28 at his Manhattan home. He was 75. The cause was prostate cancer, his wife, Diana, said.

WALSH--James J.,91, on December 13, 2008. He lived in Cranford, NJ for 57 years. A 1937 graduate of Fordham University and an Army Signal Corps veteran of WWII, he held a Master's degree in Transportation from the Wharton School of Business. He worked with Nabisco Brands Corporation. He and his wife were recipients of the Cranford Clergy Council, Martin Luther King Jr. Distinguished Service Award. Surviving are his wife, Arleen; his children, Isabelle, Julie, James, Vincent, Ellen, Frances, Christopher, and Arleen; 21 grandchildren; and six great-grandchildren. Visiting 2-5pm Sunday at the Dooley Funeral Home, 218 W. North Ave., Cranford. Mass 9:30am Monday at St. Michael's Church, Cranford. Interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

MARCHESANO--Michael A.,passed away on December 8, 2008 in Plano, TX. He was born on December 21, 1928 in Brooklyn, NY, son of Paul and Rose Marckesano. He lived most of his life in Connecticut and New York. After serving in the US Army, he became an associate of Paul Marckesano and Sons Company and Jamaica Mason. HOROWITZ--Bernice (Bunny), vivacious, warm, loving wife, mother, grandmother, philanthropist, fashionista and activist died in New York City December 10, 2008 from complications due to pneumonia. She was 84 years and widow of Arthur Horowitz, founder of Juniors Restaurant in Miami Beach. Born in New York City, Bunny lived in Miami for nearly sixty years and was a communal force. She and Arthur supported local and national arts organizations. In recognition of their generosity, Jacques D'Amboise dedicated a ballet he choreographed to Stravinsky's Symphonetta, which premiered at the NYC Ballet, to Bunny and Arthur. Avid art collectors, they built a distinctive collection with works by Picasso, Matisse, Chagall, Hans Hoffman, Archipenko and Andy Warhol. She had a sharp eye for fashion and founded Berenaka, a boutique of one-of-a kind art to wear and was ahead of her time in championing artists who worked in this genre. A passionate and fiery supporter of Israel, Bunny was, in 1994, named Woman of Valor. In 1999, Taffy Gould, philanthropist, honored her by naming the administration building of Alexander Muss High School in Hod Ha'Sharon, Israel, The Bunny Horowitz Administration Building. Bunny adored dance and won awards for ballroom routines. She was a natural hostess. Bunny and Arthur's homes in Florida and Aspen were gathering places where friends, politicians, artists and family were feted with fabulous food, flowers and music which ranged from classical to jazz. A service will be held in New York City, December 18, 3pm, Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 St. A memorial service will be held in Miami at a date soon to be announced. Bunny is survived by three sons, Jeffrey and Steven who live in New York City, James, who lives in Aspen and five grandchildren, Jessica Zoe, Will, Adam, Jake and Simon.

OIL PROJECTS SLOW Scores of top oil and gas projects have been suspended or canceled in recent weeks after the collapse in energy markets. OPEC is meeting Wednesday in Algeria to discuss ways to slow declining prices. Chakib Khelil, left, the Algerian oil minister who is the president of OPEC, suggested last week that producers would approve ''a severe production cut to stabilize the oil market.'' [B4.]

HOWARD--Fred, on December 13, 2008. Beloved companion of Bonnie Kaye, husband of the late Fay Howard, father of John and Ron Howard and dear grandfather to Eliza, Molly, Ali, Zach and Jackson Howard. Fred's passion for everything made his life anything but ordinary. There were no constraints in his mind or actions, nothing that inhibited his enormous energy and creativity, or his appetite for life. He was a creator of ideas, of products, of companies. He inspired others to think out of the box. He was born in Germany on June 16, 1922. He fled the Nazi's and emigrated with his mother to the United States as a young man, bravely serving in the US Army during WW II in key intelligence positions with other German-born soldiers in a unit called The Ritchie Boys. After the war he founded what became the largest merchandising and point-ofsale display company in the world and was responsible for many famous merchandising icons; from Timex watch displays to the Leggs egg. Fred's devotion to improving Arab-Israeli relations spanned his entire adult life. Based on principles of tolerance and fairness, he devoted much of his energy, resources and passion to fostering a just peace in the Middle East for Jews and for Arabs. We are all diminished by the loss of his blazing intellect and provocative rascally ways. He was never boring. He died peacefully in his sleep in New York, the place he loved most on this earth. It was ''his kind of town''. Services Wednesday, December 17, 1:15pm at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

von KUHN--Andrzej, loving husband of Hope, and devoted father of Geoffrey, Aleksandra, Halina, Christopher, Philip, and Hope, died on December 14, 2008 in Barboursville, Virginia. He was a European gentleman of the old school and a man of many talents, from horsemanship to international business. He was born on August 26, 1928 in Warsaw, Poland. At the end of World War II, he served as a Polish Naval Officer, attached to the British Royal Navy, on ships whose operations were engaged in minesweeping in the North Sea and English Channel. After the war, he came to New York and pursued a successful business career in the international petroleum industry for many years, serving as Senior Operating Officer of New England Petroleum Corporation, Carey Energy Corporation, and other companies. He was a patriot who loved his motherland Poland, and his adopted country, the United States of America. As a devoted husband and family man, he will be deeply missed by his wife of 58 years, his children, their spouses, his 16 grandchildren, many beloved cousins in Canada, England and Poland, his many friends, and devoted dog, Xan. The funeral mass will be at 11:00am, on Thursday, December 18, 2008, at St. Isidore the Farmer Catholic Church, Orange, Virginia. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his honor to the National Katyn Memorial Foundation, Baltimore, MD, or the National Kidney Foundation.

Donovan McNabb threw for 290 yards and two touchdown passes, Asante Samuel scored on an interception return and the Eagles defeated the struggling Cleveland Browns, 30-10, on Monday night for their third straight victory. Philadelphia (8-5-1) preserved its slim playoff hopes, remaining a half game behind three teams in the race for the N.F.C. wild card. The Eagles have to win their final two games -- at Washington and home against Dallas -- and need Atlanta or Tampa Bay to lose once to secure a playoff berth.

Barack Obama, continuing a long tradition of his predecessors, plans a procession into Washington in advance of his inauguration next month, and will arrive with his family by train. The railway ride will take place on Saturday, Jan. 17, and begin with an event in Philadelphia. The train, a special charter, will stop in Wilmington, Del., to pick up Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his family, proceed to an event in Baltimore and then end in Washington.
SCHECHNER--Kenneth S. 12/16/56 -12/23/97. Lovingly remembered, sadly missed. Mother, Dad, Alan, Diane and Karen

DULLES--Avery Cardinal Dulles, S.J. Fordham University and the Board of Trustees mourn the loss of our Trustee colleague, Avery Cardinal Dulles, S.J. Ordained at the Fordham University Church in 1956, Cardinal Dulles began his distinguished teaching career at Fordham. Following appointments at Woodstock College and The Catholic University of America, he returned to Fordham in 1988 as the Laurence J. McGinley, S.J. Professor of Religion and Society, a position he held until his retirement earlier this year. An Internationallyknown author and lecturer, he published over 20 major books and hundreds of articles, essays and reviews. In 2001, he became the first American theologian to be named to the College of Cardinals. Fordham honored Cardinal Dulles with one of the first Fordham Founder's Awards, an honorary Doctorate of Letters and the President's Medal. Cardinal Dulles honored Fordham by his distinguished presence in our community and will be sorely missed. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family, his Fordham colleagues and the members of the Fordham Jesuit Community. John N. Tognino, Chairman of the Fordham University Board of Trustees Joseph M. McShane, S.J. President of Fordham University

DULLES--Avery Cardinal, S.J. The New York Province of the Society of Jesus and Fordham University mourn the death of Avery Cardinal Dulles, S.J., who died on Friday, December 12, 2008, at the age of 90. The Laurence J. McGinley Professor of Religion and Society, Cardinal Dulles was an internationally renowned author and lecturer on theological topics and the first American to be named a cardinal who was not a bishop. Avery Robert Dulles, S.J., was born on August 24, 1918, in Auburn, NY, the son of Janet Pomeroy Avery and John Foster Dulles, who served as Secretary of State under President Dwight D. Eisenhower. He entered the Society of Jesus on August 14, 1946, and was ordained a priest at the Fordham University Church. That event, which occurred on June 16, 1956, was reported on the front page of The New York Times. Cardinal Dulles came to Fordham in 1988 to take up the McGinley Chair. On February 21, 2001, he was elevated to the College of Cardinals by Pope John Paul II on the steps of St. Peter's Basilica in Rome. Pope Benedict XVI met privately with Cardinal Dulles at St. Joseph's Seminary (Dunwoodie), in Yonkers, NY, on April 19, 2008, during the Pontiff's pastoral visit to the United States. The private audience was a recognition of the Cardinal's intellectual and moral influence as a Jesuit, a theologian and a writer. The Cardinal is survived by the children of his brother, John W. F. Dulles, and sister-in-law, Eleanor Dulles: John Foster Dulles II, Edith Dulles Lawlis, Ellen Coelho and Robert Avery Dulles; nieces Janet Hinshaw-Thomas and Lilly Holt, and nephews Foster Hinshaw and David Hinshaw; cousins Allen Jebsen, Joanna Jebsen Cook, Tina Afokpa, Per Jebsen, Dr. Mary Parke Manning, Thomas Manning, Diane Igleheart and Joan Talley; and by godson Andrew Curry. John W.F. Dulles, the Cardinal's brother, and John Dulles' wife of 68 years, Eleanor Ritter Dulles, both passed away at ages 95 and 91, respectively, in June 2008, in San Antonio, Texas. In accordance with the traditions of the Church, the Cardinal's death will be marked by the celebration of three Masses: Tuesday, December 16, 7:30pm, University Church, Rose Hill Campus, Bronx, NY. Wednesday, December 17, 7:30pm, University Church, Rose Hill Campus, Bronx, NY. Thursday, December 18, 2pm, St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York, NY. The members of the public and the University family are invited to join the Jesuit Community at each of these Masses. In addition, the Cardinal's family will receive visitors in the University Church on Tuesday and Wednesday afternoons from 2 to 5pm. In lieu of flowers, the New York Province of the Society of Jesus and Fordham University will accept donations in memory of Avery Cardinal Dulles, S.J., designated for the apostolic works of the Society of Jesus, or the Avery Cardinal Dulles, S.J., Chair in Catholic Theology, respectively. Gifts may be directed to: The New York Province of the Society of Jesus, Avery Cardinal Dulles, S.J., Memorial Fund, 39 East 83rd Street, New York, NY 10028. Debra A. Ryan, Associate Director of Development (212)774-5544 or ryan@nysj.org or Fordham University, The Avery Cardinal Dulles, S.J., Chair in Catholic Theology, 888 Seventh Ave., 8th Fl., New York, NY 10019. Robert Smith, Senior Director of Development for Stewardship (212)636-7441 or rsmith@fordham.edu.

MARGOLIS--David I. New York-Presbyterian Hospital mourns the loss of David I. Margolis, our dear friend and Life Trustee. For nearly 20 years, Mr. Margolis was one of our most loyal and committed Trustees, and was an enthusiastic supporter of the Hospital's clinical mission, particularly in neuro intensive care and ophthalmology. A proponent of collaboration in medicine, he contributed significantly to the success of the 1998 merger between The Presbyterian Hospital and New York Hospital. Mr. Margolis rendered exceptional service as Chairman of the Budget and Finance Committee of The Presbyterian Hospital for seven years, and then as Co-Chairman of the Budget and Finance Committee of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital in the critically important early post-merger years. Devoted husband, father and friend, David Margolis will be greatly missed. Our heartfelt condolences to Mrs. Barbara Margolis and the entire Margolis family. John Mack, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Dr. Herbert Pardes, President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital
RAPP--John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John Rapp, associated with The New York Times from June 1, 1956 until retiring on July 1, 1989.
LEVINE--Bernard. Beloved husband of the late Yetta (Zbar). Loving father of Gary and Martin. Dear brother of Dorothy and Sylvia. Loving uncle. WWII Veteran U.S. Army. Retired Lieutenant FDNY.
SCHIPPER--Marcus. Congregation Beth Sholom records with sorrow the passing of its esteemed member. May his memory be for a blessing.

MACMILLAN--Susan Bates, 66, of Kailua, HI, on November 28th. Born New Rochelle, NY. Survived by husband Ian T. MacMillan, daughters Julia (Colorado) and Laura, son-inlaw Richard and granddaughter Emma Crago (Hawaii). B.A., Oneonta State, M.Ed., University of Iowa. Susan's passion for gardening lives on in her children; she will be deeply missed. Friends may contact the family at sbatesmac@yahoo.com. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to UH Foundation-Harold L. Lyon Arboretum, P.O. Box 11270, Honolulu, HI 96828.
Another day brings more news of the downsizing taking place at the Citadel Investment Group, Kenneth C. Griffin’s giant hedge fund firm.

After a report in which Madonna’s publicist said that the pop star’s divorce settlement to Guy Ritchie would be upwards of $76 million, the couple would now prefer that the publicist hadn’t expressed herself. In a joint statement reported by Reuters, Madonna and Mr. Ritchie said that a “misleading and inaccurate statement, specifically in relation to the sums of money involved, was wrongly issued.” The statement added: “The financial details of the settlement will remain private, save to say that both of us are happy with our agreement. Our primary concern, like any co-parents, is the care and well being of our children.” On Monday, Madonna’s publicist, Liz Rosenberg, told The Associated Press that Mr. Ritchie would receive $76 million to $92 million in the settlement.

Will comic-book fans be watching “Watchmen” next year, when Warner Brothers plans to release its film adaptation of the superhero graphic novel? A federal judge in Los Angeles left that question unresolved Monday after declining to issue a summary judgment in a lawsuit between rival studios claiming they control the rights to the film, Variety reported. In February, Fox filed suit against Warner Brothers, saying that the film’s producer, Lawrence Gordon, never exercised an option to acquire a remaining interest in “Watchmen.” Judge Gary Allen Feess said a trial was necessary, and moved the trial date to Jan. 20, from Jan. 6. Warner Brothers plans to open its film, adapted from the comic book by Alan Moore and Dave Gibbons, and directed by Zack Snyder, on March 6.

In a Times article this week by Patrick Healy about some of the troubles Broadway theaters are facing amid the grim economy, Nancy Coyne, the chairwoman of the theater advertising agency Serino Coyne, tried to point out a silver lining to the cloud: There are a lot of new plays coming in the spring, she said — so-called straight plays, rather than the tourist-pleasing musicals that have been Broadway’s usual fare these past few seasons.

Peter Brook, the longtime director of the Theatre des Bouffes du Nord in Paris, has announced that he and his co-director, Micheline Rozan, will step down from the theater in 2010, the newspaper Le Monde reported. Mr. Brook, 83, the British director and a founder of the International Center for Theater Research, came to the Bouffes du Nord in 1974 after moving to Paris in 1970; the space was run down and had changed hands many times, but Mr. Brook’s productions there, heavily influenced by the Russian mystic G.I. Gurdjieff, quickly thrust the theater into the avant-garde. Mr. Brook told Le Monde that the direction of the Bouffes du Nord would be taken over by Olivier Mantei, the director of the Opera-Comique, and Olivier Poubelle, a theater entrepreneur.

A court in Bucharest ruled Wednesday that an art collection seized from the Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu will be returned to his heirs, Reuters reported. The collection, which includes two engravings by Goya, as well as paintings by the Romanian artists Nicolae Tonitza, Theodor Pallady and Gheorghe Petrascu, were seized by the state after Ceausescu was overthrown in December 1989 and he and his wife, Elena, were executed. Since then, the artworks have been kept in a warehouse maintained by Romania’s National Arts Museum. Haralambie Voicilas, a lawyer representing Ceausescu’s son Valentin, told Reuters that the court “eventually reached the right decision.” He added, “After years of court trials, property returns to the rightful owners.”

Taylor Swift and Britney Spears swapped places on the top of the Billboard album chart this week. Ms. Swift, whose “Fearless” (Big Machine) reached No. 1 five weeks ago and has been hovering in the Top 5 since, returns with 249,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Ms. Spears’s “Circus” (Jive), last week’s best-seller, fell to No. 2 with 200,000. The rest of the Top 10, in a week with few major new release, is familiar. Beyoncé’s “I Am … Sasha Fierce” (Columbia) holds at No. 3, Nickelback’s “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner) is No. 4, the “Twilight” soundtrack (Atlantic) reached No. 5, Kanye West’s “808s and Heartbreak” (Def Jam) is No. 6, the “Now That’s What I Call Music! 29” compilation is No. 7, AC/DC’s “Black Ice” (Columbia) jumped three spots to No. 8, the soundtrack to “High School Musical 3: Senior Year” (Disney) is No. 9 and David Cook’s self-titled solo album is No. 10.

Two Off-Broadway productions are going to great lengths to assure recession-conscious theatergoers they’ll get their money’s worth. The comedy “What’s That Smell: The Music of Jacob Sterling,” starring David Pittu as the fictional composer, is offering $5 mezzanine tickets through the end of its run, which concludes at New World Stages on Dec. 28. And the thriller “Dust,” starring Richard Masur and Hunter Foster at the Westside Theater, is offering ticket buyers a money-back guarantee; unsatisfied customers can receive a refund by mailing their tickets within two days of seeing the play to Dust-to-Dust Limited Partnership, 311 West 43rd Street, Suite #605, New York, NY 10036. Tickets for both shows can be purchased by calling (212)239-6200, or online at www.telecharge.com.

Akon, the hip-hop and R&B performer, pleaded guilty Wednesday to a harassment charge stemming from a 2007 incident in which he threw a fan off stage at a concert, The Associated Press reported. Akon, whose real name is Aliaune Thiam, threw Anthony Smith, now 16, off the stage during a June 2007 concert at Dutchess Stadium, near Poughkeepsie. The incident (watch here) was recorded on videotape, and another concertgoer said she had suffered a concussion when the young fan landed on her. The A.P. said that according to the terms of the plea bargain, Akon will serve no jail time as long he performs 65 hours of community service and pays a $250 fine.

In recent years, the Mets have had various players take on the role of Santa Claus at the team's Christmas party, and more often than not it has not led to the best of luck the next season. Mike Cameron, the 2004 Santa, had a serious outfield collision with Carlos Beltrán the following August that put him on the disabled list for the remainder of the season.

My Thursday column welcomes New York State's proposed new tax on non-diet soft drinks, as a way to reduce obesity and bolster public health. I'm a firm believer that the road to health care reform doesn't involve only universal health care, but also a series of public health initiatives to improve the diet, promote exercise and reduce salt consumption. The cigarette tax was a huge success, and a tax on sugary drinks holds similar promise. Some other countries, including Mexico, are looking at a national soft drink tax for the same reason.

They can clinch a wild-card berth and the No. 5 seed in the American Football Conference with a victory over the Jaguars (5-9), another losing team. The Colts would be even more dangerous if they could ever get healthy. Running back Joseph Addai and safety Bob Sanders are questionable for this game, and middle linebacker Gary Brackett and receiver Marvin Harrison are out.

HD Radio, the fancy name for broadcast AM and FM radio transmitted digitally, has not taken the audio market by storm. One problem has been that, unlike digital satellite subscription radio from Sirius XM Radio, HD Radio simply offers existing AM and FM channels with better fidelity and no static (although half the 1800 digital channels do carry, as with digital TV, sub-channels of additional content).

Seeing them early helps one to conceptualize the direction the industry may take years in the future. And it's also fun.

In a modest ceremony on Wednesday afternoon, Columbia University observed the "topping off" of its new 14-story Interdisciplinary Science Building at Broadway and West 120th Street, designed by José Rafael Moneo of Spain. This traditional construction milestone marks the point at which the structure reaches its intended height, typically with the raising and installation of the highest steel beam. The building, which is to open in 2011, completes the northwest corner of Columbia's main campus, 113 years after work began on the six-block complex.

Almost half of New Yorkers had difficulties affording food for themselves or their families in 2008, up sharply from 38 percent figure reported earlier this year, according to a survey released by the Food Bank for New York City this week. The findings of the report, "NYC Hunger Experience 2008 Update: Food Poverty Soars as Recession Hits Home" [pdf, and displayed below], are in keeping with what food banks across the country have observed just in the second half of the year. During that period, demand for food aid has risen more than 40 percent in areas with the weakest economies and has risen 20 percent in areas of the country with the healthiest economies, leaders of nonprofit food-distribution organizations say.

The city's Department of Homeless Services and the nonprofit advocacy group Coalition for the Homeless rarely agree on basic facts like how many homeless people there are in New York at any given moment. So it was no surprise, after The Times's article on Tuesday about homeless veterans, to get a call from the coalition quibbling about the numbers. The article, highlighting the steps New York was taking to prepare for a potential onslaught of homeless veterans from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, opened by saying "on any given night, a virtual army of 150,000 veterans are homeless across the nation, including an estimated 1,200 in New York City." Later, it offered more detail: "The city estimates that on any given night, 625 veterans remain scattered across the shelter system and another 560 or so live on the streets (local homeless advocates say that number is low)."

Despite all the signs of rapid gentrification in Brooklyn, Queens was the borough with the most improved job market in the first quarter of 2008, according to new data from the federal Labor Department. The economic picture is likely to be quite different now, as these figures predate the financial turmoil of the last several months. The Bureau of Labor Statistics said on Wednesday that the average wage earned in Queens was $852 in the first three months of 2008, or about $25 a week higher than it had been a year earlier. That 3.1 percent increase made Queens the only borough where wages grew faster than the national rate of 2.4 percent.

[UPDATE, 12/18: Oil is down again, with more drops coming.] The Annual Energy Outlook projecting United States energy trends through 2030 foresees flat demand for oil, a shrinking need for imports and enormous expansion of the percentage of light vehicles with hybrid fuel-electric propulsion. But its analysts foresee plug-in hybrids like the forthcoming Chevrolet Volt, seen by some as a way to bolster the electrical grid, remaining a sliver of the market. Of course, it's important to keep in mind the poor track record of energy forecasts. So maybe this forecast actually means plug-ins are going to rule?

Caroline Kennedy strikes me as a very impressive woman with all the right priorities, such as education. But I also find it unseemly and undemocratic that she seems to have vaulted to the top of the Senate list by virtue of who her dad was. Seeing which way the wind is blowing, Rupert Murdoch's NY Post has already endorsed her. Isn't that sexist? Isn't that the kind of system we rebelled against in 1776?
Here's a stunner: "Crash" hits the small screen and leaves critics totally divided.

One of the lessons of aid work in the last 20 years is that foreign assistance often won't work unless women are front and center. For example, educating boys has many benefits, but there's pretty good evidence that educating girls is even more effective -- primarily because it does more to reduce the number of children in the next generation. Moreover, men already tend to be in the labor force, while educating girls and training them or giving them capital tends to encourage them to participate in the economy in ways that bring real benefits to the household and to the entire economy.

Sam Talbot, the Top Chef contestant who has been cooking in Montauk lately, has signed on as the chef at a seafood restaurant in the Mondrian Hotel, opening late next year at 150 Lafayette, on the edge of Chinatown.

In a Ponzi scheme, like the one Bernard Madoff is reported to have orchestrated, new investors are brought in to pay back the old investors. There's never any actual investment; the debt just rolls over.

Ten Northeast states conducted their second auction of carbon dioxide-emissions allowances Wednesday as part of the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, an effort to combat global warming by reducing pollution from the power sector.

Peter Morgan, riding high these days with "Frost/Nixon," which he wrote for the stage and then adapted for the movie version, has a deal to make his directorial debut. And he's returning to an old standby for subject matter: Tony Blair. The movie, tentatively called "The Special Relationship," will focus on the relationship between Mr. Blair and Bill Clinton. And it will be the third time Mr. Morgan has used Mr. Blair as his muse, first for a British TV movie called "The Deal" and then for "The Queen."

Barack Obama is calling for a national day of service to take place on Jan. 19, the federal holiday for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday and the day preceding Mr. Obama's inauguration as president.
For supercar fans waiting for the second coming of Honda's great NSX, whose introduction in 1990 shook life back into Ferrari, the dream is over.

A well-prepared salad is often my favorite part of any meal. Done right, it packs tons of flavor for very few calories. Salads are rich in nutrients, and studies show that eating a salad with a meal helps fill you up sooner, so you don't overindulge on less healthful foods. There's even research to show that using full-fat dressing on a salad unlocks more nutrients in the salad than a no-fat dressing.

Updated, 5:12 p.m. | Facing its most dire financial crisis since the early 1980s and pleading for action from Albany, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved, at 11:50 a.m. Wednesday, what officials acknowledged was a "draconian" budget for 2009 that includes $177 million in service reductions across its subways, buses and commuter railroads and a 23 percent fare increase that would take effect in June. The plan would probably mean a rise in the base subway and bus fare to $2.50, from $2, and the cost of a 30-day unlimited-ride MetroCard to $104, from $81.

Yesterday, the Bagger took delivery of the collector's edition of the soundtrack to "The Dark Knight." Besides the original motion picture soundtrack by Hans Zimmer and James Newton Howard, the two-disc set includes a 40-page hardbound book, an additional 50 minutes of unreleased music and four unreleased remixes by the Crystal Method, Paul van Dyk, Mel Wesson and Ryeland Allison.

Fashion | The fashion glossies are sure flailing in the recession, a columnist writes. What's with their dubious affectations of austerity? Since when is a multi-thousand-dollar Gucci dress a "great investment"? "Maybe I have, unwittingly, been living in a bubble of poverty all my life, but when could anyone afford most of the things shown in fashion magazines?" Let readers eat cake! Or at least look at it. [Guardian]

An article on Dec. 10 about a decision by the Pulitzer Prize Board to accept submissions from online-only publications misstated the year that the Pulitzer board first accepted online material from newspapers. It was 1999 (though only in the Public Service category), not 2006. The article also misstated the number of categories that began accepting online material in 2006. It was all 14 categories — not just two breaking news categories. (Those two categories were the only ones that did not require at least one print exhibit.).

An article Tuesday about members of the Electoral College, who gathered to decide the 2008 presidential election, referred imprecisely to their obligations when voting. While individual electors are not bound by the Constitution to vote for the candidate who wins the popular vote in their state, some states do have laws requiring that they do so.

An article on Dec. 7 about the arrests of two people in India for possible involvement in the attacks last month in Mumbai misidentified the state in which the city of Nagpur, where an explosive device was defused this month, is located. It is in Maharashtra, not in Madhya Pradesh.

As the marketplace for their albums continues to dry up, more bands are lending their song libraries and likenesses to video games. Metallica confirmed on its Web site, metallica.com, a longstanding rumor that it would be featured in its own version of the Guitar Hero video game franchise. Calling it “the worst-kept secret in rock ’n’ roll,” the band, whose lead singer is James Hetfield, left, said that Guitar Hero: Metallica, would allow players to jam along to 28 Metallica songs, as well as to tracks by Alice in Chains, Foo Fighters, Slayer, Machine Head and Queen. The Web site said the game would be released in the first half of 2009. An edition of Guitar Hero centered on Aerosmith was released in June, and in October, the creators of the game Rock Band said they were developing a game around the Beatles.

The rock band Fall Out Boy had promised a special acoustic performance in Washington Square Park on Monday afternoon to promote its new album, “Folie à Deux.” The show did turn out to be special, in a way, and did not involve electricity, but it was quashed by the police because the band had not received the proper permits for a public performance. Pete Wentz, the bassist, above, apologized to the crowd: “We’re not allowed to play right now,” he said, before the group performed a quick a cappella version of its song “Grand Theft Autumn/Where Is Your Boy.”.

Western monitors believe that elections in Belarus and several other former Soviet republics are often far from fair. The Kremlin's own monitors disagree, saying that the West scrutinizes these elections more closely than those elsewhere. But what do Russians themselves think? The New York Times posted a translated version of the accompanying article on its Russian-language blog on livejournal.com on Monday. It attracted comments from readers in both Russia and Belarus, where Russian is widely spoken.

HAMMERMAN--Hazzan Saul Z. The Cantors Assembly mourns the passing of its distinguished past president, Hazzan Saul Hammerman. He was one of three brothers, all of whom were Hazzanim. While serving Beth El Congregation of Baltimore, MD for decades, one of the country's most prestigious synagogues, he prided himself on being a champion of colleagues serving more modest-sized congregations. A recipient of the Kavod Award, the highest recognition granted by the Cantors Assembly, Hazzan Hammerman was also honored in 2008 with the organization's David Putterman Award for Lifetime Achievement. We extend our sympathy to his beloved wife Aileen, children, grandchildren, family and loved ones. May his memory abide as a blessing. Hazzan Joseph Gole, President Hazzan Stephen J. Stein, Executive Vice President Hazzan Eric M. Snyder, Executive Administrator

Colorado's political picture might look simple -- historically Republican but trending Democratic in recent elections, notably in supporting President-elect Barack Obama in last month's election. But in appointing someone to replace Senator Ken Salazar, Mr. Obama's choice to be the next secretary of the interior, the Democratic governor, Bill Ritter Jr., will have to wrestle with keeping moderates and independent voters happy to keep the seat in the party's hands. Mr. Salazar, a Democrat with deep roots in the historically Hispanic farming country on the border with New Mexico, was elected to the Senate in 2004 by appealing to rural voters used to supporting Republicans. He replaced Ben Nighthorse Campbell, a Republican who chose not to seek a third term. So that would seem to point toward someone in Mr. Salazar and Mr. Ritter's own stamp -- a Democrat who knows the business end of a cowboy boot and can talk credibly about cattle, corn, irrigation and the housing anxieties of the moderate-leaning suburbs.

PATERNO TO COACH TO 2012 Coach Joe Paterno and Penn State have agreed to extend their relationship past this season, although it remained uncertain for how long. In a brief statement, the university announced that Paterno, who turns 82 on Dec. 21 and whose contract expires at the end of this season, will have the opportunity to lead the program through the 2011 season.

4th-and-Forget the Punt Kevin Kelley, a high school football coach in Little Rock, Ark., watches N.F.L. games and shakes his head at all the punts. But he understands. ''It's a job-saving thing,'' he said of N.F.L. coaches in a telephone interview Tuesday. ''There's a lot of money involved; they're worried they might get fired, and they very well might.''

''The Wrestler,'' the movie that has suddenly made Mickey Rourke an Oscar contender, is about several kinds of fakery, writes A. O. Scott: professional wrestling and filmmaking itself. (That it was written by Robert D. Siegel, a former editor of The Onion, makes that even more intriguing.) Mr. Rourke plays the title character as ''an authentic, passionate, natural performer,'' a description that fits him as well. ''Like its hero,'' Mr. Scott writes, ''the movie has a blunt, exuberant honesty, pulling off even its false moves with conviction and flair.'' ''Hard Knocks, Both Given and Gotten,'' by A.O. Scott

As much as they can serve as game changers with their ability to disrupt a passing game, the great pass rushers of the N.F.L. have also been known for inconsistency. For every three-sack game, they tend to have plenty of games in which they fail to record a sack. That is what makes Cowboys linebacker DeMarcus Ware's 2008 season so interesting -- his consistency. Through 14 games, Ware has 19 sacks, and he has had at least one sack in 13 games. Of the players who have 19 or more sacks since the statistic became official in 1982, only Mark Gastineau of the 1984 Jets had sacks in as many games. In his record-setting 2001 season, Michael Strahan of the Giants had 22 1/2 sacks in 16 games, but had one or more sacks in only 11 games. He had half a sack in two games as well. The 10 players other than Ware who have 19 or more sacks in a season have averaged 4.9 games with less than a full sack.

Break out the gloves, hats and long underwear. The United States and Mexico will open the final round of regional World Cup qualifying games at Crew Stadium in Columbus, Ohio, on Feb. 11, United States soccer officials announced late Tuesday. The United States has played Mexico in Columbus in two other World Cup qualifiers (in 2001 and in 2005), both won by the American team by 2-0 in frosty weather. The match will be the 55th meeting between the rivals in the Concacaf region; the United States has an 8-0-2 home record against Mexico since 2000.

Joba Chamberlain called this off-season the ''best'' and ''most gratifying'' of his life, and not because the Yankees have eased his transition to full-time starter by adding C. C. Sabathia and A. J. Burnett. Chamberlain, arrested in Nebraska two months ago on charges of driving under the influence, said he planned to make amends by speaking with young people about the dangers of driving drunk. ''It's all part of the growing experience,'' Chamberlain said Tuesday night before he was to accept the athlete of the year award from the Police Athletic League at its annual dinner in Manhattan. ''As a 23-year-old man, I'm still trying to grow up. We all make mistakes, and that's part of being human. Part of being human is admitting mistakes and not trying to hide from it, not trying to run from it.''

DEEP CUTS The Federal Reserve, headed by Chairman Ben S, Bernanke, left, entered a new era by cutting its target for the overnight federal funds rate to a range of zero to 0.25 percent, so low that it will have to reach for untested tools in fighting the recession. STOCKS SOAR AFTER RATE CUT Stock markets soared 5 percent as investors cheered the Fed's latest attempt to loosen credit and end one of the worst economic downturns since the Great Depression. [B9.]

DHAKA, Bangladesh -- The government lifted a state of emergency on Wednesday, allowing political parties to campaign for parliamentary elections on Dec. 29. The voting, originally set for January 2007, had been suspended by the caretaker government, which is backed by the army, after months of political violence. Having promised to root out corruption, the government arrested scores of politicians, including the heads of the two main parties, and banned all political activity.

DULLES--Avery Cardinal Dulles, S.J. Fordham University and the Board of Trustees mourn the loss of our Trustee colleague, Avery Cardinal Dulles, S.J. Ordained at the Fordham University Church in 1956, Cardinal Dulles began his distinguished teaching career at Fordham. Following appointments at Woodstock College and The Catholic University of America, he returned to Fordham in 1988 as the Laurence J. McGinley, S.J. Professor of Religion and Society, a position he held until his retirement earlier this year. An Internationallyknown author and lecturer, he published over 20 major books and hundreds of articles, essays and reviews. In 2001, he became the first American theologian to be named to the College of Cardinals. Fordham honored Cardinal Dulles with one of the first Fordham Founder's Awards, an honorary Doctorate of Letters and the President's Medal. Cardinal Dulles honored Fordham by his distinguished presence in our community and will be sorely missed. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family, his Fordham colleagues and the members of the Fordham Jesuit Community. John N. Tognino, Chairman of the Fordham University Board of Trustees Joseph M. McShane, S.J. President of Fordham University

von KUHN--Andrzej, loving husband of Hope, and devoted father of Geoffrey, Aleksandra, Halina, Christopher, Philip, and Hope, died on December 14, 2008 in Barboursville, Virginia. He was a European gentleman of the old school and a man of many talents, from horsemanship to international business. He was born on August 26, 1928 in Warsaw, Poland. At the end of World War II, he served as a Polish Naval Officer, attached to the British Royal Navy, on ships whose operations were engaged in minesweeping in the North Sea and English Channel. After the war, he came to New York and pursued a successful business career in the international petroleum industry for many years, serving as Senior Operating Officer of New England Petroleum Corporation, Carey Energy Corporation, and other companies. He was a patriot who loved his motherland Poland, and his adopted country, the United States of America. As a devoted husband and family man, he will be deeply missed by his wife of 58 years, his children, their spouses, his 16 grandchildren, many beloved cousins in Canada, England and Poland, his many friends, and devoted dog, Xan. The funeral mass will be at 11:00am, on Thursday, December 18, 2008, at St. Isidore the Farmer Catholic Church, Orange, Virginia. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his honor to the National Katyn Memorial Foundation, Baltimore, MD, or the National Kidney Foundation.

SACKS--Laury, aka Laury Goldman, aka Laury Marker. My best friend, my soul sister. You fought long and hard with the same dignity and grace you lived your life with. You were a steadfast and true friend, a dedicated and loving mother, a devoted wife and tribute to your parents. Your artistry as an actress and playwright was stunning to watch and you had so much more to contribute. I will miss your laughter and presence in my life more than words can say. To Eric, William and Talley, you have my sincerest condolences. I will always be here for you. Laury, you have taken a piece of all our hearts with you, but your light shines brightly in all us who were lucky enough to be touched by you. Rest in sweet peace. I love you Lois Robbins Zaro

The film adaptation of John Patrick Shanley’s “Doubt” received the most nominations for Screen Actors Guild awards, with five, when the nominations were announced on Thursday morning. Its four leads, Meryl Streep, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Amy Adams and Viola Davis, were all nominated for their performances, and the film was also one of five nominated for outstanding performance by a cast in a motion picture. The four other films nominated for their casts were “Frost/Nixon,” “Milk,” “Slumdog Millionaire” and “The Curious Case of Benjamin Button.” The casts of “Boston Legal,” “Dexter,” “House,” “Mad Men” and “The Closer” were nominated for best dramatic ensembles on television, and the casts of “30 Rock,” “Desperate Housewives,” “Entourage,” “The Office” and “Weeds” were nominated for best comedic ensemble. Winners will be announced on Jan. 25.

Alberto W. Vilar was sent to jail on Thursday. Convicted of 12 counts related to securities fraud on Nov. 19, Mr. Vilar had been free on bail pending his sentencing March 20. But federal prosecutors argued that Mr. Vilar was a flight risk given the prospect of a lengthy prison term and what they called his penchant for lying and stealing. They also cited the fact that he had not put up money or property to secure his $10 million bail (friends put up property and cash) and has long experience traveling abroad.

A few years ago, I was bringing a racing boat back to England after Antigua Sailing week and we made a pit stop in Horta, in the Azores Islands, after 12 dry days at sea. There was a gale building behind, a full moon overhead, the deck and rigging were streaked with phosphorescence, and I turned off the instrument lights and drove by feel, with dolphins as outriders making luminous trails through the swells. You can smell land long before you see it. It smells like newly-mown hay, makes you think of all the things you've missed at sea - high on that list, for me, was sex and hooch - and Horta has one of the best bars in the world, Peter's Cafe Sport.Peter's was founded to cater for the crews of 19th century whaling ships. It's provisioned with every alcoholic cordial a thirsty sailor ever dreamed of, open until you finish your drinks, and its veteran clientele "Glory, Glory, Hallelujah" when they're in their cups. It's the perfect spot to booze to excess - to exchange toasts with the crews of other boats you last saw in the Caribbean and the best place I ever visited to earn a five-star hangover.When I came to after the binge I had a migraine, blurred vision, liquid bowels, and shakes that started at my fingertips and reached to my elbows.

The first thought I had when I saw the snowplow front wing of the new Formula One cars was that the cars may well be designed in laboratories to allow for more overtaking, but clearly there was also going to be a lot more broken front wings during passing maneuvers. In today's L'Equipe newspaper, the French sports daily, a story analyzing the appendages quotes Aldo Costa of Ferrari as saying just that. The story predicts cars losing their front wings particularly at race starts and also from clipping high curbs.

In a blow to the New York State Trial Lawyers Association, the state's highest court ruled on Thursday that the association's famous pothole map was not sufficiently clear and therefore did not give two injured people the right to win civil judgments against New York City under the city's Pothole Law.The Pothole Law -- passed in 1979 to make it harder for people to sue -- protects the city from liability for injuries to people who trip or fall on sidewalks that are "out of repair, unsafe, dangerous or obstructed," unless a written notice of the defect has been provided to the city's Department of Transportation at least 15 days before the accident. Previously, the injured person only had to show, usually through witnesses, that the crack or hole or protrusion had been there long enough for the city to be able to fix it.

Columbia University cleared a major hurdle on Thursday in its effort to expand its campus into Manhattanville, as state officials voted to approve the project, opening the door for the use of eminent domain to allow the university to acquire land from holdout property owners blocking the project.Columbia already owns most of the 17-acre expansion zone in Manhattanville, a largely industrial neighborhood in Harlem where the university is proposing a $6 billion plan to build a gleaming new campus over the next 25 years.

A few weeks back I posted a chart that showed the disparity between what Division I-A college football coaches earn and what faculty members and academic administrators rake in. Agyness Deyn: platinum-haired pixie, Kate Moss scion, voodoo goddess? Now, thanks to Gordon Hull, a director and contemporary bricoleur of sorts, the fashion model Deyn can add a new credit to her résumé: Erzulie, goddess of love. In our latest T-commissioned film, Hull, founder of the SoHo-based global creative collective Surface to Air, appropriates elements of Afro-Caribbean culture. What emerges is an atmospheric portrait of a pine grove, and a group of soldier-initiates entranced by an ursine coyote who are pushed to perform what the director terms "the desperate act" -- all it takes it one puff of Deyn's (errr, Erzulie's) magic dust. We'll have what they're having.

BAGHDAD -- Mutanabi Street has long been the intellectual center of the Iraqi capital. But when a car bomb exploded here in March 2007 killing at 26 people the neighborhood was emptied. Blast walls blocked off the area to traffic and members of Awakening Councils, groups made up largely of former insurgents, opened checkpoints to monitor people entering the neighborhood. Resurrecting this area and breathing life back into the cafes and book stores here has long been a pet project for the Iraqi leadership.

Shares of Adobe performed so well over the last 10 years that the company's value soared to the point of putting off many potential suitors. Paul Weyrich, an icon of the conservative movement, died early this morning, at age 66, after suffering from a range of health problems. He had a hand in building some of the most famous institutions on the right, including the Heritage Foundation, the Moral Majority, the Christian Coalition and, more recently, the Free Congress Foundation.

New York State lost more private-sector jobs in November than in any month in more than seven years, the state's Department of Labor said on Thursday. The unemployment rate rose to a four-year high of 6.1 percent. In New York City, the unemployment rate jumped to 6.3 percent from 5.7 percent in October, as the traditional pre-holiday hiring spree barely happened this year. That was the city's highest unemployment rate since February 2005.

I own an apartment in a co-op building, where my daughter has been living in alone for the past five years. She is paying all the costs, including monthly maintenance and utilities. I want to transfer the shares to the apartment to her as a gift. What, if any, action can the co-op board take that could complicate this process? For instance, do I have to notify the board of my intention and can it impose any conditions for approval, like those routinely applied to prospective buyers?

Did you know that the banks are not honoring the $729,750 jumbo loan amount that Congress passed last March? My understanding is that the program passed by Congress was supposed to go for a year, until March 2009.

A New Old Age post in August, "When Mom Goes Missing,'' described the Silver Alert program, which helps locate Alzheimer's victims who wander off. Modeled on the nationwide Amber Alert system for missing children, the dozen states using Silver Alerts often piggy-back on the existing Amber Alert technology, such as bulletins on highway signs, that are in part financed by the federal government.

BCE, seeking a 1.2 billion Canadian dollar ($1.01 billion) breakup fee, has filed suit against the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan and private equity firms, accusing the consortium of withdrawing from its planned takeover prematurely.

Bernard L. Madoff, the New York financier who authorities say has confessed to a $50 billion Ponzi scheme, will not be going to jail even though he failed to meet the original terms of his $10 million bail agreement, The New York Times's Alex Berenson reported.
Police nickname for a Colombian shrimp fisherman accused of designing and building 20 mini-submarines ("narco-subs") used to smuggle cocaine into Central America and Mexico.
For Dow Kim, 2006 was a very good year. While his salary at Merrill Lynch was $350,000, his total compensation was 100 times that - $35 million.
When political appointees find permanent positions with the U.S. federal government - usually during a presidential transition.

Mary Schapiro, a veteran and diligent regulator if ever there was one, is reported to be Barack Obama's choice to head the Securities and Exchange Commission, Floyd Norris, The New York Times's chief financial correspondent, writes on his blog, Notions of High and Low Finance. It is a choice that should please those who hope the S.E.C. can recover from what must be the worst year in its history, Mr. Norris says.

The following is one in a series of reflections from Micheline Maynard, a business correspondent in Detroit, on her recent switch from a Lexus S.U.V. to a hybrid electric Toyota Prius. Share your thoughts on the topic here, or discuss the Prius directly with Ms. Maynard at our Prius Diary discussion board on Facebook.
For The Children's Investment Fund, CSX may turn out to be more trouble than its worth.

Chrysler, the automaker owned by Cerberus Capital Management, said Wednesday that it would close all 30 of its factories for at least one month, starting at the end of this week, in response to plunging vehicle sales in the United States.

The White House and the Treasury are deep into negotiations with General Motors and Chrysler over reorganization plans that could result in freeing up more than $14 billion in emergency loans to keep the companies afloat through the first quarter of 2009, The New York Times's David M. Herszenhorn, Bill Vlasic and David E. Sanger reported, citing industry executives and a senior administration official.

As the Securities and Exchange Commission begins an internal examination into how it missed the red flags of one of the largest frauds in history, it will inevitably discover that Bernard L. Madoff was a Wall Street pioneer who over the last 20 years alternately impressed and infuriated the agency's top policy makers, The New York Times's Stephen Labaton writes.
Morgan Stanley closed out one of its most wrenching fiscal years ever on Wednesday with a $2.36 billion quarterly loss and downbeat forecasts for the year ahead.

After the Mets introduced Francisco Rodríguez as their $37 million closer Wednesday, team executives posed for pictures with him. Jeff Wilpon, the chief operating officer, smiled for the cameras. He has not done much of that lately, The New York Times's Jack Curry writes.

BNP Paribas has canceled a shareholder meeting to vote on its proposed takeover of Fortis, after concluding that it wouldn't be possible to complete the deal on the timetable it had originally planned.
Electricite de France has beaten MidAmerican Energy Holdings for a deal with Constellation Energy.

Almost no segment of New York City's real estate industry was spared in the Madoff scandal, which may be history's largest Ponzi scheme: commercial brokers large and small, little-known developers and prominent families like the Wilpons and Rechlers all lost money to Bernard L. Madoff, industry executives say.
A federal jury on Wednesday found three white-collar defendants guilty in a tax-shelter trial once billed as the largest ever, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning reported.

Clearing the way for a deal worth at least $6.5 billion, Goldman Sachs has agreed to a slightly sweetened offer from Panasonic to buy its stake in Sanyo Electric, Reuters reported, citing three financial sources close to the situation.

President-elect Barack Obama's recent promise to make "the single largest new investment in our national infrastructure since the creation of the federal highway system in the 1950s," has reignited interest in a long languishing, $4 billion bridge improvement project that would ease congestion between Oregon and Washington. The project has pitted business interests against environmental advocates for years.
Struggling Australian miner Mount Gibson Iron is set to get a little help from two Chinese firms.

Veteran banking analyst Richard Bove widened his fourth-quarter loss estimate for Citigroup , saying the bank may take sizable write-downs in its capital-markets operations, similar to those seen in Goldman Sachs 's and Morgan Stanley's fourth-quarter results.
A deal between Australia's Qantas Airways and British Airways just won't fly.
As stock prices fell Wednesday after a 5 percent rally a day earlier, investors with an appetite for safety rushed to buy long-term government debt, The New York Times's Jack Healy reported.

Banco Santander got the green light from European regulators Thursday to buy the retail banking arm of Britain's Bradford & Bingley, months after the British government bought the lender to save it from collapse during the financial crisis.

When you have a lot of customer traction, it seems, it isn't hard to raise more money. Pixim, whose chips are used in hundreds of models of security cameras, has proven that by raising $13 million in new round of funding from existing investors, VentureBeat says.

History | Today King Herod is infamous for the slaughter of all the baby boys in Bethlehem in an attempt to kill the newborn Jesus -- a biblical account that is "almost certainly" untrue. Actually, he was "an astute and generous ruler, a brilliant general, and one of the most imaginative and energetic builders of the ancient world," as an Israeli archaeologist keeps discovering. [National Geographic]

Three residential tower projects, each with a special flair, made New York magazine's list of top building designs for 2008. Unlike most of the gaudy towers going up around the city, the magazine's selections represent designs that manage to simultaneously excite the mind and integrate with the existing space.

Philosophy | First there was "Seinfeld and Philosophy," then "The Simpsons and Philosophy." Now the publisher of the nearly 40-volume series has on deck "The Red Sox and Philosophy," with planned essays on stoicism; betrayal; and Nietzsche's insights into overcoming a nemesis. Looks like it has the bases covered. [Brainiac, Open Court Publishing]
Utpal Bhattacharya is finance professor at the Kelley School of Business at Indiana University.

A wise source-turned-friend, Carol Levine, who is director of the families and health care project at the United Hospital Fund in New York City, a MacArthur fellow, and editor of "Always on Call: When Illness Turns Families Into Caregivers," has written an eye-opening essay in the Albany Times Union about what could happen in the current economic climate to the "invisible workforce" of Americans, 34 million in all, who each year provide an estimated $375 billion worth of unpaid care to aging and ailing relatives and friends.

The Breeders’ Cup has reversed its decision to cut financial support for certain stakes races at about 40 North American tracks after getting a barrage of complaints from the industry. While the organization is making no long-term commitment to the stakes program, which currently affects 121 races, it announced that it would continue at least for one more year. William S. Farish Jr., the Breeders’ Cup chairman, said the organization would tap into its reserve funds to contribute the $4.5 million that it announced last week would be cut from the program because of budget concerns.

Lindsay Davenport will withdraw from the Australian Open because she is pregnant with her second child. Davenport, a three-time Grand Slam singles champion and former No. 1-ranked woman, gave birth to a son in June 2007. She returned to the tour, although she has not played since the United States Open last August.

Water seeping into a gondola tower, then freezing in extreme cold, caused a tower to rupture and collapse this week, injuring a dozen skiers at Canada’s Whistler resort, officials said. The gondola cabins remained on the line after the tower collapsed Tuesday afternoon, but several of them dropped more than 30 feet as the span sagged, and two hit the ground. Fifty-three people were stranded on the line for up for up to three and a half hours as rescue crews worked to get them down using ropes, ladders and fire trucks. A dozen people were treated for minor injuries — from bruises to a fractured vertebrae.
Marc Janko leads European soccer with 30 goals this season and will probably leave Red Bull Salzburg, the Austrian league leader, next month, possibly for England.

The Penn State women’s team, the top-seeded defending champion, is 36-0 and has not lost a set all season, but it needs two more victories for the national title, starting with Thursday night’s semifinal against No. 4 Nebraska (31-2). The other semifinal in Omaha matches No. 2 Stanford (30-3) against No. 3 Texas (29-3). The Lions have won 109 consecutive sets, breaking the 105-set streak by Florida in 2003. Penn State has also won 62 consecutive matches, another N.C.A.A. record.

The standout trotter Deweycheatumnhowe and the award-winning trainer and co-owner Ray Schnittker were unhurt when their pickup and trailer flipped on an icy road in north-central Pennsylvania. Schnittker said his truck hit an icy patch near Jersey Shore, Pa. The truck and trailer carrying the Hambletonian champion called Dewey by Schnittker flipped and slid about 30 feet down an embankment. Schnittker was unhurt in the crash, but his wife, the veterinarian Janet Durso, hurt her shoulder. Dr. John Egloff of Vieux Carre Farm in Gettysburg, where Deweycheatumnhowe was taken after the accident, said the horse sustained minor abrasions. Heather O’Reilly scored off a rebound in the 34th minute, helping the United States beat China, 1-0, at Ford Field in Detroit. The victory gave the United States a record of 33-1-2 for 2008, extending its record for wins in a calendar year. The Americans won 28 of 34 matches in 2004.
The main story for the Knicks after two tough losses to the Suns and the Lakers, was the team’s newfound resilience, and the hint of a swagger.

Because of an editing error, a news analysis article on Wednesday about a dispute in the Screen Actors Guild over a possible strike misidentified a group for which Jonathan Handel, a lawyer who commented on the dispute, has worked. It is the Writers Guild of America, not the side in the actors guild that supports authorization of a strike.

An article on Wednesday about losses in Yale University’s endowment during the financial downturn misstated the date at which the endowment was estimated to be about $17 billion, a 25 percent decline. The figure was cited on Tuesday in a letter that Richard C. Levin, Yale’s president, sent to the university’s faculty and staff; the $17 billion figure was not the estimated endowment as of Oct. 31.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the effect on several charities of a fraud involving a Wall Street investment fund run by Bernard L. Madoff misidentified an investment concern that worked with Mr. Madoff’s fund on behalf of the SAR Academy, a Jewish school in the Bronx. It is Ascot Partners, an investment fund operated by J. Ezra Merkin — not the Ascot Fund, which is a charity affiliated with the National Alopecia Areata Foundation.

A picture caption with an article in some editions on Friday about efforts by Bob Kerrey, the president of the New School, to quell a faculty uprising referred incompletely to a student protest on Dec. 10. The protest was called to demand the resignation of Robert Millard, treasurer of the board of trustees, not of Mr. Kerrey. But when the students were told that senior professors had handed Mr. Kerrey a vote of no-confidence, they cheered and called for Mr. Kerrey to step down also.

An article on Wednesday about the economic woes being suffered in Detroit misstated the given name of the chief executive of Hiller’s Markets, who has joined in efforts to support the beleaguered auto industry. He is Jim Hiller, not John.
The Pentagon believes only about 10 percent of sexual assaults are being reported at military academies, and officials say they want to create a greater comfort level for victims to come forward.
The Missouri Supreme Court has affirmed the state takeover of the St. Louis school system, which has struggled for years with poor finances and student test scores.
One of three men arrested after he was accused of making racist threats against Barack Obama before the Democratic National Convention has pleaded guilty to a weapons charge.

When Oprah Winfrey likes your first novel, it’s safe to say you’ll be writing a second. Lest there be any doubt: the Ecco imprint of HarperCollins said on Wednesday that it had acquired a new novel by David Wroblewski, whose “Story of Edgar Sawtelle” became a best seller when it was published in June and was named by Ms. Winfrey as an Oprah Book Club selection in September. “The Story of Edgar Sawtelle” tells of a mute boy on a Wisconsin farm with an uncanny ability to communicate with dogs. In a statement Ecco said that Mr. Wroblewski’s new book, as yet untitled, would be the second entry in a trilogy, and that it would trace the origins of Edgar Sawtelle’s father and uncle.
