Reflecting the recent nose dive in confidence in the art and antiquities markets, the International Asian Art Fair held each spring in Manhattan has been canceled. The event’s organizers said the current economic slump was the determining factor. Haughton International Fairs, the event’s organizer, said on its Web site (www.haughton.com) that the declining global economy had “strained the resources of many dealers” who had agreed to participate. The fair (which last year featured pieces from Oi Ling Antiques, above) had been scheduled for March 11 to March 15 at the Park Avenue Armory, at 67th Street.

After a report in which Madonna’s publicist said the pop star’s divorce settlement to Guy Ritchie would be upwards of $76 million, the couple would now prefer that the publicist hadn’t expressed herself. In a joint statement reported by Reuters, Madonna and Mr. Ritchie said a “misleading and inaccurate statement, specifically in relation to the sums of money involved, was wrongly issued.” The statement also said: “The financial details of the settlement will remain private, save to say that both of us are happy with our agreement. Our primary concern, like any co-parents, is the care and well-being of our children.” Madonna’s publicist, Liz Rosenberg, told The Associated Press on Monday that Mr. Ritchie would receive $76 million to $92 million in the settlement.

Two weeks after Random House unveiled a sweeping restructuring, the newly consolidated Random House Publishing Group division appointed Susan Kamil, editorial director of Dial Press, as editor in chief of the Random House imprint. Ms. Kamil, who has led Dial since 1993, recently shepherded the best seller “The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society,” by Mary Ann Shaffer and Annie Barrows, and has worked with authors including Allegra Goodman and Elizabeth McCracken. In other news, a spokesman for the Knopf Publishing Group, which assumed control of the Doubleday and Nan A. Talese imprints, said layoffs were announced on Wednesday at Doubleday. Paul Bogaards, a spokesman, declined to say how many people lost their jobs. A spokesman for the Crown Publishing Group said there were also an unspecified number of layoffs at its Broadway imprint.
Two Off Broadway productions are going to great lengths to assure recession-conscious theatergoers they’ll get their money’s worth.

Taylor Swift and Britney Spears swapped places on the top of the Billboard album chart this week. Ms. Swift, whose “Fearless” (Big Machine) reached No. 1 five weeks ago and has been hovering in the Top 5 since, returns with 249,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Ms. Spears’s “Circus” (Jive), last week’s best seller, fell to No. 2 with 200,000. The rest of the Top 5, in a week with few major new release, is familiar. Beyoncé’s “I Am ... Sasha Fierce” (Columbia) holds at No. 3, Nickelback’s “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner) is No. 4, and the “Twilight” soundtrack (Atlantic) reached No. 5.

STERNIN--Alice (nee Lavitt), on December 16, 2008 at age 85. Survived by her devoted husband Lester Sternin, daughters Ronnie Silver and Margie Bloomberg, six grandchildren, two greatgrandchildren, and many others in her very fortunate extended family. She was a true Che-Na-Wah daughter, from her first summer at camp in 1930, through her retirement as camp's director and owner in 1986, and until the final years of her life which were spent along her beloved Lake Balfour. Her legacy will live on in the words, deeds and memories of countless girls and women upon whom she had immeasurable impact. The Colts have won seven games in a row, righting their ship by feasting on some of the league's worst teams. Their last five games have been against teams with a combined record of 19-50-1. They can clinch a wild-card berth and the No. 5 seed in the American Football Conference with a victory over the Jaguars, another losing team. The Colts would be even more dangerous if they could get healthy. Running back Joseph Addai and safety Bob Sanders are questionable for this game, and middle linebacker Gary Brackett and receiver Marvin Harrison are out. The last time these teams played, in Week 3, they were both struggling. Jacksonville dominated the game but needed a field goal in the final seconds to win, 23-21. That victory, in retrospect, may be the highlight of the Jaguars' season. Only stopping their A.F.C. South rival from clinching a playoff spot could top it. NAILA-JEAN MEYERS

N.F.L. owners approved the sale of a majority of the Pittsburgh Steelers to the team's chairman, Dan Rooney, and his son Art II, keeping control of the team in the hands of its founding family while ending more than two years of negotiations to get the franchise in compliance with league rules. The sale assures that Dan and Art Rooney will together hold 30 percent of the team, as mandated by league rules, and that the two Rooney brothers who have casino gambling operations at dog and horse tracks will no longer be involved with the team.

In recent years, the Mets have had various players take on the role of Santa Claus at the team's Christmas party, and more often than not it has not led to the best of luck the next season. Mike Cameron, the 2004 Santa, had a serious outfield collision with Carlos Beltrán the following August that put him on the disabled list for the remainder of the season. Kris Benson, the 2005 Santa, with perhaps too much help from his wife, Anna, was traded to the Orioles a month after the party. Some suggested the Mets were trading the controversial Anna more than they were trading her husband.

The victim was shot in the torso and was taken to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital, where he was reported in stable condition, the police said. The gunman fled with lottery receipts. The police had no suspects late Wednesday night.

CARROLL--James B. M.,84, of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL; Greenwich, CT and Rye, NY died peacefully in his sleep after a long illness at McGraw Center for Caring Hospice December 14, 2008. Mr. Carroll was the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ralph C. Carroll of Rye, NY. His brothers, Ralph, Curtis and Livingston predeceased him. He is survived by a brother John Otis. He leaves his loving wife of 46 years Anne-Louise, sons Scott (his wife Delphine) and Randy (his wife Kathleen), daughter Libby (her husband Steve) Poppleton, and nine grandchildren. He was born April 3, 1924. He attended Rye Country Day School and graduated from The Taft School in Watertown, CT. He also attended Bowdoin College and graduated from Yale University in 1950. Mr. Carroll, known as ''Jimmy'' to his close friends and family, spent two and one-half years in the US Army, where he saw action on the front line in Central Europe and Northern France during World War II. He was a member of C Company, 101st Infantry, 26th Division, and received the American Service Medal, Good Conduct Medal and World War II Victory Medal. He was honorably discharged in 1946. He began his professional career as an investment broker in 1950. He was with Butler, Herrick and Marshall, and then with Wood Walker & Co. where he became a partner. In 1973 Wood Walker was bought by Legg Mason. He spent over 20 years as a floor broker on the New York Stock Exchange where he also held a seat. He retired in 1990. Mr. Carroll was named for James B. Mabon, his mother's brother-in-law, who was president of the New York Stock Exchange from 1912-14. Always the sports fan, Mr. Carroll enjoyed the NY Giants football team and was particularly fond of baseball, especially the NY Giants baseball team before they moved to San Francisco in 1958. He was also an avid golfer and member of Ponte Vedra Inn and Club, Marsh Landing Country Club in Ponte Vedra Beach and The Apawamis Club in Rye, NY. Mr. Carroll was nominated to and elected in 1989 to the United States Seniors Golf Association. A celebration of his life service will be held at 11:30am, Friday, December 19, 2008 at Christ Church in Ponte Vedra Beach. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made in his name to The Taft School, 110 Woodbury Road, Watertown, CT 06795. Services by Hardage-Giddens Funeral Home, 1701 Beach Blvd., Jacksonville Beach, FL 32250 (904) 249-2374.

Two freight trains collided Wednesday in Dresbach in southeastern Minnesota, derailing 40 cars and sending an engine into the Mississippi River. The trains collided at a switching station, said a county official. No serious injuries were reported.

PRATT--Robert Gibb, 74, of Hendersonville, died Tuesday, December 16, 2008 at the Hendersonville Health and Rehab Center following a period of declining health. A native of Locust Valley, Long Island, New York, he was a son of the late Frederick R. Pratt and Pauline Dodge Pratt Webel. He was a prior resident of New York City, West Palm Beach, FL, and resided in both St. Simons Island, GA and Henderson County for the past 26 years. He was a Partner of Williams Inference Center in Longmeadow, MA for over 20 years before retiring in 2006. He was a member of the Racquet & Tennis Club in NY City, the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, Long Island, NY, the Sloane Club in England, the Sports Car Club of America, the Hendersonville Country Club and had attended Cummings Memorial United Methodist Church in Horse Shoe, NC. Golfing and racecar driving were two of his greatest passions in life. Helping others in need was an important part of his life's work. Survivors include his loving wife of eight years, Elise Irby Pratt; one brother, Arthur D. Pratt and wife Sally of Naples, FL; one sister, Pauline ''Polly'' Brown and husband David Fowler of Santa Fe, NM; one step brother, Richard C. Webel of Locust Valley, Long Island, NY; four nieces, Leslie Schwerin of Washington, DC, Jennifer Schwerin of Beijing, China, Christina Schwerin of New York City and Pamela Pratt of Naples, FL. A memorial service will be held at 3pm on Saturday, January 3, 2009 at the Cummings Memorial United Methodist Church with Rev. Cindy K. Lunsford officiating. The family will receive friends one hour prior to the service and will have a light reception following the service in the church hall. Burial will be held at a later date in the Pratt Family's Dosoris Cemetery in Glen Cove, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the: 12 Step Celebrate Recovery Memorial Fund, c/o Cummings Memorial United Methodist Church, PO Box 759, Horse Shoe, NC 28742 or to, Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, New York, New York 10018 or to the Frederick R. Pratt Memorial Library, PO Box 1540, Ridgeland, SC 29936. Thos. Shepherd & Son Funeral Directors and Cremation Memorial Center is in charge of services. An online register book is available for family and friends by visiting www.thosshepherd.com

SPRIZZO--John E. United States District Judge John E. Sprizzo died peacefully in his sleep Tuesday morning, December 16, at Roosevelt Hospital, New York City, surrounded by family members and devoted friends. Judge Sprizzo was a fiercely principled and devoutly religious individual. A man of towering intellect, his academic, legal and judicial accomplishments were extraordinary. The many awards which he received from universities and religious and civic organizations attest to the genius of his work. He was a teacher and inspiration to decades of law clerks who had the privilege of serving in his Chambers and later who always returned for the yearly reunions the Judge so thoroughly enjoyed. The Judge's legacy cannot be measured alone by career achievements. Above all, he loved life and lived every minute of it with passion and grace. He was a person of prodigious and diverse tastes. Until health related issues arose, he could always be found on Saturdays at the sixteenth pole at Belmont Race Track and in the evenings resplendent in his tuxedo at the Metropolitan Opera Club--where he could recite every line of virtually any opera without aid of a teleprompter--and then even later in the evenings hosting post-opera parties at P.J. Clarke's. A mountain of a man, one could not help but be captured by his quick wit, infectious smile, hearty laugh and genuine friendship. He was a devoted father, grandfather and brother who loved his family as deeply as he did his Church and its teachings. Like the protagonist in CP Cavafy's Ithaka, John Emilio Sprizzo had a ''marvelous journey'' through life and enriched all those he engaged with the brilliance of his mind and spirit. He was the beloved grandfather of Katie and Nina Bolka and Maria Hatzipetros. He leaves his wife, Maria, his brother, Carmine, his two daughters Ann Esther Sprizzo and Johna Bolka and his son Matthew. A wake will be held Saturday and Sunday, December 20 and 21 from 2:00pm-5:00pm and 7:00pm-10:00pm at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 345 Avenue U, Brooklyn, NY 11223, (718) 449-1300. A funeral Mass will be held Monday, December 22 at 10:00am at St. John Nepomucene Church, 411 East 66th Street, New York, NY (212) 734-4613. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to: Katie's Corner at Jonathan's Place, P.O. Box 140085, Dallas, TX 75214.

TO gymgoers used to sleek, bright equipment, the kettlebell is downright intimidating. The cast iron weight rose to prominence in Russia and has long been used by serious bodybuilders. It was also the preferred workout tool of Soviet soldiers. ''Traditionally the kettlebell is used in hardman training,'' said Pavel Tsatsouline, a kettlebell trainer and former instructor for the Russian special forces who helped introduce kettlebells to the United States.

ASH--Joseph H.,Jr. Funeral service for Mr. Joseph H. Ash, Jr. of Rosedale/Springfield Gardens, New York, who passed away on December 13th, 2008 in a local hospital in Tampa, Florida will be held Friday, December 19, 2008 at 11:00am at Calvary Baptist Church, 111-10 Guy R. Brewer Boulevard, Jamaica, New York, with Pastor Victor T. Hall, Sr., officiating. Interment will follow in Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, New York with Military Honors. Mr. Ash leaves to cherish loving memories of him with his wife, Rutha P. Ash; daughters, Tonya Nicole Ash-Digregorio and husband, Anthony of Poughkeepsie, New York, Toya Michelle Ash and Natasha Lynn Ash of Queens, New York; sister; Deborah Ash of Columbia, SC; nephew, Christopher Ash and wife, Pam of New York City; grandniece, Jayla; grandnephew, Christopher, Jr. of New York City; cousins, Bernard Seabrooks of New York City and Roslyn Hardy of New York City; his devoted friend, Abe Gatling of Virginia, who always stood by his side, and numerous other family and friends. Joseph was born in New York City on August 30, 1937. He attended Boys High School in Brooklyn, New York and Old Westbury College in Long Island, New York. Mr. Ash was honorably discharged from the U.S. Army. He was a former employee of the NYC Transit Police Department, where he retired after serving 20 years. He did not enjoy retirement so he joined the New York Times Security Force and retired in 2002. Mr. Ash was a member of Calvary Baptist Church, Queens, New York. In spite of severe knee and hip pain, he would always fall on his knees and pray. The remains will repose at Calvary Baptist Church on Friday, December 19, 2008 from 10:00am11:00am and the family will be present to receive friends. Gilmore Funeral Home is in charge. LIEBER--Rabbi David. The Jewish Theological Seminary mourns the passing of its distinguished graduate, president emeritus of the American Jewish University, formerly the University of Judaism (UJ), for many years JTS's West Coast affiliate. As the president of the UJ, Rabbi Lieber played a pivotal role in the evolution of the Conservative Movement on the West Coast, including the establishment of a Camp Ramah. Throughout his presidency Rabbi Lieber was an eloquent spokesman for pluralism and Jewish commitment. His contributions as senior editor to the publication of the Torah commentary Etz Hayim and to the Rabbinical Assembly are invaluable to the quality of American Jewish life. We express our deepest condolences to his widow, Esther, and their children. May his entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman
GREEN--Robert James, 86, died December 16, 2008. Services will be Monday, December 22nd at Canaan First Baptist Church, 132 West 116th Street at 7pm.

Calling Broadway the main street of the Upper West Side, Paul Goldberger wrote in ''The City Observed: New York'' (1978) that it was ''like a child's room that is permitted to remain in disorder by parents who feel that children should be permitted to have their own mess.'' ''If you doubt the economic wisdom of letting a street be that way,'' he continued, ''count the empty storefronts: there are virtually none from Lincoln Center to Morningside Heights.''

LANKENAU--Robert Allen, 73, of Port St. Lucie, passed away Monday, December 15, 2008 at Lawnwood Regional Medical Center in Ft. Pierce, FL. Mr. Lankenau was born in Brooklyn, NY, and had been a resident of Port St. Lucie for the past eight years coming from Lords Valley, PA. He served as a 2nd Lieutenant in the United States Army. He was a member of the Church at Hemlock Farms in Lords Valley, Pennsylvania and the Palm City Presbyterian Church in Florida. He was the founder and 1st President of the Rotary Club in Lords Valley, PA and a member of the Port St. Luci Rotary in Florida. Prior to retirement he worked for several years as a CFO for the Garment Industry cosmetic in New York City. He was also President of Sasson Licensing and Magee Apparel in New York. Survivors include his loving wife of 52 years, Ruth G. Lankenau of Port St. Lucie, FL; two daughters, Debra A. Lankenau of Stone Mountain, GA; Cynthia G. Lankenau of Jacksonville, FL and one son, John R. Lankenau of New York, NY. Memorial Service will be held at a later date in Lords Valley, PA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Jude Children Hospital, 5201 Blue Lagoon Drive, Miami, FL 33126. Services are under the direction of Forest HillsByrd, Young & Prill Funeral Home in Port St. Lucie, FL. Please sign the registry at www.foresthillsfunerals.com
GABEL--Faye. Happy Birthday. When we think of you we smile. We miss you. Iris, Michele, Suzy, Monica, Randi and all your Great-grandchildren

Hello, Brooks Atkinson Theater — are you ready to rock? The Off-Broadway musical “Rock of Ages” will be making its way onto Broadway (with a cocky, Mick Jagger-like strut, no doubt) in the spring, the show’s producers announced. “Rock of Ages,” which combines a narrative about an aspiring rocker and the small-town girl he loves with songs by Journey, Bon Jovi, Pat Benatar and many other 80s-era hair bands, is to begin previews at the Atkinson on March 20 and open on April 7; its current Off-Broadway run at New World Stages is scheduled to end on Jan. 4. Earlier this month, New Line acquired the film rights to the musical; Chris D’Arienzo, who wrote the show’s book, is expected to write and direct the film.

Mike Bell, a professional wrestler better known by the nickname “Mad Dog,” was found dead Sunday at a drug rehabilitation facility in Costa Mesa, Calif., The Associated Press reported. Mr. Bell, 37, who had appeared on television programs like World Wrestling Entertainment’s “Monday Night Raw,” was also a subject of the documentary “Bigger, Stronger, Faster*,” directed by his brother Christopher. The film, which focuses on the use of performance-enhancing substances in sports, drew material from the Bell brothers’ experiences as wrestlers and power-lifters; Mike Bell spoke candidly in the film about his addictions to painkillers and alcohol. Dan Akin, a supervising deputy at the Orange County coroner’s office, told The A.P. that a cause of death could not immediately be determined and that toxicology tests were being ordered.

UPDATE: On Tuesday, Citibank filed suit against Sheldon H. Solow, saying that he had not paid $67 million in loans and $18.5 million in letters of credit, according to documents filed in New York Supreme Court and first reported on cityfile.com. The documents can be viewed in their entirety here at cityfile.com.

Another cast substitution has struck the Metropolitan Opera’s production of “Tristan und Isolde”: Linda Watson will sing the role of Isolde on Saturday, replacing Katarina Dalayman, who is ill, the Met said. Last Friday, Waltraud Meier filled in for Ms. Dalayman. Earlier this month, Gary Lehman substituted as Tristan for Peter Seiffert when he was ill; Mr. Lehman was also one of four tenors to sing the role when the opera was performed at the Met last season. Ms. Watson first sang Isolde in 1998 at the Deutsche Oper am Rhein, and has sung Brünnhilde in Wagner’s “Ring” cycle at the Bayreuth Festival since 2006.

The pianist Alfred Brendel concluded his 60-year performing career with a concert Thursday night at the Musikverein in Vienna, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Brendel, 77, announced his retirement in November 2007 before commencing a nearly yearlong tour; he played his last concerts in New York at Carnegie Hall in February. The program of his final concert, performed with the Vienna Philharmonic, consisted of Mozart’s Piano Concerto No. 9, known as the “Jeunehomme,” followed by encores of Bach’s “Nun komm der Heiden Heiland” and a piece from Liszt’s “Années de Pèlerinage”; audience members included Austria’s former chancellors Alfred Gusenbauer and Wolfgang Schuessel. In an interview with Gramophone magazine, Mr. Brendel said he had chosen the Mozart concerto because it is “a perfect work, with that special freshness of something done for the first time and succeeding at the same time.”

A pangram is a crossword that uses every letter of the alphabet in the grid. They're rare. In fact, there hasn't been one since I started writing the Wordplay blog, until today. This list of pangrams at XWord Info shows all of them going back to 1993. Some constructors seem to strive for them. I call Barry Silk "Dr. Pangram" because, after today, four of the previous seven are by him. This is Brad Wilber's first.

Set against the majestic mesas and dangerous past nuclear testing facilities of the Land of Enchantment, the third annual New Mexico Bowl pits Colorado State of the Mountain West Conference against Fresno State of the WAC. While Colorado State is happy to return to bowl play after a two-year absence, Fresno State cannot be pleased about its status as one of the nation's most disappointing non-B.C.S. conference teams. In the two previous New Mexico Bowls (New Mexico 23, Nevada 0 in 2007; San Jose State 20, New Mexico 12 in 2006), defense was the story. Will offense finally have its say?

On Dec. 14 the Italian railways introduced a new high-speed train line between Rome and Milan. What used to take four and half hours (and often more) is now a three and a half hour journey (At least in theory. I never underestimate the propensity of Italian trains not to run on time).
David Carr talks with Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott, co-chief film critics of The New York Times.

Almost one-quarter of U.S. medical students now graduate from medical school with $200,000 or more in debt, an expense that limits entry to the profession, The New England Journal of Medicine said on Thursday.

The estimated 4,600 employees from Wachovia's investment banking division will see their bonuses reduced at least 90 percent this year, an unidentified manager in the unit told TheStreet.com.

If it's December, then that must mean that B.Y.U. is in the Las Vegas Bowl. The Cougars are making their fourth consecutive appearance in the game and have won the last two. Arizona is not as familiar with the setting, as the Wildcats are playing their first bowl game in a decade. It's been a long time since the Desert Swarm glory days. These teams do know each other pretty well, having faced off in thir 2006 and 2007 season openers. Expect plenty of points in this one, with two offenses that average more than 35 points a game.

Retailers in the United States have had a tough 2008 as consumer spending came to a screeching halt. But 2009 isn't looking any better. In fact, most retail experts and economists predict that it will probably be worse.

The Bagger has put the crank in the side of the machine lately and, um, produced quite a bit of copy. The immersion, though, has left him unable to unhitch from the Oscar grid. Just this afternoon, he found himself perusing Life magazine's Academy Award archives, which recently became available on Google. It's a sickness, this creeping Oscar jones, but you could do worse than stare at an image of Grace Kelly and Clark Gable at the 26th annual back in 1954. Movies stars seemed more like, um, movie stars back then.

If you like your cameras special (edition), Leica says it will offer a version of its D-LUX 4 compact digital camera clad in anodized titanium. The company says it will produce only 10,000 of the cameras, which will be available in January.

Some five million visitors are expected to crowd Washington for the presidential inauguration on Jan. 20, but a free phone app may make it just a little easier to get around, find a meal and connect to the Web.

Color us Coco-friendly black and white, but don't color us surprised: the latest victim of these troubled times is the Zaha Hadid-designed Chanel Mobile Art Pavilion. Somewhat inexplicable even in a flush economy, the traveling, snail-shaped guerrilla gallery, built to house interpretations of Chanel's iconic 2.55 handbag by such artists as Sylvie Fleury, David Levinthal and Fabrice Hybert, has finally deflated after stops in Hong Kong, Tokyo and New York City. A company spokesperson tells WWD, "We will be concentrating on strategic growth investments." Karl Lagerfeld, who didn't even show up for the unveiling in Hong Kong, has no comment. Perhaps he's too busy designing his next vanity stuffed animal. This time it had better come with a bag.

General Growth Properties, the nation's second largest mall operator, is putting the South Street Seaport in Lower Manhattan up for sale, along with Harborplace in Baltimore and Faneuil Hall in Boston. The company, which is struggling and billions of dollars in debt, said on Friday that it was looking at its options for the three popular tourist markets. This year, the company unveiled a billion-dollar plan for the redevelopment of the South Street Seaport, which embraces several historic, cobblestoned blocks.
Barack Obama announced Representative Hilda Solis, a California Democrat, as Secretary of Labor and Representative Ray LaHood, an Illinois Republican, as Secretary of Transportation.

You may be familiar with the Magic Jack if, like me, you've been bombarded with their television ads over the last few weeks. Supposedly, it lowers your phone bill to mere dollars a month, though how the product works remains a mystery. As long as it works and Bernie Madoff isn't involved. But can the Magic Jack, sponsoring the inaugural St. Petersburg Bowl, produce a solid bowl game? Well, if you're like me and have missed college football terribly these long two weeks, then yes. If you're a casual college football fan, you may want to use this three-hour block to schedule a trip to Home Depot.

The college football bowl season kicks off with the rematch everyone has been waiting for! Perhaps that's overstating things, but the Demon Deacons and the Midshipmen did meet on Sept. 27 in a game that had its share of interesting facets. Way back then, Wake Forest was ranked in the Top 25 and Navy had not beaten a ranked team since 1985. That all changed after the Midshipmen's 24-17 victory. Now the Demon Deacons have a shot at revenge. This will be the first time in 63 years that they will play two games against a team in one season. Will Wake take advantage? Do the Midshipmen have the edge with the game being played in Washington, D.C.? Will you be tuned in at 11 a.m. when the game kicks off?

Bernard L. Madoff has been ordered by a federal judge to provide a written list by the end of the year of his assets and liabilities, a key step in finding what is left for investors after authorities said Mr. Madoff admitted squandering at least $50 billion in a Ponzi scheme.

I woke my nephew, Andrew, at 6 a.m. Thursday for the trip to Stoneham in the hills of western Maine. It was 14 degrees outside, still dark, but the sky was mostly clear and pale with a half moon. It was going to be a good day to work.
The S.&P. 100 -- also known as the OEX after its ticker symbol -- is supposed to be 100 of the biggest companies in the S.&P. 500. Being on the list certifies a company as a really big one.

Renaldo Clarke, one of two men who scaled the Midtown headquarters of The New York Times on June 5, pleaded guilty on Friday to one count of reckless endangerment in the second degree.

The first skirmish in what promises to be a war of attrition between groups that want maximum supplies of renewable energy and groups that want maximum protections for landscapes and endangered wildlife ended Thursday when the California Public Utilities Commission, in a 4-to-1 vote, approved a 123-mile, $1.9 billion power line from El Centro to northwestern San Diego.

When the Boston Red Sox wanted to sign Daisuke Matsuzaka two years ago, the team's chief executives traveled to California to negotiate with Scott Boras, the pitcher's agent. The Red Sox doubted that Boras was negotiating in good faith. The strategy worked and the Red Sox signed the pitcher to a six-year, $52 million deal.

In the summer of 2007, Kelli Roman's Facebook photo disappeared from her profile. It showed her nursing her infant daughter, Ivy, and while Facebook never responded when she wrote to ask why, she assumes it was because someone complained that the photo was obscene. Other mothers, she's since learned, have received e-mails from Facebook warning they risked being banned from the site if their breastfeeding photos were put back.

The popular iPhone seems to have a way of becoming, ahem, "lost." But there are a number of apps that can help you recover a missing phone.

The BBC's media iPlayer has been an enormous success in Britain since it arrived last year, and a model for on-demand programming: it gave viewers there the opportunity to stream or download the Beeb's eclectic TV and radio shows, albeit with restrictions put in place by a digital rights management system.

Here's a cool little gift that lets you get instant prints of photos stored on digital cameras and cellphones. The Polaroid PoGo is a palm-size printer that delivers 2-inch by 3-inch photos in a little more than a minute.

World | "Commentators should hesitate before prophesying the decline and fall of the United States," writes the historian Niall Ferguson. It rebounds from even the worst financial crises because "these crises, bad as they seem at home, always have worse effects on America's rivals." [American Interest]

Monologue | Aired Thursday night on CBS: The nice thing about the holidays is the holiday spirit. Let me give you an example of how the holiday spirit affects people. You know that guy that threw the shoes at President Bush? Well, today, he was throwing fruit cakes.
Monologue | Aired Thursday night on NBC: This week President Bush hosted the annual White House Hanukkah party. Yeah, there was an awkward moment when Bush made a wish and blew out all eight candles.

In his memoir, "Knucklehead," the wildly popular children's author Jon Scieszka recalls his childhood growing up in Flint, Mich., with five brothers. Diversions like playing with fire and being left at home to watch his siblings - "We watched Jeff roll off the couch, we watched Brian dig in the plants and eat the dirt" - vied with the favorite family sport of "slaughter ball." Which was pretty much what you might imagine, with a football. As our reviewer Lisa Von Drasek notes in this Sunday's Book Review, "Good thing Scieszka's mom was a nurse."
Monologue | Aired Thursday night on NBC: Thank you for coming out on such a cold day. It is cold, isn't it? Man, everybody was shivering. It's like the whole city's in rehab.

Today's stop on the whirlwind Caroline Kennedy listening and political-exploration tour could not have been more different from the circus-like atmosphere that has been a fixture of her meetings with notable New Yorkers in recent days.
Heading to Turkey with your heart set on buying a rug? Are echoes of caveat emptor (buyer beware) ringing in your head? Then you are off to a good start.

Film | The film "Doubt," about a priest suspected of pedophilia, "limns the particular joylessness of Irish Catholicism," writes Frank McCourt. "You don't have to be Catholic to get inside this film but it helps ... to have heard the swish and swing of nuns' rosary beads and habits, to have sniffed the sourness of celibacy." [Daily Beast]
Call it Wall Street's holiday credit-rating massacre of 2008.

Is anybody out there celebrating? It's hard to tell this year. The crowds of tourists around Rockefeller Center are as thick as ever, but everything is much more subdued than the usual holiday season in New York. Maybe it's the gray, dank weather in New York? C'mon, it's the effect of the economic implosion, not only on our bank accounts but on the national psyche.

On Thursday, the six finalists for the North American Car and Truck of the Year awards were announced in Detroit. Among the finalists are the Volkswagen Jetta TDI and the Mercedes-Benz ML320 Bluetec diesel S.U.V.

Updated at 3:15 p.m.Cerberus Capital Management, the owner of Chrysler, said Friday that it would put $2 billion from Chrysler Financial into the automaker's operations after being granted a $4 billion government loan.

The "best sequence of 2008"? According to Anthony Lane of The New Yorker, that accolade goes, hands down, to the car chase in "We Own the Night." In a year where, by Mr. Lane's estimation, films failed to gain traction in the memory, that one had staying power.

Anyone pondering where to go for hospital care will find a trove of useful data on a new Web site launched by the Commonwealth Fund, a respected New York-based foundation that seeks to improve the performance of the American health care system.

Under intense pressure from the City Council, the Bloomberg administration is backing down from a contentious proposal to revamp the city's sprawling system of senior centers, officials said on Friday.

Following our earlier posts (here and here) on the season's hockey titles, we add a pair of books about two men, both of whom made lasting impressions on the game, though for vastly different reasons. One was perhaps the best goaltender of his or any generation, the other became one of the game's most beloved figures (see photo, right), though for his fictional exploits -- or maybe they weren't so fictional at all.
Carl Icahn has won a court decision. It probably leaves him worse off than if he had lost.
They say you can tell a lot about a businessman from his golf game. Perhaps golf partners should have paid more attention to Bernard Madoff's handicap.

Literature | As we ponder the ghost of Christmas present, here's a cheery thought for Dickensian times: The "thin gruel" of Oliver Twist's workhouse didn't match reality, researchers say. "In fact, contemporary recipes suggest such workhouse gruel was substantial, with each pint containing 1.25 ounces of best oatmeal." On top of that, beef and mutton. [Reuters]
Updated at 3:40 p.m. Eastern

The first cookbook I used was Craig Claiborne's ''New York Times Cookbook''; the first cookbook I bought was ''Joy of Cooking.'' But the first one I fell in love with was Paula Peck's ''Art of Good Cooking.'' Ms. Peck, who wrote in the 60s, was one of the original minimalists. Check out this dessert, which takes about three minutes to make and -- especially when prepared with the ricotta you can buy these days -- is magical.

Politics | The unavoidable Caroline-Palin comparison, from Jonah Goldberg: "Palin's selection triggered troughs of bile, vomited up from nearly every respectable liberal quarter ... Meanwhile, Caroline, with a resume perfectly suited to being a Kennedy and little else, is a Cinderella who deserves a Senate seat because, well, she just does." [National Review]

After more than four years running Microsoft's game studio, Shane Kim was given a new assignment this fall, running strategy and business development for the unit that makes the Xbox game console. In his words, that means figuring out "what we want to be when we grow up."

Updated, 6:03 p.m. | A heavy snow started to fall in New York City and the region around 10 a.m. on Friday, just a day before the official start of winter. Snow and sleet were expected to continue until around 1 p.m., with a potential accumulation of two to four inches, according to the National Weather Service.

The cable wires to my condo unit are too old to maintain a digital feed. The cable company wants a letter from the board permitting access to the common property to repair my cable. The board wants a letter from the company indemnifying the board from liability in case of an accident. Neither side will budge, and I will soon be without television or Internet access. What are my rights?

As an owner in a building that was incorporated as a condominium but is now being run more like a co-op - where buyers have to submit onerous financial documentation to the board of managers - what recourse do I have when I want to sell my apartment?

I have lived in an apartment in the Bronx since May 2008. My lease ends on April 30, 2009, but I would like to break the lease because of excessive noise from other tenants. I have contacted the management office several times by certified letter, e-mail messages and telephone calls, and nothing has been done. How can I go about breaking the lease without paying any penalties?

Alternate-side parking regulations are suspended in the city because of the snowstorm. Typically, the city orders such a parking pardon during and shortly after snowstorms, but there have been times when the decisions have not been so simple. Now the City Council has passed a bill to make the practice law.
Bernand L. Madoff's giant Ponzi scheme has created legions of losers across the world. These include huge European banks, charitable organizations, Eliot Spitzer's family and many, many others.

Jeremy Piven says he's dropped out of Speed the Plow because he was suffering from elevated levels of mercury, which may be due to his being a frequent sushi eater who consumed fish about twice a day.

The Bagger does the math on what movie your family should look for under the Christmas tree and reaches the stunning conclusion that movies in which the underthings of adolescents hit the floor should be some cause for concern. And after much wandering across all the contenders, he finally settles on "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button."

The protracted Senate race in Minnesota took another twist Friday morning as Democratic challenger Al Franken moved ahead of Republican Senator Norm Coleman on day four of the state canvassing board's review of challenged ballots
W. Mark Felt, dubbed Deep Throat by WoodStein, has died.

Our long international nightmare is over. Mats Sundin will be in Vancouver and all's right (or wrong) with the world. Jason Botchford in The Vancouver Province says the reason has much to do with the Canucks' style of play.

The final game at Jacques Plante Arena for the Shawinigan Cataractes was Thursday night, and the Drummondville Voltigeurs made the night a somber one with a 3-2 victory. The arena was built in 1937. The full report on the arena is here, and the game story is below in the roundup.

In the good old days, like say, last year, the trade papers carefully parceled out their prime for-your-consideration advertising covers among those jockeying for Oscar nominations. But in the past two weeks, Daily Variety has done anything but, with five covers going to "Frost/Nixon." And just in case potential voters weren't getting the message, there were four covers during abut the same period on The Hollywood Reporter. When you stack it all up, it represents an impressive show of force on behalf of a movie that looks to be in the thick of things.

It's been quite a week for those seeking to revive the country's focus on the importance of science and engineering to human progress, the need for new energy choices in a world heading toward 9 billion people, and attention to the degrading biosphere. We'll be doing a lot more coverage of President-elect Barack Obama's pledge to boost the role of science in policymaking, and we'll be asking his team lots of questions. I have one big question. What do they plan to do to invigorate the country's innovation pipeline, from the classroom to the lab to the boardroom? (See the chart at right for a view of the world's current lack of interest in an energy revolution. Scroll down for the longer-term view of American research priorities.)

Kohlberg Kravis & Roberts chose Michael Michelson and Alexander Navab, two veteran deal-makers, to lead the firm's core private equity business in North America. The two men will report to George Roberts and Henry Kravis, co-founders of the firm.

General Motors will withdraw as the lead sponsor of the Montreal International Jazz Festival, one of the biggest and most prestigious in the world, because of the crisis in the auto industry. G.M. has contributed about 10 percent of the festival’s $25 million annual budget but will not renew its current five-year sponsorship contract, which expires after the 30th-anniversary season next summer, said Alain Simard, president of the festival’s parent company, L’Équipe Spectra. “We have a year and a half to find a new lead sponsor,” Mr. Simard said. “It’s not easy in these times, but in 30 years we have never been without a sponsor.” With more than 500 concerts, about two-thirds of them free, the festival regularly attracts more than a million visitors to the city. The lineup for next summer includes Buddy Guy, Chucho Valdés, Madeleine Peyroux, Patricia Barber, Dave Holland and Gonzalo Rubalcaba.

BASU--Sreyashi Jhumki, Ph.D. The NYU Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development mourns the death of our esteemed colleague, Associate Professor Sreyashi Jhumki Basu. Dr. Basu's scholarship provided new protocols for teaching science in schools and opened doors for urban youth to experience the joys of learning science. A cherished friend and dedicated mentor, Jhumki will be deeply missed. Our heartfelt condolences to her husband, Alexander Konstantinou, her mother Radha Basu, and her father Dipak Basu.

'FANTASTIC MR. FOX' Peter Rabbit was more lucky than skilled when escaping a determined farmer. But that can't be said of the title character in Roald Dahl's children's novel ''Fantastic Mr. Fox.'' Dahl's hero could outmaneuver, outrun and, yes, outfox not just one irate farmer but three, the bad guys Boggis, Bunce and Bean.

''The Class'' was shown as the opening-night selection of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Manohla Dargis's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 26; the full text is online at nytimes.com/movies. The film, in French with English subtitles, opens Friday in New York and Los Angeles. The young bodies crowding ''The Class,'' an artful, intelligent movie about modern French identity and the attempt to transform those bodies into citizens through talk, talk, talk, come in all sizes, shapes and colors. With their cellphones and pouts, these bored, restless junior high students look pretty much like the fidgety progeny of Anytown, U.S.A. One difference being that these African, Arab and Asian Parisians live in a country that insists its citizens have only one cultural identity, even if it is an identity -- as France's smoldering suburbs vividly suggest -- that many of these same young people don't feel welcome to share.

International drug testers are keeping a watchful eye on Lance Armstrong during his probation period, he said. Armstrong said he has been tested for drugs 11 times in the past 18 weeks and twice in the past four days. The latest test was conducted by officials from the International Cycling Union on Thursday at his Texas home. ''UCI control. They flew a guy from Germany for it. That makes a ton of sense,'' Armstrong wrote on Twitter, a social networking Web site.

The Boston Red Sox were believed to be the favorites to sign the free-agent first baseman Mark Teixeira. But John Henry, the team's owner, sent an e-mail message to several news organizations on Thursday night in which he said the team was no longer pursuing Teixeira. ''We met with Mr. Teixeira and were very much impressed with him,'' Henry said in his e-mail message. ''After hearing about his other offers, however, it seems clear that we are not going to be a factor.''

The death toll in Zimbabwe's cholera epidemic has risen to 1,111, an increase of 133 in two days, the United Nations humanitarian office in Geneva said Thursday. The epidemic has stricken an estimated 20,500 people since August, as Zimbabwe remains crippled by economic and political troubles. Most public hospitals have closed, the sanitation system has broken down in many cities and water has become tainted.

Curiosities abound around, and within, ''It's a Wonderful Life,'' beyond the well-known fact that this holiday perennial only did moderately well when it came out (though it has had remarkable second, third and fourth lives on television and video -- even in color). Here are a few odd facts culled from various sources, including ''It's a Wonderful Life: A Memory Book,'' by Stephen Cox (Cumberland House Publishing; 2005): The film was scheduled to be released in January 1947 -- yes, after Christmas -- but was rushed out in late 1946 in the hope it would garner Oscar nominations. It got five, but didn't win any awards.

The board of the financially troubled Museum of Contemporary Art here reached a preliminary agreement Thursday to accept a $30 million rescue offer from Eli Broad, the billionaire philanthropist who was a founding trustee of the museum and is one of this city's biggest arts patrons, according to three people close to the board. The agreement, which the board voted on at a long meeting, is not final and is subject to numerous conditions, including Mr. Broad's examinations of the museum's financial accounts, according to the people, two of whom attended the meeting.

Officers removed Steven Zimmermann, 19, a sophomore, from a hallway at the New School on Thursday. Students scuffled with security guards and the police there on Thursday morning after an overnight sit-in to protest the leadership of Bob Kerrey, the university president. Around 11:30 p.m., Mr. Kerrey was seen emerging from the building on Fifth Avenue and into a throng of protesters, some of them students, who hurled insults and demanded his resignation. About 30 of the protesters pursued Mr. Kerrey for several blocks. At one point, Mr. Kerrey, who lost part of his leg in Vietnam and wears a prosthesis, broke into a run before ducking into a nearby brownstone. More at nytimes.com/cityroom.

Rockets Over Gaza Signal An Expired Mideast Truce Rockets are flying over Gaza again. The six-month truce that Israel and Hamas, the militant Palestinian leaders of Gaza, agreed to on June 19 is over. Though things are likely to deteriorate further in the short term, both sides need the truce and will probably grope their way back. The question is, how soon and after how much suffering? PAGE A11

Jacob Zuma, the president of South Africa's governing party, the African National Congress, said Thursday he was suing a political cartoonist for about $700,000, saying he was unfairly maligned by an illustration that showed him unbuckling his pants in preparation to rape Lady Justice. The cartoon, which appeared in The Sunday Times in September, mocked Mr. Zuma's attempts to avoid prosecution on corruption charges. In 2006, Mr. Zuma was tried and exonerated on charges of sexual assault. The cartoon, by Jonathan Shapiro, offended the politician's ''dignity and reputation,'' according to a letter delivered to the newspaper this week. BARRY BEARAK

Australian swimmers 18 years and under will be barred from wearing full bodysuits in competition under bylaws passed by the Swimming Australia board. The board also agreed with other leading swimming nations to ask the governing body FINA not to approve further swimsuits and ban the use of multilayer suits after some competitors in Beijing wore several suits to help with buoyancy. Under the new bylaws, male swimsuits cannot extend above the waist or below the knees, and female suits must have open back and shoulder designs. Zippers and other types of fastening systems have been barred.

Hawaii has resolved its dispute with the former coach June Jones over the early termination of his contract. Under the agreement, the June Jones Foundation has donated $100,010 to a scholarship fund. In addition, an undisclosed donor has contributed $100,000 to the university, which said it was owed $400,008 in damages because Jones left for Southern Methodist before his five-year deal expired June 30.

The Olympic gold medalist Shaun White won the snowboard slope-style competition, and Spencer O’Brien of Canada took the women’s event in the first stop on the inaugural Winter Dew Tour in Breckenridge, Colo. White, 22, from Carlsbad, Calif., scored 95.17 points on his second run.

ESPN’s N.B.A. and college basketball commentators will switch roles during a Jan. 7 doubleheader. Mike Tirico and the analysts Mark Jackson and Jeff Van Gundy will call Davidson at Duke at 7 p.m. Eastern, followed by Dan Shulman and Dick Vitale providing commentary when the Denver Nuggets host the Miami Heat at 9 p.m. “It’s been over two decades since I’ve worked an N.B.A. game, but basketball is basketball at all levels and a free throw is still worth a point,” Vitale said.

Penn State, the defending champion, and Stanford, runner-up the last two years, survived five-set semifinals Thursday to advance to a rematch for the N.C.A.A title in women’s volleyball. The Nittany Lions lost their first two sets of the year but improved to 37-0 with a victory over Nebraska. The Cardinal (31-3) defeated Texas to advance to the title match for a record 14th time.

Re "Expert Opinions, From Neutral Observers" While I frequently appreciate your principled analysis, today's thought process was an especially evenhanded discussion of a very complex issue.The complexity of the matters giving rise to and exacerbating this economic crisis is nearly beyond the understanding of even most New York Times readers. To do justice to The Times and its readers on most any of the aspects of the crisis would truly require broadsheet-sized news stories to supply the facts necessary for readers to really be able to arrive at informed opinions.While there is some continuity of theme to all these events - greed, absence of regulation, cheap money, irresponsible lending and management and so on - the nuance is massive and nearly impossible to explore in 1,000 words.

A capsule summary on Friday for an article about the conviction of a senior Rwandan military officer and two accomplices on genocide charges misidentified the man in the accompanying picture. The man shown seated is Lt. Col. Anatole Nsengiyumva, one of the accomplices — not Col. Theoneste Bagosora, the senior officer.

I went to Mumbai this week, thinking I would learn about how India is dealing with the credit crisis. Truth to tell, the country is dealing with the aftermath of its own real-estate and stock-market bubbles -- not to mention the terrorist attacks that took place in late November -- but those reports will have to wait for future columns. What I quickly discovered is that most people wanted to talk about America and its headlong rush into subprime lending, and the disaster that ensued. "We used to think that America was the teacher and we were the students," one businessman told me over breakfast this morning. "We always thought you knew so much more than us. That notion has been shattered."

An article on Dec. 8 about strong sales of products in online virtual worlds, using information from Virtual Greats, a seller of such products, referred incorrectly to the investment bank Allen & Company. A judge has sent Alberto W. Vilar, right, to jail pending his sentencing on March 20 for a conviction on 12 counts related to securities fraud. At a hearing on Thursday the judge, Richard J. Sullivan of Federal District Court in Manhattan, said, “I think there’s ample evidence that there is an incentive to flee and the ability to flee if Mr. Vilar were so inclined,” according to a transcript. Current measures to keep Mr. Vilar in New York, like a curfew and electronic ankle bracelet, are “not foolproof,” the judge said. Mr. Vilar’s lawyers said they would appeal the order, as well as the conviction. Mr. Vilar, an investment adviser, was a major donor to art institutions before market losses led him, prosecutors asserted, to steal money from his investment clients.

The collapsing economy hasn’t completely discouraged acts of philanthropy: on Friday, New York University announced that its Institute of Fine Arts had received a gift of $4 million from the real estate developer Sheldon H. Solow. The donation will be used for fellowships and financial aid for students, the university said. Mr. Solow, the founder of Solow Realty, is a life trustee at both N.Y.U. and the institute; the university said students supported by the donation funds would be named Sheldon Solow scholars. “The gift could not have come at a better moment,” Judy Steinhardt, the chairwoman of the institute’s board, said in a news release. Solow Realty is among the organizations that notified federal authorities of suspected wrongdoing at Dreier L.L.P, a law firm accused of cheating investors of $380 million. On Tuesday Citibank filed suit against Mr. Solow, saying that he had not paid $67 million in loans and $18.5 million in letters of credit, according to documents filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan and first reported on the Web site cityfile.com.

A Times editorial on Aug. 1, 1968, declared: ''Public opinion polls possess the fascination inherent in any attempt to read the future. But in fact they are a reasonably trustworthy guide only to the past.'' With this in mind, we look back four decades to the opinion polls of 1968 -- a year dominated by an unpopular war, racial tensions, economic unease and a presidential election upon which much would hang. Sound familiar? Unless otherwise noted, all of the polls below are from 1968 and, unless edited for space, the language is that used at the time.

(Cinemax) DEFINITELY, MAYBE (2008) A soon-to-be-divorced father regales his tweener daughter (Abigail Breslin, above) with stories about his romantic past, then leaves it to her to figure out which one of his beloveds (names changed to protect the innocent as well as the fairy tale concept) wound up being her mother. Elizabeth Banks, Rachel Weisz and Isla Fisher play the girlfriends in question. While this ''nimble and winning little romance,'' written and directed by Adam Brooks, is ''hardly perfect, it navigates the choppy waters of modern courtship with commendable, understated honesty,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. He also gave this film about New York singles extra credit for actually being filmed in the city. SWISKAY--Alice, died December 18, 2008 two months before her 91st birthday, this Valentine's Day. She is mourned be her three daughters, Elaine Rose, Carolyn (Barry) Greene and Laura (Nick) Unger, and her grandchildren, Jordin Green, Brian Greene, Katie Unger, David Unger and Sidney San Martin. She was deeply loved and admired by all who knew her.

SNYDER--Harold. The trustees, faculty and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of our dear friend and generous benefactor Harold Snyder. Mr. Snyder was a stalwart supporter of the Leon H. Charney Division of Cardiology at the NYU School of Medicine, establishing with his family the Harold Snyder Family Professorship in Cardiology and helping to launch the new Cardiovascular Genetics Program in the division. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Tamara Hirschl Snyder, his daughter Beryl Lynn, his sons Jay and Brian and their loved ones. Kenneth G. Langone Chairman, Board of Trustees NYU Langone Medical Center Robert I. Grossman, M.D. Dean and CEO NYU Langone Medical Center Glenn I. Fishman, M.D., Director Leon H. Charney Division of Cardiology NYU School of Medicine

SNYDER--Harold. Our deep sadness is only tempered by the wonderful memories of a dear friend and amazing man who we will love and miss forever. We extend our condolences to his wife Tamar and the entire Snyder family. Sondra and Seymour Goldman
WEINER--Joan. We will miss you and the good times we all shared. Pearl and Maurice Jane and Bob

COUGHLIN--Patricia Parham died on November 8, 2008, in Stowe, Vermont, due to complications from cancer. She was born in Montreal on September 9, 1931, to Mavis and R.A. Parham. She is survived by her beloved husband of 52 years, G. Gordon Coughlin, Jr.; three sons, and daughters-in-law, George and Ann Vitaletti-Coughlin; Robert and Patricia Coughlin; Crosby and Deirdre Coughlin; and four grandchildren, George, Phoebe, Charlotte and Patrick Coughlin.

WARBURG--Anita, died peacefully December 14 in her Manhattan home, days shy of 100. Born in Hamburg to Max and Alice Warburg, sister to Eric, Lola, Renata and Gisela, she emigrated to London 1935 where she worked for Jewish Refugee Committee and British Red Cross. Briefly married to Manchester Guardian correspondent Max Wolf. Moved to Manhattan 1938. Sculptor, painter, patron, board member and consultant to Institute for International Education, Mannes The New College of Music, and countless others. Leaves behind many devoted nephews, nieces, cousins and friends. Donations in Anita's memory to Mannes, 150 West 85th St., NY, NY 10024.

SNYDER--Harold, 86, of New York City. Generic drug pioneer Harold Snyder died December 18 after a brief illness. Mr. Snyder promoted the widespread use of generic drugs which have improved the lives of millions of people throughout the world. At his death, Mr. Snyder served as a director of Teva Pharmaceuticals Ltd., the world's largest generic pharmaceutical company, and as a principal of HBJ Investments. His philanthropy was wide ranging; whether through The Beatrice Snyder Foundation, his many direct gifts, or his participation in organizations large and small. Born on April 25, 1922, Mr. Snyder grew up in NYC, the son of immigrant parents. Despite his enormous success later in life, he never forgot the poverty of his childhood. His caring and generosity touched countless lives around the world; from local charities to medical research, from ecology to music. He was also a passionate promoter of progressive causes. He never regarded any issue as too insignificant to prevent his tireless involvement. Mr. Snyder served in the Army Air Corps on a B-17 bomber during World War II. He graduated from New York University in 1948 and received an M.S. from Columbia University in natural science in 1950. Mr. Snyder was one of the founders of the generic drug industry. In 1964 he formed Biocraft Laboratories in Elmwood Park, NJ with his wife of 49 years, Beatrice. He served Biocraft as President, CEO and Chairman for the next three decades where he worked closely with his entire family. Under his stewardship, Biocraft became one of the largest generic drug manufacturers in the U.S. In 1985, it was the first generic drug manufacturer to be listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Snyder is survived by his wife, Tamar Hirschl Snyder, an Israeli artist, whom he married in NYC, his daughter, Beryl, and his sons, Brian and Jay, all of NYC, and by six grandchildren, Quentin, Jackson, Maxwell, Ophelia, Brette and Evan. The service will be on Monday, December 22, at 11:45am at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th at Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to The Harold Snyder Charitable Fund, 592 Fifth Avenue, 6th Floor, New York, NY 10036.

LOEB--Nedra Ruth. Beloved wife of Werner L. Loeb and mother of Janice, Susan, Chuck and five grandchildren. We kiss and hug you all the time. Funeral service Sunday, 2pm, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St.

On Feb. 15, 2007, the city issued about 4,000 parking violations, many of them to snowbound cars violating alternate-side parking regulations. At first, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg told New Yorkers to stop ''griping'' over parking tickets. But after drivers raised a furor, he issued a rare apology and said the tickets would be dismissed.

An entry in the Spare Times for Children listing on Friday about the Holidays Festival at the Children's Museum of Manhattan included performance times for the entertainer Louie Miranda on Sunday that were changed after the section went to press. FRIEDMAN--Dr. Mark H. The heart of a child with the mind of a Nobel Laureate. Inventor of the most effective migraine treatment ever. After him they broke the mold and ground it into pieces. We love you a million. Services Sunday December 21, at 10am, Riverside Chapel Mount Vernon, NY.

State Senator-elect Hiram Monserrate, a Queens Democrat, was arrested early Friday and accused of slashing his companion in the face with a broken drinking glass during an argument in his Jackson Heights apartment, the authorities said. He then drove her to a hospital outside the city, officials said, where she required 20 stitches. Mr. Monserrate, 41, who is in his final days as a city councilman, was charged with second-degree assault, a felony that carries a maximum sentence of seven years in prison, the police said. If Mr. Monserrate is convicted, state law requires that he be expelled from the Senate.

HERSH--Stephanie Charlotte, Holocaust survivor, 83, died on December 17, 2008 with her daughter and friends by her side at Memorial SloanKettering, after a long battle with cancer fought with courage and dignity. Born Sarah (Stepha) Urbach to Anna and Isaac. Beloved and loving mother of Anita K. Hersh, beloved and loving wife of the late Jack Hersh. Stephie survived numerous Nazi ghettos, concentration camps, and labor camps. She fled Eastern European Communism in 1947, making her way to Rome, Italy, where she met and married Jack. Together they came to the United States in 1949 to make a new life, and settled in Mount Vernon, NY. Stephie was active in charities and political campaigns. A voracious reader, she had an encyclopedic knowledge of a broad range of subjects, a sly wit, and a keen sense of humor. Her impeccable sense of style stayed with her to the end. Stephie was a source of love and inspiration and an incredible life force, and will be deeply missed by those who had the pleasure of knowing her. Funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell's, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC, on Sunday December 21 at 11:00am. Interment to follow at Shaarey Pardes Accabonac Grove Cemetery in East Hampton, NY. Shiva will be observed following internment on December 21, as well as on Monday December 22 starting at 7:00pm at the home of Anita Hersh in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations in Stephanie's memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center to support cancer research, c/o Dr. Katherine Bell-McGuinn, MSKCC, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021, or to The Blue Card (help for indigent Holocaust Survivors), 171 Madison Avenue, Suite 1405, New York, NY 10016.

McNULTY--John Thomas, 92, of Rye, New York, devoted husband of Virginia, died Thursday afternoon, December 18, 2008, at his home. He was a wonderful father and grandfather. He is survived by Susan M. Dill, Marianne Stoupnitzky and Robin Dawson, and eight grandchildren.

This interconference game has huge playoff implications for Baltimore and Dallas, who are each in wild-card position but have a handful of teams bearing down on them. Oh, and it is most likely to be the last game played at Texas Stadium. The Cowboys have won 213 of their 312 games there since 1971. This is only the third meeting between the teams; the Ravens won the first two, which were played in Baltimore. But the teams can relate to each other, each having recently endured a demoralizing loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers. Tony Romo was banged up by the Giants and cannot be looking forward to another swarming defense. But maybe it is Joe Flacco who should be afraid. The Cowboys' defense, led by DeMarcus Ware, is on a tear, and Flacco is not. In his last two games, Flacco has a passer rating of 40.3, with one touchdown and three interceptions. NAILA-JEAN MEYERS

GORDON--Kenny. K.G.,ten years have passed and while we miss you more than words can describe, the wonderful memories we shared together cannot fade. Finance | Which is it? Is the United States an impending inflationary disaster, with no one left to finance "the Obama administration's looming titanic fiscal deficits"? Or is it the world's "only remaining super-borrower," so powerful in attracting investors that it should actually lend some of the money it borrows (prints) to other countries, to keep the world economy afloat? Two views. [Wall Street Journal, Financial Times]

Culture | As you head out for last-minute holiday shopping, ponder this and see if it makes sense: Victor Gruen, a Jewish socialist refugee from Vienna, was the father of the shopping mall who soured on his own creation, blaming it for suburban sprawl. His solution: move the mall back to the city as pedestrian shopping zones. Now this "urban version of the suburban version of the urban" is being transplanted back to the suburbs. Got it? All for consumers less inclined to shop now anyway. [Atlantic]

History | Other key battles in English history like Agincourt and Waterloo have been subjects of feature films, but the 1066 Battle of Hastings has been ignored -- until now. Now three films are in the works, from people with pedigrees in "Gladiator," "Boys Don't Cry" and "Trainspotting." All plan to show the clash between King Harold and William the Conqueror as "the falling out of two comrades, using the trusted cinema combination of violence and contrasting love lives." [Times of London]

Evan Turner had 21 points and ignited a second-half rally with 9 points and 2 blocked shots to guide No. 17 Ohio State to a 71-53 victory over visiting Iona. Alejo Rodriguez scored 17 points for Iona (4-7).

The injured French sailor Yann Elies has been rescued from his yacht by an Australian Navy ship. Elies broke his leg Thursday while working on the deck of his yacht Generali during the Vendée Globe round-the-world race. The race Web site said Elies was picked up by the frigate Arunta on Saturday, after it sailed 800 miles from Australia’s west coast.

Are you still using paper bank statements and Excel to manage your money, or do you trust a Web site to help you out? Amid the big slump, many people are turning to the Web, as I wrote in an article on Saturday. Disillusioned by banks and the stock market, they are logging on to sites that pull together their financial data from across the Web, help them create budgets and offer a community where they can talk about their finances with others.

An article on Jan. 21 about Kabul, Afghanistan, misidentified the country that financed a project to restore part of the National Museum there and misstated the material used to make the museum’s main staircase. The restoration of the central hall and main stairs was financed by The Netherlands, not Austria, and the staircase is made of travertine, not marble.

Roger Cohen’s article (Dec. 7) hits the mark on how the new administration should look at U.S.-Cuba relations. To really widen the unfortunately narrow path to a new era, however, the new administration must start from scratch. Washington should set a new tone that will avoid reliving the consequences and implications of old, failed policies of confrontation and antagonistic rhetoric. Those old policies have only served to grant Havana a near-perfect pretext to sustain and justify their reluctance to opening spaces for democratization.

As a victim of unremitting harassment throughout middle school and high school, I have to respond to Dacher Keltner’s romanticized notions of teasing (Dec. 7). While I appreciate that there is a difference between teasing and harassment, I certainly do not trust underpaid and overworked educators to know where to draw the line. And while the author may claim a knowledge of the difference between teasing and harassment, I highly doubt that someone who was lightly teased — for having a name children perceived as funny — has any idea of the hell that some children live through every day. Certainly many of their educators do not.

EPSTEIN--Seymour. Former President and CEO of Shelburne Shirt Company died De cember 19, 2008 at 89. Born in Brooklyn, NY and attended Boys High, he graduated from Columbia College and Columbia Law school in 1942. he was honored to accept membership to Columbia Law Review. He passed the bar before attening Columbia Midshipman's School. During World War II Mr. Epstein served as a naval commander in both the Atlantic and Pacific theaters. Although he loved the law, after the war he accepted the responsibility of a leadership role in the family business at the request of his father. He took a small family run shirt company and expanded it into an international manufacturing business. He served on the board of the National Manufacturers Association and was proud that he could offer business opportunities to his family and extended family members. He was respected for his honesty and integrity not only in business, but in his personal life as well. His caring and generosity touched all who knew him. He was honored and proud to be in a position to donate to many charitable organizations such as the UJA and NYU Langone Medical Center. His philanthropy was wide ranging and he encouraged and inspired his children and grandchildr en to recognize the importance of charity. He created a charitable foundation in his parents name to enable all in his family to participate in experiencing the joy of giving even at a very young age. His generosity knew no bounds. His devotion to and love of his family was the driving force of his life. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife of 61 years, Muriel nee Joseph, his children, Randy Austin and her husband Bruce Firger, Bob Epstein and his partner Jacqueline Buckner, Jane Epstein and her husband Edgar Roeper, and Susan Gross and her husband Jeffrey Gross; his seven adored grandchildren David Austin and his wife Tammy Yuen, Lauren Austin, Cass, Josh and Alex Epstein, Sam and Jamie Gross and his great granddaughter Amelia Rose Austin who gave him such great joy in the last two years. He is also survived by his brother Selwyn Epstein, his beloved sister and brother-in-law Blossom and Irwin Greystone, and his many nieces, nephews and friends. In addition to his devotion to his immediate family he was a role model and trusted advisor to his large extended family all of whom knew they could look to him for his wise advise, counsel and love. He will be in our hearts forever. Services will be held at Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave, NYC on December 23rd at 11am. Donations in Seymour's name may be made to NYU Langone Medical Center Stem cell research.

THIS WEEK'S RECOMMENDATIONS THE STREET: Seeking men and women fully dressed? The joyful street-style blogs are for the traveler who likes the sit-in-a-cafe-and-observe part and can be brought around -- in the recession, anyhow -- to the from-the-comfort-of-your-home part. My favorites are the pristine ones that don't have muddy, trashy party pictures that really belong on MySpace. I like a point of view, lucid pictures, some analysis and lots of air in the design. That means: Face Hunter (London and beyond), The Sartorialist (New York and beyond), Garance Doré (Paris), Copenhagen Street Style, Stockholm Street Style, Altamira NYC, Stil in Berlin, The Style Scout (London), Style-Arena (Tokyo by neighborhood; see especially Harajuku, which first defined street style), The Streetswalker (Tel Aviv), Toronto Street Fashion, Styleclicker (Munich), On the Corner (Buenos Aires), Austin Style Watch, 2 Threads (Australia), The MidWasteland (Chicago), Miss at the Playa (miscellaneous), Hel-Looks (Helsinki), Look at Me (Moscow), Shanghai Viva, Glam Canyon (London), ReykjavikLooks.

CHAINS Seeds of America. By Laurie Halse Anderson. Simon & Schuster. $16.99. (Ages 10 and up) Anderson's fine new novel could almost be a middle-grade companion to M. T. Anderson's ambitious ''Octavian Nothing'' books. While not playing down the cruelty to Isabel and Ruth, two young slaves in a loyalist New York household, ''Chains'' brings lively interest to the business of daily life as Washington's army rises. Against a backdrop of tragedy, the story centers on hope that the sisters can escape to freedom. (A finalist for the 2008 National Book Award for young people's literature.)

DINOSAUR VS. BEDTIME Written and illustrated by Bob Shea. Hyperion/Disney. $15.99. (Ages 3 to 6) An exuberant and determined little dinosaur faces up to a series of tests, including bath time, tooth-brushing and dinner, besting them all (''roar! roar! roar!'') until in the final challenge he meets his match. In vibrant paint, ink and photo collage, the fearsome red dinosaur, with angry eyebrows and a gleeful grin, is a comical stand-in for any young would-be monster who has made up his or her mind and won't budge. But in the end, thankfully, ''Bedtime wins. Good night, dinosaur.''

CAMPBELL--Alastair Francis Sutherland, died peacefully December 12, 2008 at his home in Boca Grande, FL after a year long struggle with cancer. Born August 20, 1941 in England, educated at Malvern College and Bristol University (LL.B., 1963). He began his career with Esso Petroleum Ltd. in London in 1967. He was transferred successively to Esso Europe Inc. in 1973, to Exxon Corporation in New York in 1977, to Exxon Company, International in New Jersey in 1985. In 1993 he became General Counsel of Exxon Ventures (CIS) Inc., based in Houston until his retirement in 1998. He will be remembered for his dedication, honesty, keen legal intellect and incisive wit. He served on the Boca Grande Community planning panel and the Gasparilla Island Water Association, and had plenty of time for photography and model boat making. Alastair F.S. Campbell is survived by his wife Pamela Prentice Campbell, three stepdaughters: Countess Helena DeBelloy (Frederick), Joanna Booth (Christopher), Katrina Guittat (Christian), 10 step-grandchildren, two sisters in England, Alexa Bainbridge (Ian) and Helen Mallows (Richard) and an aunt, Miss Edwina Burton. Services for a memorial service are pending. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Mr. Campbell may be directed to M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, P.O. Box 4486, Houston, TX 77210-4486

SLIDESHOW: A Brother's Art, Lost and Found In 2000, Robert Weiss opened the Object Image Gallery in Brooklyn, where some of his best sellers are his own paintings. His brother, Kenneth, loved painting too, but went through some rough patches and eventually stopped painting. In October, Kenneth died of kidney failure at 66. About a week later, Robert found a box of Kenneth's paintings and drawings dating back to 1958. Robert had thought they were lost, but about a dozen are now on view in his gallery. From left to right above, Kenneth's Brooklyn backyard and self-portrait and Robert with the portrait in his gallery. At right, a watercolor by Robert.

WARBURG--Anita, died peacefully December 14 in her Manhattan home, days shy of 100. Born in Hamburg to Max and Alice Warburg, sister to Eric, Lola, Renata and Gisela, she emigrated to London 1935 where she worked for Jewish Refugee Committee and British Red Cross. Briefly married to Manchester Guardian correspondent Max Wolf. Moved to Manhattan 1938. Sculptor, painter, patron, board member and consultant to Institute for International Education, Mannes The New College of Music, and countless others. Leaves behind many devoted nephews, nieces, cousins and friends. Donations in Anita's memory to Mannes, 150 West 85th St., NY, NY 10024.

HELLER--Austin Norman, 94, passed away peacefully on December 15, 2008 in Mason, Ohio. He was a chemical and environmental engineer with a distinguished career that included appointments as NYC Commissioner of the Department of Air Resources, 1966-1970; State of Delaware, Secretary of the Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control, 1970-1973; appointed by President Ford as Assistant Administrator of the US Energy Resources and Development Agency, 1976-1977. In 1969, he received the Children's Asthma Research Institute Humanitarian Award. He served in the US Navy during WWII and continued serving as a LCDR in the naval reserve. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 58 years Frances (nee Sandler) in 2001. He is survived by his two children, two grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. He was loved and will be greatly missed.

THE LUMP OF COAL By Lemony Snicket. Illustrated by Brett Helquist. HarperCollins. $12.99. (Ages 4 and up) ''Miracles can happen, even to those who are small, flammable and dressed all in black.'' On this cheery note a different kind of holiday story opens, featuring a scowling lump of coal. ''Like many people dressed in black, the lump of coal was interested in becoming an artist'' -- or, failing that, at least a charred line on a salmon fillet. It's a far, far better thing that the lump ends up in a naughty boy's stocking, bringing unlikely fame and fortune to the pair, and a fitting conclusion to a hilarious Christmas tale.

It was another fairly calm week for the markets, with the stock market indexes barely budging from their starting point -- no small achievement in a year of relentlessly high volatility. President Bush's announcement on Friday that the government would provide a $13.4 billion loan to the Detroit automakers bolstered the markets. And so did the Federal Reserve's moves on Tuesday to strengthen the economy. The Fed cut its benchmark short-term rate to a range from 0 to 0.25 percent -- essentially as low as it could go. And it pledged to use all the tools at its disposal to restore the battered financial system.

The No. 1 seeding in the American Football Conference is on the line, but Pittsburgh (11-3) and Tennessee (12-2) could also use this game in Nashville to get to know each other. Whatever the result, these teams could meet again with even greater stakes in a few weeks in the conference championship game. Sunday's game determines where that game would be played. The Steelers and the Titans already know that this will be a bruising defensive battle. Pittsburgh and Tennessee have allowed the fewest points in the N.F.L. this season. But the Titans, coming off a disconcerting loss to the Texans, are at a disadvantage without their two best defenders, Albert Haynesworth and Kyle Vanden Bosch.
