HERSH--Stephanie Charlotte, Holocaust survivor, 83, died on December 17, 2008 with her daughter and friends by her side at Memorial SloanKettering, after a long battle with cancer fought with courage and dignity. Born Sarah (Stepha) Urbach to Anna and Isaac. Beloved and loving mother of Anita K. Hersh, beloved and loving wife of the late Jack Hersh. Stephie survived numerous Nazi ghettos, concentration camps, and labor camps. She fled Eastern European Communism in 1947, making her way to Rome, Italy, where she met and married Jack. Together they came to the United States in 1949 to make a new life, and settled in Mount Vernon, NY. Stephie was active in charities and political campaigns. A voracious reader, she had an encyclopedic knowledge of a broad range of subjects, a sly wit, and a keen sense of humor. Her impeccable sense of style stayed with her to the end. Stephie was a source of love and inspiration and an incredible life force, and will be deeply missed by those who had the pleasure of knowing her. Funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell's, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC, on Sunday December 21 at 11:00am. Interment to follow at Shaarey Pardes Accabonac Grove Cemetery in East Hampton, NY. Shiva will be observed following internment on December 21, as well as on Monday December 22 starting at 7:00pm at the home of Anita Hersh in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations in Stephanie's memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center to support cancer research, c/o Dr. Katherine Bell-McGuinn, MSKCC, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021, or to The Blue Card (help for indigent Holocaust Survivors), 171 Madison Avenue, Suite 1405, New York, NY 10016.
INTERNATIONAL IN DARFUR, ANGRY YOUTHS

SNYDER--Harold, 86, of New York City. Generic drug pioneer Harold Snyder died December 18 after a brief illness. Mr. Snyder promoted the widespread use of generic drugs which have improved the lives of millions of people throughout the world. At his death, Mr. Snyder served as a director of Teva Pharmaceuticals Ltd., the world's largest generic pharmaceutical company, and as a principal of HBJ Investments. His philanthropy was wide ranging; whether through The Beatrice Snyder Foundation, his many direct gifts, or his participation in organizations large and small. Born on April 25, 1922, Mr. Snyder grew up in NYC, the son of immigrant parents. Despite his enormous success later in life, he never forgot the poverty of his childhood. His caring and generosity touched countless lives around the world; from local charities to medical research, from ecology to music. He was also a passionate promoter of progressive causes. He never regarded any issue as too insignificant to prevent his tireless involvement. Mr. Snyder served in the Army Air Corps on a B-17 bomber during World War II. He graduated from New York University in 1948 and received an M.S. from Columbia University in natural science in 1950. Mr. Snyder was one of the founders of the generic drug industry. In 1964 he formed Biocraft Laboratories in Elmwood Park, NJ with his wife of 49 years, Beatrice. He served Biocraft as President, CEO and Chairman for the next three decades where he worked closely with his entire family. Under his stewardship, Biocraft became one of the largest generic drug manufacturers in the U.S. In 1985, it was the first generic drug manufacturer to be listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Snyder is survived by his wife, Tamar Hirschl Snyder, an Israeli artist, whom he married in NYC, his daughter, Beryl, and his sons, Brian and Jay, all of NYC, and by six grandchildren, Quentin, Jackson, Maxwell, Ophelia, Brette and Evan. The service will be on Monday, December 22, at 11:45am at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th at Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to The Harold Snyder Charitable Fund, 592 Fifth Avenue, 6th Floor, New York, NY 10036.

When Americans lose their jobs, as is happening in growing numbers, many also lose health insurance. But even for employed people with medical coverage, an illness can mean not only a sharp break with the life they have known, but also financial disaster. Employment-based insurance frequently does not sustain someone through the entirety of a serious medical ordeal. Often, a health crisis will ultimately mean the loss of a job, and with it insurance. Medicaid and Social Security disability provide a vital, if minimal, safety net, but qualifying for them can take time, while medical bills pile up, leading to trouble paying the rent, utility bills and other expenses.

MURPHY--Jean C. Triolo, of Glen Cove, LI, NY passed away peacefully and surrounded by love in her home on December 11, 2008. Beloved mother of MiMi and the late Marty Murphy. Loving sister of Sadie Irwin, the late Salvatore Triolo and the late Nat Triolo. The family wishes to extend their gratitude to Dr. Sarwat Kamal whose compassion, generous spirit and kindness to both Jean and MiMi was monumental in their greatest time of need. Jean was a graduate of Immaculata High School and Pace University. She dedicated her professional life to the North Shore University Hospital at Manhasset as the Finance Supervisor of five departments. Jean will always be remembered as a leader in her field and a mentor and inspiration to those who had the pleasure of knowing her. Jean was a pure person, a woman of great depth, integrity, honor and old fashioned values. She had a great sense of humor. A voracious reader, Jean had a encyclopedic knowledge on a broad range of subjects and loved crossword puzzles, all of nature and her favorite four pawsPenni Nuggets. Jean will be forever cherished and remembered for a courageous full life lived extraordinarily well. Rest well Mommy-my heart is broken. A funeral mass was held at St. Boniface Martyr Church, Sea Cliff, L.I. officiated by Father Fred. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery.

Upon entering the M1-5 Bar in TriBeCa, all an erstwhile banker had to do was grab a pink bracelet. That meant ''looking for a job.'' Recruiters and supporters of the unemployed donned bracelets with other colors. Doug Hirschhorn, a performance coach and executive trainer, second from right below, consulted with participants in the event. At bottom left, Catherine Miller, a job seeker, talked to Roland C. McBarnette, a recruiter at the Forum Group. The event was sponsored by Dealbreaker.com, the Wall Street blog, and TheLadders.com, the jobs site.

SNYDER--Harold. Our deep sadness is only tempered by the wonderful memories of a dear friend and amazing man who we will love and miss forever. We extend our condolences to his wife Tamar and the entire Snyder family. Sondra and Seymour Goldman

Address: 179 Sturges Highway The Property: A traditional colonial with four bedrooms, two and a half baths, hardwood floors, a screened porch and a two-car attached garage. Built in 1978, the house feels a bit tired, especially the dated kitchen, but it offers 3,000 square feet of living space, with additional space in the walk-out basement ready to be finished. The property's three-plus acres abut conservation land and are set well back from the road.

BUTLER--William Jack, died on November 14th in Santa Barbara, California, where he lived in retirement after a career with Mobil Oil. He was Chairman of the Board and Director of Mobil Saudi Arabia and Middle East Regional Director of Mobil Oil Corporation. He was also a Director of several Saudi shipping companies and Mobil affiliates in Africa and the Middle East. He was a graduate of Harvard and of Harvard Business School. He studied engineering for two years at the University of Michigan, played varsity football there and belonged to Delta Kappa Epsilon. Jack Butler was a naval aviator (Lt. Cmdr.) during World War II, after which he joined the Arabian American Oil Company and established the first television station in the Middle East. His articles on the Middle East were published in the Harvard Business Review, Barrons, Business Week and Foreign Affairs. When he returned to Saudi Arabia with Mobil in 1975, he negotiated and signed contracts for fourteen new companies, including 2 refineries, a petrochemical plant, and the management of the construction and operation of the worlds largest-capacity crude oil pipeline from the Persian Gulf to the Red Sea. He was an avid tennis player, scuba-diver and skier in his active years. And he loved books. He is survived by his wife Patricia, son Peter, two grandchildren, Sarah of Santa Barbara and Ross of McLean, Virginia. His son Christopher predeceased him in 1998.

FLAUM--Stuart David. We honor the life of Stuart Flaum. He was a soul mate and father, leader, buddy, and friend. We will cherish the happy memories that were shared and celebrate his incredible life. Stuart touched the lives of everyone who crossed his path and will be deeply missed. He leaves behind his loving wife, Janice, of 57 wonderful years, his darling daughters, Mindy and Andrea, son, Bruce, and his grandchildren, Danna and Zoey. Services will be held at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, located at 11115 Jog Road, Boynton Beach, FL on Sunday December 21 at 10am.
To the Editor: Re ''A Bensonhurst Boyhood, Unlocked at Last,'' (New York Observed, Dec. 14), about reminiscences of a childhood in Brooklyn posted online by the author's father:

ESTILL--Mark. On Tuesday, December 16th, 2008, the world lost an incredible man in Mark Thomas Estill, 54. His new rock star wife, Beth, held his hand and his gaze in his house in Moncure, North Carolina as he passed away. He had been diagnosed with lung cancer four weeks prior. Mark, of course, never smoked. His brothers Jim, Glen and Lyle are planning the next ''Brothers Weekend'' (a concept which Mark had created), in his honor. His mother Ann and his father Don joined us all, and they miss him very much. It comes as no surprise to the legions of nieces and nephews he loved and brought to multiple hockey games that the Hurricanes beat the Canadiens later that evening, and no doubt Mark would see that as ''Beautiful''. The family is having a private affair, but we cordially invite the community to paint the town Hurricane Red on December 28th at Mark's biodiesel plant on the edge of town. Mark hated flowers, and the family would appreciate those so inclined to donate in his name to Girls Rock North Carolina, a foundation whose goal is to empower young women through music (www.girlsrocknc.org) and the Abundance Foundation, which is focused on local food, renewable energy, and community (theabundancefoundation. org).

THE HANUKKAH MICE By Steven Kroll. Illustrated by Michelle Shapiro. Marshall Cavendish. $14.99. (Ages 4 to 8) On the first night of Hanukkah, a mouse family ventures from its mouse hole and up the basement stairs to watch the candles being lighted and Rachel opening her first gift, ''an exquisitely carved dollhouse with a porch and white trim.'' The next nights bring new gifts to delight the mice -- miniature chairs, a sofa, and a dining table and dishes that appear on the table bearing real, tiny latkes and applesauce. Rachel, it seems, has caught on, and so in the end the mouse family enjoys its own holiday feast.

O'SHEA--William Joseph, of Greenwich, Connecticut, passed away on December 18th at the age of 75 at Greenwich Hospital. Born in New York City on August 30, 1933, William attended the Loyola School, The College of the Holy Cross (AB 1954), and Fordham University (LL.B. 1957). William was admitted to the New York Bar in 1958 and the Connecticut Bar in 1979. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Charlotte Donovan O'Shea and their children Charlotte (Peter) Glovin, William (Kiku) O'Shea, Daniel (Kelly) O'Shea, Stephen (Jennifer) O'Shea and Emily (Peter) O'SheaCreeden, his grandson William and granddaughters Eliza, Abaigeal, Anna, Kendall, Emma, Molly, Courtney, Katie, Chloe and Lily, and his sisters Mimi Grady and Edwina Reid. A partner in the New York Law firm Burns, Kennedy, Schilling & O'Shea and predecessor law firms, William represented such clients as Catholic Relief Services, The Reformed Church of America, the St. Francis de Sales School for the Deaf (whom he has represented since 1965), The Sisters of Mercy, the Sisters of St. Francis, the Franciscan Missionaries of Mary and Cable and Wireless Ltd. He was a beloved and devoted husband, father and grandfather, who most loved gathering his brood for family reunions in Lake Placid, NY. William was a lifetime member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick and a fervent New York Giants Fan. William will be missed by all who knew him. Calling hours will be from 3 to 5 and 6 to 8pm Monday December 22nd at Leo Gallagher & Son, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT. A funeral service will be held at St. Michaels Catholic Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT. at 11am on Tuesday December 23rd. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the St. Joseph School for The Deaf, 1809 Clarkson Road, Chesterfield, MO 63017.

PROOF In the old days, drunkenness was as much part of New York City society as evening clothes. This is the city where Zelda Fitzgerald jumped wildly in the fountain in front of the Plaza, the city of ''Breakfast at Tiffany's,'' written by another fabulous alcoholic, Truman Capote. It's the city of late nights with sloshed celebrities at the Stork Club. It's the city that gave its name to Manhattans and Bronx Cocktails, the city of John O'Hara and Frank O'Hara, of drunken brilliance and brilliant drunks. I don't drink. I know the savage, destructive power of alcoholism. It's a soul stealer. Yet, there's a mischievous part of me that misses all that extreme behavior, all those nasty but somehow amusing surprises, all that glamor even when so much of it ended in pain, institutions and early death. For us sober people there is a kind of drunkenfreude to watching others embarrass themselves, mangle their words and do things they will regret in the morning -- if they even remember them in the morning.

Will diners pay as much as $15 for a burger, fries and a shake? Bobby Flay, the celebrity chef, is betting that they will, if you give them something superior to the standard fast food fare. Mr. Flay's newest enterprise, Bobby's Burger Palace, is an attempt to mix quality food with convenience. After opening his first burger restaurant in July on Long Island, Mr. Flay has brought his new venture to New Jersey, opening the second Bobby's Burger Palace on the periphery of the Monmouth Mall this month. Open for lunch, dinner and late-night snacks, the restaurant features 10 burgers, none of them run of the mill.

THE NEWS Officials at the Interior Department frequently interfered with scientific work in order to give endangered species as little protection as possible, according to a report by the department's inspector general. BEHIND THE NEWS In examining 20 policy decisions about endangered species, the report cited serious flaws in the way the department reached 15 of them, and suggested that the new administration reconsider them. Most involved Julie A. McDonald, who was a senior official in the department until May 2007. Her ''zeal to advance her agenda'' did ''considerable harm'' both to the species and the department's integrity, morale and reputation, the report concluded.

AT SNOQUALMIE FALLS, NEAR FALL CITY, WASH., JUNE 28, 2008: Hugo Sanchez, 24, an aerospace engineer from Los Angeles, with his girlfriend, Cynthia Hernandez, 25. ''I went up to the Seattle area for business and someone recommended the Snoqualmie waterfall for a day trip. My girlfriend was able to fly up, so we decided to take a day trip there. We didn't know what to expect, and once we got there we saw this amazing waterfall, and we found out you could hike all the way down to it. It was different from what I'm accustomed to seeing in Southern California. We don't have much rainfall -- we don't have waterfalls or any big rivers or anything like that. We got as close as we could, we were just standing there, admiring the scenery, and just talking. It was good to have her there.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

BAKER--Leon C.,Attorney, Philanthropist. Leon C. Baker, 84, of Boca Raton died after a short illness on November 28, 2008. Lee Baker was born in Brooklyn, NY of immigrant parents. He attended Townsend Harris High School. He briefly attended Brooklyn College, but left to enlist in the Marine Corps after Pearl Harbor. He quickly rose to the rank of 1st Lieutenant and served in the Pacific Theater. After the war, he was stationed in Hawaii. While there, he risked court marshal by insisting to his commanding general that African-American marines not be excluded from educational courses Lee was in charge of organizing. After World War II, Lee attended Harvard Law School. Although he had to work full time to support himself, he was named an editor of the Harvard Law Review and graduated second in his class. While at Harvard, he met Gloria Clyman, who became his wife of 60 years. After graduating from Harvard, Lee joined the law firm of Thayer and Gilbert. While there, he assisted clients who were resisting Sen. Joseph McCarthy. At the age of 29 he was named the general counsel of Helene Curtis Industries, the cosmetics company, in Chicago. He remained there until 1962, when he became the general counsel and executive vice president of Revlon. Subsequently, he went into private practice as counsel to the New York City law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. While there, he specialized in the field of mergers and acquisitions. He was also involved in numerous business and real estate ventures. Lee and Gloria moved to Florida in 1984. In 1993, at the age of 70, Lee took the Florida Bar so that he could do pro bono legal work for people who could not afford a lawyer. He and Gloria also became very active in numerous charities, including Jewish Federation, Hadassah, Boca Raton Community Hospital and the Boca Raton Museum of Art. On a personal level, Lee delivered food to the needy for Jewish Family services. Lee was an ardent supporter of the State of Israel. He and Gloria were early supporters of Operation Moses, which brought Ethiopian Jews to Israel. They also provided funds to bring refugee Jews from the Soviet Union and Argentina to Israel. In addition, they established a tennis complex at Qiryat Shmona in Israel as well as contributing ambulances to the American Red Magen David. They also helped establish the Israel National Blood Center. Lee was an avid supporter of his alma mater, Harvard Law School, where he established scholarships for needy students. A student dormitory, Baker House, was named for him. Lee Baker will be best remembered as a man who unselfishly helped others when he saw people in need. Most often, he did this anonymously. His family will remember that his great passions were his loved ones, lifelong learning, and the law. He is survived by his wife Gloria, his children Robert, James, and Carol, 14 grandchildren, and his brother Edwin H. Baker. In lieu of flowers or food, the family requests that donations be made to Jewish Federation of South Palm Beach County, 9901 Donna Klein Boulevard, Boca Raton, FL 33428.

The annual Santacon came to town Dec. 13. Started in 1994 in San Francisco, the celebration has spread to 72 cities in a dozen countries. This year's New York spoof included about 5,000 Santas, a few carrying wish lists from the big financial firms. The event's organizers describe it as ''nonlogical''; it is attended for absolutely no reason by anyone who wants to wear a Santa suit. The convention started at 10 a.m. in the bars on West 33rd Street and moved on to the main post office, below. The Santas then roamed the city, stopping at bars along the way and often pouring into the subway.

ERHART--William Kent. May 4, 1929-December 15, 2008. William Kent Erhart, 79, died December 15, 2008 in Naples, Florida. He is survived by his wife Julieta; daughters Susan, Katherine, Maria, Linnea and Kristina, and son Erik; brothers Charles Erhart, Charles Chapin, Peter Chapin, and Shepard Erhart, and sister Joanna Tyson; grandchildren Susannah, Kent, Kelsey, Matthew, Kyle, Per Erik and Zara; many nieces and nephews. Born in New York City, Bill attended Groton School and Yale University. He lived and traveled many places, but his life's work and passion was music. Throughout his life he sang, conducted, produced and taught music in many forms, with special love for classical and Gilbert and Sullivan light opera. In addition to music, his true loves were his wife Julieta, good food and wine, travel, animals, the beach, the Boston Red Sox and his family. IT'S been a wild month for Think Global, the Norwegian electric carmaker. Early this month, the company announced upbeat plans to increase production of its tiny plastic-bodied City from 2,500 to 10,000 cars annually by the end of 2009 and expand throughout Europe and into the United States. The car had already gone on sale in Scandinavia. But last week Richard Canny, Think's chief executive, announced that Think desperately needed $14.5 million to $29 million in loan guarantees from the Norwegian government to continue financing its short-term operations. Mr. Canny said that without government money Think would halt production, with the hope of restarting it early next year. He also said up to 70 percent of Think employees would be laid off.

The Man Booker Prize said that the financial services company that sponsors the annual literary award would continue to subsidize it, despite the fact that the company has about $360 million in funds linked to Bernard L. Madoff, Bloomberg News reported. The Booker Prize, the prestigious British literary award, has been sponsored since 2002 by the Man Group, a publicly traded investment group and hedge fund, which increased the cash award accompanying the prize from about $31,000 to about $73,000. The group said it had $360 million invested in two funds linked to Mr. Madoff, the former Wall Street executive accused of defrauding clients of more than $50 billion. But Jane Acton, a spokeswoman for the Man Booker Prize, told Bloomberg, “There’s absolutely no reason to suggest that there would be any difference to the sponsorship deal we have at the moment.”

If you’re planning to visit Washington for the presidential inauguration on Jan. 20, better get to the Corcoran Gallery of Art while you can. The museum has announced that it will be closed from Jan. 26 through March 13 to restore the roof of its beaux arts building, according to an announcement on the Corcoran’s Web site, corcoran.org. The roof, completed in 1897, is around 48,000 square feet and 85 percent glass; it has not undergone a major repair since the early 1980s, and suffers from leaks in wet weather. “We fixed the places we know,” Christopher M. Leahy, the Corcoran’s chief financial officer told The Washington Post. “In the rain last week, we didn’t have leaks in the places we knew, but we did have new leaks.” The museum is expected to reopen in time for a March 14 exhibition on Maya Lin.

A tongue-in-cheek comment by a Broadway advertising executive that seemed to come at the expense of Cleveland is now paying dividends for theatergoers from there. In a report in The Times last week, Nancy Coyne, chairwoman of the theater advertising agency Serino Coyne, said that the decline in Broadway musicals would lead in the spring to an increase in straight plays, adding: “I think New Yorkers will come out for them once the tourists go away. We’re horrible snobs. We hate tourists from Cleveland.” Though the remark elicited the anger of some Clevelanders, it has also earned them free theater tickets: the musical “Chicago” will give one free ticket to any Cleveland resident (with government-issued photo ID) who comes to a Monday, Tuesday or Thursday evening performance in January. The Plain Dealer reported that Ms. Coyne would appear on Cleveland radio stations in January and February to give away tickets to other Broadway shows.

Like Quiet Riot once warned you: Bang your head, metal health will drive you mad. Now a medical study conducted by an Australian scientist suggests that the heavy-metal practice of headbanging to fast music can cause head and neck injuries, The Guardian reported. In a study published in The British Medical Journal, Andrew McIntosh, an associate professor at the University of New South Wales’s School of Risk and Safety Sciences, writes that flailing along to a headbanging song (with an average tempo of 146 beats per minute) can cause “mild head injury when the range of motion is greater than 75 degrees”; at faster tempos the risks can range from headaches to strokes. The study concludes that listeners can reduce the risk of injury by wearing protective gear, headbanging to every other beat or “replacing heavy metal with adult oriented rock.”

DiCapo Opera Theater said it had been hit by a small storm of cancellations for its Puccini 150th anniversary gala concert, a fundraiser, scheduled for Monday night. On its Web site, of the five singers singled out as taking part only one, Fabio Armiliato, was expected to appear, said the company’s general director, Michael Capasso. According to Mr. Capasso, Mr. Armiliato’s wife, Daniela Dessi, who was to perform, suffered injuries to her face in a car accident; another singer, Francisco Casanava, had to travel to the Dominican Republic, to visit his gravely ill mother; another, Francesca Patanè, lost financing from the Italian foundation that was to sponsor her trip; and the company could not agree on repertory with Aprile Millo. Mr. Capasso said that all the singers were to appear for no fee and that high-level replacements had been found. Renata Scotto will still be the host, he said.

A 3,300-year-old Egyptian sculpture has been returned to Egyptian officials at a ceremony in London 18 years after the work was stolen by a convicted smuggler, the British law firm Mishcon de Reya announced. The Head of Amenhotep III, a sculpture that dates to the 14th century BC, was smuggled out of Egypt in 1990 by Jonathan Tokeley-Parry, a restorer of antiques who covered the head in liquid plastic to disguise it as a souvenir. In 1997 Mr. Tokeley-Parry was convicted of trading in stolen antiquities and jailed for three years. The head was recovered in 1999 by the art and antiques division of London’s Metropolitan Police, but its rightful ownership took several years to determine. The head was returned Friday at a ceremony attended by the Egyptian ambassador to Britain and a representative of Egypt’s antiquities council.

The world tour of the Chanel Pavilion, a mobile art exhibition sponsored by the luxury designer, has been canceled as Chanel reassesses its business strategies in the troubled economic climate, Agence France-Presse reported. The pavilion, created by the Iraqi-born British architect Zaha Hadid to display artworks inspired by Chanel’s 2.55 handbag, finished its visit to Central Park in November and was scheduled for stops in London and Moscow next year. Made of 700 pieces, the pavilion weighed 180 tons and had to be shipped in more than 50 containers; for its New York run, Chanel paid a $400,000 rental fee to the city, and made a gift of an undisclosed amount to the Central Park Conservancy. A Chanel spokeswoman told Agence France-Presse: “In the current context we have to arbitrate. We prefer to refocus on our strategic investments in terms of development.”

Alcohol is often called a "social lubricant," which I always took to mean that it was friendlier than other lubricants -- like that party-pooper, motor oil. But "social lubricant" apparently refers to the fact that alcohol eases conversation by removing your fear of saying something idiotic, or, if you have no such fear, by dulling the fight-or-flight reflex of acquaintances who otherwise would be nimble enough not to get stuck talking with you.

A number of conservative economists have been arguing against a stimulus plan centered on government spending. Fair enough. But one argument I keep reading bugs me: it's the claim that spending-based stimulus is bad because economic theory tells us that a marginal dollar of private spending is better than a marginal dollar of government spending.
So Rush Limbaugh, Bill O'Reilly, and Karl Rove all claim that the financial crisis was a liberal conspiracy, generated either by evil mastermind Chuck Schumer or by wily journalists.

Updated, 3:42 p.m. | A judge in Brooklyn declared a mistrial on Monday in the case of Lee Woods, who was accused of murdering Police Officer Russel Timoshenko during a traffic stop in Brooklyn last year. The mistrial means that the fate of Mr. Woods, 30, will not be decided until next year, and it is another setback for prosecutors in the case. Last week, one of Mr. Woods's co-defendants was convicted of the officer's murder, but another co-defendant was acquitted.

It is hard to pinpoint the worst part about the Jets' 13-3 loss to the lowly Seahawks on Sunday: the pickle it made out of their playoff situation, the fact that the Patriots could leapfrog them for a playoff berth, or the fact that their former quarterback, Chad Pennington, could squash their hopes. There are some images that simply need no elaboration. This is one of them. It's a prayer session in a government building in Belgrade in May 1999, taken after the Yugoslav government graciously agreed to release three American soldiers it had taken hostage.

Whatever else it's remembered for in the publishing industry, 2008 may be remembered as the year that e-books finally caught on. Kindles are a regular sight on my train these days, and seem poised to become as ubiquitous as iPods: due to unexpected demand (or shrewd marketing?) Amazon sold out well before the holidays and established a Kindle waiting list, elevating the device to the vaunted commercial realm of Birkin bags and Tickle-Me-Elmos. Meanwhile, executives at one publishing house recently told me they now read all of their manuscript submissions on Sony Readers, not paper, and they may eliminate bound galleys in favor of electronic review copies.

Philip K. Dick wondered whether androids dream of electric sheep. We don't know the answer to that one, but we do know what Android developers dream of: XML and New York Times movie reviews. Or at least one particular developer does. Jacek Ambroziak, an XML expert and avid reader of The Times, has created an Android app that uses the Times Movie Reviews API.

He can go from making the chic, retro-rich Baghari for the contemporary incarnation of Robert Piguet to the delicate translucent-flower-in-a-white-space-station cult favorite Chinatown for Bond No. 9 to the brutalist 21st-century chypre (take out the labdanum, put in asphalt and the scorched scent of steel under a welder's arc) of Sean John's Unforgivable.

Hedge funds have suffered a shakeout in 2008. The average hedge fund fell almost 20 percent, according to Hedge Fund Research. No fund has yet required a bailout. But many won't be around in the new year, and those that have survived are battered and bruised.

Despite the turmoil in the markets and the economy, venture capitalists invested more than $7 billion in seed and early-stage companies in more than 1,400 deals in the past four quarters, according to the MoneyTree Report from the National Venture Capital Association. BusinessWeek reported that the figure represents more money raised by young companies than in any calendar year since the dot-com bubble burst in 2001.

More than 40 partners of Thacher Proffitt & Wood, a Wall Street law firm that has struggled to survive the financial crisis, are leaving to join a bigger firm, Sonnenschein, Nath & Rosenthal, lawyers involved in the transaction said Sunday. The move could lead to the end of Thacher, a firm that traces its history back 160 years, The New York Times's Patrick McGeehan writes.

Connecticut's touted solar rebate program, which experts have pointed to as exemplary, may not be so perfect after all. Munich Re has agreed to buy American International Group's Hartford Steam Boiler unit for $742 million. The sale price is about a third less than the U.S. insurer paid for it eight years ago, Bloomberg noted.

Administrators for Lehman Brothers in the United Kingdom are close to selling a 900-million pound-portfolio of subprime mortgages, The Telegraph reported. Kevin O'Leary, the Canadian entrepreneur, is about to enter the "Shark Tank." A friend asked my advice the other day about which medical alert pendant would be the best for her aunt, a plucky woman in her 80s who lives alone, tends ably to most of her own needs, takes daily walks, still enjoys the cultural riches of New York City and travels solo to visit relatives clear across the country. But lately she is less steady on her feet, at risk for falls and needs the security of being able to summon help even if she can't get to the telephone.

Wednesday, 6 a.m. Surveillance is to this century what theology was to the last: a branch of study given to the notion that inscrutable powers are forever looking down on us from the silence of the sky. It stands to reason, then, that the watchdogs at Norad, the North American Aerospace Defense Command, begin tracking Santa Claus today on his annual sleigh journey from the North Pole. Tune in to a live video feed on the high-speed digital "Santa Cam" as the old man banks above Manhattan. And you thought the military spied only on us. Details.

D-Wave Systems, a Canadian start-up, claims to have concocted a way of proving that its quantum computer is actually a quantum computer. But to pull off the proof, it needs thousands of people to volunteer spare time on their personal computers.

Economy | Property bubbles aren't all bad, an article says. Three cases in point are Florida's land boom and bust of the 1920s, which cemented the state's reputation as a glamorous destination; Britain's railway mania of the mid-19th century, which spurred development that may have immunized it from Europe's civil unrest; and the 1990s tech bubble, which expanded fiber-optic capacity. "You can start with misallocation of capital and stupidity and still end up with something useful." [Economist]
Headlines from the world of property:

World | "Pay close attention to Greece," writes Robert D. Kaplan. "At a time of worldwide economic upheaval, it might eerily presage disturbances elsewhere in 2009." Such unrest looks like what intelligence officials have been worried about for some time now -- that the meltdown could weaken fragile governments and threaten global security. Concern No. 1, of course, is Pakistan. Yemen is another worry. [Atlantic, Washington Post]

Internet | It's called a milestone linking Wikipedia with the academic peer-review process: The journal RNA Biology plans to require article writers to also submit a Wikipedia page that summarizes the work. The journal will then peer review the page before publishing it in Wikipedia. [Read, Write, Web; Nature.com]

Asia | Walking away from North Korean nuclear talks is a "realistic option," an ex-Times military writer says. Obama has enough on his plate. "He could tell the North Koreans quietly that they appear not to be interested in negotiating in good faith. If they change their minds, let him know. Meantime, a threat to U.S. forces, allies, and friends would be met with a forceful response in time, place, and method of American choosing." [Real Clear World]

SNYDER--Harold, 86, of New York City. Generic drug pioneer Harold Snyder died December 18 after a brief illness. Mr. Snyder promoted the widespread use of generic drugs which have improved the lives of millions of people throughout the world. At his death, Mr. Snyder served as a director of Teva Pharmaceuticals Ltd., the world's largest generic pharmaceutical company, and as a principal of HBJ Investments. His philanthropy was wide ranging; whether through The Beatrice Snyder Foundation, his many direct gifts, or his participation in organizations large and small. Born on April 25, 1922, Mr. Snyder grew up in NYC, the son of immigrant parents. Despite his enormous success later in life, he never forgot the poverty of his childhood. His caring and generosity touched countless lives around the world; from local charities to medical research, from ecology to music. He was also a passionate promoter of progressive causes. He never regarded any issue as too insignificant to prevent his tireless involvement. Mr. Snyder served in the Army Air Corps on a B-17 bomber during World War II. He graduated from New York University in 1948 and received an M.S. from Columbia University in natural science in 1950. Mr. Snyder was one of the founders of the generic drug industry. In 1964 he formed Biocraft Laboratories in Elmwood Park, NJ with his wife of 49 years, Beatrice. He served Biocraft as President, CEO and Chairman for the next three decades where he worked closely with his entire family. Under his stewardship, Biocraft became one of the largest generic drug manufacturers in the U.S. In 1985, it was the first generic drug manufacturer to be listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Snyder is survived by his wife, Tamar Hirschl Snyder, an Israeli artist, whom he married in NYC, his daughter, Beryl, and his sons, Brian and Jay, all of NYC, and by six grandchildren, Quentin, Jackson, Maxwell, Ophelia, Brette and Evan. The service will be on Monday, December 22, at 11:45am at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th at Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to The Harold Snyder Charitable Fund, 592 Fifth Avenue, 6th Floor, New York, NY 10036.

EPSTEIN--Seymour. Former President and CEO of Shelburne Shirt Company died De cember 19, 2008 at 89. Born in Brooklyn, NY and attended Boys High, he graduated from Columbia College and Columbia Law school in 1942. he was honored to accept membership to Columbia Law Review. He passed the bar before attening Columbia Midshipman's School. During World War II Mr. Epstein served as a naval commander in both the Atlantic and Pacific theaters. Although he loved the law, after the war he accepted the responsibility of a leadership role in the family business at the request of his father. He took a small family run shirt company and expanded it into an international manufacturing business. He served on the board of the National Manufacturers Association and was proud that he could offer business opportunities to his family and extended family members. He was respected for his honesty and integrity not only in business, but in his personal life as well. His caring and generosity touched all who knew him. He was honored and proud to be in a position to donate to many charitable organizations such as the UJA and NYU Langone Medical Center. His philanthropy was wide ranging and he encouraged and inspired his children and grandchildr en to recognize the importance of charity. He created a charitable foundation in his parents name to enable all in his family to participate in experiencing the joy of giving even at a very young age. His generosity knew no bounds. His devotion to and love of his family was the driving force of his life. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife of 61 years, Muriel nee Joseph, his children, Randy Austin and her husband Bruce Firger, Bob Epstein and his partner Jacqueline Buckner, Jane Epstein and her husband Edgar Roeper, and Susan Gross and her husband Jeffrey Gross; his seven adored grandchildren David Austin and his wife Tammy Yuen, Lauren Austin, Cass, Josh and Alex Epstein, Sam and Jamie Gross and his great granddaughter Amelia Rose Austin who gave him such great joy in the last two years. He is also survived by his brother Selwyn Epstein, his beloved sister and brother-in-law Blossom and Irwin Greystone, and his many nieces, nephews and friends. In addition to his devotion to his immediate family he was a role model and trusted advisor to his large extended family all of whom knew they could look to him for his wise advise, counsel and love. He will be in our hearts forever. Services will be held at Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave, NYC on December 23rd at 11am. Donations in Seymour's name may be made to NYU Langone Medical Center Stem cell research.

Wednesday, 6 a.m. Surveillance is to this century what theology was to the last: a branch of study given to the notion that inscrutable powers are forever looking down on us from the silence of the sky. It stands to reason, then, that the watchdogs at Norad, the North American Aerospace Defense Command, are tracking Santa Claus on his annual sleigh journey from the North Pole. Tune in to a live video feed on the high-speed digital ''Santa Cam'' as the old man banks above Manhattan. And you thought the military spied only on us. Details: noradsanta.org.

When ratings are calculated to include viewers who watched recorded programs within seven days of the original air date, several shows on smaller cable networks like the SciFi Channel showed major ratings gains over the initial broadcasts. ''The Fringe,'' above, with Anna Torv, along with ''America's Top Model'' (CW), ''The Starter Wife'' (USA) and ''The Office'' (NBC), each had ratings increases of 27 percent. The advertising trade group that proposed that people with cancer deserve more privacy protections than those with heart disease has adopted a new version of its guidelines for how ad networks use data about Internet users. It is no longer trying to distinguish among different diseases. But it is drawing another line that may appear equally arbitrary: Whether people's Internet browsing indicate they actually have a disease, rather than are doing research about a medical topic.

A.F.C. A year ago, H. Wayne Huizenga, the MIAMI DOLPHINS owner, wept that his team had won only one game. He's going to be a blubbering mess if the Dolphins, who beat the Chiefs on Sunday, beat the Jets next week because that will make them A.F.C. East champions. It could be revenge for Chad Pennington, dealt from the Jets to make room for Brett Favre. Next up: Jets. The JETS have done everything possible to miss the playoffs. Their loss Sunday means they have to beat Miami and hope that New England loses to Buffalo so they can win the division. If New England wins, the Jets would make it as the wild card if they beat the Dolphins and the Ravens lose. Next up: Miami. Something simple: the BALTIMORE RAVENS, who beat the Cowboys on Saturday night, would clinch the A.F.C.'s final wild-card spot with a victory at home. Next up: Jacksonville. If this were the Bowl Championship Series, the NEW ENGLAND PATRIOTS would earn style points for how they mauled the Arizona Cardinals, then got a huge boost from their nemesis, the Jets. If the Jets beat the Dolphins, and the Patriots win, the Patriots would win the division. If the Ravens lose, and the Dolphins win, the Patriots are in as a wild card with a victory. But if the Dolphins win and the Ravens win, the Patriots would be shut out, no matter what they do. Next up: Buffalo. You better believe the official Ed Hochuli will not be on the field when the DENVER BRONCOS and the SAN DIEGO CHARGERS meet in a winner-take-all game for the A.F.C. West championship. Denver won the first meeting in Week 2 on the famously botched fumble/incompletion call by Hochuli. Denver has squandered a three-game lead with three to play. Next up: Chargers. The TENNESSEE TITANS clinched home-field advantage throughout the A.F.C. playoffs by beating the Steelers, 31-14. The PITTSBURGH STEELERS are the No. 2 seed. The INDIANAPOLIS COLTS clinched a wild-card spot with their victory over Jacksonville on Thursday. N.F.C. The MINNESOTA VIKINGS wasted an opportunity to clinch the N.F.C. North with a loss to the Falcons, but that at least gives meaning to Monday night's game between the Packers and the Bears. Minnesota would win the division with a victory next week or a Chicago loss Monday night. Next up: Giants. Despite a loss to the Ravens on Saturday, the DALLAS COWBOYS are in as a wild card with a victory next week at Philadelphia. It is the first time Norv Turner has helped the Cowboys since he was coaching Troy Aikman -- the Chargers' victory over the Buccaneers on Sunday gave the Cowboys a huge break. Next up: Philadelphia. The TAMPA BAY BUCCANEERS lost their third straight and now not only need to win next week, but also need Philadelphia to beat Dallas. Next up: Oakland. Despite their loss to the Redskins, the PHILADELPHIA EAGLES are not quite out yet. They have to win, and Tampa Bay and Chicago have to lose. Next up: Dallas. The CHICAGO BEARS are also still barely alive, but need a ton of help. First, they must win Monday. Next up: Green Bay. Wonder if Michael Vick was watching when the ATLANTA FALCONS clinched at least a wild-card spot with their victory over Minnesota and Tampa Bay's loss to San Diego. Next up: St. Louis. The GIANTS secured home-field advantage throughout the N.F.C. playoffs with their victory over the CAROLINA PANTHERS, who have clinched a playoff berth but still need a victory or an Atlanta loss to win the N.F.C. South.

Sports meets survival in the Iditarod Trail Invitational. It’s not the famous annual dog-sled mush, it is a 1,100-mile race over frozen Alaska terrain without the aid of dogs or motors. “Some ski, some bicycle and others run,” writes Michael Brick for The New York Times, who joined up with Bill Merchant, the race’s founder and entrance judge, and his wife, Kathi Hirzinger-Merchant, who helps run Alaska Ultra Sport and administer the race.

Jürgen Flimm, the German theater and opera director, has been named the artistic director of Deutsche Staatsoper Unter den Linden in Berlin, and will take over the position on Sept. 1, 2010, Agence-France Presse reported. Mr. Flimm’s appointment comes at the end of a round of musical chairs: he announced earlier this year that he would not continue in his role as artistic director of the Salzburg Festival in Austria, a position he has held since 2006, when his contract expires in 2011, having clashed with Thomas Oberender, the festival’s drama director. And at Staatsoper, he will be replacing Peter Mussbach, who has frequently feuded with its musical director, Daniel Barenboim. In April, Mr. Mussbach denounced Mr. Barenboim and Klaus Wowereit, the mayor of Berlin, for using “mafia” tactics against him after the mayor said he would not renew Mr. Mussbach’s contract with the state-run opera company.

As Christmas approaches, concertgoers who bought tickets for the now-bankrupt Baltimore Opera Company won’t be left out in the cold. A group of area arts organizations have announced they will honor any nonrefundable tickets for productions of “Porgy and Bess” and “The Barber of Seville” planned by the opera company, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection earlier this month. Washington National Opera said in a statement that it was offering vouchers for its spring production of “Peter Grimes,” and Centerstage said in a statement that it would provide tickets to its productions of “Fabulation,” “‘Tis Pity She’s a Whore” and “Souvenir.” The Baltimore Sun reported that Baltimore Symphony Orchestra would make available tickets to four of its concerts, including three conducted by Marin Alsop, and that the Hippodrome theater would offer tickets to its productions of “Cats,” “Movin’ Out” and “Annie.”

A court officer has deemed that Britney Spears’s father is worth even more to his daughter’s resurgent pop-music fortunes than previously estimated — to the tune of more than $50,000. On Monday, a Los Angeles County Superior Court commissioner awarded Ms. Spears’s father, Jamie, an additional $51,000 in back pay and a raise of $1,200 a month, on top of the $10,000-a-month salary he receives as conservator of his daughter’s career, the Associated Press reported. In February, Mr. Spears was granted temporary control of his daughter after Ms. Spears, 27, was placed under psychiatric evaluation. That conservatorship was made permanent in October, though Ms. Spears can petition to have it removed. Earlier this month, Ms. Spears’s album “Circus” debuted at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart.

You better watch out, you better not cry, you better not gag at the misshapen sight of a scientist who’s been tossed into a tank of radioactive goo, I’m telling you why: the “Toxic Avenger” musical is coming to town. The musical, adapted from Lloyd Kaufman‘s long-running film series of low-budget horror–comedies, will get an Off-Broadway run at New World Stages, its producers announced. The musical, written by Joe DiPietro (“I Love You, You’re Perfect, Now Change”) and David Bryan (the keyboardist of the band Bon Jovi), and directed by John Rando (the director of “Urinetown” and Broadway’s “The Wedding Singer”) had its debut in the fall at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, N.J. Its Off Broadway run is scheduled to begin performances on March 18 and open on April 6.

Bruce Springsteen completists may need to make a trip to Wal-Mart when his new album, “Working on a Dream,” is released Jan. 13 Jan. 27: Billboard reported that on that date two weeks earlier, on Jan. 13, the retailer will offer a greatest-hits album exclusive to Wal-Mart. It will consist of songs recorded by Mr. Springsteen and the E Street Band (including “Born to Run” and “Darkness on the Edge of Town”) but omit hits from the Boss’s solo career.

Some years ago, the evolutionist and atheist Richard Dawkins pointed out to me that Sir Isaac Newton, the founder of modern physics and mathematics, and arguably the greatest scientist of all time, was born on Christmas Day, and that therefore Newton's Birthday could be an alternative, if somewhat nerdy, excuse for a winter holiday.

My inaugural season as a baseball beat writer was in 2005, when I covered the Texas Rangers for The Dallas Morning News, and I remember one thing from the first full day at spring training: standing in foul territory near the first-base dugout, I watched Mark Teixeira field ground balls. He was 24 then, a few months older than I was. Once I got over that jolt, I started paying attention to how smoothly and effortlessly he made it look -- sort of like one of his boyhood idols, Cal Ripken Jr. His footwork was textbook, and so was his glovework. No matter how hard the ball was hit, it always found its way into Tex's glove.

My grandmother, and then my mother, made latkes (potato pancakes for you non-Yiddish speakers) and, perhaps, even more interesting, potato nik. (You can see a story and even a video about the "nik" here, and you can see me cooking latkes with Mr. Lauer on Today, which I did today, here).

I see that Stephen Dubner is wondering why restaurant food is lousy in London. I actually wrote about that once; my theory, basically, was that England industrialized in an era when primitive transportation technology wasn't up to delivering fresh food to the new urban masses, and the lack of taste stuck.

My landlord was negligent about fixing the locks on the entrance doors to my building. Despite complaints from the tenants, the locks remained broken for months, enabling anybody to walk into the building. Not until after my apartment was burglarized did the landlord fix the locks. Can I recover some of my losses by making a claim with the landlord?

My disabled father is a tenant in a rent-controlled building. Recently, he had a fall and was taken to the hospital. While he was in the hospital, I had to mail in his rent check. When I called the landlord to find out the address, I was told that they would refuse any check that was not in the tenant's name. I am afraid that if this happens in the future, I will not be able to get a check from my father to the landlord. Is this policy legal?

There are no presents under the Christmas tree in the Open Door drop-in shelter in Midtown. The tree is an artificial, tinseled totem wedged between a Pepsi machine and a trash can in a large, spare room where a couple of hundred men and women sit all night in metal folding chairs trying to simultaneously sleep and keep close track of their belongings at their feet.
Al Franken reportedly now leads the Minnesota Senate race by 48 votes, according to the latest numbers from the Secretary of State's office. The counting is not over, but it's winding down.
Olympic hopeful Sara Hall offers training tips for runners.

Culture | Why computer games are a throwback to art of the past: they revive "the idea that difficulty is artistically desirable," a critic says. "It's a bit of an irony that difficulty thrives in the newest medium of all - and it's not by accident, either. One of the most common complaints regular gamers make in reviewing new offerings is that they are too easy. (It would be nice if a little bit of that leaked over into the book world.)" [London Review of Books]

Howard Wolfson, the combative spokesman for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential campaign, has decided not to go to Washington with his old boss, and instead will work closer to home on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's re-election campaign, our sibblog City Room reports. It says this is a sign of how Mr. Bloomberg is taking no chances in trying to win a third term. There had been speculation that he would join Ms. Clinton at the State Department.
Caroline Brothers of The International Herald Tribune reports on the second fire to engulf the Channel Tunnel tin the past twelve years.

Updated, 4:30 p.m., Dec. 24 | Isaac R. Toussie, a Brooklyn developer who pleaded guilty to fraudulently obtaining federally insured mortgages and to defrauding Suffolk County by selling it overpriced land,was one of 19 people granted pardons on Tuesday by President Bush. [Note: On Wednesday, President Bush reversed the pardon of Mr. Toussie, citing "information that has subsequently come to light."]

Palm trees. Sandy beaches. Warm weather. No snow. Notre Dame? What are the Irish doing playing in the low-level Hawaii Bowl? Well, N.D.'s 5-2 start disintegrated into a 6-6 finish, placing the program -- and, specifically, Coach Charlie Weis -- under heavy scrutiny heading into this game and the off-season. Can the Irish get a win in Hawaii's backyard (it's the Warriors' home stadium), snapping their nine-game bowl losing streak in the process? On the other hand, Hawaii was able to deal with the loss of June Jones, the architect of its recent success, and a 4-5 start to reach its sixth bowl game in seven years.The Hawaii Bowl: Wednesday, Dec. 24, 8 p.m.

Signaling that he will take no chances in his bid for a third term, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has hired Howard Wolfson, the pit bull-like Democratic spokesman who has been a longtime adviser to Hillary Rodham Clinton, to serve as the public face of his campaign.

Bjork -- the pixie-faced Icelandic singer famous for her eclectic music, provocative music videos and outlandish fashion sense (even if you don't know her music, you likely know her swan dress at the 2001 Oscars) -- is adding "venture capitalist" to her resume.

The results of fan balloting for the Jan. 10 K.H.L. All-Star Game are in, and the perennial Russian scoring leader Alexei Morozov of Ak Bars Kazan has come out the top vote-getter, with 44,549. That's a far cry from the hundreds of thousands of ballots logged in the N.H.L. voting (which Sidney Crosby leads with more than 1.1 million), but remember that, erm, the democratic tradition is young in Russia.

At 4:30 p.m. today, Barack Obama's transition team is to release its internal report about any contacts between Mr. Obama's staff and embattled Gov. Rod Blagojevich over an appointment to the Senate seat being vacated by Mr. Obama.

Gov. David A. Paterson and four members of Congress met with United States troops in Afghanistan on Tuesday as part of a visit that included a stay in Iraq earlier this week. In Afghanistan, Mr. Paterson and Representatives Steve Israel and Anthony D. Weiner, both New York Democrats, met with President Hamid Karzai and nearly 200 troops from New York. Governor Paterson presented Purple Hearts to several service members.

Rene-Thierry Magon de la Villehuchet, a founder of the hedge fund Access International Advisors, was found dead early on Tuesday in his office in Manhattan, the French business daily La Tribune reported on its Web site, after losing as much as $1.4 billion that had been invested with Bernard L. Madoff, the money manager accused of running a $50 billion Ponzi scheme. Mr. de la Villehuchet, 65, committed suicide, La Tribune said, citing someone close to him. He had been trying to recover the money that Access International raised in Europe and invested through Mr. Madoff's business, it reported. Paramedics responded to a call at a Manhattan address matching that of Access International, people briefed on the situation told theDealBook blog, but the victim was not yet identified.
During the Iditarod Trail Invitational, racers brave hundreds of miles of frozen Alaskan wilderness on foot, ski or bicycle.

Very belatedly, I'm catching up on a promise I made to Jeff Huggins, a frequent contributor here, by posting the prepared remarks that I planned to (but failed to) deliver when I received the first John Chancellor Award given to a science writer. The award, administered by Columbia University, honors reporters locked in on a single, important theme -- in my case climate and energy -- for a good chunk of a career. (The other winner this year was Jane Mayer of the New Yorker, for her reporting on the legal and ethical ramifications of the Bush administration's war on terror.)

After winter snowstorms sent holiday travel spinning into chaos from the Northeast to the Northwest over the weekend, those corners of the country calmed down on Tuesday. But as air travel largely returned to normal in Portland and Seattle, delays and cancellations were piling up along with fresh snow at Chicago's airports.

This is easily the most intriguing of the non-B.C.S. bowls and one of the best matchups on paper of the entire bowl season. Texas Christian has one of the best defenses in the country and anybody who watched Boise State's overtime victory over Oklahoma in the Fiesta Bowl two seasons ago knows that the Broncos have plenty of offensive tricks in their playbook. Boise State is one of only two undefeated teams in the country. The other, of course, is Utah, which got into the B.C.S. mix thanks partly to a 13-10 comeback victory against T.C.U. The Horned Frogs' other loss came at Oklahoma, a nonconference win the Sooners pointed to when making the case that they deserved the Big 12 South title over Texas. These programs have been two of the premier non-B.C.S. teams for some time and bragging rights between the Mountain West and Western Athletic conferences are at stake.

In discussing the economic stimulus plan now being formulated by President-elect Obama and his aides, Senator Joseph R. Biden was sounding a fair bit like Senator John McCain and other Republicans today, warning that such spending not turn into an earmark-laden porkfest for lawmakers.

Health | Finding cancer early can improve survival rates for patients to 90 percent. But much of the money for cancer research is focused on devising better drugs and chemotherapies that might kill cancer in late-stage patients, when the disease is strongest and the prognosis as miserable as the treatment. It's time to put the focus on early detection, an article says. [Wired]

My post on John P. Holdren's appointment as presidential science advisor prompted complaints that I was making too much of Dr. Holdren's loss of a bet to the economist Julian Simon about the price of some metals. But that bet wasn't just about metals. It was about a fundamental view of how adaptable and innovative humans are, and whether a rich modern society is "sustainable." Dr. Holdren and his collaborator, Paul Ehrlich, were the pessimists.

Lehman Brothers on Monday won bankruptcy court approval to sell its prized investment management division, including Neuberger Berman, to a group led by Neuberger's management, Reuters reported.

Call it the year of the un-deal: Reuters reports that more mergers and acquisitions were withdrawn in 2008 than ever before, depriving the bankers who toiled on these transactions of millions of dollars in fees.

Global merger volume dropped by almost a third in 2008 to $2.89 trillion, according to preliminary data from Thomson Reuters, ending five years of deal growth. It marks the lowest annual deal volume since 2005.

Circuit City Stores, the nation's second-biggest electronics retailer, received final approval Monday for $1.1 billion in debtor-in-possession financing in order to keep operating while it's in Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, The Associated Press reported.

Through more than a year of giant bailouts and bankruptcies, HSBC was one of the few big banks to emerge with its reputation largely intact, wrote Landon Thomas Jr. and Julie Werdigier of The New York Times. The global financial giant did bet on subprime mortgages - and lost. But it nonetheless managed to maintain a robust market value compared with its diminished peers, lending it an aura of unrivaled durability.

Despite a record number of merger and acquisitions deals having been canceled in 2008, many bankers believe that a combination of the need for consolidation within some industries, attractive prices of assets and folks in need of new ownership will spur a series of deals, The Financial Times reported. Still, corporate financiers are not exactly awaiting the first half of the 2009 with bated breath.

Kingate Global, one of the biggest investors in Bernard Madoff's alleged $50 billion fraud, explicitly warned its clients of the danger that the brokerage "could abscond with those assets," and yet attracted $2.75 billion, The Financial Times reported, citing documents sent to investors.

Two months before IndyMac Bancorp collapsed in July, at a cost of $8.9 billion to taxpayers, a top federal banking regulator allowed the bank to backdate a capital infusion and gloss over its deepening problems, The New York Times' Edmund L. Andrews reported, citing the Treasury Department's independent investigator.

Investigators in the Bernard Madoff scandal have begun questioning a top executive at the investment firm and have subpoenaed its accountant as well, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

Lawyers are advising private equity and hedge funds to do a bit of restructuring before year's end, in an effort to prepare themselves for the possibility that taxes on "carried interest" may more than double under the new presidential administration, Bloomberg News reports.

Assicurazioni Generali and Manulife Financial are said to be among bidders for American International Group's Philippine American Life and General Insurance, Bloomberg reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

A friend and I are planning a trip to Montreal from Dec. 30 to Jan. 4. Is there anything special to do for New Years Eve? We're in our mid-20s and would love a good night out, but I'd rather not spend a lot of money on an all-you-can-drink club. Any ideas?

Although Nortel Networks has received offers worth close to $1 billion for its Metro Ethernet unit, it continues to weigh alternatives before making a deal. The Globe and Mail reported that the company is trying to determine whether additional units should be put up for sale, such as its carrier networks division.

Barclays, the first British bank to access the European Investment Bank fund, has expressed concern that a 14 billion pound ($20.7 billion) European fund for smaller business loans may mistakenly be seen as a lifeline for firms with cash flow problems, The Telegraph reported.

An investor who lost nearly $2 million investing with Bernard Madoff has filed a claim against the Securities and Exchange Commission alleging the agency was negligent in failing to detect an alleged decades-long fraud, The Wall Street Journal reported.

HFA Holdings, the Australian hedge-fund manager, saw its shares more than halved in value Tuesday after it said it had suspended redemptions in three funds with immediate effect. MarketWatch reported that the fund cited "deteriorating liquidity in underlying investments" for the suspension.
Funny or Die, a comedic video Web site co-founded by Will Ferrell and backed by Sequoia Capital has raised $3 million from a single unnamed investor, Reuters reported.

Mecachrome International, a maker of engine parts that sought protection from creditors earlier this month, has secured a 30 million euro ($24.6 million) financing that will allow it to meet current operating needs during restructuring.
Shaw Brothers's founder, Sir Run Run Shaw, has offered to take the entertainment conglomerate private for 1.33 billion Hong Kong dollars ($172 million), Variety reported.
The CIT Group, a commercial lender, won federal approval to convert to a bank holding company, a step toward getting an investment of as much as $2.5 billion from the federal government.

Britain's Whittard of Chelsea, a tea and coffee retailer, verged on filing for administration on Monday, The Telegraph reported without naming sources, becoming the latest retailer in that country to suffer.
Bendigo & Adelaide Bank has sold 175 million Australian dollars ($120 million) in shares to boost capital.

Internet | Think digital democracy holds great promise? Guess again, says a new study. Exclusion on the Internet "is structural, woven into the hyperlinks that make up the Web ... and it is social, in the small group of white, highly educated, male professionals who are vastly overrepresented in online opinion." Given the glut of choices on the Web, "trickle-up theories" of online discourse don't pan out; rather, "winner-take-all" patterns prevail. ["The Myth of Digital Democracy," first chapter]
Online entertainment community Chakpak has attracted additional investment from venture capital companies Accel Partners and Canaan Partners, The Economic Times reported.

VantagePoint Venture Partners has landed $435 million for its second fund, VentureWire reported, giving further credence to the idea that the cleantech industry may be spared from the economic crisis.
Bridgepoint Education filed with U.S. regulators on Monday to raise up to $230 million in an initial public offering.

VILSECK, GERMANY -- Christmas echoes the line of Charles Dickens in that "it is the best of times and the worst of times." And like no other season, it allows us like Charles Dickens memorable character Ebenezer Scrooge to step out of our shoes for awhile and empathize a bit more with our fellow man.

When Tennessee's Keith Bulluck and LenDale White stomped on and wiped the ground with a Terrible Towel in the closing seconds of the Titans' victory over Pittsburgh on Sunday, they seemed to be disrespectful and classless at best. For Pittsburgh fans, the Terrible Towel is a time-honored symbol of the Steelers' five Super Bowl championships. But after a closer look, I think it is legitimate to ask the following question: Were the players really as out of line as so many outraged Steelers fans and pundits would have you believe?

Film | A new biography of Charlie Chaplin "convincingly argues" that his being sent to a Dickensian orphanage as a boy inspired a recurrent theme of his films: the "passionately heartbreaking scenes of beautiful young mothers torn away from their terrified, weeping children." Also, his classic drunk slapstick routines were "inspired directly" by his poor, inebriated father. [Washington Times]

Literature | Why are the British embracing John Milton as a champion of liberty on the 400th anniversary of his birth? If the poet were alive today, a commentator writes, "he would be depressed to see that the country of his birth retains a monarchy, and even more so an established church." Rather, "it is far more accurate to say that Milton was a key founder of the American liberal tradition, than of the British one." [Open Democracy]

Canada | Never mind the beer-swilling McKenzie Brothers; Canada has a stoned driver problem, a columnist says, citing statistics showing that more people drive under the influence of marijuana and other drugs (10 percent) than alcohol (8 percent). She blames inadequate enforcement of Canada's pot and drug laws. [Edmonton Sun]
Through Eric Musselman's blog, coaches share stories and tips on how to motivate, how to teach, how to win. He has agreed to plug us into his network periodically.
A Norwegian rider, Tony Andre Hansen, was stripped of his Olympic bronze medal in team jumping after his horse tested positive for a banned drug at the Beijing Games.

Bill Davis Racing, the reigning Nascar ruck series champion and 2002 Daytona 500 winner, agreed to be sold to two North Carolina investors after failing to secure sponsorship for next season. The investors, Marty Gaunt, the former general manager of Red Bull Racing; and his partner Michael Held, will acquire a majority stake in the race team and full ownership of Triad Racing Technologies from Davis, which supplies Toyota Motor Corporation engines and parts for other race teams.

Ivica Kostelic of Croatia won a World Cup slalom Monday for his second podium finish in two days on the Gran Risa course in Alta Badia, Italy. The top American finisher was Ted Ligety, in 12th place. Bode Miller split a gate during the opening run and was disqualified. Kostelic won with a combined time of 1 minute 39.83 seconds. He placed second in the traditional giant slalom Sunday, his best result in the discipline.

Rafael Furcal denied that he reneged on a deal with the Atlanta Braves before agreeing to a contract last week with the Los Angeles Dodgers. “We never gave the nod to the Braves,” he said Sunday after arriving in the Dominican Republic to play winter ball for the Aguilas of Cibaenas.

Pitcher Chien-Ming Wang and the Yankees avoided salary arbitration when they agreed to a one-year, $5 million contract. Wang, a 28-year-old right-hander, was 8-2 with a 4.07 earned run average in 15 starts last season before injuring a foot while running the bases at Houston in mid-June. He did not return. Wang made $4 million last season after losing in salary arbitration. He had asked for $4.6 million.

Telefonica Blue of Spain won the third leg of the Volvo Ocean Race, closing the gap on the overall leader, Ericsson 4 of Sweden, during the 1,950 nautical miles from Kochi, India, to Singapore. The United States team, Puma Ocean Racing, arrived second. It was 1:47 ahead of Sweden’s Ericsson 3, which beat Ericsson 4 by 40 seconds after more than nine days of racing. The teams are scheduled to leave Singapore on Jan. 18 for Qingdao, China, on the fourth stage of the around-the-world race.

Andy Rautins tied a team record with nine 3-pointers and scored a career-high 29 points to lead No. 17 Syracuse to an 82-71 victory over visiting Coppin State on Monday night.

A music review on Monday about a concert featuring the soprano Julianne Baird, at the Rose Theater, misstated her surname at one point among several descriptions of her singing. It was Ms. Baird who sang “with the almost vibrato-free sound associated with vocalists from the early-music movement,” not “Ms. Brewer.” (Christine Brewer was scheduled to perform but withdrew because of a family emergency.).

An obituary on Thursday about the Hall of Fame quarterback Sammy Baugh misstated the year he was a first-round draft pick by the Washington Redskins. It was 1937, not 1936.

The Talking Business column on Saturday, about India’s avoiding the subprime lending crisis, reversed the initials of a former governor of the Reserve Bank of India, whose policies helped hold bankers to high lending standards. He is Y. V. Reddy. The error also appeared in an accompanying caption.

An article last Tuesday about the challenges facing Adm. Mike Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as he adjusts to an Obama administration misstated the position taken in 1993 by Colin L. Powell, the chairman at the time, regarding the policy governing gay men and lesbians in the military — a law that President-elect Barack Obama strongly opposes on moral grounds. Mr. Powell opposed lifting an outright ban on gay men and women in the military but supported the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy that Congress passed as a compromise.
Two months before IndyMac Bancorp collapsed, a federal banking regulator allowed it to backdate a capital infusion, a Treasury Department investigator said.

An article on Monday about conservative radio talk show hosts’ jockeying for position as a new administration takes office misstated the title of Gary Schonfeld, who said he expected conservative hosts to have more fun with a Democrat in the White House. He is president of the network division of Westwood One, not president of its network programming.

An article on Dec. 12 about the difficulties that India faces in deciding how to respond to recent terrorist attacks in Mumbai misidentified the job held by Xenia Dormandy, a former Bush administration official who specializes in South Asia. Ms. Dormandy is a senior associate at the Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs at Harvard’s Kennedy School of Government; she does not run the center.

RAYMOND--Dorothy Sarnoff, age 94, died peacefully on December 20, 2008, predeceased by her husband Milton Raymond, her brother Dr. Robert Sarnoff, and her sister Elaine Sarnoff. Dorothy will be remembered by the many charities she supported. Dorothy's life consisted of one amazing, successful career after another. She performed as a concert soloist, opera singer, Broadway actress, and TV guest performer. Dorothy was an author, lecturer and speech teacher through Speech Dynamics. She may best be remembered for her performance as Lady Thiang in the original 1951 Broadway production of Roger and Hammerstein's ''The King and I'' where she sang a song which truly described her life -''Something Wonderful''. Interment private.

WIENER--Seymour, 85, of Manhattan, East Moriches, formerly Belle Harbor, died peacefully Saturday, December 20, 2008. Beloved husband of Ronnie, father of Phyllis, Ellen, Peter, Bruce, Lauren, Allie, grandfather and greatgrandfather. An extraordinary man who lived an extraordinary life and positively affected all who came in contact with him.

NEUHAUSER--Arthur I.,90, of E. Brunswick, NJ, formerly of Merrick, NY died Sunday, December 21, 2008. Mr. Neuhauser retired from the NY Times after a 40 year career as journalist and editor of the culture, obituary and society desks. He was predeceased by his wife, Roslyn Blinder Neuhauser in 1980. Surviving are his daughter, Claudia Scherzer, two sons, Ken and Mitch Neuhauser, eight grandchildren, one greatgrandchild, and his sister Judith Lowell. Funeral services Tuesday 10:15am in Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, NJ with burial in Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. For directions, visit: www.msmc.us

Eight is an important number in China. Its association with good fortune makes it a big hit for license plates and mobile phone numbers. It's no accident that the Beijing Olympic Games opened on the eighth day of the eighth month in 2008. But the number may have another meaning. If economic growth falls below 8 percent, some say, China's masses will turn the country into a simmering cauldron of unrest.

PAULSEN--Gordon W.,on December 20, at Foulkeways Community in Gwynedd, PA. President of the Maritime Law Association of the United States from 1982-84, he balanced careers as admiralty lawyer and church organist, represented Swedish America Line in the high-profile Stockholm - Andrea Doria case, and received a knighthood from King Harald of Norway. He served in the U.S. Army and received his law degree from Columbia Law School. Over a career spanning more than 50 years, he handled many significant maritime matters as senior partner at Haight, Gardner, Poor and Havens, and later, Of Counsel at Healy and Baillie. He was instrumental in the implementation by the United States of the International Maritime Rules of the Road and a fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. Paulsen's second career was actually his first love: music. He played organ and directed the choirs of many New York area churches, most notably The Community Church of Douglaston where he served as Organist and Music Director for 40 years, simply for the love of ''making a joyful noise unto the Lord''. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Janet Wessling Paulsen, his children Faith, Bruce G. and Emily Paulsen, their spouses Barton Sacks, Barbara Dunne Paulsen and Martin Livezey and six grandchildren. He is also survived by a sister-inlaw, Frances Paulsen and nephews Keith and Eric Paulsen. He is pre-deceased by his brother E. Leslie Paulsen and nephew Kenneth Paulsen. A memorial service will be held at 2pm on January 10 at the Community Church of Douglaston, 39-50 Douglaston Parkway, Douglaston, NY 11363 (718229-2169). Memorial contributions may be made to the Organ Fund of the Community Church of Douglaston.

He is also survived by his children from his former wife, the late Corinne Schube, daughter Ann Katzenstein, sons Edward and Peter, and their spouses Paul Katzenstein, Diane Schube, and Leona Schube, loving grandfather of Sarah and Andrew Katzenstein, Samuel and William Schube and Benjamin Schube. JETER BRISTLES AT QUESTION As the temperatures at the Trump Wollman Skating Rink in Central Park dropped into the 20s on Monday night, Derek Jeter was icy when asked about the off-season rumors simmering around the Yankees.
