A slide show of works by Richard Prince and Wallace Berman, two artists with almost nothing in common biographically, but who are paired in an exhibition, ''She,'' focusing on a subject that interested both artists: women. Berman loved photographing women, seemingly just for the pleasure of taking the shot; most of his pictures were never even printed during his lifetime. Mr. Prince mines the ways that society has portrayed women and how women have seemed to want to be portrayed. ''She'' will open Jan. 15 at the Michael Kohn Gallery in Los Angeles. Above left, Mr. Prince in Milton, Mass., in the mid-1970s. At right, an untitled photograph by Mr. Berman from 1964. nytimes.com/design

EISINGER--Dr. Robert P.,died peacefully at home on December 20, 2008, at age 79, after a long illness. Son of Jacob and Rose Sapir Eisinger, loving husband of Miriam (nee Blumberg), beloved father of Ari and Dina, grandfather of Rebecca and Abraham Lange, and father-in-law of Marc Lange. He had a distinguished career in medicine, including starting the first dialysis unit in New York City at the Manhattan VA Medical Center, and serving as Chief of Nephrology at UMDRobert Wood Johnson Medical Center for many years. He will be remembered as a caring physician, an inspiring teacher, a lifelong birdwatcher and naturalist, and a loving friend. The family wishes to extend its gratitude to the wonderful nurses who cared for him in his final days. A private memorial service will be held. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Dr. Eisinger may be directed to the Massachusetts Audubon Society, 208 South Great Road, Lincoln, MA 01773.

SARNOFF--Dorothy Raymond, age 94. Her colleagues at Ogilvy mourn the loss of an elegant woman, friend, mentor, and confidant who taught us to speak more effectively and to live life more richly. Her students also include a President, heads-of-state, CEOs, and innumerable aspiring executives. Her teaching followed a successful singing career of opera, supper clubs, and Broadway. We will always remember her confidencebuilding mantra: ''I'm glad I'm here. I'm glad you're here. I care about you. I know that I know''. Shelly Lazarus Bill Phillips Jerry Pickholz Ken Roman Bill Weed

HENDERSON--Joseph A.,of Lincroft, NJ on December 22. U.S. Army veteran of the Korean War, Member of the New York Stock Exchange, Fourth generation NYSE specialist at Henderson Brothers, Inc., avid fisherman, orchid grower, soup kitchen worker, friend of the poor and less fortunate and devout and humble servant of Our Lord, Jesus Christ. Born August 27, 1932. Son of John C. and Marie Anita Henderson. Brother of Charles, John (deceased), Robert (deceased) and Peter Henderson, Mary SeamanMeyer and M. Anita Gassert. Devoted husband of Joan Gassert Henderson (de ceased) and loving father to Joseph, Jr., William, Margaret, Anne and Matthew Henderson, Sara Buckley and Joan Cleary and proud grandfather of 16 wonderful grandchildren. Wake to be held at St. Mary's RC Church, Colts Neck, NJ on Tuesday from 79PM. Funeral Mass will be offered Wednesday 9:00AM at St. Mary's Church. Services by the Holmdel Funeral, Holmdel, NJ 732-946-3322. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to Mother Teresa's Missionaries of Charity, 144 Ridge Avenue, Asbury Park, NJ 07712.

TABER--Janet Beebe, died Saturday, December 13, 2008, in her home in Pittsburgh of cancer. She was 80. She was president of the Rebecca House and director of the Hillman Cancer Institute. She was preceded in death by her husband, George H. Taber III in September. Janet is survived by her sons, Stephen of Sao Paulo, Brazil; Michael of Fairfax, Vermont; and John of Freedom, Pennsylvania; two sisters; Marcia Fenn of Maine and Diana Richardson of Massachusetts; and five grandchildren.

A decision by Walt Disney has left C.S. Lewis’s enchanted wardrobe a little more bare: the company said it would not help finance and produce the next movie in the “Chronicles of Narnia” series, based on Lewis’s fantasy novels, The Hollywood Reporter said. The franchise, jointly produced and financed by Disney and Walden Media, had a hit with its first entry, “The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe,” which was released in 2005 and grossed $745 million worldwide. But a sequel, “Prince Caspian,” released in May, grossed $419 million. Disney had an option to take part in a third movie, “The Voyage of the Dawn Treader,” which it chose not to exercise. “Dawn Treader” is in preproduction for a 2010 release.

The legal battle among the studios and networks fighting for control over “Project Runway” has inched ever-so-slightly along the catwalk. On Tuesday, a judge denied the Lifetime channel’s request to consolidate the various lawsuits in federal court, Variety said. The suits stem from a decision by the Weinstein Company, which produces “Project Runway,” to move the show from Bravo to Lifetime. NBC Universal, the parent company of Bravo, has sued the Weinstein Company, which has sued Bravo, and Lifetime sued them all, saying that the channel had exclusive rights to the show. In New York, District Court Judge Richard J. Sullivan did not rule on the ownership of “Project Runway” but rejected the consolidation request. A sixth season of the show remains up in the air, pending the resolution of the suits.

Citing the right of all people to have “access to their heritage without pornographic restraint,” a descendant of Louis XIV has filed for an emergency injunction to halt an exhibition of Jeff Koons’s sculptures at the Château de Versailles, Agence-France Presse reported. Prince Charles-Emmanuel de Bourbon-Parme has asked an administrative court at Versailles to halt the exhibition, called “Jeff Koons Versailles,” which juxtaposes an encased display of vacuum cleaners and a giant balloon dog with the palace’s portraits of French royalty, and includes a bare-breasted woman holding a pink panther, among other works. In his complaint, the prince called the show “a desecration and an attack on the respect due to the dead,” according to Agence-France Presse. The exhibition, which has had more than 500,000 visitors since its September opening, is scheduled to close on Jan. 4.

Like a pair of squabbling mismatched brothers forced to live together, Warner Brothers Television and CBS now find themselves feuding over the hit sitcom “Two and a Half Men.” On Tuesday, Warner Brothers, the studio that produces the show, filed a $49 million breach-of-contract suit against CBS, which broadcasts it, The Hollywood Reporter said. In the suit, Warner Brothers said that the network had refused to pay additional fees the studio said it was owed if the show achieved certain ratings numbers in its fourth season, which aired from 2006 to 2007. That season, “Two and a Half Men” was ranked 19th in the ratings; in its current season it is frequently a Top 10 show, and often the only sitcom to reach such heights.

Adam Goldstein, who performs under the name DJ AM, has filed his own lawsuits stemming from a September plane crash in which he and the punk musician Travis Barker were injured, and four people were killed. On Sept. 19, a private jet on which Mr. Goldstein and Mr. Barker were to fly home from a concert in South Carolina crashed on the runway at Columbia Metropolitan Airport. On Tuesday, Mr. Goldstein filed suit against the charter companies involved in the flight, as well as Learjet and Goodyear Tire and Rubber and the estates of the two pilots who were killed in the accident, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Barker has filed similar suits, as has the widow of Mr. Barker’s assistant, Chris Baker, who was also killed.

Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) remains at No. 1 on this week’s Billboard album chart with 330,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, its third time atop the chart in six weeks at stores. In second place is “A Different Me” (Geffen) by Keyshia Cole, the R&B singer and star of the BET reality show “The Way It Is.” “A Different Me” sold 322,000 in its first week, and another new release, “Intuition” by Jamie Foxx (J Records), reached No. 3 with 265,000, while Fall Out Boy’s new “Folie à Deux” (Island) debuted at No. 8 with 150,000. Elsewhere on the chart, Britney Spears’s “Circus” (Jive) dropped two spots to No. 4 with 196,000 sales; right behind it were Beyoncé’s “I Am … Sasha Fierce” (Columbia), at No. 5 with 195,000, and Nickelback’s “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner), at No. 6 with 194,000.

My Christmas Day column is about how we should think of charities, and discusses a powerful new book by Dan Pallotta, "Uncharitable." I have some ambivalence about Pallotta's ideas, but on the whole I think he's right that we need a major rethink of aid groups and that they should be allowed to employ practices that are standard in the business world, including advertising and paying more competitive salaries. I also think that we need to think about how better to harness business to fight poverty.

Police officers from around the country are being mobilized to help Washington, D.C., manage crowds for Barack Obama's inauguration, but the New York Police Department, the biggest and one of the most experienced and nearest, will not be among them. The district's Metropolitan Police Department, which has a force of 4,000, has asked 96 localities to send a total of 4,000 officers to help with crowd control along the parade route on Jan. 20, when it expects more than 1.5 million people. The lack of an invitation apparently resulted from a communication failure between the two departments dating back several years about the city's willingness to help with security in the nation's capital.

Throughout the Mark Teixeira sweepstakes, conventional wisdom held that the Mets were rooting for the Red Sox to sign him. Christmas Past We all have a tendency to think of Christmas as somehow timeless, embedded in amber, just like the ones we used to know. But Karal Ann Marling, in her informative and entertaining book "Merry Christmas! Celebrating America's Greatest Holiday," demonstrates that Christmas has always been a dynamic holiday, constantly evolving, and that many of our most familiar rituals and much of our most ubiquitous iconography are of relatively recent vintage. Christmas trees, for example, didn't really catch on until the 1930s. In the first decade of the 20th century, only one family in four had a tree, and Theodore Roosevelt allowed one into the White House only after he was persuaded that cutting down small trees was good for conservation. The first national tree dates from 1923.

[UPDATE, 12/25: The Genesis reading by the Apollo 8 astronauts, and Christmas in Deadhorse (Alaska).] Forty years ago today, the Apollo 8 astronauts, the first humans to orbit the Moon, were taken by surprise. After three orbits spent photographing the lunar surface, Frank Borman shifted the orientation of the capsule to see the horizon. Suddenly, Bill Anders realized he was seeing the home planet hovering over the lunar horizon in what was, in essence, the first human-witnessed "Earthrise."

Vogel and Carrie Budoff Brown of the Politico think it provides a roadmap to how the next administration will handle scandals. New York State voters oppose the so-called "obesity tax" on nondiet soft drinks by a resounding margin of 60 percent to 37 percent, but support, by an even more overwhelming margin of 84 percent to 13 percent, raising the state income tax on people who make more than $1 million per year, according to results of a Quinnipiac University poll released on Wednesday.

The career of an international beauty queen may have come to an abrupt end on Tuesday when the police announced that she had been arrested in suburban Guadalajara in a Toyota Cruiser stuffed with guns and cash. Laura Zúñiga Huizar, 23, winner of her home state’s Miss Sinaloa contest, placed third in Mexico’s national contest in September and won a Latin America-wide pageant, above, in Bolivia in October. The Jalisco State Police said they arrested Ms. Zúñiga and seven men late Monday, and seized two assault rifles, three smaller guns, ammunition and more than $53,000 in cash. They said one of the men was a leader of the Juárez drug cartel. Mexican pageant officials said they would await the results of an investigation before deciding whether to strip her of her crown.
Brazil and France signed a defense agreement on Tuesday worth more than $12 billion that will give Brazil technology to develop its arms industry and build a nuclear-powered submarine.

A Canadian woman who disappeared during a blizzard has been found alive, buried in 23 inches of snow, three days after her sport utility vehicle got stuck in a snowy field. A police dog found Donna Molnar, 55, on Monday, near Ancaster, Ontario, a few hundred yards from her SUV, conscious and wearing little more than a winter jacket. The police said the snow may have insulated her from temperatures as low as 2 degrees. Ms. Molnar, a school secretary, was in critical condition on Tuesday but expected to survive. “It’s a miracle, there’s no doubt about that,” said her husband, David Molnar.

After an American official said he had “lost it” and a British official called him “an impossible obstacle,” President Robert Mugabe responded Tuesday by saying the United States and Britain were “stupid” to think he should not be part of a unity government. The top United States diplomat for Africa said Sunday that Washington could no longer support a power-sharing proposal that left Mr. Mugabe as president, a position seconded by Britain’s Africa minister on Monday. Mr. Mugabe described the comments as “stupid and foolish thinking” because only Zimbabweans could make such a decision, he said. “We are not going to listen to what Bush and Gordon Brown are saying. We do realize that these are the last kicks of a dying horse.”.

After a two-day lull in the worst riots to hit Greece in decades, hundreds of anarchists marched through Athens on Tuesday and a gunman opened fire at a bus carrying 19 riot police officers. Two bullets hit the bus but no one was injured in the shooting, near a university campus in Athens. The anarchists chanted “cops, pigs, murderers” and waved flags in a largely peaceful protest during the third week of antigovernment protests since a teenager was fatally shot by the police.

Four animal rights activists were convicted Tuesday for mounting a seven-year campaign of blackmail and intimidation against suppliers of an animal testing research center near Cambridge. Three others had previously pleaded guilty. The group’s tactics included threatening phone calls, bomb hoaxes, threats of attacks with H.I.V.-infected needles and sending letters to neighbors falsely accusing the supply company managers of being pedophiles. The campaign against suppliers of Huntingdon Life Sciences, a research laboratory that is regarded as one of Europe’s most advanced centers for animal testing for biomedical research, had threatened to close the company and curb animal testing in Britain. Sentences will be handed down next month.

Israeli forces killed three Palestinian militants on the Gaza border on Tuesday, the deadliest clash since a truce expired Friday between Israel and Hamas, the militant group that rules Gaza. Israel said the three militants were planting explosives in northern Gaza along the border fence. Soldiers crossed a few yards into Gaza and engaged the Palestinians, who threw grenades. The soldiers returned fire, killing the three, according to Israeli news media.
A witness in the corruption trial of Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska has told the judge he never would have testified if he had known he did not have immunity from prosecution.
Two data recorders provided a preliminary timeline of the crash, federal transportation investigators said.
Recreational saltwater anglers no longer face a January deadline to register with the federal government.
A Massey Energy subsidiary has agreed to pay $4.2 million in civil and criminal penalties and plead guilty to federal charges, a U.S. attorney said.
The mother of a bullied teenager who planned an attack on a high school has been sentenced to three months to a year in prison for providing him with explosive material and access to firearms.
By the time Roxanne Adorno gave birth to her daughter, at 36, she was determined to give her something she had never known: support.
Boise State’s high-flying, free-wheeling offense was halted by the stout Texas Christian defense as the Horned Frogs won the Poinsettia Bowl on Tuesday.
This is the weekly notebook that runs in Wednesday's paper. It's a little longer here because we have more room on the Internet.
Thursday, Dec. 24, 1908

Wipro, an outsourcing company, said it would buy Citi Technology Services for $127 million, as Citigroup sheds assets. Wipro said it would also sign a six-year outsourcing agreement with Citi worth at least $500 million. Citi Technology Services was started in 2005 and is expected to report revenue of $80 million in 2008.

Precision Drilling Trust, Canada’s largest drilling company, won shareholder approval for its $1.4 billion takeover of Grey Wolf, based in Houston. The acquisition allows Precision to increase its drilling capacity and gain 122 rigs. Together, Precision and Grey Wolf had revenue of $1.8 billion in the year ended June 30.

A group of farmers sporadically blocked a rural highway to protest government farm policy, returning to methods used during a four-month conflict earlier this year. The protest took place a day after President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner announced a series of measures that did not include a reduction in export taxes on soy, the country’s top crop. Mrs. Kirchner repeated her government’s commitment to reducing export taxes on corn and wheat, and announced a cut of taxes on fruits and vegetables, but made no mention of soy. Farmers have demanded lower export taxes as global soy prices fall sharply.

The International Monetary Fund discussed lending $200 million to the Democratic Republic of the Congo to help the country cope with falling commodity prices and a conflict in its eastern provinces. A drop in cobalt and copper exports has “taken its toll on economic activity and employment, particularly in the mining sector,” the I.M.F. said in a statement. The I.M.F. said $200 million in aid to Congo was discussed under a process that helps poor nations cope with short-term swings in commodity and food prices.
Bryan Little scored his second goal of the game on a power play in the third period and the Atlanta Thrashers kept the Islanders winless in 10 games with a victory Tuesday.
James Harris resigned as personnel chief of the Jacksonville Jaguars on Tuesday, taking the fall for a disappointing year.
Mike Haywood, Notre Dame’s offensive coordinator, became the second black head coach hired by a Mid-American Conference university this week.
Portland State’s upset over No. 7 Gonzaga was its first win over a ranked team since it reinstated its basketball program for the 1996-97 season.
A four-foot high wall of water washed away parts of a two-lane road just outside Washington during the morning commute on Tuesday.
State environmental officials struggled trying to assess the damage in hopes that water supplies were not harmed by heavy metals.
NATIONAL.
Dr. Marshall was an ecumenist who in the 1970s led the Lutheran Church in America, then the nation’s largest Lutheran church, and helped pave the way for its merger with two other denominations.
A man grabbed a 6-year-old off the street in El Monte, Calif., and held him hostage in a two-hour standoff that ended with gunshots.
A Chinese court has declared bankrupt the New Zealand-based company at the center of a scandal over tainted milk.
Brian Smith, 37, is the preliminary suspect in the attacks that killed two drivers in Dallas on Monday, the authorities said.
A record number of mergers and acquisitions, worth nearly $1 trillion, were pulled so far this year, according to Dealogic.
According to a report released Tuesday, sexual abuse of children in a polygamist sect at the Yearning for Zion Ranch was common.
Yahoo’s decision to remove personally identifiable search information after 90 days is an encouraging development for the cause of Internet privacy.

A question-and-answer interview on Tuesday with Mahmoud A. Elsohly, who grows marijuana for research purposes, overstated the role of one government agency in the research. Although the National Institute on Drug Abuse does indeed contract with Dr. ElSohly’s laboratory to grow the cannabis for federally approved researchers, it does not issue permits to the researchers. (As the article noted, the Drug Enforcement Administration does.).
A top official said Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, a Sunni Muslim extremist group, helped carry out the Marriot Hotel bombing in Islamabad three months ago.
What Henry A. Kissinger said to President Richard M. Nixon 36 years ago can now be known with precision because they worked in what was, in retrospect, the golden age of White House taping.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the Holiday Festival men’s basketball final between St. John’s and Virginia Tech at Madison Square Garden misidentified the winning team at one point in some editions. As the article noted elsewhere, the winner was Virginia Tech — not West Virginia.
L’Affaire Madoff, as it has become known, has raised questions why Union Bancaire Privée did not look more closely at its returns.
Four former Guantánamo detainees should at last be given a fair hearing of their charges that they were tortured and denied their religious rights.
American commanders and Afghan leaders hope to imitate Iraq’s successful experiment, but there are fears it could prompt further bloodletting.
The money manager, R. Thierry Magon de la Villehuchet, felt he had let clients down, one client said.
The targets of the proposed investigation include Bruce R. Bent, the president of the Reserve Management Company, and his two sons.

An article in some editions on Tuesday about the Giants’ overtime victory against the Carolina Panthers on Sunday night attributed an erroneous distinction to a formidable Giants opponent in December 2007, the New England Patriots. They were undefeated at that point of the regular season — not the defending Super Bowl champions, a title belonging to the Indianapolis Colts.
Barack Obama should stick to his campaign pledge to pull combat troops out of Iraq in 16 months.
If a winner is not declared by Jan. 6, the governor can appoint an interim senator or decide to forgo one until the recount is resolved.
Middle- and upper-income families are traveling hundreds of miles to purchase a much wider selection of products at substantially lower prices than can be found in their hometowns.

An article in some editions on Saturday about a first-place sweep by Intermediate School 318 in Brooklyn in three categories of a national chess tournament omitted the names of two schools that shared the first-place award for fifth graders with the Horace Mann School in the Bronx. The co-champions are the Mamaroneck Avenue School in White Plains and the Ramaz School in Manhattan.
Michael R. Bloomberg hired Howard Wolfson, the Democratic spokesman and adviser to Hillary Rodham Clinton, to serve as the public face of his campaign.
After beating the 76ers on Tuesday, the Celtics will go for 20 in a row against the Los Angeles Lakers on Christmas Day in a rematch of last spring’s N.B.A. finals.
Devils forward Patrik Elias said that hockey takes up a smaller part of his life after a long bout with hepatitis A changed his perspective on nearly everything.
Last week, juries in Brooklyn and the Bronx faced two cases in which prosecutors sought murder convictions for defendants who were not the men who fired the fatal shots.

An article in some editions on Monday about Gov. David A. Paterson’s visit to Iraq with a Congressional delegation erroneously attributed a comment made during a conference call that included Mr. Paterson and Representatives Anthony Weiner and Steve Israel, in Baghdad, and reporters in New York. It was Mr. Weiner — not Mr. Israel — who said: “This country has been ravaged. We take solace in the small steps that have been taken to make things better here but it’s hard not to walk around the streets of Baghdad in particular and be a little depressed about it.”.
Deep-pocketed romantics who want to give a partridge in a pear tree and the other whimsical gifts from “The 12 Days of Christmas” may be in luck this year.

An article on Tuesday about steps being taken by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to build a more powerful State Department as she prepares to become secretary of state misstated, in some copies, the professional affiliation of Aaron David Miller, a public policy analyst who commented on Mrs. Clinton’s efforts. He is with the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, not the Brookings Institution.
I. Lewis Libby Jr., whose sentence President Bush commuted last year, has not applied for a pardon, Justice Department officials have said.
Amid state and city budget cuts, the bright lights have dimmed at Fiorello H. La Guardia High School of Music & Art and Performing Arts — the school of “Fame” fame.
Contention is emerging among officials against Caroline Kennedy as she pursues Hillary Rodham Clinton’s seat.
How the earth has changed since it was photographed by the crew of Apollo 8 40 years ago today.
A labor relations board ruled that Starbucks illegally fired three baristas and violated other labor laws in its effort to prevent unionization at several Manhattan cafes.
Tired of being hounded, a prominent opposition leader decided to accept a job with the Kremlin.
The Red Sox stand out in their willingness to draw a line with free agents about the price and length of contracts, even if that means allowing some deals to fall through.
Public officials have a host of very important questions to grapple with, but the most pressing may be this: How would I look if photographed in my bathing suit?
The Yankees and Mets are offering cheap or free tickets to exhibition games in April, but regular-season tickets will be less affordable than ever.
The Yankees, seemingly oblivious to the recession, have responded to their first nonplayoff season since 1993 with a swift and able vengeance.
Defensive end Shaun Ellis was fined $10,000 for throwing a large chunk of snow into the crowd on Sunday.
Even a bailout could not save three of the last remaining plants in the U.S. still making sport utility vehicles.
To restore the economy to health will require new policies that increase aggregate spending.
In Paris, the cake known as the Bûche de Noël is an opportunity for creativity, commerce, competition and consumption.
The Capitals’ Alex Ovechkin has not had much success in his trips to Madison Square Garden, but that all changed with a two-goal performance on Tuesday night.
If GMAC becomes a bank, it will be able to issue more car loans by gaining access to money under the Treasury’s $700 billion bailout plan.
The Mets, citing Johan’s Santana’s recent knee surgery, have cast doubt on the Venezuelan pitcher’s participation in the 2009 World Baseball Classic.
A photograph of the earthrise taken on Christmas Eve 1968, provided a new perspective on the thing that all humanity shares.
The Museum of Contemporary Art said Tuesday it had negotiated a $30 million bailout with Eli Broad, the city’s leading cultural patron.
In keeping with an unusual year, this column’s annual list of the economics books of the year is going to be a little unorthodox.
In addition to issuing a posthumous pardon to Charles Winters, President Bush granted 18 other pardons and one commutation on Tuesday.
We don’t just need a bailout in this country, we need a national makeover. That is why the next few months are among the most important in U.S. history.
Prosecutors have accused Kosta S. Kovachev of helping Marc S. Dreier in a series of elaborate schemes in which he sold phony promissory notes to hedge funds.
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have agreed to improve the reliability of appraisals on mortgage loans bought by the two financing companies.
A Staten Island businessman pleaded guilty to a single federal count of assisting terrorists by providing satellite services to Hezbollah’s television station.

Facing internal strife over stalled contract negotiations, Hollywood’s largest union decided late on Monday to postpone plans for a strike authorization vote.
China could soon begin building its first aircraft carrier. A Defense Ministry spokesman said that the country was seriously considering “relevant issues” in making its decision.
To advocates who have watched calls for changes in food policy gather political and popular momentum, Barack Obama looks like their kind of president.

The Metropolitan Opera’s family-friendly adaptation of “The Magic Flute,” a shortened version of Julie Taymor’s flamboyant 2004 staging, was revived on Monday afternoon.
To celebrate the 150th anniversary of Puccini’s birth, Dicapo Opera Theater performed excerpts from all 10 of his operas in chronological order on Monday.
CBS won every hour of prime time on Monday despite a lineup of repeats, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

As Christmas approaches, concertgoers who bought tickets for the now-bankrupt Baltimore Opera Company won’t be left out in the cold. A group of area arts companies will honor any nonrefundable tickets for productions of “Porgy and Bess” and “The Barber of Seville” planned by the Baltimore Opera Company, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection this month. Washington National Opera announced in a statement that it would offer vouchers for its spring production of “Peter Grimes,” and Centerstage said in a statement that it would provide tickets to its productions of “Fabulation or, The Re-education of Undine,” “ ’Tis Pity She’s a Whore” and “Souvenir.” The Baltimore Sun reported that the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra would make available tickets to four of its concerts, including three conducted by Marin Alsop, and that the Hippodrome Theater would offer tickets to its productions of “Cats,” “Movin’ Out” and “Annie.”.

Jürgen Flimm, below, the German theater and opera director, has been named the artistic director of Deutsche Staatsoper Unter den Linden in Berlin, and will take over the position on Sept. 1, 2010, Agence-France Presse reported. Mr. Flimm announced this year that he would not continue in his role as artistic director of the Salzburg Festival in Austria, a position he has held since 2006, when his contract expires in 2011. He had clashed with Thomas Oberender, the festival’s drama director. At the Staatsoper he will replace Peter Mussbach, who has frequently feuded with its musical director, Daniel Barenboim. In April Mr. Mussbach denounced Mr. Barenboim and Klaus Wowereit, the mayor of Berlin, for using “mafia” tactics against him after the mayor said he would not renew Mr. Mussbach’s contract with the state-run opera company.

Bruce Springsteen completists may need to make a trip to Wal-Mart when his new album, “Working on a Dream,” is released Jan. 13: Billboard reported that the retailer will offer an exclusive greatest-hits album on that date. It will consist of songs recorded by Mr. Springsteen, above left, and the E Street Band, including “Born to Run” and “Darkness on the Edge of Town,” but omit hits from his solo career. ... Fans of Bono, above right, and his band, U2, should save their pennies too: when that band’s new album, “No Line on the Horizon,” is released March 2, it will come in five versions, Billboard reported. The most expensive package, a $96 box set, will include posters, a hardcover book and a DVD directed by Anton Corbijn.

The Off Broadway run of Martin McDonagh’s “Cripple of Inishmaan,” a revival at the Atlantic Theater’s Linda Gross Theater, has been extended by four weeks, its producers, the Atlantic Theater Company and Druid Theater Company, announced. The play, directed by Garry Hynes and featuring Aaron Monaghan and Kerry Condon, will now close March 1. ... The one-man show “Krapp, 39,” written by and starring Michael Laurence, will receive an Off Broadway run in January. The show, about a man fascinated with the Beckett play “Krapp’s Last Tape,” played this year at the New York International Fringe Festival. It begins previews at the SoHo Playhouse on Jan. 13 and opens Jan. 22. Theatergoers who are 39 years old can attend free of charge with corroborating ID.
The show, adapted from Lloyd Kaufman’s long-running film series of low-budget horror comedies, will have an Off Broadway run at New World Stages.

A court officer has deemed that Britney Spears’s father is worth even more to his daughter’s resurgent pop music fortunes than previously estimated — to the tune of more than $50,000. On Monday a Los Angeles County Superior Court commissioner awarded Ms. Spears’s father, Jamie, an additional $51,000 in back pay and a raise of $1,200 a month, on top of the $10,000-a-month salary he receives as conservator of his daughter’s career, The Associated Press reported. In February Mr. Spears was granted temporary control of his daughter after Ms. Spears, 27, was placed under psychiatric evaluation. That conservatorship was made permanent in October, though Ms. Spears can petition to have it removed. This month Ms. Spears’s “Circus” entered the Billboard album chart at No. 1.
Fox News said Tuesday that Bret Baier, its chief White House correspondent, would replace Brit Hume as the host of its 6 p.m. political news program.

SNYDER--Harold. The Board of Directors, officers and staff of American Friends of Tel Aviv University are saddened by the loss of our dear friend, Harold Snyder. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Tamar, and the entire family. William F. Cohen, Chairman Roni Krinsky, President

LOW--Susanne Murray, died peacefully at her home in Boca Grande, Florida on December 20, 2008 at the age of 91. Beloved wife of the late Francis H. Low, she is survived by Faith Low Humann (Mrs. Edgar Humann) of Bermuda, Susanne Low Clarke (Mrs. Eliot C. Clarke) of Millbrook, New York, Linda Low Wolcott (Mrs. Frank E. Wolcott, III) of Essex, Connecticut, three grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on January 3, 2009 at 1:00pm at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Boca Grande, Florida. The family would greatly appreciate in lieu of flowers, contributions be sent to The Island School of Boca Grande or the Johann Fust Community Library in Boca Grande or the Department of Ornithology, the American Museum of Natural History, in New York.

HENDERSON--Joseph A.,of Lincroft, NJ on December 22. U.S. Army veteran of the Korean War, Member of the New York Stock Exchange, Fourth generation NYSE specialist at Henderson Brothers, Inc., avid fisherman, orchid grower, soup kitchen worker, friend of the poor and less fortunate and devout and humble servant of Our Lord, Jesus Christ. Born August 27, 1932. Son of John C. and Marie Anita Henderson. Brother of Charles, John (deceased), Robert (deceased) and Peter Henderson, Mary SeamanMeyer and M. Anita Gassert. Devoted husband of Joan Gassert Henderson (de ceased) and loving father to Joseph, Jr., William, Margaret, Anne and Matthew Henderson, Sara Buckley and Joan Cleary and proud grandfather of 16 wonderful grandchildren. Wake to be held at St. Mary's RC Church, Colts Neck, NJ on Tuesday from 79PM. Funeral Mass will be offered Wednesday 9:00AM at St. Mary's Church. Services by the Holmdel Funeral, Holmdel, NJ 732-946-3322. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to Mother Teresa's Missionaries of Charity, 144 Ridge Avenue, Asbury Park, NJ 07712.

In a setback for state lawmakers seeking to impeach Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, a federal prosecutor said Tuesday that he would not provide them with information about his criminal investigation of the governor. The lawmakers had asked in a letter to the prosecutor, Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the United States attorney in Chicago, for guidance on how the impeachment inquiry should proceed in light of the criminal case. They also requested a four-page litany of specific information, including the identities of witnesses who had been granted immunity in the federal investigation or were cooperating with prosecutors.
ADREZIN--Judith (nee Etra), died peacefully December 18, 2008. Sister of Carol Etra Wool and the late Jonathan Marc Etra; daughter of the late Lucille and Marvin J. Etra. She will be missed.

JAFFE--Phyllis S.,an early practitioner of education labor law and wife of the late Frederick Jaffe, died at home on December 22, 2008. She was 83. Mrs. Jaffe served in the Women's Army Corps during WWll, graduated from Columbia Law School in 1949 and was elected to the Ossining (NY) Board of Education in 1964 and served as president in 1966-69. Mrs. Jaffe led Plunkett and Jaffe's Westchester County office from 1975 until her retirement in 2003. Her cases included Immediato v. Rye Neck School District in which the U.S. Supreme Court upheld the right of high schools to require community service as a graduation requirement. Mrs. Jaffe was preceded in death by her brother Edwin Shelley. She is survived by and will be missed by her sons Paul, David (wife Leslie); and Rick (wife Kim) four grandchildren, Dara, Gary, Eli and Julian; her brother, Heywood, (wife Maritza), their daughter and granddaughter; and sister-in-law Florence, her children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Donations can be made in the name of Phyllis Jaffe to The Clear View School (serving children with special needs), 480 Albany Post Road, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10510. The family (pauljaffe@verizon.net) is planning a memorial service to be held at a later date.

GREENBERG--Lillian, passed away December 21st, 2008 after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Morris Greenberg, M.D., beloved mother, sister, grandmother and aunt. Shiva being observed at the home of her daughter, Felice Muchnick.

RAYMOND--Dorothy Sarnoff, age 94, died peacefully on December 20, 2008, predeceased by her husband Milton Raymond, her brother Dr. Robert Sarnoff, and her sister Elaine Sarnoff. Dorothy will be remembered by the many charities she supported. Dorothy's life consisted of one amazing, successful career after another. She performed as a concert soloist, opera singer, Broadway actress, and TV guest performer. Dorothy was an author, lecturer and speech teacher through Speech Dynamics. She may best be remembered for her performance as Lady Thiang in the original 1951 Broadway production of Roger and Hammerstein's ''The King and I'' where she sang a song which truly described her life -''Something Wonderful''. Interment private.

Along with oil, gas and seafood, Louisiana's bountiful production includes one of the nation's highest per-capita rates of players in the N.F.L. According to a 2006 survey, Louisiana led the league with one player for every 58,802 residents. No area of the state is more fertile for football than the stretch of the Mississippi River that runs from Baton Rouge through New Orleans and 75 miles south to the Gulf of Mexico. All five high schools that won Louisiana state championships this month came from the river region within a 50-mile radius of the Superdome, left, in New Orleans. Six players from that area played in the Super Bowl last February as the Giants defeated the Patriots, including Eli Manning from New Orleans, Brandon Jacobs from Napoleonville and Corey Webster from St. James.

CARPENTER--Edmund Nelson II, died peacefully at home Friday morning, December 19th, surrounded by his immediate family. He was a war hero, an attorney, a statesman, and a lover of history and literature; he was an adoring and uniquely adored husband, father, grandfather, and friend. His life was devoted to country, the Law, social justice and-above all-family. Among innumerable other achievements, he was awarded a Bronze Star in World War II for successful covert missions flown in Dien Bien Phu, formerly French Indo-China. Working in military intelligence, he was a member of the small team that rescued the celebrated Doolittle Raiders who had been trapped behind enemy lines following Pearl Harbor. He was proud of his service, and loved returning to Asia to re-visit places he had been. Throughout his life he held myriad leadership positions in the worlds of Delaware and American law: as Deputy Attorney General for the State of Delaware; as Special Deputy Attorney General for the State of Delaware; as Chairman of numerous advisory committees for the Delaware Supreme Court and the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit; as President of the Delaware Bar Association; and, later, President of the American Judicature Society, which presented him with their Justice Award. He was honored to be a Director, and later President, of Delaware law firm Richards, Layton and Finger, where his community of colleagues was like a second family. After retiring, he worked tirelessly pro bono on various legislative reforms; in 2000, he co-founded Stand Up for what is Right and Just (SURJ), where-alongside former FBI Director Louis J. Freeh-he created a new movement for local legislative reform. He served as Trustee or Trustee Emeritus for many organizations, including Princeton University, where he worked with his fellow trustees during the University's transition to coeducation. He always maintained that the school's motto, dei sub numine viget, actually meant, God went to Princeton. Throughout his life he always found time to be an influential, often anonymous, philanthropist (a word he never would have used in describing himself) through his leadership of a private family foundation. He wrote hundreds of Letters to the Editor of the Wilmington News Journal through the years, arguing for those things he believed in most passionately, perhaps above all the repeal of the Rockefeller-era drug laws that provided for mandatory minimum sentencing. He also held out hope for the decriminalization of drugs (a last Letter to the Editor on this subject was published one week before he died). He loved and found great comfort in literature, and in poetry in particular, and was uniquely drawn to Alfred Tennyson's Ulysses; he loved the lines that read: ''To follow knowledge like a sinking star, beyond the utmost bound of human thought . . . to strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield.'' He had unique charm and profound humility, and he wielded his infamous wit with subtlety and precision. He loved athletics and opera. He was deeply proud to be an American. As a close friend of the family put it recently, he was the closest thing most of us will ever get to knowing James Bond. He is survived by the love of his life, his wife, Carroll Morgan Carpenter; six loving children, Mary Wootten Carpenter, Jeff Carpenter, Katherine Revell Reynolds Carpenter, John Davis Gates Jr., Ashley Gates Jansen, Lea du Pont Carpenter Brokaw, and their spouses; and thirteen loving and loved grandchildren. The family wishes to thank: Drs. Patricia Curtin, M.D., Stephen DeCherney, M.D., Kathleen McNicholas, M.D., Lanny Edelsohn, M.D., Gerald M. Lemole, M.D., Lee S. Cohen, M.D, and Phil Blatt, MD. They also wish to thank especially Elizabeth Lea Carpenter du Pont, Mr. Carpenter's beloved niece who introduced him to his wife, and after whom his youngest daughter was named. A private memorial service was held for immediate family in their home in Wilmington on Saturday, December 20th. Please contact Hardin & Associates at 302-654-9923 for information regarding the memorial service or email information@hardininc.com. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be sent to Princeton University or to Christiana Care Health System of Delaware.

Red Zone Blues The Browns have not scored an offensive touchdown in the last five games. Worse, the Browns did not run a play in the red zone in Sunday's loss to Cincinnati -- they crossed the Bengals' 30-yard line only once -- and they have made only one red-zone trip in their last three games. In seven games since Nov. 2, opposing defenders have scored as many touchdowns (four) as the Browns players they were trying to stop. The Browns (4-11) finished 1-7 at home, beating only the Giants. ANDREW DAS

Workers scaled the Singapore Flyer, the world's largest observation wheel, on Tuesday to rescue some of the 173 passengers stuck after a fire erupted in the control room. Ten of the passengers were rescued by rope; two were hospitalized. The 541- foot-high wheel was stalled for about six hours.

HASSEN--Theodore. Trans Ocean Import Co.,Inc., One Barker Avenue, White Plains, NY mourns the untimely passing of Theodore Hassen, friend, partner, exceptional executive and former owner who retired to Windermere, Florida. He was 74. Mr. Hassen's career path started at R.H. Macy and then became floorcovering buyer at Davidson's, Atlanta with a final retail stop as floorcovering buyer at May Company, Los Angeles, California. He joined Trans Ocean in 1969 as Vice President of Product Development and Marketing. In 1982 along with Allan Wagenheim they purchased Trans Ocean. In 1998 he retired. He was on the Board of Directors of the Orlando Symphony and the PBS Station WMFE. He is survived by sisters Barbara and Lillian. In lieu of flowers please donate to the charity of your choice.

Barack Obama identified with Lincoln throughout his campaign for the presidency. He quoted from Lincoln often, he announced his candidacy for president in Springfield, Ill., and he plans to follow Lincoln's train ride into Washington from Philadelphia for his inauguration. Now his team has announced he will be sworn into office with the same Bible that Lincoln used for his first inauguration in 1861.

Adrian Mitchell, a prolific British poet whose impassioned verse against social injustice, racism and violence was often declaimed at antiwar rallies and political demonstrations, died on Saturday in London. He was 76. He had been hospitalized for pneumonia, which may have brought on a heart attack, said his agent, Nicki Stoddart.

Tough Love for Seau Patriots linebacker Junior Seau was an unwilling participant in his final tackle Sunday. Midway through the fourth quarter, Seau was tackled on the sideline by a fan who jumped out of the stands at Gillette Stadium. At first, he said, he thought one of his teammates had jumped him while celebrating the Patriots' 47-7 win over the Cardinals. ''He got an unassisted tackle, whoever he was,'' Seau said. ''We rolled around, said 'Merry Christmas,' and they pulled him away.''

To his family, friends and loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Frank J. Citing the right of all people to have “access to their heritage without pornographic restraint,” a descendant of Louis XIV has filed for an emergency injunction to halt an exhibition of Jeff Koons’s sculptures at the Château de Versailles, Agence-France Presse reported. Prince Charles-Emmanuel de Bourbon-Parme has asked an administrative court to halt the exhibition, called “Jeff Koons Versailles,” which juxtaposes an encased display of vacuum cleaners and a giant balloon dog, above, with the palace’s portraits of French royalty, and includes a sculpture of a bare-breasted woman holding a pink panther, among other works. In his complaint the prince called the show “a desecration and an attack on the respect due to the dead,” according to Agence-France Presse. The exhibition, which has had more than 500,000 visitors since its September opening, is scheduled to close on Jan. 4.

Ballet BC, the Vancouver company, has been given a holiday reprieve. On Tuesday it announced that it had sold 12,000 tickets to its year-end performances of “The Nutcracker,” featuring the Moscow City Ballet, The Georgia Straight newspaper reported. That amount is enough to keep alive the production, which Ballet BC committed to before it laid off its dance company; its artistic director, John Alleyne; and other employees in November. The company can now reorganize and present a new business plan to creditors, but it said it needed about $165,000 to rehire Mr. Alleyne and its dancers. In February Ballet BC plans to present a new version of “Carmen” by the choreographer Jean Grand-Maître.

Adam Goldstein, who performs as DJ AM, has filed a lawsuit stemming from a September plane crash in which he and the punk musician Travis Barker were injured and four people were killed. On Sept. 19 a private jet on which Mr. Goldstein and Mr. Barker were to fly home from a concert in South Carolina crashed on the runway at Columbia Metropolitan Airport. On Tuesday Mr. Goldstein filed suit against the charter companies involved in the flight, as well as Learjet and Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the estates of two pilots killed in the accident, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Barker has filed similar suits, as has the widow of Mr. Barker’s assistant, Chris Baker, who was also killed.

Official results for the next census will not be released for a few years. But it is never too early to predict how population changes might affect the makeup of Congress through the next reapportionment. A report released this week predicts significant changes in the makeup of the House of Representatives in the next decade that could see the South continuing to gain even more seats. The report cautioned that current economic factors could affect some of the population trends driving the most recent predictions.

A wintry mix of snow and ice set off scattered delays and cancellations at transportation hubs around the country on Wednesday, one of the busiest travel days of the year, forcing thousands to spend Christmas Eve camped out in airport terminals and railroad and bus stations. Some of the thorniest problems were at Chicago O'Hare International Airport, where harsh weather left a four-inch blanket of snow and allowed only three of four runways to be open for much of the day.

FRIEDMAN--Herman, 87, died peacefully in New York City on December 11. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Edith Friedman; his loving daughter Susan Oppenheim and son-in-law Stanley Oppenheim; and two loving and loved grandchildren Daniel and Joshua Oppenheim. Born in Kralovsky Chlmec, Czechoslovakia in 1921, he was a victim of the Holocaust, surviving the Hungarian Army's forced labor units and the German concentration camps to build a wonderful life for himself and his small family. His life was an epic journey through Europe, Israel, Canada and the United States and exemplified the quiet honor of caring for one's family. A wonderful man of unusual warmth, he will long be remembered as ''Abba'' by his extended family and others he touched.

EVEN a cursory look at the plentitude of wooden, weathered and functionally forgotten snowshoes that often hang crisscrossed above ski lodge fireplaces will reveal a simple truth: not every one of those bentwood and rawhide-laced contraptions were made for the same purpose. Seven-foot-long Athapaskans were used in open spaces where abrupt changes in direction were infrequent; two-foot-long Ojibwas were for speedy jaunts through changing terrain. Compared with the highly technical snowshoes of today, such a drastic variation in shape and size may seem surreal. But a similar, albeit more nuanced, observation is applicable to today's shoes when it comes to functionality. Though size varies less, there is now a snowshoe for all but the most extreme of snowy traverses: packed trails, backcountry climbs, even lake walks.

RAYMOND--Dorothy Sarnoff, age 94, died peacefully on December 20, 2008, predeceased by her husband Milton Raymond, her brother Dr. Robert Sarnoff, and her sister Elaine Sarnoff. Dorothy will be remembered by the many charities she supported. Dorothy's life consisted of one amazing, successful career after another. She performed as a concert soloist, opera singer, Broadway actress, and TV guest performer. Dorothy was an author, lecturer and speech teacher through Speech Dynamics. She may best be remembered for her performance as Lady Thiang in the original 1951 Broadway production of Roger and Hammerstein's ''The King and I'' where she sang a song which truly described her life -''Something Wonderful''. Interment private.

A decision by Walt Disney has left C. S. Lewis's enchanted wardrobe a little more bare. The company said it would not help finance and produce the next movie in the ''Chronicles of Narnia'' series, based on Lewis's fantasy novels, The Hollywood Reporter said. The franchise, jointly produced and financed by Disney and Walden Media, had a hit with its first entry, ''The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe,'' featuring Aslan, right. That 2005 film grossed $745 million worldwide. But a sequel, ''Prince Caspian,'' released in May, grossed $419 million. Disney had an option to take part in a third movie, ''The Voyage of the Dawn Treader,'' which it chose not to exercise. ''Dawn Treader'' is in preproduction for a 2010 release.

Michael Phelps, who took several months off after the Beijing Games, said he would resume training in early February to get ready for the national championships in July. ''We're basically going to take this whole year to try to get him to a point where he can really get into serious training in the fall of 2009,'' Bob Bowman, Phelps's coach, told USA Today.

As President Bush settles in for his last Christmas in office, he has been busy handing out presents to some of his top aides. And they are not the kind that require wrapping. The White House announced on Wednesday the appointments of members of the president's inner circle to high-profile boards and commissions, where they will serve far beyond Jan. 20, the end of Mr. Bush's term in office.

(ABC) WALT DISNEY WORLD CHRISTMAS DAY PARADERegis Philbin and Kelly Ripa, above with a friend, are joined by Ryan Seacrest to oversee the 25th annual holiday festivities, including parades of Disney and Pixar characters, at Walt Disney World in Florida and Disneyland in California. Miley Cyrus sets the mood for this two-hour special with a rendition of ''Santa Claus Is Coming to Town,'' and her father, Billy Ray Cyrus, will rock 'n' roll with his single ''Run Rudolph Run.'' (TCM) MERRY CHRISTMAS! Turner Classic Movies begins a holiday film festival with ''Remember the Night'' (1940), starring Fred MacMurray as an assistant district attorney who takes a beautiful shoplifter (Barbara Stanwyck, above, with MacMurray) home with him for Christmas, followed at 8 a.m. by ''Three Godfathers'' (1936), a retelling of the Nativity story that follows three fugitives (Chester Morris, Lewis Stone and Walter Brennan) as they bring a newborn out of the desert to safety. And then it's time for the Big 3: ''The Greatest Story Ever Told'' (1965), at 9:30; ''King of Kings'' (1961), at 1 p.m.; and ''Ben-Hur'' (1959), at 4. The short promotional film ''Ben-Hur: Behind the Scenes With Glenn H. Randall & Yakima Canutt'' (1959) wraps up the festivities at 7:46.

Charles Aznavour, the singer-songwriter and actor, was granted citizenship in Armenia by the decree of that nation’s president on Friday, Agence-France Presse reported. Though known as the Frank Sinatra of France, Mr. Aznavour, 84, was born Shahnour Aznavourian in Paris to Armenian parents, and has been an advocate of charity efforts to benefit Armenia; he organized a series of benefit concerts after the 1988 earthquakes there, and is the country’s permanent delegate to Unesco. He is also the first French performer to have a platinum record in Europe, and his songs have been covered by English-speaking singers from Elvis Costello to Liza Minnelli. In a statement, the Armenian president, Serge Sargsyan, said that he had granted citizenship to Mr. Aznavour, “the prominent singer and public figure, a hero of the Armenian people.”

Having hosted one week of performances by the recent revival of “American Buffalo,” the Belasco Theater will next provide a home for Lincoln Center Theater’s coming revival of August Wilson’s “Joe Turner’s Come and Gone,” Playbill reported. The play, the one of 10 in Wilson’s Century Cycle, is set in 1911 and tells the story of a man recently freed from a chain gang who comes to a Pittsburgh boarding house in search of his wife. It will be directed by Bartlett Sher, and is scheduled to begin previews on March 19 and open on April 16. Casting has not been announced.

You may not recognize the name of Patrick Halling but if you’re a Beatles fan you’ve surely heard his work: he played violin on the recording of “All You Need Is Love,” and is among the musicians asking European Union lawmakers to extend the period during which they can receive royalties for their recorded work, Bloomberg News reported. Mr. Halling, a classically trained violinist, said that he would lose thousands of dollars a year in income when songs by the Beatles, Tom Jones and the Moody Blues fall into the public domain. “I feel it is unfair that it should just be finished,” Mr. Halling said, according to Bloomberg. Under current European Union law, contributing musicians receive royalties from songs for 50 years; the British government is considering supporting an extension of that period to 75 years. The European Parliament will debate a possible extension in 2009.

Days after announcing that it had sold enough tickets to its year-end performances of “The Nutcracker” to keep the production alive, Ballet BC, the Vancouver dance company, has canceled a spring tour, the CBC reported. The planned five-city tour of Canada, in which the company was to perform a ballet version of “A Streetcar Named Desire” choreographed by its artistic director, John Alleyne, was scheduled for April. But Graeme Barrit, the president of the ballet, said, “We just can’t afford it,” according to the CBC. In November, Mr. Alleyne and the company’s dancers were laid off by the struggling ballet, which had already committed to its production of “The Nutcracker” featuring the Moscow Classical Ballet. Those shows were able to go on, but the ballet said it still needed about $165,000 to rehire Mr. Alleyne and its dancers.

In a dispute that would leave even the precocious teenager Rory Gilmore at a loss for words, the company of a producer of the comedy-drama “Gilmore Girls” has filed a breach-of-contract lawsuit against the studio that produced the show, The Hollywood Reporter said. In the suit, Gavin Polone, an executive producer of “Gilmore Girls,” said that Warner Brothers Television still owes his company a portion of the profits of the show, which aired on WB from 2000 to 2006, and on CW from 2006 to 2007. Warner Brothers has said that the show was still running at a deficit through its first six seasons. Mr. Polone’s company, Hofflund/Polone, says that Warner Brothers and the WB network have come up “with a scheme that rivals the greed and bravado of any story line defendants could script,” according to The Hollywood Reporter.
Eartha Kitt purred her way across Broadway stages, recording studios and movie and television screens.

I will put in the comment part below my own response to Bob - who agreed to allow me to post his email - and invite readers to give their opinions on some of his interesting ideas:

Chess is not simple, but it can seem uncomplicated compared with the issues swirling around the governance of the game. Recently, there have been problems relating to the staging of a Grand Prix series to select a challenger for the world championship and an incident at which a top player failed to take a drug test, violating rules of the World Chess Federation that some top players feel are unnecessary.

Both of these teams had visions of a B.C.S. bowl appearance at one point this season. But that was before both stumbled at season's end. North Carolina lost two of its last three and West Virginia two of its last four. The Tar Heels are in a bowl game for the first time since 2004, but they also have wins against the Big East teams Rutgers and Connecticut this year. Could the Mountaineers be the third team from the conference to lose to Butch Davis's squad? Meanwhile, West Virginia is in its seventh consecutive bowl game, a run that includes last year's surprisingly decisive victory over Oklahoma, a win that secured the coaching job for Bill Stewart.

The question coming into this one is whether Miami is going to be able to stop Cal's Jahvid Best, who is one of the better running backs in college football. Miami was making a surprising run at the A.C.C. title until it got absolutely torched by Georgia Tech, giving up over 400 yards on a nationally televised Thursday night game. The Hurricanes followed that up with a stinker against North Carolina State in which they gave up over 200 yards on the ground. Cal loves to run the ball, with Best coming off a team-record 311 yards and 4 touchdowns in a blowout victory over Washington. This one is going to be played in the Bay Area, which is a huge plus for the Bears and is a long trip for the Hurricanes. At the end of the day this is an intriguing meeting between two teams that haven't played each other since 1990 and is a good Saturday night game on the weekend between Christmas and New Year's. Nothing wrong with that.

I've got to be honest. This is very tough for me, but I need to get this off my chest: Fred Bierman picked Wisconsin to play in a B.C.S. game. This is true. He did this on his own, without taking any input from an outside source (such as myself). From such great expectations came a grand stumble to mediocrity, as the Badgers needed a three-game winning streak (including an overtime win over Cal Poly of the F.C.S.) to secure their seventh consecutive bowl appearance. Similarly, Florida State continued its recent malaise with an up-and-down 8-4 season. While an improvement over back-to-back 7-6 finishes, these aren't your father's Seminoles. Let's see which team brings its best effort to a bowl neither expected to attend.

Igor Gaysinsky was so awestruck by what he saw on television Friday morning that he felt compelled to witness it in person. So he hopped on the train near his home in the Great Kills neighborhood and rode it straight to the scene: a derailment at the end of the Staten Island Railway."Because I don't hear about too many accidents happening on Staten Island that are involved with the transit, I was like, 'Wow, let's check this out,'" said Mr. Gaysinsky, 21, who uses the railway to get to and from his job at a car dealership. At one point, he left the derailment to visit a friend, but then returned to gawk a second time, he said.

Guest Humorist | Daniel KurtzmanIn a year when everyone was looking for a bailout, politics really came through in the clutch for comedy. We had a governor gone rogue, a reverend gone wild, imaginary snipers and, of course, everyone's favorite mavericky, Prada-wearing hockey mom. As a salute to those who made this the funniest year since, well, last year, here's a look back at 2008's most memorable feats and foibles, in words and glorious video:

Economy | The global economy came tumbling down so quickly because of frictionless. instantaneously networked global finance, a columnist writes -- so why couldn't it rebound at comparable speed? After all, global politics have remained fairly stable thus far, and consumers in many places (the thrifty Chinese, the rich Arabs) are still in relatively good shape. Forget the Great Depression: "The way events have unfolded over the past few months simply has no precedent." [Wall Street Journal]

Culture | "As a proud Jew, I want America to know about our accomplishment," writes the columnist Joel Stein. "Yes, we control Hollywood. Without us, you'd be flipping between 'The 700 Club' and 'Davey and Goliath' on TV all day." How about these P.R. slogans? "Hollywood: From the people who brought you the Bible"; and "Hollywood: If you enjoy TV and movies, then you probably like Jews after all." [Los Angeles Times]

Mortgage rates have dropped a lot in recent weeks, which is a good thing. But there's still a huge spread between mortgage rates and rates on federal debt. Here's the spread between conventional 30-year mortgages and 10-year Treasuries (10-year because most mortgages get paid off early, when houses are sold, and the average duration is about 10 years.) This spread was historically stable at about 150 basis points, but has been nearly double that lately.

I'm in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, and dropped by the Tuol Sleng genocide museum, where I soldiered through the haunting photos of the victims and pictures of tortures. The museum is on the site of the main torture center used by the Khmer Rouge during their brutal genocide in the 1970's, and I was with my interpreter, whose father was executed by the Khmer Rouge.

This 2,624-square-foot house was built around 1890. The 48-acre property is called the Sheets Farm and has rolling pastures, exposed rock outcroppings, mature hardwoods and a natural spring to supply water. The house has original fixtures, windows and wood floors and one and a half bathrooms. There are a barn and a log cabin; both are structurally sound but need updating. Listing agent: Steve White, Roy Wheeler Realty Company; (434) 951-5112; www.virginiafineproperties.com.

TROMBONE SHORTY Troy Andrews, better known as Trombone Shorty, has been a precocious darling of New Orleans's live music scene for so long that he has grown up in the meantime. Twenty-two now, he travels and performs with Orleans Avenue, his jam band, making music that's tailored for parties, with the running commentary of march-rhythm funk drums through it all.

GODFREY--Mildred, of New Rochelle, died December 23, 2008 at age 94. Mrs. Godfrey was the Principal of PS 119 Bronx (Woodlawn) and was later the Founding Principal of PS 153 Bronx (Co-Op City). She and her husband Joseph were award winning volunteers at the NY Botanical Gardens and recipients of the NYS Legislative Achievement Award. Survived by her husband, sons, Henry and Jonathan, four grandchildren, and many nieces and nephews. Funeral Service Sunday 10am Temple Israel New Rochelle followed by interment at Sharon Gardens. For more information, Zion Memorial Chapel. 914-381-1809
ART Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. Hours vary during the holiday season; please confirm with the gallery or museum.

JAFFE--Phyllis S.,an early practitioner of education labor law and wife of the late Frederick Jaffe, died at home in Ossining, NY, on December 22, 2008. She was 83. Mrs. Jaffe served in the Women's Army Corps during WWll, graduated from Columbia Law School in 1949, and served as the president of the Ossining Board of Education 1966-69. Mrs. Jaffe led Plunkett and Jaffe's Westchester County office from 1975 until her retirement in 2003. Her cases included Immediato v. Rye Neck School District in which the U.S. Supreme Court upheld the right of high schools to require community service as a graduation requirement. Mrs. Jaffe was preceded in death by her brother Edwin Shelley. She is survived by and will be missed by her sons Paul, David (wife Leslie); and Rick (wife Kim) four grandchildren, Dara, Gary, Eli and Julian; her brother, Heywood, (wife Maritza), their daughter and granddaughter; and sister-in-law Florence, her children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Donations can be made in the name of Phyllis Jaffe to The Clear View School (serving children with special needs), 480 Albany Post Road, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10510. The family (pauljaffe@verizon.net) is planning a memorial service to be held at a later date.

CHUCK BERRY Chuck Berry is given a lovely tribute by Mos Def in ''Cadillac Records,'' the current film about the Chess label, but the man ain't dead yet. Resilient beyond all reasonable measure, Mr. Berry is 82 and not at all worried about it. His hits ''Johnny B. Goode'' and ''Maybellene'' helped form the bedrock of modern rock 'n' roll, and in his performances he doesn't stray far from those reliables.
YO LA TENGO, THE FEELIES, VIVIAN GIRLS

MY MORNING JACKET The artiest of Southern rock bands, My Morning Jacket could easily have made endless follow-ups to riffing, pealing guitar-driven rockers like ''One Big Holiday.'' But Jim James and his band keep wandering elsewhere: toward both reggae and Britpop-flavored, keyboard-centered songs on the album ''Z,'' and into funk on this year's ''Evil Urges'' (ATO). Old or new, My Morning Jacket's ringing, expansive songs are at home in big open spaces.

YOU'RE skiing slowly on an intermediate trail and you suddenly slip. You're not out of control -- you weren't going that fast -- but you are off balance. One arm flails behind your head as you teeter and twist backward until your hips awkwardly sit down on the tails of your skis. Then you hear a loud pop in your knee. You probably have just torn the anterior cruciate ligament, which in the last 20 years has become the most common serious injury in skiing, dwarfing the number of broken legs. You face major reconstructive surgery and at least six months of grueling rehabilitation.

THERE'S a school of thought that everyone should ring in the New Year at least once in Times Square. Indeed, the experience can be both breathtaking and unifying. It's cold, and many of the people in the crowd are extremely inebriated, but you become part of something bigger, much as 2,668 Waterford crystals combine to form the glittering countdown ball. One thing this Big Event is not, however, is child-friendly. Sure, there are a few children sprinkled here and there in the crowd, but Times Square -- at least on New Year's Eve -- isn't exactly child's play. Thankfully, there are plenty of other options for parents who aren't ready to confine their families to house parties or pay exorbitant babysitting fees, especially since many destinations and resorts now cater to the under-12 set.

A HEALTHY NEW YEAR'S EVE Ah, the holidays. The time of year that we stare glassy-eyed at the congealed grease in our Tupperware containers and wonder how long it's going to take to metabolize all those leftovers, not to mention the other food and alcohol that have been unavoidable for nearly a month. This weekend there's a simple solution: digest. But next week, there are a number of tours that will help you start next year on the right foot, so to speak.

Every December, hundreds of people, if not thousands, make a pilgrimage to a corner of the Bronx to stare, in awe, at megalit renditions of the Virgin Mary, St. Theresa, assorted cherubim and the Savior himself. For those who worship instead at the altar of celebrity, the site displays glittering lifelike versions of their saints as well: Rita Hayworth, Brigitte Bardot, Nicole Kidman, Audrey Hepburn, Vivian Leigh, Joan Collins and Elizabeth Taylor, all exquisitely dressed in gowns fit for the runway, designer handbags on their arms.

REIS--Arthur Jr.,beloved father of Arthur H. Reis, Diane Reis and Pamela Reis, devoted brother of Hilda Bijur, and former business leader in menswear manufacturing, died peacefully on December 23rd in his home in Manhattan from multiple illnesses. A lifelong New Yorker, born in 1916, he graduated from Deerfield Academy and Princeton University, for which he became a prodigious fundraiser, winning awards annually for his loyal service to the university he loved. In 2007, he was awarded Princeton's highest honor for service, the Harold Helm Distinguished Service Award for exemplary and sustained service to the University. After becoming the youngest executive at Pan American Airways, he joined the military in World War II, rising to the rank of captain in the Air Transport Command and received a medal for outstanding performance. For 32 years he served as president of Robert Reis & Co., a family apparel business started by his grandfather in 1885 and run by his father until 1947. As a result of his experience atop a company at age 31, he co-founded the Young Presidents' Organization, a group of business presidents under age 39 dedicated to developing modern management methods. He was a member of the Executive Committee of the New York Chamber of Commerce and was appointed by New York Governor Dewey in 1954 to the Committee on the Refugee Relief Act to coordinate placing refugees in New York State. After ending his career in manufacturing in 1978, he became a licensed real estate broker for Albert Ashforth, Inc. He served for decades as president of the board of his New York cooperative apartment building. He was married to his cherished wife Muriel Henle Reis for 55 years until her death in 2008. He was loved by his grandchildren, Chloe Hyman, Mara McCartin, Elisa McCartin and Lucas Hyman, his daughter-and sons-in-law Marianne Reis, Joseph McCartin and Kevin Hyman, his nieces and nephews, Vicky Bijur, Arthur Bijur, Fred Vogel and Carol Vogel. A loving and generous family member, a deeply loyal friend and a devoted contributor to his community, he will be deeply missed by all who knew him. Contributions in his memory may be made to Class of 1939 Memorial Scholarship Fund, Princeton University, P.O. Box 5357, Princeton, NJ 08543-5357.

IT always starts as a craving: our yearning to go someplace new or the anticipation of revisiting a place we love. Since we've been married, my husband, Marc, and I have tried to take a European vacation every year in the late fall or early winter. For us, there's something about Europe during that time of year, when the light is gray and brooding and the city we've chosen feels like it's ours alone. That time of year is when the food tastes better, and there are no lines for anything.

YOU'VE got to really want to go to Molokai, the least visited of the major Hawaiian islands. Its stunning beaches and rugged jungle interior invite exploration, and the tragic tale of its leper colony, where native Hawaiians used to be summarily exiled and a small number still choose to live, inspires an unavoidable curiosity. But hotel rooms are few, tourist amenities scarce and developers actively discouraged. Molokai stands apart from all things commercial, existing on its own terms. Yet for those of us who live on these islands and remember an older Hawaii -- magical, sensuous, isolated -- or for those who want to find some sense of how things were on Maui, the Big Island and Kauai before those islands were drawn into the hustle and flow of Oahu, Molokai is more than worth the trouble. Its lifestyle is more traditionally Polynesian, its people reserved but, when their veneer is cracked, warm and full of an ancient joie de vivre.

RAYMOND--Dorothy Sarnoff, age 94, died peacefully on December 20, 2008, predeceased by her husband Milton Raymond, her brother Dr. Robert Sarnoff, and her sister Elaine Sarnoff. Dorothy will be remembered by the many charities she supported. Dorothy's life consisted of one amazing, successful career after another. She performed as a concert soloist, opera singer, Broadway actress, and TV guest performer. Dorothy was an author, lecturer and speech teacher through Speech Dynamics. She may best be remembered for her performance as Lady Thiang in the original 1951 Broadway production of Roger and Hammerstein's ''The King and I'' where she sang a song which truly described her life -''Something Wonderful''. Interment private.

CLARKE--Brian Warner, Jr. Brian (Boru) Clarke died December 25 in Utica, NY, where he was born in 1921. He worked in military ship construction before joining the Army. On August 30, 1945, he was among the first American troops to fly into Japan. Boru graduated from Utica College in 1949 and moved to Greenwich, CT. He worked for Burlington Industries in New York City, and, in 1980, returned upstate to live in Clinton, NY. Except during the War years, all Boru's summer vacations since 1930 were spent at his family house on the West Canada Creek in Barneveld, NY. He is survived by his wife Ann; daughters Ann, Catherine and Margaret; son-in-law Peter Rinaldi; grandchildren JB Rinaldi, and Amy and Marley Silverman; sisters Margaret Howland and Catherine Cardamone. He was predeceased by sisters Agnes Kernan and Marietta von Bernuth; brothers W. Tyler Clarke and Roderick Clarke; and his daughter Phoebe.

With half its land below sea level, the country plans to prevent flooding caused by global warming "before anyone's feet are wet," by erecting dykes and levees high enough for the sea levels of 2200. Samuel P. Huntington, an influential political scientist and longtime Harvard University professor, died at the age of 81 on Wednesday, according to an obituary on Harvard's Web site. Mr. Huntington's most famous thesis - that world conflicts stem from the competing cultural identities of seven or eight "civilizations" - became a fundamental, if controversial, premise of post-Cold War foreign policy theory. His emphasis on ancient religious empires, as opposed to states or ethnicities, gained even more cachet after the Sept. 11 attacks.

Charles Aznavour, above, the singer-songwriter and actor, was granted citizenship in Armenia by the decree of that country’s president on Friday, Agence-France Presse reported. Though known as the Frank Sinatra of France, Mr. Aznavour, 84, was born Shahnour Aznavourian in Paris to Armenian parents and has been an advocate of charity efforts to benefit Armenia. He organized a series of benefit concerts after the 1988 earthquakes there and is the country’s permanent delegate to Unesco. He is also the first French performer to have a platinum record in Europe, and his songs have been covered by English-speaking singers from Elvis Costello to Liza Minnelli. The president of Armenia, Serge Sargsyan, said in a statement that he had granted citizenship to Mr. Aznavour, whom he called a “prominent singer and public figure” and “a hero of the Armenian people.”.

What if you could just take a pill and all of a sudden remember to pay your bills on time? What if, thanks to modern neuroscience, you could, simultaneously, make New Year's Eve plans, pay the mortgage, call the pediatrician, consolidate credit card debt and do your job -- well -- without forgetting dentist appointments or neglecting to pick up your children at school? Would you do it? Tune out the distractions of our online, on-call, too-fast A.D.D.-ogenic world with focus and memory-enhancing medications like Ritalin or Adderall? Stay sharp as a knife -- no matter how overworked and sleep-deprived -- with a mental-alertness-boosting drug like the anti-narcolepsy medication Provigil?

RAYMOND--Dorothy Sarnoff, age 94, died peacefully on December 20, 2008, predeceased by her husband Milton Raymond, her brother Dr. Robert Sarnoff, and her sister Elaine Sarnoff. Dorothy will be remembered by the many charities she supported. Dorothy's life consisted of one amazing, successful career after another. She performed as a concert soloist, opera singer, Broadway actress, and TV guest performer. Dorothy was an author, lecturer and speech teacher through Speech Dynamics. She may best be remembered for her performance as Lady Thiang in the original 1951 Broadway production of Roger and Hammerstein's ''The King and I'' where she sang a song which truly described her life -''Something Wonderful''. Interment private.
