CROCKETT--David W.,84, former Vice-President of the New York Typographical Union No. 6, died Monday, December 22, 2008. Mr. Crockett, born in Brooklyn, June 23, 1924, enlisted in the Marine Corps during World Ward II and served in the Pacific and China. Following the war, Mr. Crockett worked as a compositor (printer) at the New York Times and became involved in union affairs. He was elected as delegate to the International Typographical Union, Chapel Chairman and eventually Vice-President of Local 6 under President Bertram A. Powers. Along with Mr. Powers, he led the local through tumultuous times for the Newspaper and printing industry in New York during the 1960s until the 1980s. Mr. Crockett was from a family of printers. His grandfather, Walter E. Crockett, who worked for the New York Sun for many years and his father, David H. Crockett, was a printer at the New York Daily News, and for many years was responsible for the layout of the centerfold that was a prominent feature of the paper. Following retirement Mr. Crockett devoted himself to woodworking and his family. In 1948 he married Dolores A. Hunt, who survives him. He is also survived by his son, Dr. David P. Crockett and his daughter-in-law, Christine of Brooklyn, New York, a second son, Mr. Richard H. Crockett and his daughter-inlaw Alison of Huntington, New York and four grandchildren, Richard T. Crockett of Flagstaff, AZ and Matthew, Gavin and Anna of Huntington, New York. Mr. Crockett is also survived by a brother, Albert E. Crockett, of Lake Grove, NY. A wake will be held Saturday, December 27, 2008, at McLaughlin and Sons, 9620 3rd Ave., Brooklyn, NY. Interment will be Monday, December 29 at Calverton National Cemetery.

ROSENBLUM--Robert A. (Bob), died peacefully on December 23, at the age of 83, after a long and debilitating illness. He born October 11, 1925 in New York, son of Rose L. Rosenblum and Col. Abraham J. Rosenblum. He attended The Citadel in Charleston, South Carolina; New York University and received an MBA from Columbia University. He left The Citadel in 1943 to volunteer to serve in North Africa during WWII, rather than wait for his commission. Following the War he returned to the US, where he completed his education, received his MBA and married Judith Raumann in 1953. As an officer in the Reserves, he continued his connection with the military, ultimately being promoted to the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. He retired from the military in 1961, but was referred to as ''The Colonel'' by his friends and neighbors in the Five Towns, Long Island for most of his life. He owned and ran an independent insurance brokerage in Manhattan, but still found time for a wide range of community activities. He was Commodore of the Woodmere Bay Yacht Club in East Rockaway, NY; he was an active participant at Temple Sinai, in Cedarhurst, NY, where he served as President of the Men's Club and where he relished his acting roles in the community theatre group; he taught at The State University of NY at Farmingdale and at Pace College in Manhattan. Leaving Cedarhurst in the 1980s, he moved to Manhattan and divided his time between New York, Westhampton Beach and Key Biscayne, Florida; to which he retired in 2003. Ever the avid military man, he started every morning of his life with the same rigid exercise regimen that has been inculcated into him in The Citadel at age 17. An avid reader, he was incredibly strong, and he fought to the very end, a product of a longtime of military bearing. he is survived by his wife of 55 years, Judith Rosenblum (Zador); his daughter Amy Rosenblum and son-in-law Ted Savaglio; his son Michael Rosenblum and his wife Lisa; and two grandchildren, Adam and Brett Savaglio; his brother Lt. General Donald E. Rosenblum and Nancy of Savannah, Georgia, Sister-inlaw Betty Piccoli, Milan, Italy and nine nieces and nephews. Funeral on Sunday, December 28 10:00am at The Riverside 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York.

The music was loud in the Jets' locker room Friday, and the howls of laughter were even louder. No. 6 PHILADELPHIA EAGLESat No. 3 MINNESOTA VIKINGS 4:30 p.m. Sunday, FoxNobody -- not even Andy Reid -- could have imagined that benching quarterback Donovan McNabb would eventually lead to the playoffs. But after McNabb hit rock bottom on Nov. 23, the Eagles (9-6-1, wild card) have gone 4-1 to surge into the playoffs. They will encounter Reid's former offensive coordinator, Brad Childress, whose Vikings (10-6, N.F.C. North champion) bear striking similarities to the Eagles. The Vikings pass rusher Jared Allen will give the Eagles' protection headaches all day. But McNabb's mobility makes him far better equipped to anticipate and escape pressure than the inexperienced Vikings quarterback Tarvaris Jackson is to handle the Eagles' blitz-happy defense. As much attention as will be paid to the quarterbacks, both offenses rely heavily on their running backs -- the Vikings on Adrian Peterson, the Eagles on the all-around threat Brian Westbrook.

Now, I'm not a doctor, but the only logical prescription for no more regular-season N.F.L. football is, well, more football. College football, that is, where Northern Illinois meets Louisiana Tech in the 33rd annual Independence Bowl. While this year's game may not have the cachet of last year's Alabama-Colorado matchup or the Alabama-Oklahoma State game of two years ago, it's still a bowl game, albeit one lacking any major draw or hype. Nevertheless, Northern Illinois revitalized its program with one of the biggest turnarounds in the F.B.S. in 2008 (from 2-10 to .500) and Louisiana Tech won five of its last seven to make a bowl, so the potential is there for a solid bowl game. And it will help take your mind off the Jets.

In “The Remedist” (Dec. 14), Robert Skidelsky says that John Maynard Keynes has been ignored for too long and that we should “build a new structure on the foundations that Keynes laid.” While Keynes was indispensable in leading the world out of the Great Depression, we can no longer continue to focus on economic growth as the solution to our problems, which may have worked when we were in an emptier world with seemingly endless supplies of natural resources as in the 1940s. Today’s crises demand new visions of an economy based on creating livelihoods while living within the limits of our planet. Ecological economists like Herman Daly and others offer a vision of a steady state economy that uses resources at the rate that the earth can replace them. Keynes has had his day.

To the Editor: The Weekend in New York column “The Weekender’s Weekender Plugs the Last Holes” (Dec. 14), asks, “Who in their right mind comes to New York for just a weekend?” How about for the day? We live in South Florida, shop online for the cheapest fares, fly up very early in the morning and back the same night. No huge hotel bills, and we take the M60 bus from La Guardia — quick and easy.

To the Editor: The delectable Journeys column “Le Tour du Chocolat” (Dec. 14) neglected to mention Debauve & Gallais, at 30, rue des St.-Pères, in the Seventh Arrondissement in Paris. Its plain dark bars are superb; there is also a shop in Manhattan, at 20 East 69th Street.

To the Editor: A point unmentioned in the lyrical description of Sea Ranch in “Utopia by the Sea” (Dec. 14) is that the community stands close to the northern end of the notoriously hyperactive San Andreas Fault and, more ominously, not too far away from the Mendocino Triple Junction, the geologically intriguing undersea location where the three tectonic plates — the North American, the Pacific and the Gorda — meet and grind against one other.

REIS--Arthur Jr.,beloved father of Arthur H. Reis, Diane Reis and Pamela Reis, devoted brother of Hilda Bijur, and former business leader in menswear manufacturing, died peacefully on December 23rd in his home in Manhattan from multiple illnesses. A lifelong New Yorker, born in 1916, he graduated from Deerfield Academy and Princeton University, for which he became a prodigious fundraiser, winning awards annually for his loyal service to the university he loved. In 2007, he was awarded Princeton's highest honor for service, the Harold Helm Distinguished Service Award for exemplary and sustained service to the University. After becoming the youngest executive at Pan American Airways, he joined the military in World War II, rising to the rank of captain in the Air Transport Command and received a medal for outstanding performance. For 32 years he served as president of Robert Reis & Co., a family apparel business started by his grandfather in 1885 and run by his father until 1947. As a result of his experience atop a company at age 31, he co-founded the Young Presidents' Organization, a group of business presidents under age 39 dedicated to developing modern management methods. He was a member of the Executive Committee of the New York Chamber of Commerce and was appointed by New York Governor Dewey in 1954 to the Committee on the Refugee Relief Act to coordinate placing refugees in New York State. After ending his career in manufacturing in 1978, he became a licensed real estate broker for Albert Ashforth, Inc. He served for decades as president of the board of his New York cooperative apartment building. He was married to his cherished wife Muriel Henle Reis for 55 years until her death in 2008. He was loved by his grandchildren, Chloe Hyman, Mara McCartin, Elisa McCartin and Lucas Hyman, his daughter-and sons-in-law Marianne Reis, Joseph McCartin and Kevin Hyman, his nieces and nephews, Vicky Bijur, Arthur Bijur, Fred Vogel and Carol Vogel. A loving and generous family member, a deeply loyal friend and a devoted contributor to his community, he will be deeply missed by all who knew him. Contributions in his memory may be made to Class of 1939 Memorial Scholarship Fund, Princeton University, P.O. Box 5357, Princeton, NJ 08543-5357.
Television Ginia Bellafante

THERE'S nothing quite like freezing rain and foot-deep slush to make a thermal bodysuit look more appealing than a slinky party dress. Forget the sequins and five-inch stilettos. Right now, downing Champagne in a snuggly romper sounds like the best idea around. Of course, Alexander Wang didn't have that image in mind when he designed this one-piece for his resort collection. He imagined a girl hanging out in it on a motorboat, then pulling on a black blazer, platform boots and a captain's hat to hit town. Call us both crazy, but that seems like a wonderfully decadent look in which to ring in the New Year. Alexander Wang Thermal Onesie, $228 at Oak; oaknyc.com.

ROSENBLUM--Robert A. (Bob), died peacefully on December 23, at the age of 83, after a long and debilitating illness. He born October 11, 1925 in New York, son of Rose L. Rosenblum and Col. Abraham J. Rosenblum. He attended The Citadel in Charleston, South Carolina; New York University and received an MBA from Columbia University. He left The Citadel in 1943 to volunteer to serve in North Africa during WWII, rather than wait for his commission. Following the War he returned to the US, where he completed his education, received his MBA and married Judith Raumann in 1953. As an officer in the Reserves, he continued his connection with the military, ultimately being promoted to the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. He retired from the military in 1961, but was referred to as ''The Colonel'' by his friends and neighbors in the Five Towns, Long Island for most of his life. He owned and ran an independent insurance brokerage in Manhattan, but still found time for a wide range of community activities. He was Commodore of the Woodmere Bay Yacht Club in East Rockaway, NY; he was an active participant at Temple Sinai, in Cedarhurst, NY, where he served as President of the Men's Club and where he relished his acting roles in the community theatre group; he taught at The State University of NY at Farmingdale and at Pace College in Manhattan. Leaving Cedarhurst in the 1980s, he moved to Manhattan and divided his time between New York, Westhampton Beach and Key Biscayne, Florida; to which he retired in 2003. Ever the avid military man, he started every morning of his life with the same rigid exercise regimen that has been inculcated into him in The Citadel at age 17. An avid reader, he was incredibly strong, and he fought to the very end, a product of a longtime of military bearing. he is survived by his wife of 55 years, Judith Rosenblum (Zador); his daughter Amy Rosenblum and son-in-law Ted Savaglio; his son Michael Rosenblum and his wife Lisa; and two grandchildren, Adam and Brett Savaglio; his brother Lt. General Donald E. Rosenblum and Nancy of Savannah, Georgia, Sister-inlaw Betty Piccoli, Milan, Italy and nine nieces and nephews. Funeral on Sunday, December 28 10:00am at The Riverside 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York.

BRETT FAVRE vs. MIAMI PASS RUSH All week, Favre fueled speculation about the health of his right shoulder by talking about the hits it had taken. Officially, he is not injured, but he again said he had not undergone any tests. And if Joey Porter and the Dolphins' pass rush can get to him, Favre's throwing could deteriorate as the game wears on. Porter ranks second in the league with 17.5 sacks this season, behind only the Dallas Cowboys' DeMarcus Ware, and the Jets' offensive line has allowed Favre to be sacked 30 times this season, putting him in a tie for 22nd in the league. That is why the offensive coordinator Bryan Schottenheimer said that the only way to deal with Porter was by an all-points bulletin to his blockers.
Classical Allan Kozinn

CARPENTER--Edmund Nelson II, died peacefully at home Friday morning, December 19th, surrounded by his immediate family. He was a war hero, an attorney, a statesman, and a lover of history and literature; he was an adoring and uniquely adored husband, father, grandfather, and friend. His life was devoted to country, the Law, social justice and-above all-family. Among innumerable other achievements, he was awarded a Bronze Star in World War II for successful covert missions flown in Dien Bien Phu, formerly French Indo-China. Working in military intelligence, he was a member of the small team that rescued the celebrated Doolittle Raiders who had been trapped behind enemy lines following Pearl Harbor. He was proud of his service, and loved returning to Asia to re-visit places he had been. Throughout his life he held myriad leadership positions in the worlds of Delaware and American law: as Deputy Attorney General for the State of Delaware; as Special Deputy Attorney General for the State of Delaware; as Chairman of numerous advisory committees for the Delaware Supreme Court and the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit; as President of the Delaware Bar Association; and, later, President of the American Judicature Society, which presented him with their Justice Award. He was honored to be a Director, and later President, of Delaware law firm Richards, Layton and Finger, where his community of colleagues was like a second family. After retiring, he worked tirelessly pro bono on various legislative reforms; in 2000, he co-founded Stand Up for what is Right and Just (SURJ), where-alongside former FBI Director Louis J. Freeh-he created a new movement for local legislative reform. He served as Trustee or Trustee Emeritus for many organizations, including Princeton University, where he worked with his fellow trustees during the University's transition to coeducation. He always maintained that the school's motto, dei sub numine viget, actually meant, God went to Princeton. Throughout his life he always found time to be an influential, often anonymous, philanthropist (a word he never would have used in describing himself) through his leadership of a private family foundation. He wrote hundreds of Letters to the Editor of the Wilmington News Journal through the years, arguing for those things he believed in most passionately, perhaps above all the repeal of the Rockefeller-era drug laws that provided for mandatory minimum sentencing. He also held out hope for the decriminalization of drugs (a last Letter to the Editor on this subject was published one week before he died). He loved and found great comfort in literature, and in poetry in particular, and was uniquely drawn to Alfred Tennyson's Ulysses; he loved the lines that read: ''To follow knowledge like a sinking star, beyond the utmost bound of human thought . . . to strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield.'' He had unique charm and profound humility, and he wielded his infamous wit with subtlety and precision. He loved athletics and opera. He was deeply proud to be an American. As a close friend of the family put it recently, he was the closest thing most of us will ever get to knowing James Bond. He is survived by the love of his life, his wife, Carroll Morgan Carpenter; six loving children, Mary Wootten Carpenter, Jeff Carpenter, Katherine Revell Reynolds Carpenter, John Davis Gates Jr., Ashley Gates Jansen, Lea du Pont Carpenter Brokaw, and their spouses; and thirteen loving and loved grandchildren. The family wishes to thank: Drs. Patricia Curtin, M.D., Stephen DeCherney, M.D., Kathleen McNicholas, M.D., Lanny Edelsohn, M.D., Gerald M. Lemole, M.D., Lee S. Cohen, M.D, and Phil Blatt, MD. They also wish to thank especially Elizabeth Lea Carpenter du Pont, Mr. Carpenter's beloved niece who introduced him to his wife, and after whom his youngest daughter was named. A private memorial service was held for immediate family in their home in Wilmington on Saturday, December 20th. Please contact Hardin & Associates at 302-654-9923 for information regarding the memorial service or email information@hardininc.com. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be sent to Princeton University or to Christiana Care Health System of Delaware.

COCO ROCHA, the model whose flashy hair-color transformation is chronicled in great detail in the January issue of Vogue, is apparently not the only woman going red these days. ''Auburns have never been more popular,'' said Louis Licari, the colorist responsible for Ms. Rocha's copper locks (as well as those of Susan Sarandon and Linda Evangelista when she went red back in the '90s). In fact, Mr. Licari has proclaimed red to be the most important color of our time, noting that every hair color formula has turned warmer over the years. ''It simply makes the skin look more radiant,'' he explained. Fortunately, he also believes that every woman can go red -- it's just a matter of picking the right shade.

Troy, Peter R. Taffae, Jessica Pack, Joen Bettmann. Graduated from Poly Prep County Day School, summa cum laude, Rutgers University, member of Phi Beta Kappa Society, Columbia University, M.A. Paul was a writer and teacher. He served in the 75th Infantry Division during Battle of the Bulge. He was awarded the Bronze Star Medal of Valor and the Combat Infantryman's Badge. He was deeply loved by all and will be greatly missed.

It is the Ed Hochuli Bowl for the American Football Conference's West division championship. The Chargers (7-8) would almost surely already be the division champions and preparing for the playoffs if not for the officiating blunder that gave Denver a chance to score the winning touchdown in the Week 2 game between these rivals. Instead, the Broncos (8-7) had a three-game lead with three games to play, but fell apart because of a defense that has been so porous that it more than offsets the top-ranked offense in the A.F.C. As the Broncos have faded, the Chargers, who looked all but dead at the halfway point, have rallied. They have won three in a row, with Philip Rivers throwing nine touchdown passes and one interception in that time.
Pop Ben Ratliff

RAYMOND--Dorothy Sarnoff, age 94, died peacefully on December 20, 2008, predeceased by her husband Milton Raymond, her brother Dr. Robert Sarnoff, and her sister Elaine Sarnoff. She performed as a concert soloist, opera singer, Broadway actress, and TV guest performer. Dorothy was an author, lecturer and speech teacher through Speech Dynamics. JACOBS--Carl Marion III, of New York, Bellport, L.I. and Costa Rica, died peacefully at the age of 92 on December 22, 2008. Carl was the son of Carl Jacobs, Jr. and Frieda Heine Jacobs of Cincinnati, Ohio, where he was born and raised. He was a graduate of the Taft School and Yale University. Carl served in World War II and moved to New York to pursue a career in the theater. He appeared in the original New York production of Tom Stoppard's ''Rosencrantz and Guildenstern20are Dead.'' In addition, he reviewed plays for the Cincinnati Enquirer. Carl was a patron of the arts and progressive causes through the Carl Jacobs Foundation. He supported many exhibitions of the Department of Photography at the Cincinnati Art Museum and as well as donating a number of photographs to the museum. He is survived by his brother Bruce Jacobs of Anacortes, Washington, his sister-in-law Mrs. Stuart Jacobs of Cincinnati and his nieces and nephews as well as his partner Darren Moser of New York. A memorial service will be held in the spring of 2009.

OFFICIAL fuel-economy ratings from the Environmental Protection Agency are in for the 2010 Ford Fusion Hybrid, and Ford says it is ''America's most fuel-efficient midsize car with a certified 41 m.p.g. rating in the city and 36 m.p.g. on the highway.'' Ford had offered the Fusion Hybrid to journalists earlier this month in Southern California for fuel-economy runs of their own. Ford said at the time that the certification process by the E.P.A. was incomplete, but that the company expected the vehicle to achieve ''at least 39 m.p.g.'' Many of the journalists who tested the vehicles actually achieved much better fuel economy than that. I hit the high 40s in my short time driving the car.

DERRICK WARD VS. THE MINNESOTA DEFENSE (AND HISTORY) If Ward, below, can gain 52 yards, he will reach 1,000 and share that distinction with Brandon Jacobs, who has 1,089. Only three sets of N.F.L. running backs have done that in league history, and only four sets of backfield pairs have done it over all. ''I want him to get it, I really do,'' Jacobs said. ''Do whatever it takes. That is a special thing to share with someone like him and as close as we are.'' Ward said: ''We'd love to be a part of history. We'll give all the credit to the offensive line.''

McMANUS--Monsignor Charles. Pastor emeritus of St. Bartholomew's parish in Yonkers, died December 26 at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Yonkers. He was 90. He was ordained 66 years ago. He was a former principal of Archbishop Stepinac High School in White Plains, served at St. Patrick's Cathedral, and was the secretary of the Liturgical Commission. As well as St. Bartholomew's, he served as pastor of St. Bernard's parish in White Plains, was the Episcopal Vicar of southern Westchester, and served as senior priest at St. Gabriel's in the Bronx. Most recently, he was an Episcopal delegate for The Cause for Canonization of Terence Cardinal Cooke. He is survived by his cousins Patrick and Elizabeth Shannon of New York, and John Shannon of Ireland. For information call Riverdale on Hudson Funeral Home 718-884-6100.

SANDO--Steve, passed away suddenly December 23. He was just 48 years old. Steve's television career began in the Midwest after playing football at North Dakota State. His incredible talent and personality eventually brought him to New York, where he was head of operations for WCBS-TV. He moved on to CBS News, where he ran operations for Special Events, Europe and Washington. Steve nurtured field crews, editors and anchors, and lived for the big event. Whether it was Moscow, Gaza, Mogadishu, Kuwait, Kosovo, Haiti, Steve got you on the air .... anytime, everytime and from anywhere. Upon leaving CBS he took the freelance production world by storm. But that was just the resume. Steve was unique. Always bigger than life, brilliant, passionate, musical, deeply loyal and the funniest guy we knew. If we weren't so sad, he'd still have us laughing. Steve leaves behind a mother, brother and sister --all in the Seattle area --and friends everywhere he went. Steve was a great partner and will be missed by all lucky enough to have known him. Eric Ober, Jamie Stolz, Lane Venardos

Fifth Avenue's glitter was enhanced last week by snow. Shoppers on bikes, scooters, carriages and unicycles showed spirit, as did a police horse with sleigh bells on its martingale. On Christmas Eve, church bells could be heard above the sirens of diplomats' motorcades going to the midnight service at St. Patrick's. But the sight to see is Bergdorf Goodman's windows. The 57th Street windows, Nos. 6 and 7, represent deliverers of mail. The details are amazing, as in No. 1, the bird window, of which Nos. 2 and 3 are aspects. Nos. 4 and 5 depict a grotto of shells. Also not to be missed are the 58th Street windows, No, 11; and the bears, No. 12, at Bergdorf's men's store across the way. But the pièce de résistance is the 18th-century confectioner's dream, Nos. 8 and 10. David Hoey, No. 9, designed all this splendor.

MERILL--David, (66), died in Bountiful, Utah on December 24, 2008, three years after being diagnosed with stage four lung cancer. He spent those three years living exactly as he wanted working in his own art gallery in Park City painting and selling his paintings and enjoying life as part of Park City's arts community. He was born on February 2, 1942 in Salt Lake City, the only child of Harold Calderwood (Hal) Merrill and LaNae Wilkinson Merrill. He moved to New York City where he was an art director at Ogilvy and Mather, Art Director of Time Magazine, and while in Westport, Connecticut, principal of David Merrill Design. He moved back to Utah in 2002. He is survived by his mother of Bountiful, Utah, son Nicholas David Merrill of New York City, and cousins Steve Kirts and Mike Wilkinson of Salt Lake City. A Memorial Gathering will be held at Larkin Mortuary, 260 E. South Temple, Salt Lake City on Wednesday, December 31, 2008, 11am, where a visitation will be held Tuesday 6-8pm. In lieu of flowers, please donate for cancer research to Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021. Online condolence at larkinmortuary.com

Address: 428 Harbor Road The Property: Secluded on 2.55 acres high along a winding and hilly private road, this 1901 barn was converted to a 3,800-square-foot farmhouse with four bedrooms, two full baths and two half baths, a study, a root/wine cellar, front and back staircases, and a one-car garage. Quirky but sophisticated, and in need of kitchen and bath updates, this turreted manor is more country retreat than suburban outpost. An open foyer and a second-floor landing overlook the great room. In the tower is a light-filled studio accessible via a ladder staircase from the master bedroom.

FOR more than 40 years, Pirelli has ruled the calendar game, producing highly stylized collectors' items shot by the world's leading photographers. The 2009 edition is no exception. Photographed by Peter Beard, it features a small herd of half-clad supermodels -- Lara Stone, Daria Werbowy and Isabeli Fontana included -- romping with elephants, condor carcasses and big bugs in the wilds of Botswana. But giving it a run for its money this year are French Vogue and Italian Marie Claire, both of which have commissioned high-fashion calendars of their own. The French Vogue version, shot by Terry Richardson, stars 13 rising models, posed pin-up style in Louis Vuitton lingerie: Jourdan Dunn as a sexy nurse (far right), Lakshmi Menon as a bunny. Italian Marie Claire's was photographed by Karl Lagerfeld and features Eva Herzigova (right), playing 12 very glamorous characters. Both come packaged with the January edition of the magazines.

TAKING PHOTOGRAPHS AT LUCY VINCENT BEACH, MARTHA'S VINEYARD, MASS., SEPT. 15, 2008 Michael Wong, 33, a pharmacist from Seattle. ''I was on a photography workshop out in Martha's Vineyard. I don't have much vacation time, so I try to consolidate my vacation with my hobby. The great thing is that you're completely immersed in your subject, and you don't have a care in the world except waking up early and trying to take photos. We were just kind of waiting for the sun to set, and after a couple hours the tide was coming in. I saw these big rocks and I figured I would hop onto a rock to try and get some different shots before the tide completely came in. I'm just trying to balance and not fall off and make a fool of myself and not drop my expensive camera into the water. I was trying to be a little bit more creative, but the jury's out on whether I succeeded or not.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

KALINA--Sophie (nee Rottenberg), age 95, passed away December 23. A determined, courageous woman, devoted her life to preserving Jewish culture and Israel. Born Warsaw, daughter of Rabbi Abraham Rottenberg and Mrs. Sarah Rottenberg. Brilliant student, lawyer, her true career-because of rising anti-semitism and wartime upheavals - became Jewish resistance and service to Israel. Cherishing and cherished by her late husband Michael, met in the Polish resistance, where he was a leader, they endured many horrific adventures together and separately to fight German injustice and war crimes. Resettled in New York after the war, they only had several years together ended by Michael's untimely death from cancer. Sofia loved the arts, especially theater, ballet and classical music, was also an avid bridge player and reader, maintaining all these interests until 90. Despite ravages by strokes her spirit and determination remained intact until her death. She was charitable above all else. The last several years of her life were blessed by the constant, devoted care and company of a dear friend, and her companion and health care giver. Through them Sofia amazingly glowed with health and happiness. The spark of her spirit will never die. May those who remember and honor her carry her spark with them all the days of their lives. Lois Adams, former neighbor, friend

With a new year in sight, we have another opportunity to take note of some of the lives that ended in the past 12 months. This is our 15th annual Lives They Lived issue, and as always, we do not try to be comprehensive or definitive in our choices of the people evoked within these pages. Instead, this is an unabashedly idiosyncratic collection, driven by the interests, passions and whims of our editors and writers. These essays tell stories about individuals, but they also capture moments in history -- the Patty Hearst trial (Harry Kozol), the deadly Munich Olympics (Jim McKay) -- and moments in our personal histories -- adolescence (Will Elder), romance (Mildred Loving, Lew Spence), the terminal illness of a loved one (Jason Shinder). Most of all, we hope you are moved, tickled, intrigued and provoked by reading about these 24 very different lives, all memorably lived.

RAVIV--Benjamin, age 84, died peacefully at home on December 25, 2008. Beloved husband of Esther, father of Odey and Dan, grandfather of Leigh, Theodore, Jonathan, Emma. Services Sunday 1pm at ''Temple Beth-El of Great Neck''.

ABRAMS--Evelyn Korn, Psychotherapist, of Coconut Creek, FL, died peacefully after a brief illness on December 20, 2008 at 100. She was a loving mother and grandmother. She trained numerous therapists in New York, and was loved by many patients and colleagues. Evelyn Abrams was born in New York City on February 5, 1908 to Ida and Isadore Korn. She attended Lawrence High School and Hunter College and obtained an MSW at Columbia in 1946. In 1949, she married Oscar Abrams, with whom she had two sons. In the 1950s, she developed a highly-respected private psychoanalytic practice. In 1970, she participated in the founding of the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies, where she taught. She trained and supervised numerous therapists. She moved in the mid-1990s to the Wynmoor community in Florida. In the past six years, she became a prolific painter. She had a strong social conscience and remained an ardent supporter of progressive causes and world peace until the present. She was a model of remaining intellectually active and vital throughout her long life and a great inspiration to all who knew her. She is survived by her two sons, Tom and Daniel, and her three grandchildren, Rachel, Benjamin and Jonathan, all of whom loved her dearly. For info about Evelyn or for contributions in her memory, contact Evelyn Abrams. family@gmail.com.

COHEN--Rosalyn S.,of New York City, passed away on December 22, 2008. Ms. Cohen was born in New York City on April 28, 1921, the daughter of late Sam and Pauline Cohen. Ms. Cohen received her BA from Brooklyn College, her MA from Teachers College and pursued advanced studies at Yeshiva University. Ms. Cohen was an early pioneer in the special education of emotionally disturbed children. She taught at the Godmothers' League School, Bank Street College and became a highly respected professor at Brooklyn College's School of Education. Ms. Cohen is survived by her beloved nieces and nephews, Gale Cohen Ruby, Ilene Klein, Craig Cohen, Barry Cohen and Boaz Cohen, as well as many treasured cousins. She was predeceased by her sister Mary and her brothers Abraham and Herbert.

CLARKE--Brian Warner, Jr. Brian (Boru) Clarke died December 25 in Utica, NY, where he was born in 1921. He worked in military ship construction before joining the Army. On August 30, 1945, he was among the first American troops to fly into Japan. Boru graduated from Utica College in 1949 and moved to Greenwich, CT. He worked for Burlington Industries in New York City, and, in 1980, returned upstate to live in Clinton, NY. Except during the War years, all Boru's summer vacations since 1930 were spent at his family house on the West Canada Creek in Barneveld, NY. He is survived by his wife Ann; daughters Ann, Catherine and Margaret; son-in-law Peter Rinaldi; grandchildren JB Rinaldi, and Amy and Marley Silverman; sisters Margaret Howland and Catherine Cardamone. He was predeceased by sisters Agnes Kernan and Marietta von Bernuth; brothers W. Tyler Clarke and Roderick Clarke; and his daughter Phoebe.

Scotland has already given the world Robert Burns, Walter Scott and Donovan, and now an American professor says it is also the birthplace of rap battles. Ferenc Szasz, a professor of history at the University of New Mexico who specializes in American and Scottish culture, says in a new study that the lyrical tradition of battle rap derives from an ancient Caledonian practice called “flyting,” The Telegraph reported. Examples of flyting, a kind of verbal dueling in which opponents would trade rhyming (and often obscene) insults at each other, date at least as far back as the 16th century; Mr. Szasz said that Scottish slaveowners brought the practice to America, where it later evolved into hip-hop. Comparing practitioners of flyting and hip-hop performers, Mr. Szasz said: “Both cultures accord high marks to satire. The skilled use of satire takes this verbal jousting to its ultimate level — one step short of a fistfight.”

At least as far back as “Take the Money and Run,” Woody Allen has been trying to draw attention away from his musical abilities. (As a frustrated cello teacher recalls of his character, Virgil Starkwell, in that fake documentary: “He had no conception of the instrument. He was blowing into it.”) But on Sunday, Mr. Allen shared his clarinet skills with an audience of nearly 3,000 listeners at a concert in Warsaw, The Associated Press reported. The rare concert at which Mr. Allen performed outside his hometown was held at Warsaw’s Sala Kongresowa, and featured the filmmaker playing traditional jazz numbers with his New Orleans Jazz Band. “We will do our best to entertain you,” Mr. Allen told the audience, according to The A.P., before the start of the two-hour show, during which he performed several solos. Outside of Mr. Allen’s appearances at the Cafe Carlyle, his clarinet work can also be heard in the score to “Sleeper,” and in the documentary “Wild Man Blues,” about his band’s 1996 tour of Europe.

When he’s crashed the chandelier of the Paris Opera House and driven away the woman he loves with the sight of his abhorrent face, where does a musically gifted phantom go for a little R&R? Brooklyn, of course. In an interview with The Times of London, Andrew Lloyd Webber said that a recently completed sequel to his musical “The Phantom of the Opera” would send the title character to 19th-century Brooklyn, where he is reunited with his lost love, Christine, on the sands of Coney Island. “It was the place,” Mr. Lloyd Webber said, according to The Times of London. “Even Freud went because it was so extraordinary.” He added, “People who were freaks and oddities were drawn towards it because it was a place where they could be themselves.” Mr. Lloyd Webber said he planned to open the “Phantom” sequel, called “Phantom: Love Never Dies,” in London, New York and a city in Asia next year; no theaters have been announced.

So far, plans for a film spinoff of the late Fox television comedy “Arrested Development” are living up to that show’s title. Mitchell Hurwitz, the creator of “Arrested Development,” the rapid-fire family satire that ended its run in 2006, told the Web site Fancast.com that a deal was in place with Fox Searchlight to create a movie based on the show, but that he would not begin writing a script until its cast was confirmed. During its three-season run, “Arrested Development” starred Jason Bateman as the central member of a highly dysfunctional family that also included Jeffrey Tambor, Will Arnett, and Michael Cera, the star of “Superbad” and “Juno.” Asked if Mr. Arnett and Mr. Cera were the remaining members of the television cast who had not yet signed on for the movie, Mr. Hurwitz said, “I will say that Will Arnett is gung-ho, so there’s a big clue!” He added that the movie might pick up where the show left off, or could be a prequel to the series.

Though the Tom Cruise movie “Valkyrie” received mixed reviews in the United States, it has been greeted with a measured and hospitable reception in Germany, where it was once viewed with suspicion, Reuters reported. In “Valkyrie,” Mr. Cruise plays Col. Claus Von Stauffenberg, a Prussian officer who led an assassination attempt on Hitler in 1944. During the film’s production, the German Defense Ministry briefly refused to allow filming at Berlin’s Benderblock memorial, citing Mr. Cruise’s beliefs in Scientology (which is not a recognized religion in Germany), and Stauffenberg’s son, Berthold, told Der Spiegel, “I fear that only terrible kitsch will come out of the project.” But in writing about “Valkyrie,” the Kölner Stadt-Anzeiger newspaper said that any fears that the “myth of the German resistance would be put through a Hollywood filter has turned out to be wrong and prejudicial.” And the German public broadcaster ZDF said that “Valkyrie” was “neither scandalously bad nor the event of the century. Neither is it the action thriller we feared, but it is a well-made and serious film.”

We've been keeping track of various proposals for a fiscal stimulus package, which is now reportedly in the $675 billion to $775 billion range. The International Monetary Fund today released its own list of recommendations for an internationally coordinated stimulus plan. It suggests, among other things, a more aggressive economic stimulus package in the United States than in Europe because Europe already has "relatively large automatic stabilizers."

One thing that's been bothering me about the discussion over fiscal stimulus is the virtual absence of fully worked-out models, with all their t's dotted and eyes crossed, or something. Not that a rigorous model is always better than a rough-and-ready but more realistic approach, but I like to have both on hand. So I've tried a very rough sketch of a full, intertemporal maximization yada yada analysis of the fiscal policy issue. It was written in a hurry, so it's surely incomprehensible to readers who don't know the New Keynesian Economics literature, and probably incomprehensible even to those who do.

HIMMELMAN--Sol, former magazine publishing executive, passed away peacefully on December 26, 2008. He was 98. Mr. Himmelman was born in Chicago, Illinois on October 31, 1910, two years after his beloved Cubs last won the World Series. He came to New York in 1929. Starting as an office boy with a predecessor of Look Magazine, he ultimately earned executive leadership positions with the MacFadden-Bartell Corporation, Time Warner's publishing division, and as President of Select Magazines. After retiring at 75, he and his wife of 73 years, Helen, lived briefly in San Diego before returning to New York, where they became residents of the Osborne retirement community in Rye, New York. As he often said, the greatest source of happiness in his life were his wife, his son, Harold, and daughterin-law, Bonnie, three loving grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. ''Who could ask for anything more''. Interment will be private. No donations or flowers are requested, but for those who may wish to do so, a contribution can be made to the Paul Himmelman Scholarship Fund at Colgate University, c/ o Pat Caprio.

GREENE--Rabbi Barry H. One summer Saturday 30 years ago, Rabbi Greene welcomed us to our first service at Temple B'nai Jeshurun. On that morning we could not yet realize how much we would come to love and depend on him. Over the years, he has enriched our lives in countless ways with his wise and loving guidance and friendship. We will miss him always. The Dreifus Family

8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) RON HOWARD: 50 YEARS IN FILM From Opie to the Oscars, Mr. Howard, 54, above, narrates his ascent from child stardom with ''The Andy Griffith Show'' and movies like ''The Music Man'' and ''The Courtship of Eddie's Father'' to his Academy Awards for best director and best picture for ''A Beautiful Mind.'' He also discusses his latest film, ''Frost/Nixon.'' Three films that Mr. Howard appeared in or directed follow: ''Grand Theft Auto'' (1977), in which he and Nancy Morgan race to marry in Las Vegas, at 9:30; ''A Beautiful Mind'' (2001), at 1 a.m.; and ''The Journey'' (1959), his first credited role, at 3:30. 8 P.M. (HBO) LE CIRQUE: A TABLE IN HEAVEN Since 1974 Sirio Maccioni has been entertaining the crème de la crème of New York society and beyond at his family's restaurant, Le Cirque. This documentary from Andrew Rossi follows the volatile Mr. Maccioni; his wife, Egidiana; and their three sons (above, the family in an undated photo), from the shuttering of Le Cirque at the Palace Hotel after a 2004 New Year's Eve celebration through preparations for its rebirth in Bloomberg Tower two years later. It's a good place for star gazing: Cindy Adams, Tony Bennett, Robert De Niro, Rudolph W. Giuliani, Billy Joel, Henry A. Kissinger, Regis Philbin, Nancy Reagan, Martha Stewart, Donald Trump and Vera Wang are shown eating.

WIENER--Margaret S.,died peacefully on December 20 at home in Larchmont, NY. For more than 58 years beloved wife of Geoffrey R. Wiener, who survives her. Loving mother of Margaret W. Wiener (Steven L. Goldstein), Geoffrey R. Wiener, Jr. (Wendy J. Banner), Robert S. Wiener (Katherine E. Clark), and Alison H. Wiener (George A. Bryant), and grandmother of ten. Served for many years as social worker to several early childhood education programs in the Larchmont/Mamaroneck area and in the Bronx. A memorial service will be held at a later time.

One of the more intriguing absences on Sunday involved someone who was never expected to play. Oakland's owner, Al Davis, missed the Raiders' 31-24 victory at Tampa Bay. It was believed to be the second time he had not attended a game since becoming a part of the organization in 1963. The Raiders were not commenting about Davis, but The Oakland Tribune reported that doctors had advised him not to fly across the country because of swelling in his leg. On the field, Tampa Bay's Carnell Williams, who missed the first 10 games because of a career-threatening injury to his right knee, hurt his left knee on a 28-yard gain in front of the Bucs' bench. Tampa Bay linebacker Derrick Brooks left the game with a hamstring injury.

GREENWALD--Jane, 80, formerly of Hewlett, NY, died December 28. She was a true woman of her time. She was married to the late Phil Greenwald and was a loving homemaker, raising six children through the late 1960s; at which point she became a champion of women's rights and an early opponent of the Vietnam War. In the 1970s, she was seized by the entrepreneurial spirit and founded an advertising agency, which she ran successfully for a decade. Afterwards, she traveled the world, settling for a time in Vancouver, BC. In her late years, she returned to New York City to be with her family. She is survived by her children, Jonathan, Susan, Judson, Jennifer, Joseph, and Abraham; 14 grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Funeral Services will be held Tuesday, December 30 at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

'SLUMDOG MILLIONAIRE: MUSIC FROM THE MOTION PICTURE' (N.E.E.T./Interscope) In terms of musical output this has been the quietest year for the Sri Lankan-British rapper-provocateur M.I.A. since 2004, when her early singles began making the Internet rounds. But in terms of public profile, she has never been more present. This summer ''Paper Planes,'' a song from her second album, ''Kala,'' was rescued from the curio bin and used in the trailer for the stoner romp ''Pineapple Express.'' Shortly thereafter, it was sampled for ''Swagga Like Us,'' a hugely successful collaboration featuring T.I., Jay-Z, Lil Wayne and Kanye West. In October, after a long absence, she had indie gossips chattering by showing up pregnant for a performance in Brooklyn. And this month ''Paper Planes'' received a Grammy nomination for record of the year.

AUDIO: BACK STORY ON GAZA Taghreed El-Khodary, who is reporting from the Gaza Strip for The Times, discusses the scene after Israel's air strikes. In an interview with Jane Bornemeier, Ms. El-Khodary describes the bodies on the streets and the reaction of Gaza residents and Hamas officials.

KREVOR--Irving Richard, of Malba, New York City, 91, on December 21, 2008 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Rena Mae (nee Rogers) for nearly 63 years. Devoted father of Mitchell Key and David Henry; indulgent grandfather of Jean Elizabeth, Mitchell Jr., Zachary, Samuel, Nathaniel, Alex and Vivian, great-grandfather of Sophia; Loyal son of the late Samuel and Pauline (nee Friedberg); brother of the late Julius and Evelyn Plofker and uncle to many nieces and nephews. Veteran of the New York National Guard Horse Artillery; Veteran of the U.S. Army Air Corps during World War ll. Graduate of City College of New York; New York University Law School. He was an attorney in private practice as well as a high school teacher at Norman Thomas High School in Manhattan. Summer Scout Master Troop 137 Queens Boy Scouts of America. Deeply missed by family and friends, from Catherine Street to Malba --Wow! Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home 10-25 150th Street, Whitestone, NY. Interment: Calverton National Cemetery, Tuesday 12:30. Visiting hours: Monday, 2-5 and 710pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to Boy Scouts of America, Greater New York Council or The Alzheimer's Association would be appreciated.

BREST--Helen, on December 23, 2008. Beloved wife of the late Isaac, devoted mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother. We love you so and will miss you forever.

It would be easier to figure out this matchup if the Miami Dolphins had one strength. They do nothing spectacularly -- they were ranked in the middle of the league in both offense and defense -- but instead do everything solidly. They commit few penalties and make few turnovers, and they are resourceful with their personnel. The Ravens' defense is a top-three unit, but it will have to prepare for everything -- the Dolphins unveiled new Wildcat wrinkles against the Jets -- and it will have to hope it can force the occasional turnover. It helps, of course, that they have Ray Lewis and Ed Reed, who seems to intercept passes in his sleep. But like the Falcons and Vikings, the Ravens are entering the great unknown with an inexperienced quarterback going into the playoffs. Joe Flacco has been solid all season, and the Ravens can now score in bunches -- something they haven't done in years. PLAYERS TO WATCH: The entire Baltimore Ravens defense and Dolphins quarterback Chad Pennington. The Chargers' reward for not packing it in a month ago when they were three games down? A first-round meeting with the Colts, the hottest team entering the playoffs with nine straight victories. Still, the Chargers eliminated the Colts from the playoffs last season, and Indianapolis needed a last-second field goal to beat San Diego in November. The Chargers' pass defense was once the worst in the league, but entering Sunday's game against the Broncos, they had allowed just three passing touchdowns and intercepted six passes in the previous three games. The revived pass defense will get its ultimate test against the Colts, who rode Peyton Manning all season as the running game disappeared because of Joseph Addai's injury. Addai is back -- he scored on a screen pass and 55-yard run against the Titans -- and Manning is better than ever.

HOROWITZ--Israel, 92, died on December 26, 2008. Israel was a record producer and editor of Billboard. He is survived by Mildred, his wife of 62 years, his sons, Michael and Robert, his daughters-inlaw, Anita and Amy, and his grandchildren, Lea, Selina and Adam. Services will be held at Rockland Cemetery in Sparkhill, NY, on December 29, 2008 at 2pm. The family plans to hold a memorial celebration of his life at a future date.

PRYOR--Dr. John P. 42, Moorestown, NJ served in the front lines of urban America and Ground Zero, and died during his second tour in Iraq. ''Only a life lived for others is a life worth while''. Countless medics, nurses and physicians are honored to have worked with you. We deeply mourn your death. Sincerest condolences to your family.

BRANDY 'Human' (Knockout/Epic) Brandy Norwood, 29, has grown up in public, from perky multimillion-selling teenager and sitcom star to unwed mother and tenacious celebrity. Her 2004 album, ''Afrodisiac,'' pointedly addressed her breakup with her daughter's father, to whom she had pretended to be married. In 2006 she was involved in a fatal freeway accident in which she was not charged as a criminal but faces a $50 million wrongful-death lawsuit. ''Human,'' the title song of her new album, sounds like special pleading as she sings, ''I make mistakes but I can't turn back time.''

MILLER--Mary S. (nee Slattery), died peacefully on December 12, 2008 at Seaside Terrace, Laguna Beach, CA. Born June 4, 1915 in Lakewood, OH, she attended the University of Michigan. Moving to NYC in the late 1930s, she graduated from City College and then worked in publishing. Following her divorce from the playwright Arthur Miller, she received her Ph.D. in Psychology, working until retirement at Northside Center For Child Development. She was a longtime resident of Brooklyn Heights before moving to Laguna Beach, CA in 2003. She is survived by her daughter, Jane Doyle of Roxbury, CT and son Robert Miller of Laguna Beach as well as their spouses Tom Doyle and Jean Miller; grandchildren Jessica Miller of Portland, OR, Zachariah Miller of Laguna Niguel, CA, Katherine Miller of Laguna Beach, CA and one great-grandchild, Luke Miller. She is predeceased by her brother Matthew Slattery. She is also survived by her brother, Jerome Slattery of Rocky River, OH.

Beloved wife of the late Leslie, devoted mother of Susan (Jerry) and Steven (Valerie), dear sister of Edith and cherished grandmother of Rachel, Nicole and Joshua. HUNTINGTON--Samuel Phillips, 81, was Albert J. Weatherhead III University Professor at Harvard University, where he taught for 58 years. Gifted scholar and mentor, he authored or co-authored 17 books, including The Clash of Civilizations, (1996), and The Soldier and the State, (1957), He graduated from Stuyvesant High School, Yale University, '46; served in the U.S. Army, received a University of Chicago, MA and a Harvard Ph.D. in 1949. He was chairman of the Harvard Government Department; director of its Center for International Affairs, founding director of its Olin Institute for Strategic Studies, and chairman of its Academy for International and Area Studies. He was President of the American Political Science Association and was a co-founder/ editor of Foreign Policy. Advisor on foreign policy to Hubert Humphrey in the 1968 campaign, he was Coordinator of Security Planning on the Carter NSC staff. He is survived by his wife, Nancy Arkelyan Huntington, sons Timothy and Nicholas, and four beloved grandchildren. A memorial service is planned for the spring.

LEVAN--Robert, died peacefully at home on December 27, 2008 after a long illness, at the age of 91. Born in Manhattan, he attended Temple University and, upon graduation, he returned to New York City, where, for many years, he worked for the New York State Department of Labor as an Occupational Analyst. Bob always took inspiration from the city of his birth, where his interests included drawing and his volunteer work at the American Museum of National History. Bob leaves his loving wife of thirty years, Jeanne, his brother Marvin and sister-inlaw Joan. His family and friends will miss his warm and charming personality, his spontaneous humor and wry wit. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

MacMILLAN--Ian Travis, 67, of Kailua, HI, on December 18th. Born Teaneck, NJ. Survived by daughters Julia (Colorado) and Laura, son-in-law Richard and granddaughter Emma Crago (Hawaii). Preceded in death by wife Susan Bates (November 28, 2008). B.A., Oneonta State, MFA., University of Iowa Writers Workshop 1966. He was an avid tennis player, golfer and spear fisherman. A creative writing professor at the University of Hawaii (UH), he inspired countless students and writers for 43 years, winning a teaching excellence award in 2005 and the University's Distinguished Mentoring Award in 2006. He authored eight novels and six short story collections, one of which won the Associated Writing Programs Award for Short Fiction. Over 100 of his pieces have appeared in publications including Yankee, The Sun, Paris Review, Iowa Review, and Best American Short Stories, Pushcart Prize, and O. Henry Award volumes. Winner of the 1992 Hawai'i Award for Literature, and the 2007 Elliot Cades Award, recent novels include The Braid, The Red Wind, and Seven Orchids (all set in Hawai'i), and Village of a Million Spirits: A Novel of the Treblinka Uprising, winner of a 2000 PEN U.S.A.-West Fiction Award. Novel The Bone Hook is due out in 2009, and Our People, a short story collection, was published this summer. Recently he was honored with a special double issue in his name by Hawaii Review, a UH literary journal he started in 1973. He taught his children that the meaning of life is to be found in the living of it. We lost not only a father, but a teacher and a friend. His strength and kindness will be deeply missed. Friends may contact the family at familymacmillan @yahoo.com. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The MacMillan Creative Writing Scholarship for Morris Central School, c/o Judy Matson District Clerk, Morris Central School, P.O. Box 40, 65 Main St., Morris, NY, 13808. ''I am in the mail; therefore, I am.'' Ian MacMillan

Nobody -- not even Andy Reid -- could have imagined that benching quarterback Donovan McNabb would eventually lead to the playoffs. But after McNabb hit rock bottom on Nov. 23, the Eagles have gone 4-1 to surge into the playoffs. They will encounter Reid's former offensive coordinator, Brad Childress, whose Vikings bear striking similarities to the Eagles. The Vikings pass rusher Jared Allen will give the Eagles' protection headaches all day. But McNabb's mobility makes him far better equipped to anticipate and escape pressure than the inexperienced Vikings quarterback Tarvaris Jackson is to handle the Eagles' blitz-happy defense. As much attention as will be paid to the quarterbacks, both offenses rely heavily on their running backs -- the Vikings on Adrian Peterson, the Eagles on the all-around threat Brian Westbrook. PLAYERS TO WATCH: Eagles running back Brian Westbrook and Vikings defensive tackles Kevin Williams and Pat Williams.

A study of books that have won the John Newbery Medal for children’s literature has found that their protagonists are increasingly likely to be white, male and from two-parent households, even as American families become more diverse, Bloomberg News reported. The study, conducted by Brigham Young University, looked at the races, genders and family backgrounds of characters in 82 books that won the award between 1922 and 2007. It found that fewer books featuring black and Hispanic characters had won the award in the past 27 years than in the years between 1951 and 1979. “The Newbery is given for literary quality — ethnicity, gender, nothing of that is necessarily taken into consideration,” said Pat Scales, the president of the Association for Library Service to Children, which awards the Newbery Medal. She added, “We owe kids good stories that reflect their lives and give them a more global view.”

The publisher of a children’s book based on the fabricated love story of Herman Rosenblat, the Holocaust survivor who said he first met his wife when he was imprisoned in a Nazi concentration camp, has canceled pending reprints of the book and will refund the price of any returned books.In a statement released late Monday, Minneapolis-based Lerner Publishing said it was “shocked and disappointed to learn that the widely publicized Holocaust love story of Herman and Roma Rosenblat, which inspired the children’s picture book ‘Angel Girl,’ is not entirely true.”

The North Shore Music Theater of Beverly, Mass., has laid off 57 employees and may have to cancel its coming season, The Associated Press reported. The theater, which is still rebuilding from a fire that destroyed its auditorium in 2005, said that it was suffering from fewer philanthropic contributions, and from lower than expected ticket sales for its stage production of “High School Musical 2.” This year the theater dropped its annual presentation of “A Christmas Carol” in favor of the Disney musical; thus far it has sold about 13,000 tickets to “High School Musical 2,” about a fourth of what it was anticipating. Carol LaRosa, the theater’s manager of public relations, told The A.P. that the theater needed $500,000 to stay open through the spring and an additional $4 million for its next season.

Media bigshots who want to chat with Michael D. Eisner will have to get him on his cell phone from now on: Mr. Eisner, the former Walt Disney Company chief executive, is stepping away from his CNBC talk show, “Conversations With Michael Eisner,” The Hollywood Reporter said. A CNBC spokesman told The Hollywood Reporter that Mr. Eisner’s responsibilities to his venture capital firm Tornante, which owns the Web studio Vuguru and a stake in the Veoh video download site, among other businesses, made it harder for him to devote his full attention to the program. As many as three episodes of “Conversations with Michael Eisner” are still to air; recent episodes have featured Mr. Eisner’s interviews with Michael Rapino, the chief executive of Live Nation, and the television pastors Joel and Victoria Osteen.

The Terminators may be an army of unstoppable robots hellbent on the destruction of the human race, but they’ll always be welcome in the Library of Congress. The 1984 movie “The Terminator,” which set Arnold Schwarzenegger on the road to stardom (and, later, the California governor’s mansion) was one of 25 films that have been added to the National Film Registry, the Library of Congress announced on Tuesday. Among the others chosen to be preserved by the archive are John Huston’s film-noir “The Asphalt Jungle”; Richard Brooks’s film adaptation of Truman Capote’s “In Cold Blood”; “The 7th Voyage of Sinbad,” featuring special effects produced by Ray Harryhausen; and the movie that ruined whitewater rafting for generations to come, “Deliverance.”

Finally, a bit of good news on which Madonna can end her year: the soon-to-be-single pop star’s Sticky & Sweet concerts were the highest grossing musical tour of North America in 2008, the concert industry magazine Pollstar said. The Madonna tour, which recently concluded in Sao Paulo, grossed $105.3 million from its North American performances, according to Pollstar. In second place was her Canadian competitor Celine Dion, whose tour grossed $94 million this year, and third place was claimed by the Eagles, whose tour to promote their album “Long Road Out of Eden” grossed $73.4 million. The list was rounded out by Kenny Chesney ($72.2 million), Bon Jovi ($70.4 million), Bruce Springsteen & The E Street Band ($69.3 million), Neil Diamond ($59.8 million), Rascal Flatts ($55.8 million), The Police ($48 million) and Tina Turner ($47.7 million).

The marquees of Broadway theaters will be dimmed for one minute on Tuesday at 7 p.m. in honor of Harold Pinter, who died on Dec. 24, the Broadway League announced. In his theatrical career, Pinter, who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 2005, was also a frequent Tony Award honoree; his play “The Homecoming” won the Tony Award for best play in 1967, and “The Caretaker” and “Old Times” were nominated for best play in 1962 and 1972, respectively. He was also nominated for a Tony Award for best direction for “The Man in the Glass Booth” in 1969. Slide Show: Remembering Harold Pinter

Daniel Barenboim will begin 2009 by conducting the Vienna Philharmonic in its annual New Year’s concert, Agence-France Presse reported. Mr. Barenboim, 66, the Israeli-Argentinian conductor, will leadthe Philharmonic in a concert scheduled for Thursday at the Musikverein in Vienna. (A preview performance took place on Tuesday, and a New Year’s Eve concert is scheduled for Wednesday night.) Though the program customarily features marches, waltzes and polkas, this year’s concert will also include Haydn’s Symphony No. 45, also known as the “Farewell” symphony, to mark the 200th anniversary of the death of the composer. The event will be broadcast in 71 countries, and a recording will be released on Jan. 7, followed by a DVD of the performance on Jan. 12.

An oyster shell sits on the table in front of me. But I'm not about to have an oyster feast: I won't be squeezing a lemon, grinding pepper and lifting the shell to my lips. This isn't because I'd choke, though the animal from this shell would be far larger than one throatful. It's because this oyster died more than 20 million years ago, and the shell is empty.

The paper version of this puzzle is a little easier to solve. In Across Lite, there are 16 circles -- four triplets and four single circles in the left column. In print, the four loners are shaded, making them look different. They're the key to this puzzle. Perhaps you prefer the more challenging electronic version. It's something like solving without peeking at the Across Lite notepad, or doing a diagramless without noting the size or symmetry hint.

This is one of the better non-B.C.S. bowl games of the season. Both the Cowboys and the Ducks can score points, as both average about 41 a game (41.6 for Oklahoma State, 41.9 for Oregon). And neither team concerns itself too much with defense. (Oklahoma State Coach Mike Gundy has been known to go over to his team's bench and study the offensive game plan while his defense is on the field.) So, in keeping with the legacy of Holiday Bowl fireworks, expect an entertaining game with plenty of action on the scoreboard.

Not to mention the fact that, in the dead of winter, you don't have to go outside.
